HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: VICTIMS' COMPENSATION; 
Fund for Victims' Families Already Proves Sore Point

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES and DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
The compensation fund created by Congress 10 days ago, which could pay the families of victims in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks more than $1 million each, has begun to generate both resentment and confusion about its ultimate fairness and effectiveness.
 Senior budget analysts for House Democrats say that the fund, established as part of legislation to rescue the airline industry, could cost taxpayers as much as $15 billion to compensate the direct victims of the attacks -- at least 6,000 killed or missing and another 8,700 injured. 
 But already, even as the Justice Department works to establish the fund, some victims of past terrorism, from the Oklahoma City bombing to the destruction of two American embassies in Africa, are upset to be excluded.
As well, charities and relief agencies, which have raised more than $675 million so far, are worried that the federal fund may go only to families of those killed or injured in the attacks, who are already the main recipients of private charity. The fund would exclude many families who have suffered mental trauma and have lost homes, jobs or businesses. 
Legal scholars have raised questions about the fund's even-handedness and accountability. They cite, in particular, the extraordinary power of the fund's "special master," the person to be appointed by Attorney General John Ashcroft to make the fund's awards. Inevitably, they say, the special master, who is not subject to Senate approval and whose decisions cannot be appealed to any court, will have to balance the economic losses and emotional anguish of each family against the total burden on taxpayers.
The fund, which still has an undetermined price tag, was adopted as part of legislation to save the airline industry from bankruptcy after the hijackings. Devised to shield the industry from litigation, it is open to the families of anyone who suffered death or physical harm in the hijackings or the attacks.
Those who apply for relief waive their right to sue for damages sustained in the attacks in any federal or state court. But the applicants are promised a decision within 120 days, far less time than a lawsuit would take. They are also excused from having to prove who is to blame for their losses, as they would be required to do in court.
The amounts paid out by this fund must be reduced by the amount any family has received from its own private insurance, death benefits or government assistance. It is not clear whether awards from private charity would be subtracted from federal awards, something that has those involved in private fund-raising deeply puzzled about how best to distribute their money.
Stephan Landsman, a law professor at DePaul University who is advising the American Bar Association on the compensation fund, warned that a special master whose focus has to include the country's taxpayers could be, in fact, "an adversary to the claimants -- and it does not seem fair to have an adversary also making the final decision."
The early estimates prepared by the members of Congress involved in the fund's creation are, they admit, preliminary. But they agreed that the fund was structured to compensate families roughly in line with what they might expect from a court award. In cases of death and severe injury, such awards routinely exceed $1 million. "Those kinds of numbers were clearly being contemplated," said one official involved in the negotiations.
The fund's framers said their aim was to offer families an avenue for relief that would be faster and more certain than litigation. But the concerns already raised about how it will operate and whom it will serve suggest it may need refining.
The emerging questions and unhappiness about the fund were, in effect, born in compromises made to achieve its passage, according to interviews with a half-dozen Republican and Democratic participants in the process.
The basic architecture of the fund was designed in less than 24 hours, with the final passages written at 4 a.m. on Friday, Sept. 21, just hours before the measure was passed by both chambers. Negotiators for both parties said the rush was driven by the demands of airline executives, who had bluntly warned that they would be out of business without immediate financial aid and protection from lawsuits.
Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle and House Minority Leader Richard A. Gephardt had made it clear that there would be no deal for the airlines without compensation for victims. But a disagreement about how best to construct such a system of compensation surfaced.
A plan proposed by the White House would have had all victim claims consolidated for trial in federal court in Manhattan, with the government stepping in to pay claims only after the airlines' insurance was exhausted. If victims failed to prove who was to blame for their losses, they would get nothing.
Ultimately, though, the real wrangling over the nature of the fund took place when leaders of the Senate and House met in the offices of House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert on the night of Sept. 20.
The Democrats wanted an open-ended victims compensation fund presided over by a senior judge, subject to Senate confirmation, who would be empowered to award any amount of money to cover both economic losses, such as lost wages, and noneconomic losses, such as pain and suffering and mental anguish.
But they met fierce resistance from three Republicans: Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas and Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri. The Republicans demanded to know how much the fund would cost.
"Nobody had any idea of the liability we were assuming for the government," Mr. Blunt recalled in an interview. But to questions of cost, Mr. Daschle responded, "Can any of you value these lives right now? I can't."
Mr. Nickles had another concern: fairness to his own state's terrorism casualties, who had not been so generously compensated after the 1995 bombing of the Oklahoma City federal building, according to two participants in the meeting.
With pressure building from the airlines, the Republican negotiators ultimately agreed to much of what Mr. Daschle and Mr. Gephardt proposed, but not without extracting two important concessions.
First, they insisted that the federal fund had to reduce any award it made to a family by the amount of other compensation the family received, such as life insurance or death benefits. Second, they wanted Attorney General John Ashcroft to pick who would run the fund.
The Democrats say they agreed in part out of a "leap of faith" born of bipartisan spirit and in part because they saw the commitment to pay for noneconomic losses such as pain and suffering as a boon to the families of victims who earned little or had spotty employment histories. In cases involving similarly horrific deaths, awards for pain and suffering can be very large. In recent cases involving three American students killed in suicide bombings in Israel, their families received a total of $54 million in compensatory damages.
"It is expensive," Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said. "But how do you put a price tag on a life?"
Whatever its virtues, the final agreement on the fund, signed by President Bush on Sept. 22, struck some victims of previous terrorist attacks as far from inclusive enough. No equivalent fund was established to compensate those victims or their families.
"To me, you have to equalize the playing field or it's just not fair," said Kathleen R. Flynn, the mother of John Patrick Flynn, a college student who was killed in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.
Suzanne Breedlove, director of victims services for the Oklahoma District Attorneys Council, which administers the state's compensation plan for crime victims, said that some in Oklahoma City resent the notion of "making millionaires out of people." It is an equity issue, she added. "Are we going to raise half a billion dollars for every terrorist attack in America?"
Edith Bartley's father and brother were among the 224 people killed in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in Africa. Ms. Bartley, like other victims of past terrorist attacks, said she felt enormous sadness for the newly traumatized families, but also a growing anger at the vast sums of public relief and private charity now being directed toward those families.
Ms. Bartley and the families of 10 other Americans killed in the Nairobi attack have been quietly asking Congress to provide $1.5 million to each family to compensate them for their anguish. They picked the figure because that was the amount the United States government paid to the families of those killed in the accidental bombing of the Chinese embassy in Serbia in 1999.
Ms. Bartley said their pleas had been greeted with sympathy -- notably from Representative Blunt, whose daughter went to law school with Ms. Bartley -- but no action. Now, seeing the details of this new victims' compensation fund, these families find themselves feeling forgotten and heartbroken all over.
"They weren't thinking about us, and it's because it happened in their backyards, not thousands of miles away," Ms. Bartley said. "And yet all of these victims are victims of the same terrorist group."
Told of Ms. Bartley's comments, Mr. Blunt said, "Well, a lot of things in life are not fair, and this may turn out to be one of them. Some unlucky victims are more unlucky than others."
The creation of the fund, and the ambiguity in some of the language defining its mission and obligations, have also posed problems for the scores of charitable and philanthropic groups trying to help the current victims.
A key unanswered question for charities is whether the money a family has received or will receive from philanthropic sources, such as the Twin Towers Fund for uniformed personnel or the Windows of Hope fund for food industry workers, will be deducted from the federal fund's awards.
If so, the new government fund could help even out the flow of aid to those who have not benefited from specialized fund-raising efforts. But that would also oblige charities, as a matter of full disclosure, to begin advising families of the effect their aid may have on future federal awards, several lawyers said.
The fund also would make it more important for private philanthropy to steer more of its aid to the thousands of affected families excluded from the federal fund, several lawyers and charity executives agreed. Yet many donors have specified that their gifts are to be used only for direct victims -- the same people who will benefit from the new fund.
"It doesn't feel that it has been coordinated with the other relief work very well," said Kathy Bushkin, president of the AOL Time Warner Foundation.
The fund's effect on private charity was "clearly something they never thought about," said Robert A. Clifford, the chairman of the A.B.A. Task Force on Terrorism and the Law. "The attorney general should immediately speak to that question, so that the giving does not come to a halt." Several authors of the legislation acknowledged that this was a question that was overlooked in their haste to create the fund.
While many lawyers praise the fund, they note that its shape is a sharp departure from previous federal efforts to compensate victims of widespread disasters.
The fund, for instance, differs from past practice in the amount of power vested in its special master. Special masters who oversee other federal funds are typically subject to court review. In this case, there is no appeal from the special master's decisions.
The tension between providing compensation to families and limiting the government's financial exposure is already surfacing. Mr. Blunt said the special master would have "a unique responsibility to arrive at a fair settlement from all perspectives."
Still, lawyers seem to agree that the fund, if its flaws can be mended, will serve the affected families far better than lawsuits.
Mr. Clifford, a specialist in aviation lawsuits, called the bill a "necessary piece of legislation." He added, "We need to try to turn what would otherwise be a quagmire of litigation into something that melds together and helps victims."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE CLASSES; 
Pakistan Is 2 Worlds: One Urbane, One Enraged

BYLINE:  By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 30 

 BODY:
Arif Ali Khan Abbasi, educated at Oxford, retired head of Pakistan International Airlines, recently went to a mosque in Karachi to kneel for noon prayer.
 He chose a mosque favored by more hard-line Islamic fundamentalists in the Gulshan-E-Iqbal section of Karachi, and as he knelt he felt the eyes of the bearded faithful bore into him. "Because I was clean-shaven," he said. That offends them. 
 "Why did you come here," one man asked him.
"To pray," he said. He listened to the mullah's words, as much song as sermon, and was not insulted or abused in any way, as he prayed. But when he was done, he was approached by several men who told him, politely: "O.K., you have prayed. Now please leave."
Mr. Abbasi, who is so respected in business circles here that employees at Pakistan International Airlines wept when he retired, is not accustomed to being told to leave anything until he is ready to go, and then people hold the door for him.
But now, he said, he is a target of resentment that has more to do with unbending religious doctrine than with class.
It was one more sign of the divide between this city's -- and this country's -- business and upper classes, and the swelling numbers of Islamic militants. 
It does not make him angry or frightened so much as it makes him sad.
Pakistan's upper classes are not afraid -- at least not yet -- that an attack by the United States on neighboring Afghanistan will lead to such anger and violence here that the very society will suddenly crumble and be replaced overnight by a Taliban-like leadership. 
Mr. Abbasi told his story of the confrontation at the mosque at a recent dinner party in a prosperous Karachi neighborhood, a party that could have existed anywhere else in the world. Doctors stood elbow to elbow with business leaders, talking politics, some of them holding drinks of whiskey -- taboo in Islam. One of the signs of wealth here, say people with a wink, is knowing a good bootlegger. They spoke in English, not Urdu. 
"We are bloody worried," said Habibur Rahman, a business management consultant. 
"No one really knows the future," he added. There may be riots, there may be killing, but in Karachi and in Pakistan as a whole, he said, there is a great difference between talking about holy war and actually commiting it to the degree that it could tip a society. 
In Pakistan, said the city's economic and professional elite, there is a silent majority made up of people who only want to work and live decently and have their children educated -- but who will talk about defending Afghanistan and attacking outsiders because of a fealty to Islam.
"That is what Musharraf is counting on," said Kamal Majidulla, editor of the Dawn Group of Newspapers.
Unlike most places in Karachi, where anti-American sentiment seems to be everywhere, there is little badmouthing of the United States in this spacious home, over trays of Pakistani delicacies. One man proudly says he has visited 27 American states. 
A woman says she loves New York, and was there when the attack came and it broke her heart.
Outside these walls, Karachi, with 12 million people, has been tugged at from both sides.
Residents have marched to protest the government's support of the United States. Others marched in support of it -- and 11 people were injured by homemade grenades. "Firecrackers," said one woman, dismissively. 
For the upper classes, it is Pakistan's two million refugees from Afghanistan who have done most to destabilize the country. "They have no choice but to get drunk on bigoted religion," said Mr. Abassi. They have little work, and little educational opportunities. 
There are whole generations of Afghans living in Karachi who have never known anything except war. Mr. Majidullah described carpet shops where small boys who used to weave scenes of intricate detail, of princesses, camels and elephants, now weave rugs depicting AK-47 assault rifles and tanks. 
He suggested that America drop money rather than bombs on Afghanistan. Invest in the country, he continued, with schools and businesses and social programs, and give the people there less reason to hate.
It is advice that Mr. Abbasi and others say is the key to stability in their own country to keep Islamic militants in check. 
"I think Pakistan is going to have some luck, and we have not had luck for 50 years," Mr. Abbasi said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Nanni Rahman, left, and Saleem Majidulla, who belong to Pakistan's upper class, discussing the country's situation. The vast numbers of poor are more militantly religious and more sympathetic to the Taliban.; Members of Pakistan's elite at a cocktail party where the talk was about the country's political predicament in the war against terrorism. The government must straddle the roles America's ally and Afghanistan's friend. (Photographs by LynseyAddario/Saba, for The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Letting Empire Go For-Profit 

 BODY:
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has been trying since 1996 to guarantee its future by shedding its not-for-profit status. Now facing up to $50 million in losses from the destruction of its offices at the World Trade Center, the company needs to sell stock to make the investments needed to compete with other insurers. Yet its chances of converting to a for-profit corporation are caught up in political disputes. Without quick action by the state, Empire may be forced to accept a disadvantageous buyout from another not-for-profit insurer just to remain financially viable. 
 Sound management led Empire from near-insolvency to a strong balance sheet in the late 1990's. Even now, Empire is managed much as a for-profit company would be. Yet lately it has struggled to compete with New York's big for-profit insurers. Their market shares have increased almost every year, leaving Empire behind. A takeover by another not-for-profit might help, but only at the cost of hundreds, perhaps thousands of New York jobs, including those of Empire's proven managers. 
 If Empire becomes a for-profit company and raises money by selling stock, it will keep its successful management team and gain the ability to grow by acquiring other insurers in nearby states. Expanding into other geographical areas would allow Empire to exploit economies of scale without threatening competition or taking on worse risks. 
The sticking point on conversion is exactly what to do with the proceeds from Empire's sales of stock. Part of the money will help Empire to cover claims, build new offices and grow. Because the company began as a state-subsidized insurer, it has also agreed to put a big chunk of the proceeds of its stock sales to charitable purposes. Empire, the Greater New York Hospital Association and 1199/ S.E.I.U, the union of health care workers, have jointly suggested that $1 billion of the proceeds be split evenly between the hospitals and a foundation to finance public health research and insurance for poor children. But consumer groups are worried that hospitals would squander the money. The state government may also want a cut. 
If lawmakers in Albany cannot decide what Empire should do with the $1 billion, they could allow it to sell shares immediately and put the proceeds in escrow pending an agreement. But there is no reason to make Empire wait any longer.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE COMPANY; 
Rooms Full Of Instruments That No One Is Playing

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
The storage rooms at Carroll Musical Instrument Rentals near Times Square are crammed with pianos, organs, cymbals and timpani that no one is using. The company's telephones, once busy, ring only intermittently. Employees are being asked to come in late or leave early.
 Situated in a modest four-story building, Carroll is several miles from the World Trade Center and does not get most of its customers from the financial district, so one might expect that the company would be affected only lightly by the attack on Sept. 11. Yet the family-owned business, founded in 1945, has been hit hard. 
 Since the attack, it has lost about 130 orders worth thousands of dollars -- everything from a $2,000 job providing drums, organs, keyboards and a sound system for a performance at the New York Hilton to the $95 delivery of a bass fiddle to the Hotel Wellington, also in Midtown.
When a wedding at the Puck Building was canceled, so was the $600 rental of a baby grand piano. A scuttled concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine meant a requisition for choral risers was no longer needed, a $500 loss to Carroll.
In the first week after the attack, all 80 customers who had made reservations for one item or another canceled their orders. Business picked up slightly the second week, but it was still off about 40 percent, said Timothy G. Curry, who co-owns Carroll with his brothers Kevin and Raymond. It is not just the sharp decline in tourism that is hurting his business, but also the city's gloomy mood, he said Friday in an interview at his office, which is decorated with posters from Broadway shows that have used the company's services.
"People are finding it hard to smile and be joyful," Mr. Curry said. "That's what entertainment is all about."
Small companies like Carroll represent a big chunk of the New York economy. About 89 percent of the city's businesses have 20 or fewer employees. But they provide work for 700,000 people, about one-fourth of the labor force, said James P. Brown, an economist at the State Department of Labor. Carroll has 24 full-time employees.
Companies dealing with the entertainment industry, of course, are far from alone in experiencing repercussions from the attack. Many bakeries, printers, garment factories and limousine services are also feeling the pinch. "The ripple effects are enormous," said Jonathan Bowles, research director for the Center for an Urban Future, a New York advocacy group. "We're all seeing how closely tied our economy is, not just Lower Manhattan, but citywide and regionally."
Small businesses are the most difficult segment of the economy to track, Mr. Brown said, so it will be a long time before anyone can determine how many have been affected. But if the downturn lasts, many of them will close, he said.
That is not likely to be Carroll's fate, Mr. Curry said. Like a number of other small-business owners, he said he had been trying to stave off layoffs. He said Carroll's staff was always kept lean -- a policy that in normal times allows employees to earn overtime pay.
Shortly after the disaster, he said, he explained to his employees, several of whom have been with the company for 16 years or more, that their weekday hours would be cut back but that they might be able to make up the difference on weekends.
"Hopefully, they will get 40 hours," he said. "If next week, business doesn't pick up," he added, "there's a possibility that layoffs may occur."
But he said he was hopeful that a number of his clients' events would be rescheduled, like one sponsored by Clear Channel Communications, which owns five New York radio stations and was supposed to have held its company party on Sept. 12 on a cruise ship docked at the Chelsea Piers. Clear Channel had ordered $1,100 in electrical and acoustical guitars from Carroll.
The party has been rescheduled for Oct. 25 but moved to the Bowlmor Lanes near Union Square, said David Cercini, the promotion director for WCAA (105.9 FM).
There are other encouraging signs, Mr. Curry said. On Friday afternoon, the company got eight orders, two more than its recent daily average.
"Today is just one day," Mr. Curry said cautiously. "We'll have to see what happens."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-14

Pakistan Says It Consulted U.S. on Nuclear Safety
American military and intelligence officials have talked with Pakistan about installing new safeguards on its nuclear weapons and at its nuclear power plants, Pakistani officials said. But there are some formal limitations on how much assistance the United States can provide, because Pakistan has not signed the treaty to limit the spread of nuclear weapons, and because American law restricts sharing information about nuclear weapons. A3

Catholic Leaders Meet in Rome
Pope John Paul II opened a meeting of bishops from around the world who will spend the next month discussing their role in the church and that of the pope. Some church leaders have argued for more democracy, and the pope has acknowledged that his supreme role in the church has been an obstacle in his campaign to bring Christian faiths closer together. A8

Aid Workers' Trial Resumes
The trial of eight Western aid workers -- two Americans, two Australians and four Germans -- charged with trying to convert people to Christianity resumed in Kabul for the first time since the Sept. 11 attacks. The chief justice of Afghanistan's Supreme Court assured them that they would be treated fairly despite the possibility of American air strikes. A12

Fruit Cakes, Chinese Style
Moon cakes, small round pastries that are the traditional food of today's midautumn festival, have suffered in popularity as the range of food available to the Chinese people has expanded. This year, moon cakes have another problem: exposes in the state press have revealed shocking scenes from some of China's most famous factories, from bosses recycling moldy filler from previous years to workers using their shoes to mix flour. A10

Colombia Talks Canceled
President Andres Pastrana called off planned peace talks with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the country's largest rebel group, after soldiers found the body of Consuelo Araujo, the wife of the country's attorney general, one week after she was believed kidnapped by the group. Mr. Pastrana had been expected to announce the extension of rebel control over an enclave in Colombia, officials said. (Reuters)

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Signs of Flood Evoking Noah
Archaeologists have found evidence that appears to support the theory that a catastrophic flood struck the Black Sea region more than 7,000 years ago, turning the sea saline, submerging surrounding plains and possibly inspiring the flood legends of Mesopotamia and the Bible. A14

Bones Used in British Tests
Britain's Atomic Energy Agency acknowledged that thousands of bones were taken from dead babies without parental consent to help ascertain the effect of atmospheric nuclear testing. A6

NATIONAL A16-18

In Shift, Budget Surplus Is Likely to Become Deficit
Analysts say the federal budget surpluses of recent years are likely to give way to a deficit in the fiscal year that starts today. For the coming 12 months, analysts are forecasting that the government at best will balance its books after paying for military action, relief and reconstruction efforts and an economic stimulus package and will probably spend tens of billions of dollars more than it takes in through taxes. A1

Justices Face Divisive Issues
The issues that will dominate the docket for the new Supreme Court term that begins today include public financing for religious education through tuition vouchers; the boundaries of free speech on the Internet; the constitutionality of executing the retarded; the future of affirmative action in federal contracting; the legal definition of disability; and patients' rights to challenge decisions on managed care treatment. The justices have accepted some 50 cases for decision and will add 25 or 30 more over the next few months. A16

An informal task force of federal and state officials in Hawaii has been convened to address the problem of noisy tree frogs. It is considering killing the frogs the only way that has proved effective in a laboratory: by spraying acres of their borrowed habitat with concentrated caffeine and a dose of pesticide. A16

California Will Aid the Jobless
Gov. Gray Davis of California has agreed to sign a bill that will increase unemployment benefits beginning next year, senior administration officials said. The current maximum unemployment benefit is $230 per week. The bill would raise the maximum to $330 per week beginning Jan. 1, 2002. By 2005 the maximum benefit would increase to a $450 per week. A16

It has turned to retirees to augment its depleted ranks and has snapped up fire equipment destined for other cities. And, looking for more ways to protect the lives of firefighters, some chiefs have begun to say the department may have to re-evaluate its longtime mission to fight every fire. F1

The Pataki administration, steering clear of a potential lawsuit, has decided to extend a new state-subsidized health insurance program for the working poor to all legal immigrants. Letterman Leads the Way
At a time of horror and grief, David Letterman, host of the "Late Show" on CBS, has, by almost every account, distinguished himself by going back in front of the public, then gently testing how far comedy could go. He is experiencing something he has never encountered before: gratitude for his willingness to step up and lead. E6

HEADLINE: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; 
Stopping Terror

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Phony Bomb Threats Flood In After Terrorist Attacks" (news article, Sept. 27) does not mention an important subset of hoaxes. 
There is ample precedent demonstrating that terrorists use hoaxes to erode the vigilance of the authorities, divert the attention of the authorities and gain intelligence on response patterns. 
 Such deception is cost-effective and low-risk. It represents a significant obstacle to intelligence analysts in their attempts to isolate indicators of future terror attacks. Finding more effective ways to combat deception is a daunting challenge and a clear necessity.

SCOTT GERWEHR
Santa Monica, Calif., Sept. 27, 2001

The writer is a policy analyst specializing in deception and psychological operations at the RAND Corporation.

HEADLINE: States of Readiness: Do New Threats Loom?; 
Economic Factors

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Aid for a Terrorized Economy" (editorial, Sept. 28): 
 An additional indirect but major economic effect of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks may be in health care policy. 
The economic slowdown that had dramatically increased unemployment in August has been accelerated by the attack to the point of inducing a full-fledged recession. 
Most Americans who have health insurance get it through their work. When the slowdown began, 43 million Americans had no health insurance. 
As unemployment grows, the families of laid-off workers will add many more millions to the ranks of the uninsured. Perhaps when we get to 50 million or 60 million uninsured, it may at last be politically acceptable to discuss universal health insurance.

JAMES J. FLORIO
Metuchen, N.J., Sept. 28, 2001

The writer was governor of New Jersey, 1990-94.

HEADLINE: Intel to Offer New Chips Today In Hope of Buoying Laptop Sales 

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation plans today to introduce a dozen new microprocessors into the slowing market for laptop computers, including chips that the company says will run small laptops at faster speeds while draining less battery power.
 Intel, the world's largest chip maker, said it had shipped the Pentium III-M chips to computer manufacturers. Analysts expect to see laptops incorporating the new chips as early the middle of this month. 
 Separately, Advanced Micro Devices, a competitor in chips for desktop computers and fast laptops, plans to announce today that it began shipping a 1.1-gigahertz version of its Duron chip. Computers running the Duron, which challenges Intel's Celeron processor in the lower end of the chip market, will be available in the fourth quarter, the company said.
The new Intel products include a slightly faster version of its high-end chip, six new versions of its low-end Celeron processor and cooler-running chips designed for laptops that weigh less than four pounds, a category led by Intel's smaller mobile-chip rival, Transmeta.
The announcement today will increase the so-called clock speed of the fastest mobile processor to 1.2 gigahertz, or 1.2 billion cycles a second in normal mode, from 1.1 gigahertz. The clock speed slows to 800 megahertz, or 800 million cycles a second, running on batteries alone.
Laptop sales have suffered from decreased corporate spending, though not as badly as desktop sales. Manufacturers shipped 1.3 percent more laptops in the United States in the second quarter than in the period a year earlier, while desktop shipments declined 14 percent, according to the International Data Corporation, a market research firm. Desktops outsell laptops by about 3 to 1.
But while laptop sales are still increasing over all, demand for so-called ultra-light computers -- which include only a disk drive and usually have smaller keyboards and screens -- fell 33 percent.
These smaller computers have enjoyed some success in Japan but have not really caught on in the United States, where only 130,000 were shipped in the second quarter.
"Given the state of the economy, they're being overlooked for notebooks of lower average selling prices," said Alan Promisel, an analyst with International Data.
Frank E. Spindler, an Intel vice president and general manager of the mobile platforms group, acknowledged that "the mobile PC space is not immune to the business environment," but said that declining prices and the increasing popularity of wireless networking would drive laptop sales. 
Prices of the new mobile chips range from $99 for the slowest Celeron to $722 for the fastest Pentium III-M, when bought in batches of 1,000. Advanced Micro's Duron chip will cost $103, the same as the comparable Intel Celeron.
Intel has engaged Advanced Micro in a price war in the desktop chip market, even as it extends its lead in clock speed. In an invitation sent to reporters on Friday for a coming news conference, Advanced Micro said that the industry should no longer use clock speed to measure overall performance.

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Solidifying trademarkprotection in a global market, where logos can transcend language.

BYLINE:  By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
AS executives of all types try to come to grips with the business and economic fallout of last month's terrorist attacks, Nils Montan's line of work might not seem to command much urgency just now. And that may say a lot about the difficulties of returning to business as usual in the currently tense international climate.
 Mr. Montan, you see, is the guy who sticks up for Superman. And for Batman, Bugs Bunny, the Flintstones and Scooby Doo, among others. As senior intellectual property counsel for AOL Time Warner's Warner Brothers unit, Mr. Montan ensures that those lucrative trademarks are not exploited by counterfeiters or unwitting artists who assume that those familiar characters belong to their adoring public. 
 And just because they are American icons does not mean those brands' value is derived only in the United States. They are money-makers all over the world, and the sums they earn are likely to increase with the spread of the Internet and other digital technologies. 
The same can be said for most trademarks. In a global economy, creating a recognizable brand that can cross language and cultural borders is critical to manufacturers, businesses and those who create the much ballyhooed "content" that fills software, computers, television, hand-held devices, cellular phones and the Internet. 
The globalization of the trademark business is the reason the United States Trademark Association changed its name to the International Trademark Association a few years ago. And it is why all trademark holders can join the group, based in Manhattan, even if they do not own a mark registered in this country. Tsingtao, the Chinese beer brewer (which owns many other marks), recently joined the group, for example. 
The International Trademark Association has about 4,000 members in 150 countries -- companies, institutions or intellectual property professionals like law firms. In May, Mr. Montan was elected president of the association. And most of the issues he is tackling have been high on the group's agenda for several years. With the United States contemplating overseas military action, though, that agenda is not necessarily high on anyone else's list of priorities.
"We represent trademark owners wherever they may be," Mr. Montan explained. When his organization lobbies foreign governments, lawmakers and businesses, members from those countries go along so it is clear that the group is advocating what Mr. Montan called "trademarks without borders." 
"In some respects, we're not a special pleader for American industry," he said. "We hope to serve their interests, but we hope the two goals will coincide." 
In the last several years the association has dedicated itself to convincing governments that trademark enforcement and anti-counterfeiting measures are critical to everyone. 
"It's one thing to have laws on the books," said Mr. Montan, who recently published his own book on anti-counterfeiting in Asia, where China, for example, only recently cracked down on CD, video and DVD forgers. "But we have to educate policy makers abroad about the benefits of enforcing trademarks and how that is good for their economy." 
The group is also concerned about protecting trademarks as the seven new domain categories for Internet addresses are introduced. The trademark association worries about a possible "land rush" that might result as the new designations -- like .biz and .info -- become available, along with 245 new country codes. 
"In the last five years, we've been working on Internet and online issues," Mr. Montan said. "The main problem here is trademark hijacking by cybersquatters and others, and confusion among the public." 
The United States passed anti-cybersquatting laws, aimed at speculators who take online names that rightfully belong to someone else, but "a lot of jurisdictions around the world are just starting to deal with this," Mr. Montan added. For his group, that means a big push to send policy makers the message: enact and enforce laws that will protect trademarks, whether they belong to a mom-and-pop business, Warner or Tsingtao. 
Another issue has been on the association's front burner for several years -- for about as long as it has languished in Congress. The group is pushing lawmakers to ratify an international trademark treaty that creates a one-stop registration process.
Under the treaty (which dozens of other nations have already signed), a trademark holder would be able to register, update or renew a mark, or pay fees, in one country. Previously, an owner had to file separate sets of papers in every country where he wanted protection. The treaty has been held up in Congress by secondary disputes over provisions attached to the legislation, but those seem to be resolved -- or they did before the Sept. 11 attacks put most things in Congress on hold. 
"It's never over till it's signed," Mr. Montan said. "There must be some slogan like that in Washington." 
But such business as usual, for Congress and the International Trademark Association, will have to wait a bit longer. 
On the morning of Sept. 11, Mr. Montan and Alan Drewsen, the association's executive director, were preparing to fly from New York to Washington to raise these issues with policy makers and members of Congress, and for the group's board meeting. That morning, Mr. Montan was walking toward the association's office on Avenue of the Americas in Midtown Manhattan when he noticed that people around him were looking up at the sky. 
He reached the office in time to see television coverage of the second plane crashing into the World Trade Center. Fortunately, the 45 people who work at the association were out of harm's way. 
But there was no question that a trip to Washington would have to be put off. Shuttle flights and trains were canceled, board members were stranded, and Congress shut down. Stunned and horrified like countless other executives, Mr. Drewsen and Mr. Montan set their immediate agenda aside. 
Mr. Montan flew back to Los Angeles on Friday, Sept. 14, to attend to his duties at Warner Brothers. Mr. Drewsen continues to keep the International Trademark Association office running in Manhattan. 
But right now, protecting trademarks is not the highest priority for the world's governments or businesses.

HEADLINE: NTT DoCoMo Introduces New Generation Cellphone Service 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 30 

 BODY:
NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone operator, will introduce the world's first third-generation cellular phone network Monday, hoping to thwart skeptics and solidify its shaky grip on the country's $70 billion wireless market. 
 The new service, at first available only in the metropolitan Tokyo area, promises Internet connections up to 40 times faster than current phones so users can download audio and video files onto their handsets. 
 Carriers around the world will intently watch consumers' response to DoCoMo's new service, because wireless companies elsewhere have spent about $100 billion on radio spectrum to offer their own versions. But with enthusiasm for new gadgets cooling and investors unwilling to finance the network expansions needed to offer third-generation -- or 3G -- services, carriers in Europe and the United States are delaying or scaling back their plans. 
DoCoMo, which delayed the introduction by six months to do additional testing, expects to attract 200,000 new customers for the phones in the first year. Subscribers would spend about 10,000 yen ($84) a month for the service, about 20 percent more than current users.
The company, which has nearly 40 million subscribers overall, plans to spend one trillion yen ($8.4 billion) in each of the next three years to expand the service nationwide. It does not expect to turn a profit on the service until 2004.
"The migration from second-generation to third-generation phones will revolutionize telecommunications, so the first company to launch the new technology will face the highest risks," said Keiji Tachikawa, chief executive of NTT DoComo.
The company created a sensation last year with its Internet-enabled phone service, I-mode, that allows customers to surf the Web and send and receive e-mail. DoCoMo, too, is widely thought to have the most stylish phones and the best Web sites designed for its service, a big reason it commands about 57 percent of Japan's wireless market.
But like most telecommunications companies, DoCoMo has been hurt by slowing demand for new phones, which are made for its service by NEC, Matsushita, Mitsubishi, Sanyo and Sony. As Japan's recession has sapped spending on non-essential items, shipments of cellular phones have fallen two straight months and new subscriptions are growing by single digits. DoCoMo also grappled with two recalls this year of faulty handsets.
So far, the snags have not forced the company to clip back its earnings projections, although it does expect to write down its 16 percent stake in the American company AT&T Wireless Services, which has lost 36 percent of its market value since DoCoMo bought it. 
DoCoMo's Japanese rivals have not been so lucky. On Friday, the nation's No. 2 mobile company, KDDI, cut its full-year net profit forecasts 45 percent, to 35 billion yen ($292 million). The company will probably sign up only 1.25 million new subscribers this year, a quarter less than originally forecast.
"I thought they'd miss their forecasts, but not by that much," said Mark Berman, a telecommunications analyst for Credit Suisse First Boston, who says the company is losing money by focusing on budget-conscious customers like students. 
KDDI also delayed the start of its third-generation phone service until April, as did the No. 3 carrier, Japan Telecom, which operates the J-Phone group. KDDI must coordinate with Motorola, which supplies its network equipment; Qualcomm, which provide chipsets for the phones; and the handset makers Sanyo Electric, Toshiba and Hitachi. 
J-Phone, however, has proven more resilient than KDDI. Although Japan Telecom slashed this year's profit forecasts by a third, J-Phone captured nearly 35 percent of all new subscriptions in August, more than twice as many as KDDI. J-Phone's newest phones run Java software for the Internet, which allows for more intricate graphics and video games. The company's deep discounting has also attracted new customers. 
J-Phone will also get assistance from the Vodafone Group, Europe's largest mobile-phone company, which owns 45 percent of Japan Telecom, and wants to increase that stake to 66.7 percent in the coming months. Analysts say Vodafone will improve J-Phone's marketing and finances, and may sell off Japan Telecom's less profitable fixed-line division. 
Japanese telecommunications stocks, which were pummeled earlier this year, have rallied since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, as investors have sought companies with steady cash flow and largely domestic businesses. NTT DoCoMo and Japan Telecom shares have soared more than 30 percent in the last three weeks.
KDDI's profit downgrade, however, sent the company's stock plunging 11.4 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Resume, but Industry OutlookSeems Worrisome 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: YPSILANTI, Mich., Sept. 29 

 BODY:
David Jaroszewicz is doing his part to revive the economy. Under a nearly cloudless Saturday sky here, between Detroit and Ann Arbor, he is selling cars again. Mr. Jaroszewicz surveys the few clusters of couples, some drawn by General Motors' new zero percent financing, twisting through a field of Grand Prixs and Grand Ams under a towering American flag.
 This, at least, is progress. In the days after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, sales at Suburban Pontiac-Buick-GMC of Ypsilanti, where Mr. Jaroszewicz works as a salesman, and throughout the country virtually halted. "There was nothing," he said, while selling a customer a diesel truck. 
 The auto industry slump is not good news for a nation that many economists think is headed into a recession. If cars and trucks do not sell, the problems cascade from dealerships to carmakers to suppliers. Jobs are lost, plants closed, and the economy braces for the impact. "It's impossible to have a sick auto industry and a healthy economy," said Art Spinella, a consultant with CNW Marketing Research in Bandon, Ore. "The two are inseparable." 
The September auto industry slump following the terrorist attacks is expected to reduce the Big Three's combined annual sales to their lowest level in several years and possibly since the early 1990's, several analysts say. Wall Street and Washington will be watching closely on Tuesday when the industry reports sales figures, providing some of the first monthly economic data since the attacks. 
In the days after Sept. 11, a nation that loves to buy lost its appetite, especially for big purchases. "It really stigmatized the whole car-purchasing process," said Mr. Jaroszewicz, a pen clipped to his collar, a cellphone in a holster on his belt. "I had to lighten up people, start cracking jokes to get people buying cars again. We can't live in the past. We have to get out of this funk, or we're done like dinner."
Economists agree. The fortunes of G.M., Ford and the Chrysler Group were in decline before Sept. 11. Now the forces already at work -- rising unemployment, depressed stock prices, a glutted auto market and increasing marketing costs -- have worsened conditions for domestic automakers at a time they are losing market share to foreign competitors. If there is any good news, it is that the passage of time and a wave of new incentives has brought some customers back. 
"It was the furthest thing from my mind last week, buying a car," said Jereme Brown, 21, a specialist in computer-aided design. Saturday was the first day Mr. Brown and his wife, Mikel, resumed their search. 
"We were looking a month or two ago," Mr. Brown said, but after the attacks "it was kind of hard to think about anything else." Ms. Brown, 20, said they "watched a lot of TV, listened to the radio, cried."
But now, Mr. Brown said, "We're getting back in the swing of things." 
According to John Casesa, a Merrill Lynch analyst, the auto industry is only beginning a sales slump that he expects to hit bottom in 2003. "I think this is going to be very severe," he said. "It is very much like the early 90's. You had an already cautious consumer, a saturated auto market and now an event that pulls the rug out from under confidence." 
Not all analysts and economists are so pessimistic. Many expect that the Federal Reserve's eight interest rate cuts after will in time have powerful effects on businesses and consumers. "Once you get to the second half of 2002," said Diane C. Swonk, chief economist at Bank One, "there's just so much money coming into the pipeline that this economy is poised to do well." 
But most analysts have sharply scaled back their sales estimates. Mr. Casesa of Merrill projects this year's overall United States sales, including those by foreign automakers, at 16.2 million cars and light trucks, short of last year's record of 17.3 million. Stephen J. Girsky of Morgan Stanley sees overall sales of 16.1 million this year and 15.2 million in 2002, but thinks that sales will be hard to predict until the political and military implications from the attacks are clearer.
The outlook for the Big Three seems particularly soft. Mr. Casesa thinks they will sell 10.4 million vehicles this year, the fewest since 1993, while analysts at Prudential Securities project the lowest sales since 1992. David Healy of Burnham Securities sees Big Three sales of 10.8 million, the lowest level since 1997.
To help avert trouble, two top Bush administration officials met with auto industry executives after the attacks, urging that they do their best to invigorate car buying.
G.M. announced some zero-percent financing plans for all its new cars and trucks, and was quickly followed by Ford and Chrysler. Such additional incentives have succeeded, but at a cost. "They've upped the incentive ante and that seems to be working," Mr. Girsky said. "But that poses the other question, that nobody is making any money with marketing costs this high."
Analysts give several reasons that the Big Three are likely to suffer the most. Predictions are gloomy for car rental companies, which do much of their business at airports, and the Big Three rely more on sales to rental companies than foreign automakers do. Production at domestic assembly plants was hampered by parts shortages after the shutdown of air traffic for several days and by shipping bottlenecks at the borders. And the Big Three, by their own admission, were already relying too heavily on incentives. 
Ford, G.M. and Chrysler all cut production in the first quarter and have been ceding market share to foreign producers as the sale of sport utility vehicles becomes increasingly competitive. Chrysler embarked on a turnaround plan in February that includes closing six plants worldwide and reducing its work force by 26,000 over three years. Last Friday, Chrysler said it might fail to meet its fourth-quarter financial goals. 
G.M., which said last December that it would discontinue its Oldsmobile line and cut 10 percent, or about 6,600, of its 66,000 salaried workers as well as 11,000 contract workers, briefly closed some plants after the attacks and has revised its sales projections for the industry.
Ford, suffering from problems related to rollovers of Explorer vehicles, which it attributes to faulty Firestone tires, already planned cutbacks. Since the attacks, the company has said it will cut production by 110,000 to 120,000 vehicles further.
This week, the Big Three will temporarily lay off almost 18,000 workers at seven plants in Maryland, Missouri and Georgia as well as in Canada. Inevitably, these cutbacks will cause auto suppliers, who now account for much of the industry, to idle employees at their own plants. 
"When Ford shuts down Ranger production, the people in those plants that work on Ranger parts don't work," said Susan Skerker, a senior vice president of Visteon, referring to a Ford pickup truck. Visteon is a giant automotive supplier that was spun off from Ford last year. 
Some Michigan residents now want to do their best to give the auto industry a lift. John Betts, 54, works for a forklift company that supplies the Big Three. In the days after Sept. 11, he watched the celebrity telethon, called in a donation, and saw a few thousand dollars disappear from the value of his 401(k) account. But he kept shopping on car lots that were otherwise empty. 
'It's bad about what happened," he said, "but what can you do. You've got to spend money or the economy really is going to go into the dumper."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
The industry sees changes in big accounts, but also layoffs and profit warnings.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AS Madison Avenue slowly seeks a return to business as usual -- whatever that may now mean -- agencies are being affected by changes in accounts for large advertisers like the Coca-Cola Company and the Burger King Corporation, with billings estimated at $575 million.
 But normality these days includes profit warnings and layoffs, too, as several announcements late last week underscored the fragility of the advertising economy. 
 The growing uncertainty about world events, which is causing many marketers to delay or reduce ad spending, was the reason given on Friday by the Cordiant Communications Group in London to warn of a "significant reduction in profitability" for 2001.
Planned layoffs at Cordiant are being increased by 75 percent, to 700 of its estimated 10,000 employees worldwide from a previous goal of 400. 
Cordiant was not alone in making staff cutbacks. Dismissals at five other agencies will cost an estimated 525 people their jobs in coming weeks, including the Chicago office of Campbell Mithun, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, owned by the Omnicom Group; iXL in Atlanta; Media Passage in Seattle, which closed; and Modem Media in Norwalk, Conn., partly owned by Interpublic. The layoffs were reported by the online editions of the trade publications Advertising Age and Adweek.
As for the account changes, the largest involve Coca-Cola, which is realigning its agency roster for creative assignments, consolidating almost all those tasks at agencies owned by Interpublic and the WPP Group. The total billings involved are estimated at $250 million.
The shifts, to be formally announced this week, will come soon after the principal Coca-Cola rival, the Pepsi-Cola division of PepsiCo, realigned its agency roster by dismissing divisions of Interpublic and consolidating most assignments at agencies owned by Omnicom.
Interpublic is in essence being compensated for the accounts shifted by Pepsi-Cola, which had billings estimated at $200 million.
Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of Interpublic, will be awarded creative tasks for Powerade sports beverages, handled only since May by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. Billings were estimated at as much as $60 million. Powerade will replace the Gatorade sports-beverages account, which the Foote, Cone Chicago office lost in the Pepsi-Cola consolidation.
Another brand handled by Wieden & Kennedy, Diet Coke, is returning to Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide in New York, part of the Partnership division of Interpublic, which lost it to Wieden & Kennedy in late 1998. Those billings were estimated at $50 million.
Creative tasks for Sprite, the lemon-lime soft drink, at Lowe Lintas and predecessor agencies for at least 15 years, are being shifted to the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP. Billings were estimated at $85 million. Ogilvy also gains creative tasks for the Fanta line of fruit-flavored soft drinks, previously divided among various agencies.
The Sprite and Fanta assignments add Ogilvy, and WPP, to the Coca-Cola roster. Sir Martin Sorrell, chief executive at WPP, and Shelly Lazarus, chairwoman and chief executive at Ogilvy, have impressed Steven J. Heyer, who recently joined Coca-Cola as executive vice president.
Wieden & Kennedy will also lose the rest of its creative accounts, including Barq's root beer and campaigns with sports themes for Coca-Cola Classic. The new home for Barq's is not known; the sports account is likely to be headed to the lead creative agency for Coca-Cola Classic, McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York, part of the World Group division of Interpublic.
Other agencies Coca-Cola will drop include two owned by the Bcom3 Group. One is Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago, which created ads for Minute Maid juices and juice drinks and seasonal ads for Coca-Cola Classic.
The Coca-Cola work is likely to go to McCann-Erickson. It is not clear which agency will inherit Minute Maid, with billings estimated at $40 million, handled by Burnett since 1996. Foote, Cone is a good guess because until the Pepsi-Cola consolidation, its New York office handled Minute Maid's principal competitor, the Tropicana brand of juices and juice drinks.
The other Bcom3 agency being dismissed is the New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which created campaigns centered on the Coca-Cola Classic sponsorship of Nascar racing. That too is probably on its way to McCann-Erickson.
There had been widespread speculation that a smaller shop on the Coca-Cola creative roster, Berlin Cameron & Partners in New York, would also be dismissed. But Andy Berlin, chairman, said on Friday, "We retain our assignments," for Dasani bottled water, Nestea Cool tea drinks and the Mello Yello and Pibb soft drinks.
Turning to Burger King, part of Diageo, it is unexpectedly parting ways with the New York office of McCann-Erickson, which had handled for only nine months the assignment to create general market campaigns aimed at adults. Billings were estimated at $200 million.
Rather than use one agency for creative tasks, said Richard Taylor, vice president for global advertising and promotion at Burger King in Miami, the company would shift to "a new structure where a variety of creative resources will be called upon" from the Interpublic family. He confirmed a report of the decision in the online edition of Adweek.
The changes came a month after Burger King named Howard Draft, chairman and chief executive at its promotional agency, Draft Worldwide in Chicago -- part of the Partnership division of Interpublic -- to coordinate the entire Burger King account, including advertising, promotions and public relations. Two Draft divisions developed a big instant-win game, "Cash Is King," to be introduced today by Burger King.
Indeed, as Burger King expands its relationships with Interpublic agencies other than McCann-Erickson, Mr. Taylor said, Draft will add promotional programs outside the United States to its current tasks. Also, Octagon, part of the Partnership division, will be hired for sports marketing assignments, and Weber Shandwick, part of the Advanced Marketing Services division, will be hired for public relations assignments. The Minneapolis office of Campbell Mithun continues to create campaigns aimed at children.
Finally, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta named several agencies to handle assignments for a national campaign to discuss health issues with children ages 9 to 13. Total spending was estimated at $125 million.
Three agencies are part of the Publicis Groupe: Frankel in Chicago, the lead agency on the account, for assignments including promotions and online ads; Publicis Dialog in Chicago, for public relations; and Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, for creative tasks, research and media planning and buying.
Two multicultural agencies will also work on the account: A Partnership in New York, for ads aimed at Asian-American youths, and Garcia LKS in San Antonio, for ads aimed at Latino youths. The decision came after a seven-month review that been narrowed several times.

HEADLINE: Slew of Supreme Court Cases to Focus on'96 Telecom Law 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 

 BODY:
The Supreme Court begins its term on Monday with a full plate of telecommunications cases that lawyers say demonstrate the shortcomings of the landmark 1996 law that was supposed to deregulate the industry and introduce competition to telephone markets long dominated by monopolies.
 The 10 lawsuits, broadly consolidated into three sets of cases that will be argued beginning this week, present significant questions about the costs of local telephone and high-speed Internet services. 
 The outcomes could help determine how much consumers will pay for such services in the years to come, and how many competitors will be around to provide them.
In the last year, many would-be competitors have filed for bankruptcy or gone out of business, in some instances citing the economic legacy of the 1996 law. Paradoxically, it was the same law that allowed them to come into existence. 
One set of cases challenges the vital though arcane accounting methods the government uses in setting rates for rival local phone companies that rely on the networks and equipment of the regional Bell companies.
A second set involves important issues about an old regulatory scheme that treats telephone and cable services completely differently at a time when these technologies are converging and both are being used to supply high-speed Internet services. 
A third set may resolve the constitutional question of whether federal courts have the authority to review the decisions of state utility regulators, an issue that has led to conflicting rulings by federal appeals courts.
The cases, which arise as appointees in the Bush administration have been moving toward further deregulation, also demonstrate the shortcomings of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. More than five years after supporters of the law said it would revolutionize competition in the telephone industry, local markets are still dominated by four regional Bell companies, which have repeatedly filed lawsuits challenging both the law and the way it has been enforced.
By all accounts, Congress did little to head off such suits, drafting what most experts consider to be one of the sloppiest laws on the books.
"It would be gross understatement to say that the 1996 act is not a model of clarity," Justice Antonin Scalia wrote for the majority of the court in an earlier version of the telephone network rate cases that will be heard again in 10 days. "It is in many important respects a model of ambiguity or indeed even self-contradiction. That is most unfortunate for a piece of legislation that profoundly affects a crucial segment of the economy worth tens of billions of dollars."
Seth P. Waxman, a former solicitor general in the Clinton administration, who argued cases involving the act, was more succinct. 
"It is the single most poorly drafted statute ever enacted by Congress," he said in an interview. He recalled a telling incident during the oral argument in the earlier case decided by Justice Scalia, in which the justice expressed jocular skepticism after William P. Barr, the general counsel of Verizon and former United States attorney general, began his oral presentation by referring to the "plain language of the statute."
"There is no plain language in that statute," Mr. Waxman said. "It is the product of extended negotiations among telecom lobbyists, each trying to get a little something to bring back to their clients."
In the telephone cases, the court will review which accounting method is most appropriate for determining how much the regional Bell operating companies should be permitted to charge smaller companies that lease equipment in markets regulators have struggled to try opening to competition.
Charging too much would effectively kill competition, while charging too little, the Bell operating companies say, could cripple them. The Bell companies, which control more than 90 percent of the local markets, have been engaged in a fierce legal and regulatory battle over the method to be used in calculating how much they can charge to lease access to their network equipment. The newer, smaller companies say that battle has brought years of uncertainty over the rules and made it difficult for them to raise investments that are vital to such a capital-intensive industry.
"The Bell companies have appealed virtually every decision of the F.C.C. and the states to enforce the telecommunications act," said John D. Windhausen Jr., president of the Association for Local Telecommunications Services, a trade group that represents the competitive local exchange carriers. Some of the group's members are parties in the cases now before the court. 
"It's been a constant barrage of litigation because they don't like competition," Mr. Windhausen said. "They are trying to slow us down and tie up the rules. That's slowed our ability to connect with the telecom network and it's slowed our ability to attract capital in the markets and it's slowed our ability to deliver services to consumers."
Christopher J. Wright, a former general counsel at the F.C.C. who helped draft the regulations at issue in the cases, said the litigation "has had a bad effect on the competitive process."
"Congress in 1996 gave the F.C.C. six months to write these regulations," he said. "Now, more than five years later, the courts are still interpreting them. Would-be competitors need to raise money and have some sense of certainty. There hasn't been certainty for more than five years."
The court will review the proper method to calculate the fees the Bell companies can charge their rivals. After the telecommunications act was adopted, the F.C.C. issued accounting regulations outlining how the Bell companies were to calculate the price of leases to competitors. The regulations were necessary because it is too expensive for start-ups to build their own networks and they must instead rely on the components already created by the Bell companies.
Last year, a federal appeals court in St. Louis struck down an important provision in the F.C.C. rules. The provision had based the calculation of the lease prices on the "efficient replacement cost of existing technology" -- in other words the value of the equipment if it were replaced with new, more efficient and often less expensive equipment, rather than the higher prices the Bells had actually paid for the gear over the years. The Bells' rivals had preferred calculations based on the forward-looking replacement costs, which were generally lower. 
The telephone network cases, Verizon Communications v. F.C.C., No. 00-511, will be heard on Oct. 10.
In the high-speed Internet case, the court will review the application of a 1977 law, the Pole Attachments Act, which gave the F.C.C. the authority to regulate the rates that utilities can charge cable television operators to string their wires on utility poles. The agency then decided to apply that authority to regulate fees for using poles by cable companies that also provide high-speed, or broadband, Internet services.
Last year, in a challenge filed by a group of utilities, a federal appeals panel said the F.C.C. did not have the authority to regulate such fees. Since that decision, some utility companies have sharply raised their pole-attachment rates, charging what government officials say is the equivalent of monopoly rents.
The Gulf Power Company, one of the companies to file the original challenge, raised its annual attachment rate to $38.06 per pole from $6.20. Alabama Power has raised its rates to $38.81 a pole from $7.47.
Mr. Waxman said the case also presented the court with an opportunity to clarify whether broadband Internet service is a cable service or a telecommunications service. The distinction is crucial because cable companies are significantly less regulated by the F.C.C. than are telecommunications services providers. 
This group of cases, National Cable and Telecom v. Gulf Power, No. 00-832, will be heard on Tuesday.
In the third set of cases, the court will decide whether state regulators who set phone rates can be sued in federal courts or whether those courts do not have jurisdiction because of the 11th Amendment. It raises an important constitutional question, because the 11th Amendment, which had largely been ignored until recent years, generally limits the states from being sued in federal court.
Earlier this year a federal appeals court for the Fourth Circuit, in Maryland, held that a provision of the telecommunications act that grants federal courts the jurisdiction to review rate decisions by state regulators was a violation of the 11th Amendment.
Breaking with four other appeals courts, the Fourth Circuit found that the provision is "an affront to state sovereignty."
As a practical matter, Mr. Wright said, many lawyers believe that federal courts are less likely to be deferential to state regulatory commissions than state courts are. Moreover, he said, the law is more likely to be applied consistently if decisions are reviewed in the federal system, making it easier to provide telecommunications service in multiple states. 
The cases, to be heard by the court on Dec. 5, are Mathias v. WorldCom Technologies, No. 00-878, and Verizon Maryland v. Public Service Commission, No. 00-1531.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
With New Paradigm, Rattled Wall Street Looks to Washington

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Markets open for trading today in a new quarter and a new world, one where Washington, and not just the Federal Reserve, matters more than it has in many years.
 Stocks have just finished their worst quarter since the crash of 1987. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gave up 15 percent of its value, a total of more than $1 trillion, while the Nasdaq composite index fell nearly 31 percent. 
 At least for now, the steepest part of the slide appears to be over. Stocks recovered last week, and many professional investors say that if the United States can avoid a deep recession over the next year, they are reasonably valued, perhaps even cheap. But that is a very big if, and it may well depend on smart action from lawmakers, they say. 
Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers, said yesterday that the markets needed Washington to move quickly, both to ease interest rates and to stimulate the economy with tax cuts and additional spending. "We're talking about not just monetary response, we're talking about fiscal response, and we're talking about military response," Mr. Applegate said. 
The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, for its part, will meet on Tuesday, and most analysts are counting on another half-percentage point cut in short-term interest rates. The Federal Reserve also cut rates by half a percentage point on Sept. 17, the day the markets reopened after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.
But for much of the 1990's, Wall Street paid only passing attention to other broad federal actions. To many in Silicon Valley and on Wall Street, the dramas of the government shutdown of 1995 and President Bill Clinton's impeachment proved only that the federal government had become little more than a sideshow. Even before Mr. Clinton was acquitted in February 1999, the Nasdaq had begun its run to 5,000.
Last year, investors hardly seemed to care about whether Al Gore or George Bush would succeed Mr. Clinton as President. The conventional wisdom held that the need to keep bond traders happy and interest rates low would prevent either man from frittering away too much of the government's budget surplus with new spending or tax cuts.
Despite the tax cuts pushed through by Mr. Bush this spring, before Sept. 11, the federal government remained on course to run very large surpluses for the next decade (although for the next couple of years, the surpluses would have come largely from Social Security taxes).
Even as growth slowed and the stock market skidded this year, most investors thought the economy would eventually get back on track no matter what the government did or did not do to help it. Before Sept. 11, the economy and the market seemed fragile, but hardly broken. Corporate profits were plunging, and more and more economists worried that companies might try to prop up earnings by cutting jobs, hurting consumer spending.
But Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, had already cut short-term interest rates seven times since the beginning of 2001. Those cuts, combined with falling energy prices, seemed to be helping somewhat, and most economists figured that by early to mid-2002, the economy would be growing solidly again.
Then came the hijackings.
Now, for the first time in at least a decade, the financial markets are looking south for direction. The attacks damaged consumer and business confidence, and many economists think that only the president and Congress, in league with the Federal Reserve, can stop the United States from falling into a potentially deep recession.
Lawmakers from both parties appear ready to consider new government spending or tax cuts, beyond the cuts and rebates they passed earlier this year.
Even Mr. Greenspan, who in the immediate aftermath of the attacks urged Congress to act cautiously before authorizing new spending, said last week that any new stimulus package needed to be as much as $100 billion, including $40 billion in emergency aid already provided, in order to have a meaningful economic impact. 
Investors are waiting to see how quickly Congress and the White House will reach agreement on the details of a stimulus package and on its size. Those details are crucial, because a poorly designed or excessive stimulus package could send long-term interest rates higher, undoing the positive economic effects of new spending or tax cuts.
So lawmakers will have to work wisely, and quickly, investment strategists say, to give the economy and the financial markets a jolt. 
"It's absolutely critical that we get help from the government at this point, if for no other reason than to get a certain degree of confidence, both for consumers and to business people," said Stephen Slifer, chief U.S. economist for Lehman Brothers.
