HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REBELS; 
Bush Approves Covert Aid for Taliban Foes

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 

 BODY:
President Bush has approved a secret effort to strengthen a diverse array of groups opposing the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan, administration officials said today. 
 Separately, Mr. Bush has authorized $100 million in new relief aid to Afghan refugees, as part of an effort to quell resentment in Pakistan as thousands of refugees pour over the border each day. 
 Administration officials are also actively considering a plan to air-drop food into Afghanistan to forestall starvation as winter approaches. But military planners are hesitating because they have not yet figured out how to ensure that the food does not fall into the Taliban's hands. 
The administration's program of covert support for anti-Taliban groups has emerged as a key element of its plan to oust a regime that Washington has accused of sheltering Osama bin Laden and his network.
The aid is not only intended to help the Northern Alliance, the rebel group that operates from bases in northern Afghanistan. It is also aimed at stirring up resistance to the Taliban among Pashtun tribal groups in the south. 
"The purpose is to enhance their ability to move against the Taliban," a senior official said. "It is not limited to political support." 
Administration officials indicated that the assistance included financing, but they declined to explain how much money would be spent or to provide details of the effort. Funds could supply a lifeblood to the anti-Taliban groups and enable them to buy weapons, to recruit new fighters, to bribe Taliban commanders to switch sides, or to undertake other efforts to weaken the regime. 
The United States is eager to obtain these results but has shrouded the effort in secrecy to avoid giving the impression that Washington alone is determining the future of Afghanistan.
Previously American officials have ly suggested that if new fighting breaks out, the rebels could provide intelligence data and serve as proxy fighters in an effort led by the United States to track Mr. bin Laden and target the Taliban.
Encouraging defections in the ranks of the Taliban is also a prime goal. In the 19 days since the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, one administration official disclosed today, the United States has been in contact with "people who are loosely affiliated with the Taliban and have separated from them" or are likely to switch sides if they believe that the Taliban's days are numbered.
An administration official said "appropriate legal authority exists" for a full range of activities in Afghanistan, but he declined to say whether Mr. Bush had signed a presidential decision directive, a secret document that would specifically authorize covert activity. 
Mr. Bush's decisions came as anti-Taliban Afghans continued their effort to form a broad coalition centered around the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah. The king, 86, has been meeting in Rome with representatives of the Northern Alliance and commanders from the south of Afghanistan. 
Mostapha Zahir, the king's grandson, said in a telephone interview today that negotiations to form a common front were continuing and that the king, the Northern Alliance and southern commanders planned to issue a declaration on Monday. 
Those involved include Abdul Haq, a former mujahedeen commander who fought against Soviet troops in of Afghanistan and who recently returned to the region, as well as a half dozen other commanders. The king also plans to convene a "loya jirga," an assembly of Afghan leaders. 
The Northern Alliance has been fighting the Taliban for years. It controls only a small amount of territory, and its military leader was recently killed in a suicide bomb attack that American intelligence believes was instigated by Mr. bin Laden. The alliance is dominated by ethic Tajiks and Uzbeks and therefore is not acceptable to many Afghans. 
The dominant group in Afghanistan is the Pashtun, and the Bush administration has been careful to support that group as well. The former king is a Pashtun, and the Taliban leaders are also Pashtun. 
"There's no question but that there are any number of people in Afghanistan -- tribes in the south, the Northern Alliance in the north -- that oppose the Taliban," Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," alluding to the decision to support the rebel factions. "And clearly, we need to recognize the value they bring to this anti-terrorist, anti-Taliban effort and, where appropriate, find ways to assist them." 
Mr. Bush's decisions came last week as his National Security Council drafted a "guidance," or description, of its political goals in Afghanistan. The statement laid the basis for an effort to oust the Taliban. It charged that the Taliban were allied with terrorists, repressed the Afghan population, interfered with the delivery of aid and were not legitimate rulers of the nation.
Even though the Bush administration has been quietly encouraging the effort to form a broad anti-Taliban coalition around the former king, the statement asserts that Washington was not taking sides about who should lead the fractious nation. 
"The Taliban do not represent the Afghan people, who never elected or chose the Taliban faction," the guidance said. "We do not want to choose who rules Afghanistan, but we will assist those who seek a peaceful, economically developing Afghanistan, free of terrorism. The international community must devote itself to stabilizing Afghanistan."
Elaborating on the guidance, a senior official said: "We do not want to appear to be taking sides or favoring one ethnic group or one party, or one group of tribes. We will judge people by whether they support the objective."
In Afghanistan, the Taliban reacted defiantly to indications that the United States was trying to overthrow their leadership and replace it with a rebel coalition overseen by the former king. "Don't you know the nature of Afghans, that they will fight against your corrupt administration?" Mullah Muhammed Omar, the Taliban leader, told the king in a radio broadcast. "How dare you think you can return to Afghanistan backed by the United States. How are you going to rule the country? How can you think of such things?"
Anti-Taliban groups, for their part, said they expected that the United States would strike soon and urged it not to stop until it had rid Afghanistan of terrorism and the Taliban.
"In my opinion, the reaction by the international alliance will be soon," Abdullah Abdullah, the foreign minister for the Northern Alliance, said at a news conference in Tajikistan, speaking in English. "We have offered our willingness to cooperate." 
Military action is not the only way to counter the Taliban. By giving aid, Washington wants to show that its efforts are not directed against the Afghan people. And it also wants to reassure Pakistan that it is not insensitive to the refugee burden.
In the earliest planning for the response against Mr. bin Laden, the White House was concerned that the Taliban would steal the food shipped in, and keep it from the nearly 12 million Afghans affected by famine. 
But European allies and Arab nations warned Washington that the deaths of Afghan civilians, whether by bombs or starvation, would weaken popular support for the anti-terror effort. 
In the last week, two of the biggest international relief agencies won permission for the first time from the Iranian government to ship food over the Iranian border into Afghanistan. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Committee of the Red Cross receive their biggest financial support from the United States. 
Similarly, last week the United States Agency for International Development won White House backing to urge top international agencies to send as much food as possible to important positions in Afghanistan.

HEADLINE: OBSERVATORY 

BYLINE:  By HENRY FOUNTAIN 

 BODY:
This Old, Old House
 The homeowner who wants to do some work on the house has a lot of choices of where to get materials -- there's a lumberyard here, a hardware store there, and, of course, a Home Depot everywhere. 
 A thousand years ago, the Anasazi people in Chaco Canyon in northwestern New Mexico had far fewer options. To build their great houses -- masonry pueblos with hundreds of rooms -- they needed millions of pounds of stone and hundreds of thousands of timbers for the beams and lintels.
The stone was no problem, being easily obtained from the surrounding sandstone cliffs. But nearby conifer forests were quickly used up, forcing the Anasazi to harvest trees from mountains that were 45 to 60 miles away and carry the timbers -- some more than 15 feet long and weighing over 600 pounds -- back to the canyon. 
Now, scientists from the University of Arizona and the United States Geological Survey have determined precisely which mountains all those timbers came from. They analyzed the ratio of two isotopes of strontium in the logs, making use of the fact that trees incorporate the element from dust, water and bedrock as they grow, and the ratio differs depending upon the geological makeup of an area.
By comparing the isotope ratios to those from modern trees, the scientists discovered that the timbers were harvested from the Chuska and San Mateo Mountains, but not from the San Pedro Mountains, which are equally distant. They also found that timbers from the Chuska and San Mateo ranges were incorporated into the same houses.
Writing in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, the researchers say their findings suggest that the Anasazis' procuring of trees wasn't just a simple case of using up one resource and moving on to the next. Social and economic ties with other communities probably influenced where they got the timbers, and the Anasazi themselves had to have great organizational abilities to produce a labor force capable of getting them.

Following the Water
Droughts have spawned some of history's great human migrations. But drought can have an effect on a micro level, too. Witness what researchers have discovered about the activity of cyanobacteria in the desert.
Cyanobacteria (sometimes called, misleadingly, blue-green algae) are photosynthesizing organisms, usually unicellular, that often grow in long, threadlike colonies. In the desert, cyanobacteria, with fungi and lichens, often make up the organic crust that develops on rocks and soil.
Studying soils from badlands in Spain, researchers from Arizona State University and Bordeaux University in France have discovered that some cyanobacteria migrate within the soil as the moisture level changes. Cyanobacteria just beneath the surface appeared on the surface within minutes after the soil was wetted, and disappeared as the soil dried out.
Adding compounds that inhibited energy use by the cyanobacteria stopped the process completely, indicating the organisms were not just hitching rides on the water, via surface tension, as it moved. The researchers, writing in Nature, say the ability of cyanobacteria to follow water may be crucial to their survival in harsh conditions.

That Travelin' Manatee
The Florida manatee that made a name for itself six years ago by traveling all the way to Rhode Island is at it again. It has been sighted near Norfolk, Va.
Manatees normally migrate northward to the Carolinas, but they rarely go farther north. In 1994, this manatee, a male, traveled to the Chesapeake Bay (earning the nickname Chessie) and the following year he was spotted off Point Judith, R.I.
Wildlife officials in Virginia recognized Chessie by his distinctive scars. They expect that once he decides to head home, he will do so under his own power, as in previous years.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
Roadblocks on the Path to Stability

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
"Some Voices," a tough social drama from 1994, was the response of a young British playwright, Joe Penhall, to newly enacted laws (in Britain) that released large numbers of the institutionalized mentally ill back into the general population. 
 In the play a young schizophrenic named Ray, sent out into the world only with a bottle of pills he is loath to take, leaves the asylum and is taken in by his brother, Pete, a diligent and well-meaning restaurant owner who is nonetheless emotionally unequipped to cope with Ray's instability. 
 The play, being presented through Friday at the Greenwich Street Theater, is a little overwrought, but it is a sensitive and entirely unsentimental work in which every character suffers more than he or she deserves. Not only is Ray's eager lurch toward a normal life doomed by his inner vertigo, but Pete's hard-earned stability is ominously threatened as well. 
Beyond these two, Laura, the young, pregnant Irishwoman Ray falls for and whom he tries to rescue from an abusive boyfriend, ends up being sucked into violence herself; the boyfriend, Dave, though deserving of a harsh comeuppance, meets an especially gruesome fate. Finally, Ives, an asylum inmate who is older and sicker than Ray and who either is released or escapes and goes unlooked for, becomes the most hapless victim of a public policy the playwright clearly deplores as expedient and cruel.
The play may be purposeful, but it isn't polemical. The characters are too credibly and carefully drawn for that, and the actors (all New York based, but British or Irish born) are individually intelligent and thorough in their performances. The cast is the best thing about the show. 
As Ray, Victor Villar-Hauser has a haunting grin and a bounding, physical manner that conveys the kind of obstinate misapprehension of reality that those who want to help the mentally ill find so deeply frustrating. As Pete, a sturdily built actor, Mike Finesilver, carries the burden of an unhappily single working man with weary determination. Laoisa Sexton is a wounded and sexy Laura; David Costelloe is a fierce and suitably stupid Dave; and in a small tour de force Patrick Tull, a graying, decrepit Santa of a man, is Ives, a chilling wise fool, close to terrifying in his crazed eloquence.
"Some Voices" first appeared in New York Off Broadway two years ago; this new version is produced by Ludovica Villar-Hauser ("The Countess"), Victor's sister, and directed by Kevin Kittle. It is a no-frills affair, which is what you might expect in a tiny (74 seats) out-of-the-way (west of SoHo) house. But in this case the evidently lowest of budgets hasn't been used to serve the play adequately.
Overall the show has an uneven pace, a halting quality that makes it feel longer than it ought to, which is partly the fault of the script. It was Mr. Penhall's first play (his latest, "blue/orange," is a current London hit and also concerns the treatment of the mentally ill), and though it isn't exactly long-winded, it's far from economical. Unfortunately the production doesn't do much to solve this. 
For one thing the sets, made of simple modules on wheels that are moved around and recombined between scenes, are neither evocatively nor attractively designed, and why they're painted a glowing lime green is an unhappy mystery. 
With nine scenes in each of the two acts, the interruptions are frequent, and Mr. Kittle hasn't figured out a better way of smoothing them over than playing recorded British rock music of a sardonic and angry ilk.

SOME VOICES

By Joe Penhall; directed by Kevin Kittle; sets and costumes by Valerie Green; lighting by Douglas Filomena; sound by Susan Williams; company manager, Ralph Carhart; production stage manager, Mel Besaw; co-producer, Benham Latimer. Presented by the Villar-Hauser Theater Development Fund Inc., under the direction of Ludovica Villar-Hauser. At the Greenwich Street Theater, 547 Greenwich Street, West Village.

HEADLINE: Rational and Irrational Fears Combine in Terrorism's Wake 

BYLINE:  By ERICA GOODE 

 BODY:
The familiar became strange, the ordinary perilous.
On Sept. 11, Americans entered a new and frightening geography, where the continents of safety and danger seemed forever shifted.
 Is it safe to fly? Will terrorists wage germ warfare? Where is the line between reasonable precaution and panic? 
 Jittery, uncertain and assuming the worst, many people have answered these questions by forswearing air travel, purchasing gas masks and radiation detectors, placing frantic calls to pediatricians demanding vaccinations against exotic diseases or rushing out to fill prescriptions for Cipro, an antibiotic most experts consider an unnecessary defense against anthrax. 
Psychologists who study how people perceive potential hazards say such responses are not surprising, given the intense emotions inspired by the terrorist attacks. 
"People are particularly vulnerable to this sort of thing when they're in a state of high anxiety, fear for their own well-being and have a great deal of uncertainty about the future," said Dr. Daniel Gilbert, a professor of psychology at Harvard.
"We don't like that feeling," Dr. Gilbert said. "We want to do something about it. And, at the moment, there isn't anything particular we can do, so we buy a gas mask and put an American decal on our car and take trains instead of airplanes."
But, he added, "I'll be very surprised if five years from now even one life was saved by these efforts."
Still, many psychologists said avoiding flying might be perfectly reasonable if someone is going to spend the entire flight in white-knuckled terror. And though experts say gas masks will offer dubious protection in a chemical attack, if buying them helps calm people down, it can do no harm.
"The feelings may be irrational, but once you have the feelings, the behavior is perfectly rational," said Dr. George Lowenstein, a professor of economics and psychology at Carnegie Mellon University. "It doesn't make sense to take a risk just because it's rational if it's going to make you miserable. The rational thing is to do what makes you comfortable."
The public's fears may be heightened, he and other experts said, by the sense that the government failed to predict or prevent the Sept. 11 attacks, making people less trusting of the reassurances offered by the authorities, who have said that biological attacks are unlikely and, with vastly heightened security, air travel is safe. 
Checkpoints on highways, closed parking structures at airports, flyovers by military aircraft and other security measures, they added, while reassuring many people, may for others increase anxiety by providing a constant reminder of danger.
In fact, the threats now uppermost in many people's minds, Dr. Lowenstein and other psychologists said, are examples of the kinds of risks that people find most frightening.
"All the buttons are being pushed here," said Dr. Paul Slovic, a professor of psychology at the University of Oregon and the author of "The Perception of Risk." Threats posed by terrorism, he said, "are horrific to contemplate, seem relatively uncontrollable and are catastrophic." 
He and other researchers have found that risks that evoke vivid images, that are seen as involuntary, that are unfamiliar or that kill many people at once are often perceived as more threatening than risks that are voluntary, familiar and less extreme in their effects. For example, in studies, people rank threats like plane crashes and nuclear accidents higher than dangers like smoking or car accidents, which actually cause many more deaths each year. 
This fact is a source of endless frustration to some scientists, who cannot understand why people panic over almost undetectable quantities of pesticides on vegetables but happily devour charcoal-broiled hamburgers and steaks, which contain known carcinogens formed in grilling. And, when asked to rank the relative dangers of a variety of potential hazards, scientific experts routinely give lower ratings to things like nuclear power and pesticides than do laypeople, researchers have found. 
"Everything in some sense is dangerous, in some concentration and some place, and usually not in others," said Dr. James Collman, a chemistry professor at Stanford and the author of "Naturally Dangerous: Surprising Facts About Food, Health and the Environment."
He said his daughter called him after the terrorist attacks to ask if she should buy a gas mask.
"I told her not to panic," he said. "I thought it was sort of statistically a silly thing to do, and were there ever any toxic gases out there, whatever mask she had might or might not be effective anyway."
Yet psychologists say the average person's responses make sense if one realizes that human beings are not the cool, rational evaluators that economists and other social scientists once assumed them to be.
Rather, the human brain reacts to danger through the activation of two systems, one an instant, emotional response, the other a higher level, more deliberate reaction.
The emotional response to risk, Dr. Lowenstein said, is deeply rooted in evolution and shared with most other animals. But rationality -- including the ability to base decisions about risk on statistical likelihood -- is unique to humans.
Yet the two responses, he said, often come into conflict, "just as the experts clash with the laypeople."
"People often even within themselves don't believe that a risk is objectively that great, and yet they have feelings that contradict their cognitive evaluations," Dr. Lowenstein said. 
For example, he said, "The objective risk of driving for four or five hours at high speeds still has got to be way higher than the risk of flying." 
Yet Dr. Lowenstein added that a group of his colleagues, all academic experts on risk assessment, chose to drive rather than fly to a conference after the terrorist attacks.
"If you ask them which is objectively more dangerous, they would probably say that driving is," Dr. Lowenstein said. And though his colleagues cited potential airport delays, he said he suspected fear might also have played into their decision.
President Bush and other policy makers in Washington, Dr. Lowenstein said, must contend with a similar struggle between reason and emotion in shaping their response to the attacks.
"A lot of what's going on is this battle where the emotions are pushing us to respond in a way that would give us quick release but would have all sorts of long-term consequences," Dr. Lowenstein said.
In fact, studies show that once awakened, fear and other emotions heighten people's reactions to other potential hazards. In one study, for example, students shown sad films perceived a variety of risks as more threatening than students who saw emotionally neutral films.
Fear can also spread from person to person, resulting in wild rumors and panic.
One example often cited by sociologists who study collective behavior is the so-called Seattle windshield pitting epidemic, which occurred in 1954, a time when cold war fears ran high and the United States was testing the hydrogen bomb.
That year, tiny holes in car windshields were noticed in Bellingham, Wash., north of Seattle. A week later, similar pitting was seen by residents of towns south of Bellingham. Soon, people in Seattle and all over the state were reporting mysterious damage to their windshields. Many speculated that fallout from the H-bomb tests was the cause. Others blamed cosmic rays from the sun. At the height of the panic, the mayor of Seattle even called President Dwight D. Eisenhower for help.
But eventually, a more mundane explanation revealed itself: In the usual course of events, people did not examine their windshields that closely. The holes, pits and dings turned out to be a result of normal wear and tear, which few had noticed until it was drawn to their attention.
The antidote to such fears, psychologists say, is straightforward information from trustworthy sources.
"Trustworthiness has two elements," said Dr. Baruch Fischhoff, a psychologist in Carnegie Mellon's department of social and decision sciences. "One is honesty and the other is competence."
Attempts by the authorities to use persuasion often fall flat, Dr. Fischhoff said, because "if people feel they have to peel away the agenda of the communicator in order to understand the content of the message, that's debilitating." 
"Give me the facts in a comprehensible way, and leave it to me to decide what's right for me," he said. 
Yet what psychologists can say with some certainty is that, if no further attacks occur in the near future, people's fears are likely to fade quickly -- even faster than the fearful themselves would predict.
Studies suggest, Dr. Gilbert said, that "people underestimate their resilience and adaptiveness."
"We have remarkable both psychological and physiological mechanisms to adapt to change," he said. "I guarantee you that in six months whatever New Yorkers are feeling will seem pretty normal to them, even if it is not exactly what they were feeling before."

HEADLINE: Front Row 

BYLINE:  By Guy Trebay

 BODY:
High-Flying Models Grounded
 Aside from pilots and media moguls, few people log more air miles than fashion models. Any notion of these beautiful minicorporations whiling away their hours on tropical beaches or in the makeup chair at photo studios, while not exactly misguided, hardly indicates the whole picture. "It's a plane-a-day business," said Frances Grill, the owner of Click Model Management. The reality is that without frequent flying, she said, "a girl can't have a full career." 
 It is particularly crucial for models to be in motion during the weeks that constitute the collections' seasons. Throughout these brief cycles, the established names draw huge salaries, working as many as seven catwalks a day in New York, London, Milan and Paris at fees that can approach $10,000 a show. For agencies, show season is a crucial time, both for product testing and the bottom line. For newcomers, it's the best way to begin a career. 
Now, all that has changed. "Girls are not wanting to fly right now," Ms. Grill said. "Those who are, are going with a lot of trepidation." 
Many big-name models, among them Maggie Rizer, Mini Anden, Erin O'Connor and Karolina Kurkova, had already headed to Europe before the World Trade Center attack, and some are based in Europe anyway. Consequently, the runways in Milan have not exactly been underpopulated. But those women who had not made the trip to Europe early, said Conor Kennedy, an agent at Elite, "just fled."
An informal survey of modeling agencies in New York suggests that scores of young models kept flying after Sept. 11, but not to the fashion capitals of the world. Most headed straight home. Jennie Knight, one of Click's promising prospects, was booked for a number of European catwalks and editorial features. Immediately after the attack, Ms. Knight returned to her family in Utah. Cristine Fontanari, a coltish Brazilian blonde, who had been optioned for the new Jil Sander advertising campaign, joined a phalanx of South American models who chose to wait things out in the relative tranquillity of another hemisphere. 
"It's difficult enough saying to a girl's parents, we'll be transplanting your daughter from her small town and flying her halfway around the world," Chris Gay, an agent at Next, said. "When something like this happens, it's better to go home and regroup." 
Since models in a sense are the fashion industry's mine canaries, the long-term effects on the industry of horrific circumstance and an enfeebled economy can be read in their fates. The biggest impact on the New York economy, Mr. Gay said, "is that a lot of American buyers didn't go to the shows." Instead, many collections will be flown to New York and shown in scaled-down private presentations that generate far fewer jobs. Obviously, rescheduled shows and smaller casts "mean less income for agencies," said Mr. Kennedy of Ford. "We're all aware that this economy is going to be a little rough." 

A Watch Cools Down
In the fictive delirium that is fashion hype, the consumer who wears a TechnoMarine watch goes rock climbing in remote locations but relishes the view of busy streets from a glamorous New York pied-a-terre; goes scuba diving and white-water rafting "in uncharted waters," but never passes up the opportunity to have a cocktail party by the pool at his Hamptons beach house; enjoys camping out and cooking food over an open fire, yet dines in "decadent" French restaurants. "You are impossible to categorize," goes the accompanying claim, yet it's obvious that the person being described is a dinosaur.
If there is anything that recent events rendered outmoded it is excess. And few luxury signifiers fit the bill more neatly than TechnoMarine. Introduced in 1997 by Franck Dubarry, a former ad man and Club Med director, the watches wedded gel band dive-watch features with diamond-encrusted dials. (Think Ivana Trump meets Swatch.) And the sticker price made the Rolex Submariner, perennial timekeeping toy of choice among Wall Street wizards, look like a steal. To say that TechnoMarine took off is understatement. First year sales of $700,000 rocketed to $23 million last year. Among fashionistas, few items were both hotter and cooler.
But suddenly, $16,000 diamond pave watches designed for ogling clown fish seem more than showy. Interpreting the new economy in its own way, perhaps, TechnoMarine has introduced a bargain line. TechnoSport ($250 to $350) is "lower priced," said a spokeswoman. "No diamonds, more urban," and more suitable "for this point in time."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Green's First Shot for the Runoff

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
 Mark Green, the public advocate, released a 30-second ad called "Faces" yesterday, his first television commercial of the runoff campaign for the Democratic mayoral nomination. 

PRODUCER -- Trippi, McMahon & Squier

ON THE SCREEN -- Close-ups of sad and frightened-looking children, shot in black and white, fade in and out. When the announcer first mentions his name, Mr. Green is shown in color, addressing a classroom, in front of a teacher's desk and an American flag. Then he is shown meeting with adults, presumably parents. The phrases "Reduce Class Size," "Improve Safety and Security" and "Pay Teachers Better" appear on the screen. Mr. Green is shown high-fiving a boy in a park. In the next shot, in black-and-white, he is framed by a row of columns. The New York Times editorial endorsing him in the primary is shown, with the words "toughness," "courage" and "leadership" highlighted. A shot of Mr. Green talking to people on a stoop follows. Finally the camera shows two girls in a classroom, in color. One looks clear-eyed and confident, the other smiles.

THE SCRIPT -- The narrator, a woman, says: "We've seen fear in their faces, tears in their eyes. And now, they need us more than ever. Not just to rebuild our city's economy, but to improve our public schools. Mark Green's education plan will reduce class size, improve safety and security and pay teachers better. Mark Green, the only Democrat for mayor endorsed by The New York Times for his 'courage,' 'toughness' and 'leadership.' Mark Green, rebuilding our city, keeping them safe, improving their schools."

ACCURACY -- Mr. Green has repeatedly called for smaller classes, especially from kindergarten through third grade, which he says should be limited to 20 students. Improved school safety has not been one of his major campaign themes up to now, but he has proposed tougher laws against assaulting teachers and "zero tolerance" for juvenile crime. Mr. Green has called for reducing the gap between the salaries of teachers in New York City and the suburbs but has not said by how much. (His opponent, Fernando Ferrer, has called for raising teacher salaries by 30 percent.) The editorial endorsement in The Times said that Mr. Green had "always had political courage" and that he "scores high" on the qualities of leadership and toughness.

SCORECARD -- The ad manages to invoke the attack on the World Trade Center without depicting it or even mentioning it. "Rebuilding our city" is certainly a new tag line. By using the images of frightened and sad children, the ad gives Mr. Green a chance to highlight the two sides of his campaign: rebuilding the city in the aftermath of the attacks, but also concentrating on what he calls "home-front issues," like education. And it cannot hurt to use the words "safety" and "security," even in the context of an education plan.
 MICHAEL COOPER

HEADLINE: Defenses in Alaska 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Alaska Antimissile Site: Too Close for Russians' Comfort?" (news article, Sept. 26):
 Since Sept. 11, grass-roots organizations in Alaska have stepped up their opposition to the unproved and now outmoded multi-billion-dollar missile defense site in Alaska, even as Congress has muted its criticism and increased appropriations. 
 Alaskans and defense contractors must put aside short-term opportunism in the interest of national defense and the Russian alliance.
The billions requested for missile defense against rogue nations could be better spent to defend Alaska's oil fields and pipeline, to reduce the Russian nuclear stockpile and to buy up unemployed Soviet expertise now available to terrorists. 

STEPHEN CONN
Executive Director, Alaska Public
Interest Research Group
Anchorage, Sept. 26, 2001

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion; 
Business as Usual, but Not Quite, on the Runway in Milan

BYLINE:  By CATHY HORYN

DATELINE: MILAN, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
In almost any circumstance, fashion has trouble dealing with reality. How often do you see clothes in a magazine that would look ridiculous in real life? How many times have you read that a $600 handbag is "well priced"? Fashion editors have a genius for accommodating extremes, and most of the time the public is happy to play along in the deception.
 But since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, retail spending has stalled, the economy is weakening and the designers presenting their collections for next spring seemed to be suddenly stranded in the breech. They want to go forward -- "appropriately and positively!" as a video message at the Versus show on Saturday perkily announced -- but how to do that? And what can appropriate possibly mean to a world that last applied that word to the wearing of garden party hats after Labor Day? 
 For Donatella Versace it meant, simply, business as usual: girlie skirts and graffiti prints parading past giddy celebrities. On Tuesday, she's giving a dinner for the newlyweds Jennifer Lopez and Cris Judd at her Lake Como house. 
"There will be a reaction to what happened in New York, but I don't think designers will do things differently," said Sarah Lerfel of the Paris boutique Colette, outside the Prada show on Friday. "You never see politics in clothes." She nodded toward the crowd. "Fashion is sometimes on another planet," she said. "It's superficial. I look around, I see the same people, in black. Nothing has changed."
Yet financially, fashion executives are bracing for a storm. "Things are going to be very difficult," said Domenico De Sole, chief executive of Gucci. "Our sales are very strong in Europe, Asia is holding and New York is obviously hurting. My strategy is simple. We stay the course and watch expenses." Both he and Luigi Maramotti, president of Max Mara, said the economic fallout could last well into the new year.
"A lot will be decided in the next 12 months," Mr. Maramotti said. 
Companies like Gucci and Max Mara, with their own stores and no-frills management style, may be better fixed than others. And as Mr. Maramotti said after the Max Mara show, with its romantic peasant blouses, sashed dresses in men's-wear fabrics and crisp Sergeant Pepper jackets, "we make nice clothes for real people."
As Italy is the source for much of the fashion merchandise around the world -- more than the United States and France -- the economy added to the sober mood here. Though the Milanese are out shopping in droves, restaurants and hotels are less crowded, and the absence of American retailers has been conspicuous as well as criticized.
"I think they should have come," Mr. De Sole said. Giorgio Armani, who was in New York during the attacks, agreed. "They had a psychological reaction that was normal," he said, "but from a professional point of view, I'm here, they should be here." At a cost of about $12,000, he arranged for satellite links today with Tokyo and New York to transmit his show live to retailers. And Gucci and Prada plan to bring their spring collections to New York this month.
That no single collection has stood out has more to do with shifting fashion tastes than the ongoing crisis, though everybody seems absorbed in it. Tom Ford said before his Gucci show on Saturday that he had made some changes in his presentation, like lowering the runway, taking out many black outfits and switching to more romantic music. "I think excess and frivolity had already started to wear thin," he said. 
So out goes the louche and in comes the laid-back. Mr. Ford's best looks came early in the show: slouchy pants in ivory cotton canvas worn with shrugging T-shirts or loose manila suede jackets tied straitjacket-style in the front. While the models occasionally looked swallowed up by the clothes -- the paper-bagged pants and skirts, low-belted trench coats and silky pajama pants with heart-shaped cutouts -- the collection had a sweet tomboy mood redolent of the 1970's. Annie Hall if she had been liberated from Woody Allen.
Curiously, though, there must be something in the uneasy air that is spawning a certain beddy-byeness. One of Mr. Ford's more perversely cozy numbers was a union suit, with drooping crotch, and those slightly distressed and flaring suede toppers did suggest . . . mmm . . . a bed jacket. Miuccia Prada was of a similar mind the night before, showing piped cotton shirts based, she said afterward, on men's pajama tops.
Ms. Prada's collection was not exactly a snore, but neither was it a wake-up call to a new direction. One of her strengths is to propose seemingly banal styles, like a thin, sleeveless gray pullover or a prissy knee-length skirt, and treat them both casually and elegantly. The knit vest appeared over clinging ivory T-shirts and shells in softened lame or silvery damask patterns, some drizzled down the front with a crushed ruffle.
But with dress looks that hinted of Chanel, pj's that brought to mind Charvet, and lame that dipped into Charo country, Ms. Prada got herself into a thematic jam. Backstage, lighting a postshow Marlboro, she said she had spent 10 years developing the lame and searching for the right approach to it. Alas, this time her brainwork showed.
The trouble with Mr. Armani -- sometimes, just sometimes -- is that he takes himself too seriously for a guy who, by now, knows every trick in the book. He knows about taste, simplicity and how to cut a jacket to the bone. The best was a brown-checked number with razor-sharp shoulders and a slightly pinched waist that practically heehaws at the rest of the tailoring here.
But he needs to let go of some of his ideals. The world has been going progressively casual for the last decade, and while Mr. Armani led the revolution in softer clothes, the real trick now is to make even the elegant look casual. His version of low-slung pants has the waistband folded down, in two small flaps, below the navel -- a neither-here-nor-there gesture. A slight nautical theme ran through the day clothes, with familiar Chinese embellishments for night.
Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce put on a good show that in its boy-friendliness suggested that they, too, were taking a pause. Boned black jackets came out over low trousers or flounced skirts. There were pants in eccentric swirls of suede, and loose chiffon tops in fresh shades of delphinium and rose. 
The Marni show today was a bolt out of the blue -- delphinium and azure, mixed with beach hues and beatnik satchels adorned with trinkets. Everything about the collection was cheerful and uncomplicated, from faded ticking-striped coats to flaring sundresses slung with tough leather belts.
Is Jil Sander's minimalism too elusive for its designer, Milan Vukmirovic? He showed a lighter hand this season, with jersey chemises and simple skirt and blouse combos, but he can't finesse the details that lift plain luxury from the J. Crew variety. 
In the notes to his show on Sunday, Gianfranco Ferre said he had let himself "succumb" to the mysteries of India, as if he were helpless to avoid sausage-tight pants, metallic fretwork tops and tutu leather. But Mr. Ferre fell off the reality wagon years ago and hasn't been able to get back up.
What remains to be seen is how all these clothes will be played in magazines and advertisements in a world suddenly facing a different reality. Will Gucci have to back off from its aggressive ads? "I don't know," Mr. De Sole said. "I don't know." Some of the current ads, notably Versace's, with their evocation of Stepford wives, were already behind the curve. As one editor said: "She's rich. We know it. So what's next?"
"We've already gone too far," said Franca Sozzani, the editor of Italian Vogue. "But what I don't want to give up is the dream. Because women don't buy the clothes. They buy what they think they will become in the clothes."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
An agency giant is expected to warn of lower profits, and analysts darken their outlook.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
FURTHER underlining the deteriorating condition of the advertising economy, one of the world's largest agency companies is expected to warn investors today that profits will not meet expectations, while several analysts further reduced their estimates for ad spending this year and next.
 "We're at the height of uncertainty," said one of those analysts, Lauren Rich Fine, who follows agencies and media companies for Merrill Lynch. "Companies are trying not to make decisions." 
 Ms. Fine now estimates that ad spending in 2001 will decline 3.1 percent from 2000, compared with her previous estimate, made 11 days before the terrorist attacks, that ad spending this year would decline 2.6 percent from last year. 
Ms. Fine is for the first time predicting a decline in 2002 from 2001, of 0.8 percent. Her previous estimate called for ad spending to grow next year by 1.7 percent.
"We're going into a recession, and people do cut back," Ms. Fine said. "Advertising goes down as the economy goes down."
Another analyst who reduced estimates for 2001 and 2002 is Michael J. Russell Jr. at Morgan Stanley.
"It's just a waiting game," Mr. Russell said. "We're looking for a full year of negative numbers, until the third quarter of 2002."
Mr. Russell's revised estimate for 2001 calls for a decline in ad spending of 9.1 percent from 2000, compared with his previous forecast for a 7.4 percent drop. For 2002, he now predicts a scant increase of 0.2 percent from 2001 rather than the rise of 3.4 percent he had previously forecast.
One reason the analysts reduced their estimates was the cutbacks in spending for television commercials and newspaper ads after the terrorist attacks, as the news media reduced or eliminated advertising to increase coverage.
According to CMR, a company that tracks ad spending, national broadcast and cable television networks and local TV stations lost $313.2 million in revenue from Sept. 11 through Sept. 15.
"Most people think it will take a little while until the spending comes back," said David Peeler, president and chief executive at CMR in New York, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres. "We'll be closely looking over the next couple of weeks to see if there's an increase, but it's too soon to tell."
There were losses of ad revenue at 14 local and national newspapers, too, for Sept. 12 through Sept. 14, Mr. Peeler said, but those were generally less than the losses suffered by their TV counterparts.
Turning to the profit warning, it is expected to come from Havas Advertising in Paris, the world's fifth-largest agency company in billings, at $26.3 billion, and revenue, at $2.8 billion. The warning is to come as Havas reports its financial results for the first half of 2001.
The warning would come four days after another large agency company, the Cordiant Communications Group in London, issued a similar warning. Cordiant unexpectedly notified investors that revenue would decline 5 percent this year because the attacks worsened the outlook for the already weakening economy. Previously, Cordiant executives had forecast a revenue increase of 11 percent for 2001.
Jennifer Gery, a spokeswoman for Havas at Brainerd Communicators in New York, said yesterday that she was unable to obtain comment from executives at Havas about what they planned to announce because they were in a "quiet period" that prevents them from discussing the news before its release.
Mr. Russell at Morgan Stanley said he expected profit warnings from agency companies based in Europe because "Europe is in a later economic cycle" than the United States.
"We already knew in this market that this would be a difficult year," he added. "This year has now gotten more difficult for them."
Wherever agency companies are based, Mr. Russell said, "they are going to have a problem" if they have "a lot of exposure to technology, financial services and travel," that is, many clients in problematic categories.
"The stock market is looking for a 1950's agency, with exposure just to the basic goods," he added, staples like packaged foods, soft drinks and paper products.
Ms. Fine said that for all the downward revisions she had made recently in her forecasts, "I'm done -- I hope, I hope, I hope."
"People will have to go back to building brands," she added. "You can start to bake in some recovery in '03."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE TREASURY SECRETARY; 
Ad-Libbing His Way Into Trouble

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
Shortly after the terrorist attacks, the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, summoned reporters to the Treasury Department's diplomatic reception room to describe how the strikes had hurt the economy and what the administration would do to limit the damage.
 Although Mr. O'Neill often freely ruminates about the economy, taxes, and just about everything else, this time he read a brief, prepared statement word for word, then turned to leave without answering questions. A Treasury official later explained that the White House had demanded a unified stance on the economy at a delicate moment. 
 Mr. O'Neill, who developed a reputation for speaking his mind and straying beyond the administration's line on numerous issues, has found himself playing a less central role in economic policy making than his recent predecessors. Not only has he had his leash shortened, but several other administration officials have also encroached on Treasury's turf. While the White House says that the Treasury secretary is still an integral part of the administration's economic brain trust, officials are also urging Mr. O'Neill to become more of a team player. "The time has come," one White House official said, "to get on and get along." 
That order could prove difficult for the voluble and occasionally irritable Mr. O'Neill. He set out to shatter traditions and overthrow established policies that he felt had lost touch with the reality he knew as the chief executive of Alcoa, the aluminum giant. In the process, he has tweaked fellow administration officials and senior Republicans as much as Democrats, and raised doubts among many critics whether he has the weight to manage the tottering economy.
Mr. O'Neill promised when nominated to the post 10 months ago that "his days as a maverick are over." They had actually just begun. He has questioned the Clinton-era mantra of supporting a "strong dollar," disputed the administration's line that long-term tax cuts could spur the economy out of its slowdown, and pooh-poohed bailouts for emerging markets -- though he did not always articulate an alternative.
Under pressure to instill confidence after the terrorist attacks, Mr. O'Neill, in the eyes of many critics, ad-libbed his way into trouble. Asked if the economy was headed for recession, he told a television interviewer, simply, "I don't think so." Most private analysts agree with the chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, who last week called an American recession a "done deal."
A commentary in The Wall Street Journal last week accused Mr. O'Neill of squandering his credibility and called his prediction that the stock market could be approaching prior highs within 12 or 18 months a "burst of irrational exuberance."
Mr. O'Neill acknowledges that he has taken hits for focusing on things that are "below the threshold" of what many people consider the proper duties of the administration's economic chief, like improving worker safety at the Treasury Department and converting the ornate 19th-century offices into corporate-style open cubicles.
Even when he is right -- and supporters say the shibboleths he disdains are indeed often wrong or outdated -- he has a tendency to speak out before the administration is prepared to turn his words into policy. That habit has come under fire at a time when volatile markets and the shaky economy are seen as needing a steady hand, not an iconoclast.
"He was the chief executive of a major corporation, captain of the ship, and he still has that demeanor," said Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee. "He should be acting more like a chief financial officer."
Mr. O'Neill's freelancing sometimes pays off, Mr. Grassley added. The Treasury secretary conspicuously questioned whether the administration's original tax-cut plan gave enough short-term kick to the economy, and he pushed the idea of immediate tax rebates on a reluctant White House. He publicly entertained the idea of eliminating taxes on corporations before the president gave the go-ahead, but now has been joined by other administration officials in the push to reduce such taxes as part of any new stimulus package.
"We all thought he was crazy to be going on like that," Mr. Grassley said. "It looks pretty smart now."
While there are no signs of a rift between Mr. Bush and Mr. O'Neill, the president has, contrary to his last few predecessors, dispersed responsibility for economic policy broadly. After the Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. Bush gave Mr. O'Neill the high-profile duty of tracking down the financial assets of Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network.
But Josh Bolten, a deputy White House chief of staff, was tapped by Mr. Bush to head a new "domestic consequences group" to coordinate the administration's efforts to counter the economic effects of the terrorist strikes. Meanwhile, Lawrence B. Lindsey, the president's top economic adviser in the White House, and Donald L. Evans, the commerce secretary, have pivotal roles planning tax cuts and coordinating the airline bailout, say Republicans who help the administration plot economic strategy.
Mr. O'Neill also does not appear to have had a decisive role in working out the terms of a stimulus package with Congress. The week following the attacks, lawmakers held a high-level, closed-door session to discuss the stimulus with Mr. Lindsey; Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman; and Robert E. Rubin, Treasury secretary under President Clinton. Mr. O'Neill was not invited to attend.
Treasury officials said Mr. O'Neill was tied up in a National Security Council meeting that day and that he has had many opportunities to consult with Congressional leaders about stimulus measures since then.
Though Mr. O'Neill had appeared regularly in public since the attack, some administration officials have privately questioned his effectiveness, say prominent Republicans who advise the administration on economic issues.
These critics say he sounded glib about the strength of the economy at a time when he should have worked to reassure rattled investors. The performance, they say, contrasted unfavorably with the administration's national security team. While White House officials dismiss talk of replacing him during a crisis environment, some people close to the administration said frustration with his performance was mounting.
"He's the only cabinet member who hasn't really stepped into the national dialogue in a persuasive way," one influential Republican said. "At the White House, disappointment is widespread."
Mr. O'Neill bemoans such sniping as the product of Washington's "layers of cynicism." The 65-year-old secretary is no political naif. He had an earlier stint in government when he served as a top budget official in the Ford administration. But he projects a Mr. Smith-goes-to-Washington sense of befuddlement, arguing that the city's calcified culture has no place for outsiders who challenge received wisdom.
"I've been disappointed that there doesn't seem to be a larger clientele, including in the media, for people who tell the truth," he said in an interview last week. "When I do something and it's off the beaten path, people say, 'Oh, my God, this is not the way we play the game.' "
The president, Mr. O'Neill said, is not among the cynics. Because the Treasury secretary has come under criticism, including from some conservative commentators, Mr. O'Neill says he has made a point of checking in with his boss. The president has reiterated that he likes advisers with independent ideas, not "pussycats who spout the party line," Mr. O'Neill said.
"If I thought I was reducing the president's effectiveness I would leave tomorrow," he said.
Supporters in Congress and the administration argue that his no-nonsense approach is valuable. Like Mr. Greenspan, they say, he prefers facts to theory. When there are not enough facts, he goes out of his way to find them.
During the post-attack crisis, for example, he had a private breakfast in New York with the chief executives of American Express, Bethlehem Steel and several other members of the Business Roundtable, a lobbying group. Mr. O'Neill asked them to come armed with data. He scribbled copious notes on the fine points, like week-by-week changes in credit card use, to develop a nuanced picture of the economy.
Like the president, Mr. O'Neill cultivates an image as a Washington outsider. But the Treasury secretary is arguably more of a purist. He does not have a dedicated speech writer, for example, in contrast to his most recent predecessor, Lawrence H. Summers, who had two.
Seemingly oblivious to how his words are perceived, Mr. O'Neill sometimes dives into analysis of subtle policy details on hot topics of the moment. He did that with the president's No. 1 priority early in his term, tax cutting, casting doubt on Mr. Bush's own contention that reducing income tax rates would revive the slowing economy.
Though he has an array of flat-screen market monitors behind his desk, Mr. O'Neill has at times ignored the power his words have to send traders scurrying to their terminals.
He has had difficulty disguising his disdain for the "strong dollar" policy of the Clinton years, preferring to let the market dictate currency values. But when on a visit to Europe he casually hinted that he had doubts about the old talk, the value of the dollar on global currency markets sank sharply. That forced a retraction of his comment and an angry retort that he would "rent Yankee Stadium" if he intended to effect any change in dollar policy.
While many economists agree with his desire to stop bailing out developing countries, some have scolded him for seeking to impose a new way of doing things overnight.
Though he has come under some pressure lately, Mr. O'Neill shows few signs of becoming more like the political pussycat he disdains.
When a friend asked him recently whether his habit of ruminating provocatively would get him in trouble, Mr. O'Neill was characteristically blunt.
"The president hasn't told me to shut up yet," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
The dollar proves to be surprisingly resilient in the wake of the attacks.

BYLINE:  By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
THE dollar, a symbol of America's financial strength, has been surprisingly resilient in the wake of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
 Although the dollar was weakening before the attack -- and faces more downward pressure in the months ahead -- it has been remarkably stable as investors around the world have considered the new political and military uncertainties and the threat of a global economic slowdown. 
 Measured on a trade-weighted basis, the dollar is virtually unchanged since the attacks. While it has fallen 2.1 percent against the euro, the dollar has been rising against the Canadian dollar, the Mexican peso, the Australian dollar and emerging-market currencies, including the Brazilian real.
"I think its pretty impressive the way the dollar has held up so far," said Neil M. Soss, chief United States economist at Credit Suisse First Boston. 
The dollar had risen almost 30 percent against the world's major currencies in the last six years and was the strongest it had been since early 1986 before beginning to slide this summer. Even with the 16 percent drop against the euro some analysts are predicting -- including a 10 percent fall after Sept. 11 -- the dollar would still be up more than 16 percent since the euro's debut in 1999.
A moderate decline in the dollar is not all negative. The dollar normally falls in a recession and that helps in the healing process. American exports like heavy machinery become relatively cheaper and thus more attractive abroad, while products aimed at the domestic market, like cars, become more competitive against imports that cost more.
Analysts are not expecting a precipitous plunge by the dollar that would make other financial markets unstable and, possibly, restrict the Federal Reserve's options on cutting interest rates. 
"There is a pace of decline that can reduce the pressure on the American export market but not restrain policy makers," said Robert Sinche, head of global currency strategy at Citigroup.
This all means that the dollar's major decline is expected to be against the euro, which is now the currency of 12 European nations. Several analysts are predicting that the dollar will fall to parity -- the euro equaling $1 -- over the next 12 months. The dollar fell 0.8 percent yesterday as the value of the euro rose to 91.70 United States cents.
But a big decline against the world's other major currency, the Japanese yen, is much less likely, given the shaky Japanese economy and financial system. Michael Rosenberg, head of global foreign exchange research at Deutsche Bank, projects that the dollar will rise about 4 percent against the yen in the next six months.
In fact, the Japanese government is working to weaken its own currency to try to ward off a recession by making its exporters more competitive. The Bank of Japan has sold yen and bought dollars -- and euros -- seven times in the last two weeks, pushing the value of the dollar higher. In the first eight days after the attack, the dollar dropped 3.9 percent against the yen. Now it is just 0.6 percent below where it was on Sept. 10.
"The dollar ought to decline in this environment," said Larry Kantor, global head of foreign exchange strategy at J. P. Morgan. "But when you do the math, it is hard to get much out of it."
The main reason the dollar has been resilient is that many of the United States' other major trading partners, in addition to Japan, are also suffering economically, in part because of their dependence on trade with America.
The Canadian dollar usually has not done well when the United States economy is in trouble and has been in a general decline against the American dollar since the early 1990's. Mexico, a major oil producer, could be hurt by the sharp drop in oil prices, which have fallen 15.4 percent since the attack. Australia depends on the export of wheat, coal and many other commodities whose prices have also fallen recently because of the threat of a global recession.
Wall Street's performance also made sticking with the dollar more palatable. While American stocks were hit hard, especially after the market reopened after being closed four days, they did not do any worse than stocks in Europe or elsewhere.
Also helping the dollar is the fact that the negative forecasts of a sharp economic decline are being combined, currently, with the expectation of a brisk recovery next year, in part because of aggressive interest rates cuts by the Federal Reserve, around $100 billion in new government spending and the possibility of another tax cut.
"If the recession and recovery unfold as we anticipate, the United States will be moving into a growth phase with low unemployment, very low inflation and high rates of investment," said John Lipsky, chief economist at J. P. Morgan Chase. "It is that favorable prospect that continues to limit the weakness of the dollar."
Of course, he added, "there are developments that could call that outlook into question."
The expected plunge into a recession, which makes the Unites States less attractive to foreign investors, along with the prospect of military action by the United States and the fear of what terrorists might do next, means the dollar will fall further for a while.
"I would not rush out and buy the dollar now," said Jeremy Fand, global head of foreign exchange strategy at UBS Warburg. "I still think there is risk for the dollar in the near term."
Mr. Soss of Credit Suisse First Boston also argues that the dollar will be weakened by a slowdown in American productivity as a result of the terrorist attack. This is because the enhanced security the country needs will slow the movement of goods and people.
The fall in stocks was discouraging foreign investors before Sept. 11. Now the decline in interest rates, led by the Fed's half-point cut when the stock market reopened on Sept. 17, is making fixed income less attractive. In just the last four weeks, the difference between the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note and Germany's 10-year security has gone from 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, in favor of the Treasury to 23 basis points in favor of Germany. And the Fed is expected to cut short-term interest rates when policy makers meet today.
Even a slowdown in the inflow of foreign investment will weaken the dollar, analysts say. This is because the United States has a $106.5 billion current account deficit that depends on foreign flows to cover it.
There were signs before the attack that important foreign flows were slowing.
In the second quarter, according to the latest data, foreign direct investment, which includes mergers and acquisitions, totaled $31.6 billion, down from an average of $37.2 billion in the previous four quarters. Flows into stocks slowed to $35 billion from $41.7 billion in the previous quarter, according to a breakdown by Citigroup.
Flows into bonds had not slowed by the second quarter, but Mr. Sinche of Citibank said "there is not a lot of reason to think that the fixed-income inflow that held up so well at the beginning of the year will do as well now."
And recessionary forces alone, like the slowing of trade, will push the dollar lower.
In the 1990-1991 recession, the trade-weighted dollar, adjusted for inflation, dropped 4.9 percent. It fell 6 percent in the 1973-1975 recession, which was the last time there was a concurrent decline of the world's major economies.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
Spending Edges Up, but Factory Index Drops

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
Consumer spending rose modestly in August as tax rebate checks put more money in shoppers' pockets, the government reported today.
 For the second consecutive month, spending rose 0.2 percent, the Commerce Department said. 
Disposable incomes -- the amount of income left after taxes -- also rose for a second month, reflecting the effect of tax rebate checks and lower tax rates. 
 In August, disposable incomes increased 1.9 percent, the biggest rise since December 1993, after a 1.7 percent rise in July. Excluding the tax changes, disposable incomes rose 0.3 percent in July and August.
The income and spending figures are not adjusted for inflation.
Personal incomes, which include wages, interest and government benefits, were unchanged in August after rising by 0.5 percent in July, reflecting the weakened state of the nation's labor market. The flat reading was the weakest income growth since January 1994. 
Before the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, analysts were optimistic that consumers -- whose spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity -- would continue to spend in coming months and keep the economy afloat.
Now most economists say the economy will fall into recession this year. In the wake of the attacks, consumer confidence has plunged, layoffs have jumped and billions of dollars in business have been lost.
Manufacturers, hardest hit by the ailing economy, foundered in September for the 14th consecutive month. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of business activity fell to 47 from 47.9 in August. An index above 50 signifies growth in manufacturing and below 50 indicates contraction.
Despite low interest rates, the slumping economy made builders more cautious. Construction activity fell 1.1 percent in August, after falling 0.8 percent in July, the Commerce Department said.

HEADLINE: 28,000 State Workers Strike in Minnesota, Drawing Fire 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
Nearly 28,000 Minnesota state employees walked off the job today in a demand for higher pay, drawing criticism from many Minnesotans, who said the strikers were acting selfishly at a time of national crisis.
 Union leaders defended the walkout, saying that with national leaders urging Americans to return to their normal lives, the strikers, who have been without a contract since early summer, were doing nothing more than what they had threatened to do long before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. 
 "On one hand we're told it's unpatriotic," said Jan Carlson, a regional director of the Minnesota Association of Professional Employees, which represents about 10,500 of the strikers. "But on the other hand people say let's return to normal and continue with our life, and strikes have long been a part of American life." 
The strike, one of the nation's largest in decades involving public employees, pits two powerful unions against Minnesota's usually outspoken governor, Jesse Ventura, who has adopted a low profile in this dispute.
The walkout began at 6 a.m. and immediately had a broad effect. Driving tests and birth registrations were delayed. The Minnesota Zoo was closed. The Minnesota National Guard deployed 920 of its members to help operate 120 state-run health care centers, whose social workers, psychologists, nurses' aides, food workers and janitors were among the strikers.
Many Minnesotans said they could not imagine a worse time for a strike, coming as it does when the nation is gearing up to battle terrorists, the economy is reeling, and any number of states, including this one, are struggling with deteriorating budgets.
"I think it's kind of inappropriate right now, because suddenly there are so many people out of work around the nation and so many people are hurting from Sept. 11," said Betty Hopewood, an accounts specialist at US Bank in downtown St. Paul. "There's so much need in other places right now. These state employees are paid pretty well."
The strike is "a lot," Ms. Hopewood said, "considering everything that's going on."
Passing a half-dozen pickets in St. Paul, Kent Nielsen, a police detective in the Minneapolis suburb of Brooklyn Park, said: "I personally don't think there is a need to strike. I don't think the distance between the two sides is far enough to warrant a strike."
But at a rally this morning near the stately, domed Minnesota Capitol here, union leaders, joined by hundreds of workers, maintained that the strike was justified. In past years, they noted, they have often accepted raises lower than inflation. Now they want a catch-up raise that is higher than inflation, a demand not met by the state's latest offer, made late Saturday night. 
State officials, predicting a budget shortfall, say they cannot offer more.
The state has offered the Minnesota Association of Professional Employees a one-time 4 percent raise in a two-year contract. It has offered a 3-percent-a-year raise for two years to the other striking union, Council 6 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents about 19,000 state workers, most of them lower-paid than members of the professional employees association. (Some 1,700 members of Council 6 did not strike today; they are state prison guards, forbidden by law to do so.)
In contrast, Council 6 is demanding 5 percent annually for two years, a moderation of the 6.5 percent it sought until the weekend. The average yearly pay for members of Council 6 is about $31,000, and for members of the professional employees association $47,000.
The unions held demonstrations today in St. Paul, Duluth, Rochester, Brainerd, Mankato, St. Cloud and Moorhead. At the rally at the Capitol here this morning, members sang "God Bless America" and chanted: "Who does the work? We do. Are we patriotic? Yes." 
Lorita Powell, a customer service worker in the Department of Revenue, said she was insulted by the state's position.
"For the past three or four years," Ms. Powell said, "the state supposedly had a surplus and gave out huge amounts in rebate checks to the taxpayers. The past few years our raises were below inflation, and now they say they don't have enough money to even reach inflation."
Many strikers ridiculed Governor Ventura, accusing him of dodging the dispute.
Mr. Ventura issued a statement on Sunday saying he had sought to reach a fair settlement.
"The fact is," he said, "even with our last offer, we would have had to cut services and employees to retain a structurally balanced budget."
"I have a responsibility to the public to stay within the budget passed by the Legislature," the governor said, "and I will. The last thing I would do is put the State of Minnesota in fiscal jeopardy." 
Defending their offer, state officials noted that in addition to across-the-board raises, about half the unionized employees had received modest annual "step" raises that were pegged to increases in experience on the job. But many strikers complained that a state effort to change their health coverage would increase their co-payments and prescription-drug outlays in a way that would wipe out much of any raise.
The strike is having its greatest impact on several state-run homes for veterans, six large campuses for addicts and the mentally ill, and about 100 community-based homes for the retarded. Hundreds of National Guard troops worked closely with doctors, nurses and managers today to keep those operations running. 
"We've had only one day of strike, but so far we've been able to maintain our core treatment services," said Elaine Timmer, assistant commissioner in the Department of Human Services.
Many union members predicted a long strike, remembering that their last one, in 1981, continued for 22 days.
State and union officials said it was too early to tell how many workers had crossed picket lines.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Striking state employees rallied yesterday at the Minnesota Capitol in St. Paul. Their leaders dismissed accusations of selfishness amid crisis. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Official in Election Battle Turns Eyes to Florida Race 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state who became a household name for her role in the presidential recount last year, is expected to announce on Tuesday that she will run for Congress next year.
 Adam Goodman, a veteran media consultant who had helped chart Ms. Harris's rapid ascent in the Republican Party, said today that she would issue a morning news release announcing her intentions. 
 "She is going to issue a statement that has consequences about her political future," Mr. Goodman said. 
Officials from the state's Republican and Democratic Parties have said that Ms. Harris has been putting together a campaign team in recent months and that they expected the announcement on Tuesday.
Ms. Harris, 44, is expected to run in the 13th District, a Republican stronghold around Sarasota. The seat is held by Representative Dan Miller, a Republican who has said he will not seek another term.
Republican Party officials predicted that she would easily win the Congressional contest and that the Democrats would have a difficult time finding a serious challenger.
"Certainly if Katherine Harris decides to run for Congress then she will be a congresswoman," said Daryl Duwe, a spokesman for the Republican Party. "She is enormously popular in that district; she is from that area and served that area in the State Senate."
The Democrats say, though, that they will vigorously oppose Ms. Harris in a district in which Mr. Miller twice ran unopposed.
"We're not surprised that she is running, and we do welcome Katherine Harris to the race because very few people will turn out more Democrats to vote," said Tony Welch, a spokesman of the Democratic Party, which so far has not announced a candidate in the district.
The wealthy granddaughter of a Florida citrus baron, Ms. Harris represented Sarasota in the State Senate from 1994 until 1998, when she was elected secretary of state, making her the state's top election official. It was a low-profile position until the presidential election thrust her into the spotlight. Her rulings on absentee ballots and late election returns were criticized as partisan by Democrats but enhanced her standing in the Republican Party.
Mr. Welch said her handling of office computers that were used in the recount was indicative of her mismanagement. In August, Ms. Harris turned over four computer hard drives used to draft correspondence during the presidential race for an inspection by news organizations to determine if any records were destroyed during the election stalemate in Florida last November.
The issue of the hard drive contents stems from an article in The New York Times on July 15 about the handling of overseas absentee ballots in Florida. The article said Republican political consultants, including Mr. Goodman, had orked on computers in the "war room" to help shape post-election instructions on which absentee ballots were valid.
Democrats have also criticized Ms. Harris for her international travel as secretary of state.
"It is a low-profile office," Mr. Welch said, "and it gained the highest profile of any secretary of state in the country by bungling an election and just about everything that followed that." 
Ms. Harris's office declined to comment today about her political intentions or the Democrats' criticism. Shortly after the series appeared in The Times, though, Ms. Harris defended her role in the election, saying she had acted properly and without bias. Although she initially denied access to the computers, she later decided to permit the examination, saying she wanted to assure the public that her office had maintained and released all public records and because of the "historical importance these records hold."
The independent investigation concluded that some information had probably been permanently erased but found no evidence that records had been systematically purged as part of an intentional effort to destroy election documents. 
While Ms. Harris may be an easy target for the Democrats to criticize, she may not be as easy to beat.
She is beloved in parts of the state, including Sarasota, for her work in expanding Florida's involvement in international commerce and as an arts advocate. As a state senator, she headed the commerce and economic development committee.
Just as important, supporters say, she is likely to benefit from a public suddenly united behind President Bush, much in the way his younger brother, Gov. Jeb Bush, is expected to in his re-election bid next year. 
Criticizing Ms. Harris, who was President Bush's Florida campaign manager, for her role in the election will now be significantly less effective, her supporters say.
"That would be a losing strategy," Mr. Duwe said. "People were already tired of hearing about it a long time ago, and post-Sept. 11 they do not want to hear the Democrats talk about allegations of a stolen election."
