HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Share Prices Fall a Bit After a Host of Profit Warnings

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks fell moderately yesterday as investors, still nervous about the scope of the United States military response to the terrorist attacks, were discouraged by more weak economic data and a fresh wave of corporate earnings warnings.
 Companies ranging from MGM Mirage, the entertainment, gambling and hotel company, to Jack in the Box, the fast-food restaurant chain, warned yesterday that they would not meet analysts' earnings estimates for the third quarter. Both said a decrease in consumer spending after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon had hurt their businesses. 
 Stocks dropped from the opening -- dashing hopes that the rally on Friday would carry over -- after economic reports showed that manufacturing continued to contract in September for the 14th consecutive month and that consumer spending grew less than expected in August.
But stocks narrowed their losses in the afternoon, bolstered by biotechnology, drug and airline issues.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 10.73 points, or 0.1 percent, to 8,836.83. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 18.34 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,480.46. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.39 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,038.55.
David Henwood, the chief investment officer at Raymond James & Associates, said the stock market's recent losses and the slowdown in consumer spending were dampening investors' sentiments.
"Coupled with poor corporate news and poor corporate earnings, it's not the best setting to get people excited about jumping in and buying stocks," Mr. Henwood said. "We had thought that you were going to see a turn in the economy in the first half of next year. That's a little more iffy now. It may not be until the second half of next year."
For the most part, trading was cautious yesterday as investors made few moves in advance of today's meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers, who are expected to lower interest rates.
Shares of MGM Mirage fell $1.14, to $15.81, after the company said its third-quarter profit would be substantially lower than the 38 cents a share that analysts had forecast. 
SunGard Data Systems also warned that it would fall short of Wall Street's forecasts, earning 21 to 22 cents a share. Analysts expected more than 25 cents a share. Its shares slipped $2.84, to $20.53.
Jack in the Box was one of the day's biggest decliners, falling $4.99, to $23.01. The fast-food company lowered its forecast for the entire year and said it expected to report earnings of 49 cents a share for the fourth quarter -- down from a previous forecast of 53 to 57 cents a share.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices gained yesterday as a decline in manufacturing in September bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates at a policy meeting today.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 13/32, to 103 22/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.53 percent from 4.59 percent on Friday. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 21/32, to 100. Its yield fell to 5.38 percent from 5.42 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Compaq Misses Sales Goals And Expects Quarterly Loss
Compaq Computer said that it had missed its third-quarter sales goals by as much as 12 percent and would post an operating loss, largely because of a virtual halt to its business after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
 Michael D. Capellas, the chairman and chief executive, cited additional reasons for the shortfall, including fallout from its announced merger with Hewlett-Packard. He insisted that the deal would continue. Page C6. 

Dollar Maintains Its Resilience
The dollar, a symbol of America's financial strength, has been surprisingly resilient in the wake of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Market Place. C12.

Consumer Spending Rises 0.2%
Consumer spending rose 0.2 percent in August as tax rebate checks put more money in shoppers' pockets, the government reported. Personal incomes, which include wages, interest and government benefits, were unchanged in August. A separate report showed that construction activity fell 1.1 percent in August, the biggest drop in 13 months. C8.

Stocks Slide on Economic Data
Stocks fell moderately as investors were discouraged by more weak economic data and a new wave of corporate earnings warnings. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 10.73 points, to 8,836.83. The Nasdaq composite index fell 18.34 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,480.46. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.39 points, to 1,038.55. C13.

Rules Shifting for Air Travel
Since the attacks, every aspect of air travel has come under re-examination -- not just security, but everything from customer service to flight operations. C10.

Thousands Could Lose Insurance
Thousands of people are in danger of losing their health insurance in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, according to consumer advocates and health care agencies. C4.

Reversal on New Accounting Rule
In an abrupt reversal, accounting rule makers have decided that no expenses stemming from the attacks will be classified as extraordinary. But the new rule will encourage companies to tell investors just how badly operations were hurt by the attack. C9.

Mademoiselle to Cease Publication
After struggling to revamp its identity in a depressed advertising environment, Mademoiselle, the 66-year-old magazine for young women, long considered a mainstay of the Conde Nast stable, is closing. It will cease publication with the November issue, which goes on sale next week. The editor in chief, Mandi Norwood, above, and the publisher, Lori Burgess, are leaving the company. C2.

Much of Swissair Seeks Bankruptcy
Swissair took action to revamp itself, including a filing for bankruptcy protection for many of its operations and a sale of control of its regional subsidiary to two large banks. In effect, Swissair will continue as a brand, but not as a company. World Business, Section W.

U.S. Inmates Seek Right to Sue
The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether inmates in a federal prison or detention center run by a private contractor can file suit against the company, accusing it of violating their constitutional rights. A22.

Salon Turns to Subscriptions
The Web magazine Salon, facing lower advertising revenue and increased costs, has decided to make its news and political coverage available only to paying subscribers. C4.

French Company Withholds Fee
SFR, one of France's largest wireless operators, is withholding its initial payment on a new mobile phone license in an attempt to press the government into renegotiating the fees. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Salon Will Start Charging its Web Readers 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
The Web magazine Salon, facing sharply lower advertising revenues and increased costs for gathering news, has decided to make its news and political coverage available only to paying subscribers.
 The goal, said David Talbot, the editor of the six-year-old magazine, is to rely on circulation revenue for half of next year's $7.5 million budget. That goal, an ambitious one by the standard of any magazine, is an indication of the unremittingly sour climate for Web advertising. 
 Another high-profile online site, Steven Brill's Contentville, quit business on Friday, leaving its 15 employees without jobs. In an e-mail message to the staff, Mr. Brill said, "Despite the great work of the Contentville staff and the great support we had from our partners, my idea for Contentville just didn't work." Contentville allowed readers to go to one site to find and purchase articles from a variety of newspapers and magazines, as well as books, dissertations and other sources.
"We're dealing in a very difficult environment, not only for advertising," said Michael A. Kupinski, a media analyst for A. G. Edwards. "Finding subscription-based revenue is going to be a rough go."
Mr. Talbot said in an interview yesterday that he aimed to get 250 to 300 new subscribers daily until the end of the year. Salon charges $30 for a one-year subscription and $50 for two years, he said.
In a message to subscribers, Mr. Talbot wrote: "Some readers have implored Salon to reconsider this decision, pointing to the urgency of the times and the importance of Salon's coverage of world events. But this is precisely why we need our readers' support now. In recent days, Salon has committed substantial resources to covering the war between America and Islamic terrorism." Readers, he added, needed to pitch in.
The online advertising recession, which began nearly a year ago as one dot-com after another closed its doors, led Salon to develop its premium-content division in April. Since then, Mr. Talbot said, he has attracted 15,500 subscribers.
He said that two rounds of financing earlier this year had also brought in about $3.25 million, adding: "We've got enough money to give us a cushion. There's no real crisis looming for Salon." The magazine's stock price closed yesterday at 22 cents a share. It was delisted from the Nasdaq national market earlier this year, but trades on the Nasdaq small cap market.

HEADLINE: United to Cut Business Fares By About Half 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
In the first major fare cuts since the terrorist attacks three weeks ago, United Airlines said yesterday that it was cutting business fares in the United States and Alaska by as much as 50 percent and was eliminating the Saturday-night stay for tickets bought 10 days or three weeks in advance.
 The new fares, which are available through the end of the year and include all holidays, are sure to be matched by the other major carriers, travel agents said last night. 
 "It's a tremendous sale," said Blake Fleetwood, president of Planetarium Travel in Manhattan. "In 20 years there has not been a sale like this." 
But business travelers, while providing the bulk of airline profits, make up only about 8 percent of passengers. "In order to bring the crowds back, they are going to have to cut leisure fares," he said.
Air traffic plunged after the terrorist attacks in which two United jets and two American Airlines jets were hijacked and crashed into the World Trade Center, the Pentagon and a field in Pennsylvania. 
Indeed, American Airlines, the world's largest carrier, reported yesterday that its traffic fell 33.7 percent in September compared with traffic in the month a year earlier even as its capacity was down 22.3 percent. Continental Airlines said its traffic for the month was down 31 percent with an 18.6 percent decrease in capacity. The last two weeks of the month, 50 percent and 54 percent of its seats were filled with paying customers. American is a unit of AMR; United is a unit of UAL. 
Most major airlines need to fly with at least 65 percent of their seats filled to break even. Yet despite mounting losses that persuaded Congress to give the industry $5 billion in cash and $10 billion in loan guarantees, the major airlines were reluctant to cut prices to increase traffic. 
Many airline executives were convinced that the country was so traumatized by the attacks that fare sales would stimulate little traffic and therefore simply deepen their losses. But last week, passengers began to return to the country's airports in greater numbers. 
"We've been waiting for somebody to do something," said Terry Trippler, who tracks airline pricing for the Web site OneTravel.com. "It's like the marketing departments of the airlines left the country. I'm glad it's United who announced it first. They are getting back up, brushing themselves off and getting back at it." 
The new fares trim prices up to 50 percent for tickets bought 21 days in advance and up to 25 percent for tickets bought 10 days in advance. But in both cases travelers are not required to stay over a Saturday, a restriction the airlines use to compel business travelers who want to get home to see their loved ones on the weekend to pay more. 
For example, a round-trip ticket from New York to Los Angeles bought three weeks in advance will now cost $1,174 compared with $2,386. A ticket from New York to Chicago purchased 10 days in advance falls to $1,052 from $1,418.
The new business fares are still much higher than leisure fares, which require a Saturday stay over. But the cuts will go some distance toward reducing the gap between business and holiday fares, which ballooned during the economic boom in the last half of the 1990's. 
"This is a huge discount," Mr. Fleetwood said. "What it is doing is bringing some rationality back into the fare structure."
Even before Sept. 11, business travel had slowed drastically, creating economic agita for many carriers. "The airlines have got to get the briefcases back on the planes," Mr. Trippler said. "This could help them in the fourth quarter."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
World Bank Says Poor Nations Will Suffer Worst Economic Toll

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
Though the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks will very likely take a heavy toll on the economies of the United States and other wealthy nations, they may have an even greater impact on poor nations that do not have safety nets in place to absorb a sharp economic downturn, the World Bank predicted in a report issued today.
 Slower growth in world trade, a slump in tourism, lower commodity prices and falling foreign investment could reduce economic output across the developing world, straining already weak social service and health care systems, the bank said. 
 It estimated that 40,000 children worldwide will likely die from disease and malnutrition and 10 million people will fall below the bank's extreme poverty line of $1 dollar a day or less as a direct result of slower economic growth. 
"We've seen the human toll the recent attacks wrought in the U.S.," said the World Bank president, James Wolfensohn. "But there is another human toll that is largely unseen and one that will be felt in all parts of the developing world, especially Africa."
The ripples from the attacks were varied and widely felt, bank economists said. Tourists have canceled about 65 percent of vacations in the Caribbean. Indian businesses are paying 10 to 15 percent more to ship goods abroad because of rising insurance and security costs. Agricultural prices have dropped globally by about 5 percent since the attacks, a loss that comes directly out of the incomes of farmers in Africa and Latin America.
Next year the richest countries on average are likely to expand at a 1.25 percent rate, down from a forecast 2.2 percent growth in 2002. Poor countries are expected to expand at a 3.7 percent rate, .6 percentage points off the bank's pre-attack expectations.
While the decline in output may be greater in the United States and other developed countries, those nations also have far greater resources to cushion the blow, the bank said.
"The 300 million poor in sub-Saharan Africa are particularly vulnerable because most countries have little or no safety nets, and poor households have minimal savings to cushion bad times," the bank said.
The growth estimates are preliminary, bank officials have stressed. Bank officials said they are prepared to step up lending as needed to counter the effects of the attacks.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Loudonville: A Drop In Consumer Confidence 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

 BODY:
 New Yorkers' confidence in their economic well-being, and thus their willingness to spend money in stores, plunged after the World Trade Center attack, according to the latest survey by the Siena College Research Institute. 
Confidence, as measured by a running index of attitudes, fell to 72.0 in late September from 80.7 in late August. The decline for metropolitan New York City was larger than in upstate New York, where the index fell from 82.2 to 77.6. Nationally, the index fell from 91.5 to 81.8 in the same period. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
ANDRUCKI, JEAN

 BODY:
 ANDRUCKI-Jean. Born in New York Hospital on October 1, 1957. She grew up and attended school in Smithtown, New York. She was in the first class to attend Smithtown High School West, where she played three sports. She was in the first graduating class and was awarded the scholar athlete award and most valuable female athlete. While a student at Smithtown High School she and her dear friend, Kathy Hanlon, chaperoned dances for the Junior League for developmentally disabled citizens for three years. She also volunteered as a camp counselor at Camp Wilton in New York State. As a young woman, Jean led a group of adults and children who, for several years, sang in the local nursing home during the holidays. She also brought out children from the city to spend "weekends in the country" at Smithtown. Jean travelled extensively visiting Africa twice to view the natural beauty and the wildlife. She was greatly concerned about the environment and found her joy in the outdoors camping, kayaking, and bicycling. As an adult, Jean completed four triathalons and although girls could not play soccer when she attended high school, she did manage, as a woman, to join the Bergen Kickers and later to play with Leitrim's team in the upper Bronx. Jean attended Stony Brook University graduating in 1980 from an accelerated program and earning a B.A. in political science and an M.S. in Urban Policy Sciences. In 1981 she completed an M.S. in Mechanical Engineering. 
Jean was initiated into Pi Sigma Alpha, the national Political Science honor society. Jean joined the Port Authority in April 1982. In December '83 she was assigned to the Fire Safety Section. In '85 she was elected into the Society of Fire Protection Engineers. She advanced through the P.A. and was presently the Operations Manager for Risk Management in the Treasury Dept. Jean was the kind of aunt every kid wished for. She loved her nephews dearly and certainly did dote on them. They are George and Michael Andrucki and Michael Devlin Izzo. We truly looked forward to her weekends at home in her beloved Smithtown; she never really became a full fledged "city girl." We, her family, will grieve endlessly for her. Our lives and the lives of all her many friends will never be the same with the loss of her beautiful spirit and her compassionate, loving heart. The world will be a poorer place having lost this gentle and kind woman. Services for Jean will be held in Hoboken at Frank Sinatra park on Friday, October 5 at 6 P.M. and in Smithtown, St. Patricks Church, Main Street, 10:30 mass on October 11. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to The Nature Conservancy, 4245 North Fairfax Drive, Arlington, VA. 22203-1606.

HEADLINE: Waiting for Economic Answers 

 BODY:
President Bush and his national security team have done a good job of assuring the American people that they understand the political and military challenges of the fight against terrorism. The administration has seemed less sure-footed when it comes to handling the threat to the nation's economy. With Congress beginning to debate a possible stimulus package this week, the White House has been surprisingly silent on how seriously it regards the current economic situation, or what it wants to do to improve it. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill and the rest of the Bush team have yet to show full command of the issues they face. 
 The White House says the president has become convinced of the need for a sizable economic package but wants to consult with Democrats and Republicans in Congress on its size and shape. Tomorrow he plans to meet with business leaders in New York City. Aides to Mr. Bush say that the delay in shaping a package is wise, especially after both Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin counseled two weeks ago that more time is needed before it is clear how much trouble the economy is in. 
 No one was expecting the administration to have a fully formed package by now. But it would be useful to hear some principles from Mr. O'Neill and others. First, the need to prop up a faltering economy should not be an excuse to carry out tax cuts that special interests have been pushing all year. Congress is likely to cave in to at least some demands of the business lobbyists unless the president draws a firm line. That is particularly important because the administration rounded up support for its income tax cuts by suggesting that business interests would get another crack at tax breaks for themselves later on. Mr. Bush must make it clear that he knows this is no time to redeem a pledge to campaign donors.
Only the president answers to the needs of the entire country. It is up to him to make sure that the stimulus package is very narrowly targeted on tax cuts and spending programs that will ease the lives of Americans who lose jobs during the recession, and encourage consumer spending. Jump-starting the economy will cost money, and probably send the federal budget into the red. In that case it is all the more important to make sure the money is spent wisely, preferably on infrastructure projects that will have a long and useful life. 
Mr. O'Neill's erratic statements have sometimes rattled investors and, according to some reports, marginalized him as a policy maker and spokesman. It was also not useful for the secretary to try to influence the markets with empty cheerleading and predictions of an imminent upturn. 
Americans are waiting for Mr. Bush to take command of the economy and show that he can adapt to changed circumstances and fashion a program that favors immediate need over ideology. If the president's current advisers are not up to the job of reassuring the nation, Mr. Bush needs to improve his bench.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
In Pakistan, A Shaky Ally

BYLINE:  By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
For years, Pakistan has seemed a place about to blow. Bankruptcy is at the door; angry mullahs are at the gate. The corruption of the powerful is epic, the poverty of the masses crushing. The army has taken charge, again putting democracy on the shelf. More people own guns than refrigerators.
 This country, then, may seem a strange choice as America's indispensable ally in the hunt for Osama bin Laden. Islamic guerrillas -- many would call them terrorists -- openly operate inside Pakistan's borders, with government support. 
 But for the Bush administration, Pakistan it is -- a rediscovered crony from America's cold war days, forced back into friendship at gunpoint to fight terrorism. In his Sept. 19 speech to the nation, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler for the last two years, explained that he was facing an American ultimatum -- join us or fight us -- and that he felt that the country's very survival was at risk. 
In many ways, it is. The country is polarized. On one side stand sympathizers with the West who have felt increasingly marginalized in recent years and believe that the current turmoil may be a rare stroke of fortune that halts the "Talibanization" of Pakistan, a drift toward the fundamentalist Islam of neighboring Afghanistan. On the other stand the holy warriors, the hope of the country's myriad dispossessed.
Pakistan, with a population between 140 million and 150 million, is the world's seventh most populous country. Like many nations in the third world, it seems to be simultaneously moving ahead and falling behind at frantic speeds. It is this dichotomy that explains some of the violence of the country's conflicts.
Today, someone claiming to be from one of the best-known of Pakistan's radical Islamic guerrilla groups, Jaish-e-Muhammad, took responsibility for a suicide bombing at the state legislature in Srinagar, in Indian-administered Kashmir. The attack killed at least 26 people. 
One of this region's many open secrets is that the Pakistani government itself has armed Islamic militants, sending them off to fight the Indian authorities in Kashmir in an attempt to wrest the contested Himalayan territory, which is primarily Muslim, from Hindu control. 
A Pakistani Foreign Ministry spokesman, in a statement today, condemned the Srinagar attack. "Pakistan condemns terrorism in all its forms and manifestations," he said. 
But whatever the government's past relationship to Jaish-e-Muhammad, it seems clear that the United States, in its new determination to combat terrorism, has sided with a military government that has not been averse to backing insurgency in Kashmir.
Radical Muslim political parties, historically weak at the polls, are traditionally potent in the streets, where the number of poor and the number of refugees grow. Kalashnikovs are everywhere, as are men who know how to use them. Twin jihads -- one in Afghanistan, one in Kashmir -- save many from the idle hours of joblessness and fill them with lethal, self-righteous purpose.
But the radical Islamists drawn to holy war, however grateful for their supply of guns and grenades, very often despise the national leaders who provide them. The more those Pakistani leaders look like American cronies working to oust the Taliban government in Afghanistan, the more the hate may grow.
By drafting this fragile and fractious nation into a central role in the "war on terrorism," America runs the danger of setting off a cataclysm in a place where civil violence is a likely bet and nuclear weapons exist. 
Pakistan has long been the speculated locale for one of the world's worst nightmare scenario, in which Islamic terrorists, in league with rogue elements of the military, seize control of the government and wield the vengeful sword of jihad with a nuclear tip.
Islam is a growing force here. Hundreds of religious schools, known as madrassahs, have eagerly sent their students to fight at the Taliban's side. Pakistani border guards wish them well as they head to the front lines. 
Last Friday, in a drama repeated in hundreds of towns and cities across the country, mullahs at the Red Mosque in Islamabad followed the gentle chanting of afternoon prayers with frenzied threats of violence: Death to America! Let Americans come here to be buried!
A plea went out for 50,000 volunteers to defend Afghanistan against "the infidels." The entreaty was made with the desperate ardor of merchants at a going-out-of-business sale. Many of Pakistan's fundamentalist clerics endorse the Taliban's formula for a pure Islamic state. Without the Taliban, these mullahs would be without their rallying point.
An 18-year-old spectator, Tai Muhammad, said he had pledged his life to the anti-American jihad, enlisting at the mosque's sign-up table. "People like me will be the Americans' reception committee," he said, grinning in satisfaction. 
Lambasted along with President Bush was General Musharraf, called a traitor to his country, his religion and 1,400 years of Islamic history.
Afghanistan, Mr. bin Laden's sanctuary, is not merely Pakistan's neighbor. Pakistani intelligence agents have been the Taliban's godfathers, turning a throng of self-righteous religious students into a militia of self-assured soldiers.
Until recently, the Taliban have been useful to Pakistan, providing an ally on its western flank as rival India lurks to the east, and a breeding ground for Islamic militancy that could be redirected toward Kashmir.
So to many at the Red Mosque, Pakistan's cooperation with America seems like a sellout. 
American money, of course, is not an insignificant inducement, especially to a nation $37 billion in debt with virtually no prospects of climbing out of the hole.
So far, a windfall has yet to appear, though America -- suddenly forgiving of the testing of nuclear weapons and the eschewing of democracy -- has removed many economic sanctions against Pakistan. Together with the Japanese, the United States has rescheduled nearly $1 billion in debt and authorized $90 million in aid.
Indeed, renewed solvency is the hope of many Pakistanis who believe that a decisive battle has at last been joined.
"It's a wonderful thing," said a retired general, speaking on condition of anonymity. "We were in a state of drift. The silent majority was being dragged in a terrible direction by a very vocal minority. This is God-sent. We're saved."
That optimistic view is shared by much of a Westernized elite that would see the Taliban's overthrow as the logical halt to the onrushing fundamentalism in their own midst.
Many have long assumed that an upheaval was inevitable, with moderate Islam battling the religion's extremist, intolerant version.
That confrontation is better fought now than later, they say. "If there is a silver lining in this, it's that the radicals, the jihadists, will be de-fanged now instead of 10 years later when they'd be stronger," said Pervez Hoodbhoy, a physicist and peace activist.
But radicalism has deep social roots here. In the cities, the turn of a street corner can seem to be time travel between centuries. Wide boulevards clogged with expensive cars become narrow lanes where shrouded women carry jugs of water on their heads. 
About 75 percent of all Pakistanis reside in rural areas. Most are sharecroppers, eking out a subsistence. In some areas, feudal families still hold sway, making private laws and operating private jails.
While the wealthy send their children to college in America or Britain, many of the poor are deprived of even an elementary education. The literacy rate is below 40 percent. A fifth of Pakistan's government schools are "ghosts," with buildings but no students or teachers, General Musharraf himself admitted. This void increasingly has been filled by thousands of madrassahs. Considered a godsend by the destitute, they feed and house their pupils while teaching them the wisdom of the Koran and the moral requirement to fight in holy wars.
Islam is the great refuge of Pakistan's masses. In mosques, in the fields, on the roadsides, men drop to their knees and perform their daily prayers. However empty their pockets, they are equal in these genuflections before God.
But it is not a simple picture. Fundamentalist Muslims, like secular ones, are minorities. Between them are a multitude of gradations in the practices of faith -- one reason why recent polls suggest layers of ambivalence about the current crisis, 
Before General Musharraf's address to the nation on Friday, the pollster asked people whom they would support in a war between America and Afghanistan. Seven percent said America and 67 percent Afghanistan, with about 26 percent neutral. Four days after the speech, those who said they would side with the United States remained the same, though 20 percent shifted from Afghanistan to neutrality.
Some of this sentiment reflects a general doubt that America has enough proof against Mr. bin Laden to warrant a punishing attack on Afghanistan. At the same time, many Pakistanis are merely wary of America, regarded as a companion of shallow sincerity.
"Unfortunately, America seems to be Pakistan's friend only when it suits America's needs," said Zahid Mahmood, a bank manager. "When the need is over, America deserts you." 
In the 1980's, America had great needs in the region. In late 1979, the Soviet Union sent its troops into Afghanistan, getting itself closer to a warm-water port. Using Pakistan as a pipeline, the United States and other nations then financed the Afghan resistance. The Soviets soon found themselves bogged down in a crippling war against guerrillas adept at mountain combat. The cold war's end swiftly followed the Soviets' humbling retreat in 1989.
America's attention span, as well its affection, did not last much longer. That was a shock to Pakistan.
Money had seemed a token of friendship, and in 1990 the United States aid package to Pakistan was $564 million; only Israel and Egypt received more. But then the largesse was suddenly withdrawn, the penalty for Pakistan's continuing program to develop nuclear weapons in pace with its archenemy India.
"Looking out for No. 1, that's the American way, isn't it?" snickered Ajab Gul, a barber in Peshawar. "That is what Americans are proud of. We're different." 
But the loyalties of Pakistanis are no simple matter, either. 
In 1947, after a flurry of cartography, Pakistan and India were mapped out of the British Empire. Pakistan was devised with religious cohesion as a Muslim state. But it, rather than India, has been the one struggling for a national identity.
The country is split among several ethnicities and languages. Mr. Gul, the barber, is Pashtun and admits to feeling a greater affinity for the Pashtuns of Afghanistan than the Sindis of Karachi or the Punjabis of Lahore in his native land.
Democracy has never taken a firm foothold. The military has remained the dominant institution, and while it has failed in its three wars with India, it has had repeated success in overthrowing its own democratically elected governments.
During the 1990's, however, it was civilian governments that generally maintained control. The indefatigably corrupt governments of Prime Ministers Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif -- as well the stopped-up American spigot -- helped plunge the economy into the red while at the same time discrediting democracy in the eyes of the people.
Both Ms. Bhutto and Mr. Sharif now live in exile. Their political parties, the Pakistan Peoples Party and the Pakistan Muslim League, are in disarray. For now, public assembly is forbidden. 
By order of the Supreme Court, a return to civilian government is supposed to occur by next October. General Musharraf, who recently assumed the title of president, has promised to abide by the timetable.
But his future, like his country's, is now linked to matters that could not have been foreseen a month ago: the number of American soldiers who will touch Pakistani soil, the amount of blood spilled in reflexive outrage, the havoc caused by the coming onrush of refugees and the furtive ability of a Saudi-born multimillionaire named Osama bin Laden.

HEADLINE: Japan Is Preparing For a Recession 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
Having battled through three recessions in the last decade, Japanese executives are preparing for a fourth, and business confidence is dropping, according to the latest quarterly Tankan survey released today by the Bank of Japan. 
 The most closely watched indicator in the survey, the index of large manufacturers, plunged 17 points, to minus 33, the worst decline since the Asian financial crisis in 1998. 
A zero reading indicates neutral sentiment; negative numbers mean pessimists outnumber optimists. 
 Survey forms were mailed to 8,700 companies on Aug. 29; about 30 percent of the responses were received before the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States and the rest fterward.
Leading executives are steeling themselves for a long downturn. "We have to face the reality of recessions in the U.S. and Europe and a slow recovery in Japan," said Nobuyuki Idei, executive chairman of the Sony Corporation, which sharply cut its earnings forecast last week.
Naoyuki Akikusa, chief executive of Fujitsu, said he saw no recovery in the technology sector. "With demand for cellular phones and computers plunging, conditions in the semiconductor market have suddenly gotten more severe," he said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FEDERAL RESERVE; 
Fed Chief Urges a Considered Recovery Plan

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
In the wake of the terrorist attacks, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has counseled Congress and the Bush administration not to rush ahead with an economic stimulus plan, saying that the government should take a little time to assess the scale and nature of the economic damage before acting.
 But Mr. Greenspan is not showing any such caution when it comes to his own area of responsibility, interest rate policy. Analysts said the Fed was all but certain to reduce rates when it meets on Tuesday, in what would be its second rate cut since Sept. 11 and its ninth this year. Odds are that this cut, like the last one two weeks ago, will be half a percentage point. 
 In moving quickly and aggressively, Mr. Greenspan is sticking to the playbook that has worked effectively through his 14-year tenure as central bank chief: deal with crises through rapid, forceful action to stabilize the financial system and the economy, and worry about longer-term consequences later.
But as he surveys the economic and political landscape, Mr. Greenspan confronts some tricky issues. One is the possibility that the Fed will cut rates too much, sending the economy into overdrive next year and forcing it to backtrack by raising rates.
The Fed has already brought its benchmark federal funds target down to 3 percent from 6.5 percent this year, one of the most intensive periods of monetary policy easing on record. The economy has probably yet to feel the full kick from the early rate cuts, which have a lag period.
Although this year's rate cuts do not seem to have packed as much of a punch as in the past, the Fed has often had to take back some of its cuts when the immediate crisis passed. When it rapidly lowered rates late in 1998 in response to the global financial crisis that began in Asia, it helped fuel what became an unsustainable economic and investment boom that led it to raise rates through much of 1999 and into 2000.
In 1998, of course, the economy was strong to start with, despite the turmoil in the financial markets; today, it is weak and almost certainly getting weaker. 
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported today that manufacturing activity declined in September for the 14th consecutive month. The group's widely watched purchasing management index fell to 47 from 47.9, a smaller drop than economists had expected, but the outlook is for further declines in the months ahead.
Moreover, oil prices have declined, giving the Fed leeway to act without worrying about inflation. And there is considerable pressure on the Fed to help restore investor, consumer and business confidence at a time when the psychological aftereffects of the attacks are probably more important in economic terms than the physical damage and disruption.
"The Fed is taking the attitude that it would rather err on the side of being too easy than not easy enough," said Paul L. Kasriel, a Northern Trust Company economist.
Still, Mr. Greenspan has to be careful not to expend his ammunition too quickly. If he and his colleagues lower the federal funds rate to 2.5 percent on Tuesday, they will have to consider holding future rate reductions to a quarter of a percentage point.
Otherwise, it would risk soon finding itself in a situation that afflicts the Japanese central bank: with official short-term interest rates at or near zero, it becomes difficult to use monetary policy to encourage economic activity.
Mr. Greenspan is also trying to gauge the proper stance for interest rate policy at a time when Congress and the administration seem increasingly likely to agree on a sizable, though as yet undefined, package of fiscal stimulus measures.
Even as he has encouraged Congress and the White House to go slow in developing a stimulus plan, Mr. Greenspan has advised Congress that if it wants to make any such package effective, it will have to be big. By that, he has said, he means something in the area of $100 billion, including steps taken so far, like the $40 billion in emergency spending already being disbursed for relief and military activities.
But Mr. Greenspan has also signaled he is worried that a fiscal stimulus package could become an excuse to abandon fiscal discipline, undermining plans to pay down most of the $3.3 trillion national debt over the next decade. 
Should the bond market suspect that the government has reverted to the profligacy of the 1980's, Mr. Greenspan suggested in Congressional testimony last month, it might punish the economy by pushing up long-term interest rates. Indeed, he said, there was some evidence that concern on Wall Street about the long-term budget outlook was already putting upward pressure on long-term rates.
Mr. Greenspan's concern about fiscal policy getting out of hand was driven in part by Federal Reserve research showing that the housing market has played a crucial role over the last year and a half in offsetting the losses that many households have suffered in the stock market. With home prices rising and mortgage rates low, homeowners have been able to refinance regularly, reducing monthly payments or taking cash out of their homes to spend on other things.
Should mortgage rates, along with other long-term rates, rise because of concern about the federal budget, that source of consumer confidence and cash could dry up, removing one of the few areas of strength in the economy.
The central bank's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee will convene on Tuesday just after President Bush meets with leaders of both parties in Congress to begin drawing up the outlines of a fiscal stimulus plan. 
At a breakfast meeting with the lawmakers, Mr. Bush is expected to set out a framework for what such a plan would encompass, including aid for laid-off workers, tax breaks for companies and some sort of tax cut for individuals.
While the timing is a coincidence, it will be a chance for Mr. Greenspan to demonstrate that monetary policy can be applied more decisively than fiscal policy.
Mr. Greenspan, said Paul McCulley, an economist at the investment firm Pimco, "still believes that monetary policy should be the dominant and dominating countercyclical policy tool."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PRESIDENT; 
Bush Expected to Give Approval To Airport's Reopening Shortly

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to reopen Ronald Reagan National Airport, administration officials said today, and will probably make the announcement on Tuesday. The officials added that the airport could begin operating within days.
 But the officials said the president wanted additional security, including what one described as "the heavy presence of air marshals" on flights. The officials also said that the number of flights would be limited at first, but that the US Airways and Delta Air Lines shuttles to New York would probably be the first to begin operations. 
 The officials also said the airplanes would not be restricted from taking off or landing from the north. Last week, officials said the Bush administration had considered such a restriction to avoid air traffic over the Pentagon. But officials said today that idea was rejected as unworkable.
Such a restriction would have sharply cut air traffic at the airport because jets need the flexibility to land and take off from both the north and the south, depending on the direction of the wind.
Mr. Bush was expected to announce other security measures for the airport, possibly including more screening of passengers and luggage, officials said.
Under such a program, pilots would have to identify themselves 20 minutes before landing at the airport, instead of just a few minutes before. They might also use special codes to verify their identities.
The White House has come under increasing pressure to open Reagan National, the only commercial airport in the nation still out of service after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. In the past week, its shutdown has created a battle between security and economics, with angry Virginia lawmakers threatening to push through legislation to force it open if the president did not act first.
The closing of the airport, which is in Virginia across the Potomac River from the White House and other national landmarks, has prompted thousands of layoffs, battering the area's economy and aggravating most members of Congress, who regularly use the airport.
The airport generates about $5 billion a year in revenue and normally employs 10,000 workers. But 4,000 of them have now applied for unemployment. US Airways, which has a hub there, has cut 11,000 jobs.
Today a Virginia delegation -- including Gov. James S. Gilmore III and Senators John W. Warner and George F. Allen met with Andrew H. Card Jr., the president's chief of staff, and Karl Rove, one of the president's closest advisers, to press their cause.
Afterward, Mr. Allen said that Mr. Rove and Mr. Card had been receptive to the case they had presented.
"Let's just recognize that the Secret Service, it's their job to be paranoid," Mr. Allen said. "But you can't live your life in a bunker."
Mr. Allen added that he had received a call from the White House late in the day inviting him to an announcement that the president expected to make Tuesday morning.
Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, has repeatedly faced questions since last week about whether Mr. Bush -- who flies on Air Force One in and out of Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, on the other side of Washington -- was concerned about the problem at Reagan Airport. Restaurateurs, hotel operators and taxi drivers are all hurting financially and say that the airport's closing had signaled to tourists around the country that Washington is a dangerous place to visit.
"He's very sensitive on these points," Mr. Fleischer said. "There are obviously security considerations because of the unique location of National Airport, which literally puts the airplanes on the flight path to and from National, seconds away from many major federal facilities."
Lawmakers and transportation officials agree that security must be increased at the airport. Last week, Norman Y. Mineta, the secretary of transportation, said he would be willing to place armed sky marshals on all flights arriving at or departing from the airport, if that would get it running again. Some local officials have suggested expanding the regional airspace security program.
Today the White House also said that Mr. Bush would visit an elementary school in New York on Wednesday, his second trip to the city after touring the wreckage of the World Trade Center on Sept. 14. Officials in New York said that the school was P.S. 130 in Chinatown, which was closed for the first days after the attack but has since re-opened.
Mr. Bush was also expected to meet in Manhattan with what one administration official described as "leading national businessmen and women to receive their perspective on the slowing economy, and have a dialogue."
Mr. Bush continued to talk today with foreign leaders by telephone, conversing with President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic and Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed of Malaysia. Mr. Fleischer said Mr. Bush thanked Mr. Havel for the Czech Republic's support in recent days and told Mr. Mahathir that the administration's antiterrorism campaign was a "struggle against evil, and not Islam."
The president visited the headquarters of the Federal Emergency Management Agency today, where he thanked employees.
"Yours was an organization that was used to dealing with acts of nature -- hurricanes or tornadoes, and fires or floods," Mr. Bush said. "And then, all of a sudden, some evil people came and they declared war on America. And your agency and the good working people, true Americans, had to rise to the occasion."
 --------------------

Ouster Reported Planned at Logan
 BOSTON, Oct. 1, (AP) -- The head of security at Logan International Airport is being ousted, an official in the governor's office said today.
The security chief, Joseph Lawless, was appointed in 1993 as the head of public safety at the Massachusetts Port Authority, which runs Logan, the Port of Boston and several regional airports. Before then, Mr. Lawless, a former state police official, had handled security for Gov. William F. Weld. 
"He will be removed very soon," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift was scheduled to make a speech Tuesday night to discuss her plans for tightening security at the Massachusetts Port Authority and throughout the state.
A call left for Mr. Lawless' spokesman after business hours Monday was not returned. Mr. Lawless has an unlisted home phone number and could not be reached for comment.
Governor Swift today called security lapses at the airport "unacceptable." The two jets that were crashed into the World Trade Center towers originated at Logan. About 150 National Guard members will be assigned to Logan and the state's other airports starting Friday.

HEADLINE: Making the Most of Giuliani 

BYLINE:  By Fred Siegel; Fred Siegel is a professor of history at Cooper Union and a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute.

 BODY:
New York is on the edge of an economic abyss. That reality -- not the mayor's personality or city politics -- is what New Yorkers have to focus on as they consider Rudolph Giuliani's request to stay on for three months after his term ends. Regardless of who in New York likes Mr. Giuliani and who doesn't, and regardless of the unwillingness of many local politicians to see him remain in office even a day after Jan. 1, he has come to symbolize the best of New York to the rest of the country. And we badly need the rest of the country to help pay for our reconstruction.
 Before Sept. 11, the city and the nation were sliding into a shallow recession. Now, after the mass murder at the World Trade Center, the fall is expected to be steep, with New York especially hard-hit. In the first months of struggling to regain a footing, and with the sinking economy making adjustments harder, the city needs not only seasoned leadership, but also a spokesman who is viewed favorably around the country and can inspire as much national confidence as possible. 
 There are political obstacles, of course, to giving Mr. Giuliani 90 more days to get a coherent city response in motion. State and local legislators, who would have to approve any plan to let the mayor stay on, are not notably enthusiastic. Sheldon Silver, speaker of the State Assembly, suggested yesterday that Mr. Giuliani might become head of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center property. But that plan overlooks the importance of the mayor's national popularity at a moment of economic peril.
In the next month alone, New York could lose a frightening 108,000 jobs and nearly $17 billion in production and spending, according to a study by the Fiscal Policy Institute for the New York City Central Labor Council. The businesses below 14th Street are most deeply hurt by the losses of people and property downtown, but the lights are going out along Broadway, too. Hotels all over the city are half empty, and conventions are being canceled. The city has lost 5,300 jobs in air transportation. Sales at Federated Department Store outlets, including Macy's and Bloomingdale's, have been down since Sept. 11 by 20 percent nationally, but by 40 percent in New York.
But the biggest damage is to the financial industry, on which the city economy is disproportionately dependent: it accounts for less than 5 percent of New York's jobs but roughly 18 percent of wages paid in the city. Before Sept. 11, profits at financial firms were already faltering and Wall Street bonuses, the mighty engine of retail and real estate sales, were expected to drop by as much as 50 percent. Now not only will earnings and bonuses drop further, but a slow slide in local employment in this industry has given way to an avalanche of job losses.
Many of the jobs fleeing to New Jersey and elsewhere will never return. And with so much office space lost, we now face the unpleasant prospect of rising rents in the midst of an economic slump, adding to the pressure on businesses.
Time is of the essence in mitigating what's likely to be a deep downturn for New York. The struggling businesses need help now, not after a new mayor learns the ropes. And the country's sympathy and attention are with us now. By the time the next mayor is fully in control of the city government, the 2002 political season will have begun, as will a new year of budget negotiations for the federal and state governments, which will both find themselves in fiscal difficulty. New York needs to move quickly on its rebuilding agenda before our needs get caught up in the inevitable complication of Congressional, state legislative and gubernatorial races, not to mention fights over the 2002 reapportionment of legislative seats.
Washington has promised $40 billion in recovery and rebuilding money, but what kinds of strings will be attached? And who will receive the money? Will it be Albany or the port authority, both of which have agendas not always in synch with New York City's?
Mayor Giuliani's national popularity is an invaluable asset for the rebuilding of New York. Why not make the most of it? If he can stay in charge for an additional three months, he can help move the federal money through Congress with a maximum of speed and minimum of restrictions while magnifying the city's say in how the money is used.
Unprecedented events demand unprecedented responses. It is in the interest of all of New York to let Mayor Giuliani seize the moment so that by April 1, when a new mayor takes charge, the city will at least have a fighting chance to stave off the worst of what the economy has in store for us.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED; 
Words to a Hurt World: Action, Not Deliberation

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's address yesterday to the General Assembly of the United Nations, as recorded by The New York Times.
 On Sept. 11, 2001, New York City, the most diverse city in the world, was viciously attacked in an unprovoked act of war. More than 5,000 innocent men, women and children of every race, religion and ethnicity are lost. Among these were people from 80 different nations. To their representatives here today, I offer my condolences to you as well on behalf of all New Yorkers who share this loss with you. 
 This was the deadliest attack -- terrorist attack -- in history. It claimed more lives than Pearl Harbor or D-Day. This was not just an attack on the city of New York or on the United States of America. It was an attack on the very idea of a free, inclusive and civil society. It was a direct assault on the founding principles of the United Nations itself. 
The preamble to the U.N. Charter states that this organization exists to reaffirm faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person, to practice tolerance and live together in peace as good neighbors and to unite our strength to maintain international peace and security. 
Indeed, this vicious attack places in jeopardy the whole purpose of the United Nations. . . . 
The United Nations must hold accountable any country that supports or condones terrorism. Otherwise, you will fail in your primary mission as peacekeeper. 
It must ostracize any nation that supports terrorism. It must isolate any nation that remains neutral in the fight against terrorism. Now is the time, in the words of your charter, the United Nations Charter, to unite our strength to maintain international peace and security. 
This is not a time for further study or vague directives. 
The evidence of terrorism's brutality and inhumanity, of its contempt for life and the concept of peace, is lying beneath the rubble of the World Trade Center less than two miles from where we meet today. 
Look at that destruction, that massive, senseless, cruel loss of human life, and then I ask you to look in your hearts and recognize that there is no room for neutrality on the issue of terrorism. You're either with civilization or with terrorists. On one side is democracy, the rule of law and respect for human life. On the other is tyranny, arbitrary executions and mass murder.
We are right and they are wrong. It's as simple as that. And by that I mean that America and its allies are right about democracy, about religious, political and economic freedom. And the terrorists are wrong, and in fact evil, in their mass destruction of human life in the name of addressing alleged injustices.
Let those who say that we must understand the reasons for terrorism come with me to the thousands of funerals we're having in New York City -- thousands -- and explain those insane, maniacal reasons to the children who will grow up without fathers and mothers and to the parents who have had their children ripped from them for no reason at all. . . . 
We're a city of immigrants unlike any other city, within a nation of immigrants.
Like the victims of the World Trade Center attack, we're of every race, we're of every religion, we're of every ethnicity. And our diversity has been our greatest source of strength. It's the thing that renews us and revives us in every generation -- our openness to new people from all over the world. 
So from the first day of this attack, an attack on New York, on America, and I believe on the basic principles that underlie this organization, I've told the people of New York that we should not allow this to divide us because then we would really lose what this city is all about. . . . 
We can't let terrorists change the way we live. Otherwise they will have succeeded.
In some ways, the resilience of life in New York City is the ultimate sign of defiance to terrorists. We call ourselves the capital of the world in large part because we're the most diverse city in the world. And we're the home of the United Nations. So that spirit of unity amid all our diversity has never ever been stronger. . . .
Freedom from fear is a basic human right. We need to reassert our right to live free from fear with greater confidence and determination than ever before here in New York City, across America and around the world. With one clear voice, unanimously, we need to say we will not give in to terrorism. 
Surrounded by our friends of every faith, we know this is not a clash of civilizations. It's a conflict between murderers and humanity.

HEADLINE: World Tourism Officials Look Hard for Optimism 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
Along with a tropical rain, gales of bad news battered a world tourism conference here this week: dozens of trans-Pacific flights canceled, hundreds of Japanese tour groups dropping trips to the United States and tourism bookings vanishing in Asia's poorest nations, including Cambodia, Nepal and Thailand.
 But inside the hall housing the World Tourism Organization meeting, industry veterans urged a steady hand at the tiller as the $500 billion travel and tourism industry navigates a world changed by the terror attacks of Sept. 11, when four commercial jets were hijacked in the United States and three were used as missiles. 
 In the short term, some countries, like China, will probably gain, while others, like the United States, will probably lose. But in the long term, they said, world tourism will continue to expand. 
"For Europeans, Japanese and Americans, business and pleasure travel have now become a fundamental need," Francesco Frangialli, secretary general of the organization, said.
Taking the long view, Mr. Frangialli said he thought air security issues would be resolved, consumer confidence would return, and after a bad fourth quarter of 2001, world tourism would resume growing by 4 percent a year. 
Delegates from Europe said a return to normal travel was in sight.
"By the end of September, the net effect of cancellations and new reservations was a drop of 4 percent -- in terms of volume, that's half a day of work," said Felipe Gonzalez Abad, director general of Savia Amadeus, a reservation system used by 6,000 travel agencies in Spain.
The apparent decision by the United States not to retaliate against Afghanistan with a big conventional military campaign seems to be reassuring European travelers.
"We have seen a significant improvement in bookings since the U.S. has communicated that the action is likely to be covert, rather than overt," said Martin Brackenbury, international director of Airtours, a British tour operator.
While Britons may tell pollsters they are reluctant to fly, they appear to be equally reluctant to pass up bargains. "People may have anxieties, but if the price is right, they will still fly," Mr. Brackenbury said. His company, he said, was having success filling seats using discounts.
Pushed by people's hunger to get away from home, travel has historically proved resilient. In this crisis, Europeans will still travel, although they may drive to Southern France rather than fly to Morocco. Something similar is at work in Japan, where trips to America are being scrapped in favor of China or trips within Japan.
As a group, the Japanese spend much more traveling abroad than foreigners do visiting Japan, and they contribute greatly to the travel surplus of the United States. But the Japan Travel Bureau, the nation's largest travel operator, has already recorded 78,600 cancellations of Japanese trips to the United States for September and October.
"We fear that the terrorist attack has more impact on air trips," Tsuneo Nishiyama, a spokesman for the bureau, said in Tokyo. "A phenomenon of avoiding airplanes is emerging now."
Fear of flying across the Pacific is costing Japanese airlines dearly. Japan Air Lines, which earns about 40 percent of its revenue on trans-Pacific flights, expects to lose $150 million from canceled flights in September and October. It flies less often now to Hawaii, Chicago, Los Angeles and New York. Its main rival, All Nippon Airways, lost 30 percent of its international traffic volume for the last three weeks in September.
"The terrorist attack was a major blow for airline companies," Yasuhiro Takebayashi, a JAL spokesman, said today. "We don't know how big the damage will develop into or how long it will last."
Crowds seemed thin today at Narita, Tokyo's international airport, where just a few weeks ago, 75,000 passengers passed through each day. But Haneda, Tokyo's domestic airport, seemed unaffected.
"Many Japanese tourists are afraid of international flights, but domestic traffic is almost normal," said Etsuko Yano, who checks in passengers for All Nippon at Haneda.
American carriers have sharply curtailed trans-Pacific service, with half the usual number of weekly flights on some routes, like United's Tokyo-Chicago run, and none at all on others, like Northwest's Osaka-Los Angeles service.
Many seats on those flights were once filled by Japanese business travelers, but companies are keeping them home. "We basically banned all the overseas trips by employees, including employees of our offices in the U.S. and Asian countries," said Kenji Hamai, a spokesman for Fuji Xerox.
In the rearranging of tourism within Asia, Hong Kong and the rest of China are seen as safe and appear to be emerging largely unscathed. "For China, this is not a real problem," said Zhang Xin Hong of the China National Tourism Administration.
But more turbulent Asian nations are losing visitors. Cambodia's tourist arrivals dropped by an estimated one-quarter in September. Nepal has lost about half of its hotel bookings for its fall season.
After gangs of Islamic extremists conducted "hunts" for Americans in some parts of Indonesia, the State Department warned Americans to put off travel to the country, the world's largest Muslim nation, and Americans are now scarce there.
Even Thailand, Southeast Asia's leading destination, will probably have to settle for 2 percent growth in arrivals over last year, rather than 8 percent.
"It's just inappropriate to travel now -- this is not the time to have fun," said Akiko Yamamoto, a 31-year-old graduate student in Tokyo, explaining why she and her sister canceled their trip to Thailand last week. Noting heightened activity at American bases in Japan, she said, "I assume there will be many combat planes flying around Japan; it's not fun to imagine my aircraft flying with warplanes."
Attitudes like these mean tourism planners must start promoting again, C. Derek Hood, Japan director for the Canadian Tourism Commission, said at the conference. Noting that Canada has become the No. 3 destination for Japanese tourists after the United States and Britain, Mr. Hood said he would go ahead with a four-day trade show promoting Canadian travel in Tokyo and Osaka this month.
Many at the conference predicted that world travel would be back on the growth curve when they meet again two years from now in China.
"It was pretty frightening to see those images on TV, but I think those fears fade pretty fast," said Deborah Luhrman, a spokeswoman for the conference, which began last week in South Korea. "I was scared to come to Seoul, but as soon as I got on the plane, all those fears went away. I was back doing what I have been doing every month for the last 10 years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A sharp slowdown in the tourism industry led to long lines and lengthy waits last week at the Honolulu unemployment insurance claims office. (Cory Lum for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Okinawa Justice Is Tilted Against Them, Americans Say 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: MIHAMA, Japan, Sept. 29 

 BODY:
This is the story of a rape and of a death and the different attention each has provoked on this small island where more than 20,000 American troops are based.
 Both incidents can be traced back to an unassuming restaurant named the 3F, which caters to Japanese and to the American troops based here in almost equal measure. Both incidents have reflected and accentuated the tensions here over an American presence that a growing number of Japanese find excessive. 
 First came the reported rape of a Japanese customer by Timothy Woodland, a 24-year-old Air Force staff sergeant, at 2 a.m. on June 29 in the parking lot outside the restaurant. 
Then, barely a week later, Gerald C. Fearr, the 62-year-old American husband of the Japanese owner of the restaurant, died moments after being struck, in front of his house, in a late-night altercation with a young Japanese man. The dispute centered on a a debt owed by Mr. Fearr's wife.
Among Okinawans, the allegation of rape quickly became a focus for rage, the most widely deplored in a growing list of offenses of which American servicemen here have been accused since the rape of a 12-year-old schoolgirl by two marines and a sailor in 1995. 
But although Mr. Fearr's death became front-page news in the American military newspaper Stars and Stripes and was deplored by those who knew him here, it received almost no coverage in the Japanese press and prosecutors quickly dropped the matter. 
For Mr. Fearr's family and for foreign military personnel in Okinawa, the contrast in the official handling of the two cases is glaring.
They contend that the legal deck is stacked against Americans on this island where feelings toward the American presence have become increasingly hostile.
"Out there a person may have been raped, and they had police around here day and night combing the area for evidence and using lie detectors," said Ken Roberts, a retired Air Force master sergeant who is married to Mr. Fearr's stepdaughter and is the manager of the 3F restaurant.
"Another man was killed in front of his house," he continued, "and the police just came by once, noted the position of the body and were like, sorry." 
Okinawan authorities deny that they treated Mr. Fearr's death lightly, and point to their arrest and brief detention of a suspect, Riki Matsuyama. "The suspect was charged with assault," said Junichi Okumura, deputy chief prosecutor. "The charges were dropped because the autopsy results showed no direct link to the victim's death. The cause of death was a heart attack."
As Mr. Fearr's case languishes, the rape case has had ever widening repercussions. The trial of Sergeant Woodland began recently. He has insisted on his innocence.
Already, the trial is one of the most heavily publicized court cases in Japanese history. It has come to encompass decades-old grievances over the concentration of many of the 47,000 American forces in Japan on this small island.
Since the end of World War II, American troops have been stationed here, where they can easily be sent to the Asian mainland in case of a conflict there. The United States maintained complete control of the island until 1972, when the administration reverted to Japan.
The arrangement has long been considered convenient to both countries because of the island's proximity to potential conflict zones near Taiwan and the Korean peninsula for the Americans, and because the concentration of large numbers of American troops here kept them out of sight of the bulk of Japan's population, which lives elsewhere.
A political movement aimed at eliminating the American presence sprung up in Okinawa almost immediately after it reverted to Japanese control. This movement gained popularity in the 1980's after a series of incidents involving American troops angered the population.
Okinawa's economy, however, is heavily dependent on the American presence, with most jobs and much of the commerce related directly or indirectly to the American military presence. Despite the political opposition, opinion polls have consistently indicated that a majority of Okinawans do not favor the total withdrawal of Americans from the island. 
Still, the rape case has been a major irritant in relations between the United States and Japan, although that has been somewhat muted by a strong show of solidarity after the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States.
The trial has had nonstop news media coverage. Charges have been energetically pressed. The proceedings have prompted American complaints about due-process shortcomings in the Japanese legal system, both from American diplomats and from Americans here.
The perception of a discrepancy in the handling of incidents involving Japanese and foreign suspects has fed American anger. While the Woodland case continues to garner front-page attention, the recent arrest of a sergeant from Japan's Self Defense Force for molesting a 12-year-old girl merited only a brief item in most newspapers. 
American officers have been privately scathing in their reactions to the Woodland case. "If Woodland is guilty then he should be punished," said a senior American officer. "But there is a very real question whether a man who has already been convicted in the press can get a fair trial under a system like the one they have here."
Many of the concerns over the Japanese legal system were stated openly during an uneasy few days when the United States hesitated before surrendering Sergeant Woodland.
It was only the second time the American military had handed over a suspect to Japanese authorities before an indictment, and the surrender came about only after high-level discussion between the two countries. 
Criminal suspects, like Sergeant Woodland, are theoretically subject to 23 days of detention, during which time they can be interrogated indefinitely, without the benefit of counsel. 
Since his indictment, Sergeant Woodland has been held without bail in a spartan detention cell without cigarettes, newspapers, television or air-conditioning. He is able to communicate only with his mother, grandmother and lawyer. Even Bibles sent to him by well-wishers have been given to him with messages of encouragement ripped out, United States military sources say. 
For the sergeant's Japanese lawyer, too, the case raises questions of fairness, but not necessarily the procedural ones that worried American military authorities.
"American servicemen tend to hang out with and date Japanese ladies in places like this," said the lawyer, Tsuyoshi Aragaki. "I personally think that this was the background to this matter." Mr. Aragaki said that his client and the plaintiff had sexual intercourse, but that it was consensual.
He added that the reported rape should have been treated as an ordinary criminal case. But now, "this is no longer about an American serviceman, but about the larger issue of American bases in Okinawa."

HEADLINE: A Looming New York Fiscal Crisis 

 BODY:
The New York economy, already shaky before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, is headed for an aftershock that could produce the biggest budget crisis since the 1970's. Estimates of lost city and state tax revenues over the next 18 months approach $10 billion. The shortfalls would come on top of multibillion-dollar deficits already projected for the next fiscal year. In preparing his first budget, the next mayor of New York City may have to close a gap of $4 billion or more, a nearly impossible task without major sacrifice by New Yorkers and help from Albany and Washington.
 Until recently, some of the mayoral candidates might as well have been campaigning on the moon for all the attention they paid to the challenge lying ahead. Now they are beginning to speak more frankly about the future problems. But the difficulties with the city's budget were not all created by the terrorists. Irresponsible practices over the last several years allowed the Giuliani administration and City Council to use surpluses from the Wall Street boom to plug deficits that were bound to remain when the boom faded away. 
 The city can probably limp through its current fiscal year, which ends next June 30. But for the year beginning July 1, the Giuliani administration is projecting a $4 billion gap. That would represent about 8 percent of the budget, and it does not include any raises negotiated in future labor contracts. It would be heartbreaking for City Hall to have to ask the city's heroic work force, especially its uniformed services, for pay freezes and givebacks. It would be almost suicidal to try to deny the teachers a significant wage hike at a time when higher-paying suburban schools are competing for staff and city students are being required to pass increasingly difficult achievement tests. But some very tough choices are in the offing.
The city will no doubt call for help from Albany, and the state needs to do what it can. But Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature are not likely to have much leeway. The state budget is itself dependent on the very businesses that have been hit hardest -- finance, insurance, tourism and retail sales. With its so-called "bare-bones" budget passed earlier this year -- and decried as inadequate by everyone from Mr. Pataki to the local school districts -- the state can very likely make it to the end of its fiscal year on March 31. For the next year, the state could easily face its own deficit of several billion dollars.
One way of easing the crunch would be through federal aid -- if Washington can be persuaded to compensate the city for tax revenue lost because of the destruction of the World Trade Center. The city also may be able to use $2.5 billion in emergency borrowing allowed by the Legislature. But that could create new problems: If the city runs a deficit of more than $100 million, the laws enacted during its fiscal crisis of the late 70's call for a control board, headed by the governor, to take over city finances. To address all these problems, Mr. Pataki should begin working immediately with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, the legislative leaders and all the mayoral candidates.
In a time of trial and tragedy, it will be hard for the city to get used to the fact that the economic boom of the last several years is now gone. In fact, it was gone even before the attacks on the World Trade Center. Deferring the task of dealing with the coming emergency will only make that emergency worse.

HEADLINE: Marketing Campaign for Gold Miners 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: DENVER, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
AngloGold, Barrick Gold and other mining companies have proposed spending as much as $200 million a year on the industry's biggest marketing campaign ever, aimed at increasing bullion prices and demand for gold jewelry. 
 The campaign, to be initially financed with 30 cents from every ounce of gold produced, could increase annual gold demand as much as 13 percent, adding $12 billion to sales, based on estimates by consultants at McKinsey & Company. 
Gold prices that have lingered below $300 an ounce for four years could rise as much as $40, they said. 
 More advertising and promotion will eventually increase jewelry demand that probably will fall next year, before the United States emerges from a recession, mining executives said at a conference on gold in Denver. Jewelry accounts for 80 percent of gold use, and bullion prices have dropped 24 percent since 1996. 
"Why should we be deterred by short-term events," said Randall Oliphant, chief executive of Barrick, the fourth-largest gold producer. "Now is the time to do our homework. And we all believe the world will come back and that all recessions end." 
So far, companies that account for about 70 percent of world production are backing the campaign. Along with South Africa's AngloGold, the largest producer, proponents of the plan include Kinross Gold of Toronto; Randgold Resources of Jersey, the Channel Islands; Sons of Gwalia of Perth, Australia; and Gympie Gold of Sydney. AngloGold is a unit of Anglo American.
