HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
As travel beginsto pick up again, the airlines are using new strategies, and prices, to sell tickets.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS air travel slowly picks up again, the major airlines are busy promoting lower business-travel fares, tweaking advance-purchase and minimum-stay restrictions, and devising new ways to sell tickets on the Internet and through targeted e-mail promotions to regular customers. 
 On Monday night, United Airlines announced what it called "new fare options" that included reductions of 50 percent off regular walk-up business fares for 21-day advance purchases and 25 percent off for 10-day advance purchases. 
 This prompted the other major airlines yesterday to say they had matched United's offerings -- but also promoted several to note that even before United's announcement they already had in place business fares that, according to a Delta Air Lines spokesman, Tom Donahue, are "at least as low as, or lower than, the fares United introduced" with great fanfare Monday night.
What's going on here, travel industry analysts said, may represent a significant and perhaps lasting change in the ways air-fare sales are promoted, as airlines struggle to get more higher-paying business fliers back on their planes quickly. 
In the past, fare sales were typically announced in national advertisements in which the airlines often exactly matched one another on prices and terms. Now, as economically distressed airlines frantically adjust schedules, crews and equipment to try to raise the most cash possible from each mile flown, new fares and more creative advance-purchase and frequent-flier promotions are being tailored to specific market segments and often promoted directly to customers through the Internet. 
"There's a lot of activity going on today; some of it's new, and some is not new," Steve Shook, a vice president of the travel management company Carlson Wagonlit, said yesterday of the fare announcements. 
For more than a month, analysts said, major airlines have been offering sharply lower fares on some popular routes, while recalculating advance-purchase and Saturday-night-stay restrictions to gain competitive advantages, market by market and route by route. 
In recent weeks, Southwest Airlines, National Airlines and other smaller regional carriers began aggressively promoting even sharper fare cuts, in some cases by extending fare sales that were already under way before Sept. 11.
Now, with business travel stirring once more, the major carriers appear to have jumped into that game with both feet. 
United's announcement Monday of across-the-board cuts of up to 50 percent in business fares -- and the dropping of the hated Saturday-night-stay requirement on those fares -- re-ignited the air-fare activity and confusion.
American Airlines, Continental Airlines and US Airways all said yesterday that they had matched United's fares nationally. American, Delta, Northwest Airlines and others also had new promotions offering frequent-flier and other bonuses on their Web sites yesterday. Delta also said yesterday that it was beginning a promotion on its Web site and on radio stations that included 10,000 free tickets to New York City as part of a "Delta Loves NY" campaign.
Meanwhile, like Delta, Northwest said that it already had comparable or better fares in place than the ones United announced Monday. 
In February 2000, Northwest introduced a fare package called Bizflex that was "a halfway point between the traditional unrestricted highest business fares and the leisure fares with all the restrictions," said Kurt Ebenhoch, a Northwest spokesman. Those fares -- which have no expiration dates -- started out at a maximum 40 percent discount; the maximum discount is now 50 percent, with a shorter advance-purchase requirement, Mr. Ebenhoch said. 
"We've been offering either lower or less restricted fares for a year and a half," he added.
People in the industry agreed that the earlier Northwest fares were comparable to United's, but said that Northwest's were less comprehensive. Mr. Ebenhoch said that Northwest now matched all of the new United fares.
Whatever the quibbling over who got there first, however, the new fare activity is seen as a clear sign that the airlines, each of whom has amassed rich databases of marketing information for frequent fliers, have begun to look to the Internet as a way to calibrate fares and special offers with unparalleled precision.
"Previously we had to have a sweeping fare release that was based on a market or a season or an entire schedule," Mr. Ebenhoch said. "Now we're able to pinpoint not only specific markets but specific flights within specific markets."
Mr. Shook, at Carlson Wagonlit, said that there was a "changing dynamic" in airline sale promotions, with "a lot of marketing going on at the Web sites."
During past events that have severely disrupted travel, like the 1991 Persian Gulf war, "the Internet wasn't available as part of a supplier's recovery strategy," said Suzi LeVine, the director of product marketing at Expedia Inc.
"For the first time with the Internet, quick distribution channels exist for suppliers," she said. "In the past, an airline or a hotelier or a car rental agency would have to fire up a whole new ad campaign, put it through to the media, send it out to the travel agents. Now, with the Internet, we're able to right away use our e-mail communications to let people know very quickly about things that are going on."
Mr. Donahue, the Delta spokesman, added, "These fare sales are coming fast and furious."
Now that the federal government has backed off the prohibition against curbside check-in at many airlines, some airport officials would like to see a rethinking of security-screening rules.
"We've asked the F.A.A. for a little flexibility," said Jerry Orr, aviation director of the Charlotte/Douglas International Airport in Charlotte, N.C., where, as at many airports, restaurants and shops are within the secure zone. 
He added: "We said we saw no security problem in allowing people without tickets through checkpoints. To the contrary, adding an additional level of decision-making at the checkpoint causes more confusion and opportunity for something to fall through the cracks, rather than if you just screened everybody that presented themselves. In any security process you don't want to create crowds; you want to get people dispersed as much as you can."

HEADLINE: Banks' Rates Giving Savers Little to Cheer 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
As miserable as returns have been on stocks, investors who seek out the most conservative investments -- money market accounts and certificates of deposit -- have also suffered this year as the rates paid on these savings have dwindled.
 The rate on the average one-year C.D. has fallen to 2.94 percent from 5.33 percent at the start of the year, according to Bankrate.com, a Web site that tracks savings products. It is the lowest since that group began collecting data on rates in 1984. 
 The decline in money market yields is less severe but also steep, falling from 2.11 percent to 1.55 percent. These rates are based on a survey before Federal Reserve policy makers cut short-term rates yesterday for the ninth time this year, pushing them down in total by four percentage points, to a 39-year low. 
The shrinking returns on deposits are especially hard on people who depend on interest income for living expenses, like retirees. Consumers say they have been shopping around, trying to get the best deals possible. But banks have complicated that task, often forcing customers to wade through a menu of different C.D. and money market rates, which can vary depending on factors like the size of your bank balance, where you live and how much other business you do with your bank.
It used to be that there was one regular rate for C.D.s, and then a jumbo C.D. rate, meant to reward customers who committed to locking up large amounts, typically as much as $100,000. Today, many banks offer several rates for the same product. 
Elena Wells, a retired supervisor for New England Telephone living in Medford, Mass., is one of many people getting sticker shock from falling rates. Ms. Wells, who keeps a fair amount of her money in C.D.s or money market savings accounts, was intrigued when a bank representative said in July that she could renew a C.D. at an attractive 4.9 percent rate for one year. There was just one catch: the rate was available only if she opened a $500 checking account at the bank, Houston-based Encore Bank. She complied, she said, when the bank said she did not have to keep a minimum balance.
"We have come up with attractive specials from time to time, in exchange for getting people to do more business with us," said James S. D'Agostino Jr., chief executive of Encore. "For people living on a fixed income, every quarter of a percent helps."
Some consumers also find that the rate they get depends on where they live. "Pricing does vary quite a bit based on geography," said Gordon J. Goetzmann, a senior vice president with the First Manhattan Consulting Group, which analyzes the banking industry. 
This past summer, Wells Fargo customers in Los Angeles were getting just 1.5 percent interest on a money market account requiring a $10,000 minimum deposit, even as the bank was paying twice that in Phoenix, according to Bankrate.com. Recently, that gap has shrunk: as of Sept. 26, the rate in Los Angeles was 1.24 percent, compared with 1.01 percent in Phoenix, according to Bankrate.com.
"Pricing can vary, depending on how competitive a market is," said Leslie L. Altick, head of consumer deposits at Wells Fargo. Still, she said, "local bankers do have discretion to offer higher rates to customers who have been with us a long time." Chase Manhattan, for example, will sometimes offer different rates, depending on whether you have a traditional savings or a premium savings account. Consumers can also purchase a C.D. on the Internet or by phone, through the division of the bank that issues credit cards. 
And recently, Chase had several special offers. In August, Chase customers on Long Island could purchase a tax-deferred C.D. paying 3.65 percent if they were willing to tie up $5,000. Chase is eager to attract customers in the area, thanks to its attractive demographics.
"The idea is to identify who your best customer is and give them the best service," said Beth Hirschhorn, a senior vice president in the retail marketing division at Chase.
Banks in general are willing to pay a little extra to win the long-term loyalty of good customers. While the short-term rates at which banks borrow from the government fell 1.26 percentage points in the second quarter, bank deposit rates fell only 0.65 of a point, according to research by Susan Roth, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. The difference, she said, reflects banks' efforts to compete with brokerage firms and other financial services companies.
Chase and Citigroup say that for some time they have been offering various rate tiers that favor their better customers. But the practice is clearly growing. In January, Bank of America began promoting a money market brokerage account to customers with balances over $100,000 or those who had at least one other business relationship, like a car loan or mortgage, with Bank of America. 
The bank raised the rate on the account to make it more competitive with the average money market mutual fund. Partly because of the promotion, Bank of America's average deposits increased by 3 percent in the second quarter, with money market savings account balances rising 19 percent.
The rate that Bank of America is offering on the account, now 2.99 percent, is nearly double the 1 percent rate offered to a customer with less than $2,500 on deposit. But Bank of America executives say the bank is not shirking smaller customers.
"We think we offer competitive products in every pricing tier," said Barbara DeSoer, who is in charge of the marketing and consumer products divisions.
The good news is that consumers are no longer at the mercy of the rates offered by their local banks. "The biggest change from 10 years ago is the Internet," said Carlos Figueroa, who runs C.D. Desk, a brokerage firm specializing in selling C.D.s to institutional investors. "Consumers are now better informed, and that makes the market much more competitive."
Thanks to Web sites that track rates offered on savings products, like Bankrate.com, it is easier to figure out what your bank is paying at the branch down the block or out of state. 
Some of the best offers come from Internet-only banks, which do not have branches and aim to keep their own costs low.
"For me, my loyalties are not to any one bank," said Ian Gordon-Brown, a foreign exchange currency trader who recently shifted most of his assets to C.D.s offered by IndyMac Bank, a California institution that operates primarily by Internet and phone. "If I can get a half a percentage point higher at another bank, I will put my money there."

HEADLINE: What Energy Shortage?; 
Falling DemandTurns the Oil Patch Upside Down

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
Business was in overdrive at the Apache Corporation earlier this year. Apache, one of the largest independent natural gas and oil companies in the United States, committed to spend close to $900 million this year to find and develop energy resources in North America.
 But now, in the wake of a recent sharp drop in demand for oil and gas -- a decline that is likely to accelerate after the terrorist attacks undermined an already weak economy -- the company is sharply scaling back. Apache reckons it may spend only $300 million for exploration and development in North America next year. 
 "We could do next year what we did this year, but I think we'd be brain dead if we did," said Raymond Plank, Apache's chairman and chief executive. 
Just five months ago, homeowners in California and elsewhere were shocked by the soaring price of electricity and natural gas. The White House warned of a looming energy crisis and called for expanded drilling for oil and gas, even in wildlife reserves, and the construction of one new electricity plant each week for the next 20 years.
Now energy demand and prices have tumbled. Nowhere is that more evident than in what used to be called the nation's "oil patch" and now more accurately the "energy patch." In Texas, Oklahoma and elsewhere, drilling activity is plunging as a shrinking economy, milder weather and competition from other fuels throttle demand for natural gas, causing prices to drop as quickly as they shot up last year.
The decline in spending on exploration and development has many experts worried that the United States will face another supply squeeze when economic growth -- and gas demand -- returns.
Oil prices have also fallen, for some of the same reasons that natural gas prices have tanked. But increasingly, natural gas is more important than oil to the Southwestern "oil patch." While major oil companies invest in large oil projects in West Africa and other sites abroad, the emphasis at home has shifted. In the 1980's, two out of three drilling rigs operating in the United States were drilling for oil; today four out of five are drilling for natural gas.
By and large, natural gas is a continental market -- almost all the gas consumed in North America is produced here -- and there is no OPEC to curtail production when prices drop.
Major oil companies invest long-term to drill in big deepwater oil fields or remote areas like Kazakhstan, where many can make a profit as long as oil costs more than $15 a barrel. (It closed in New York today at $22.79 a barrel.) But much of the gas in the United States and Canada is produced from shallow wells that cost less to sink, so investment is more speculative -- and drillers are quicker to shut them down when prices fall.
That is what is happening now. Across North America, upstream capital spending on natural gas and oil is roughly expected to fall 25 to 40 percent next year, said Art Smith, chief executive of John S. Herold Inc., an energy research and consulting firm in Norwalk, Conn. "Everyone is taking a more cautious view of things," he said.
While some in the industry may spend more in hopes that cold winter weather will cause prices to rebound, Mr. Plank said, "I don't think it behooves one to bet the farm on the weather."
Already, the number of natural gas rigs in the United States has dropped 11 percent from the peak three months ago, to 953, according to Baker Hughes Inc., an oil field services company based here.
Ken Hersh, managing partner of Natural Gas Partners, a $1 billion private equity fund in Dallas that invests in energy companies and properties, predicts the gas rig count could fall as low as 700 -- just enough to keep overall domestic gas production from declining, he said.
Other signs of a slowdown abound. At Global Marine Inc., one of the world's largest offshore drillers, the daily rates charged for 250-foot jackup gas drilling rigs in the Gulf of Mexico have dropped from a peak of $52,000 in May to the low-$20,000 range today.
"Every week it seems like four or five more rigs are being stacked," said Michael Dawson, a vice president at Global Marine, which is based here. He said he had expected the demand for gas, and prices, to rebound in the first quarter of next year, but that is now less likely after the terrorist attacks. "It's harder to say when the inflection point might be," he said.
What remains to be seen, according to many industry experts, is whether prices will whipsaw back up when the economy rebounds. While no one predicts a quick return to a price of $10 per thousand cubic feet -- the peak last winter -- many analysts said they thought demand could quickly outstrip production again in a year or two, increasing prices again.
Before last year, natural gas prices and drilling activity had slumped as warm winters, the Asian recession of 1997-98 and low oil prices made other fuels less expensive.
Gas prices rebounded sharply last year, spurring a modest increase in domestic production, but now that revival in drilling is beginning to slow. This year, production rose by about 500 million cubic feet a day, or just under 1 percent of daily consumption, estimates Ed Kelly, director of North American natural gas research for Cambridge Energy Research Associates. But next year it may increase only another 100 million cubic feet a day, he said. 
"The effect of this decline in drilling could become apparent in six or nine months, just as the economic rebound gets underway," Mr. Kelly said. He expects gas to fetch a little more than $2 per thousand cubic feet in the first half of next year, rising to about $3 by the end of 2002.
The slowdown in the economy and milder weather are also taking a toll on merchant electricity generators, another formerly high-flying industry that has slumped lately as power prices -- in California and elsewhere -- have dropped as demand fell. According to Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Company, an investment bank in Arlington, Va., total domestic electricity output in the week of Sept. 21 was 2.5 percent lower than the same period last year.
Some analysts expect that what had been a headlong rush to build new power plants earlier this year could give way to a period of consolidation -- exemplified last week by Reliant Resources Inc.'s deal to buy Orion Power Holdings Inc. for $2.9 billion -- as shares of some large generators have fallen 40 percent to 60 percent in the last five months.
For the time being, soaring inventories of natural gas have eliminated any concern about supplies. With six weeks remaining for injections of gas into underground storage, the nation had 2.85 trillion cubic feet of gas in inventory on Sept. 21, or about 86 percent of storage capacity, according to the American Gas Association. That is 19 percent more than the same time last year.
But Mr. Hersh notes that prices for gas to be delivered in four or five years are still $3 or higher. While that is lower than what these "forward" prices were earlier this year, they remain about $1 more than the trading range of natural gas forward prices before the volatility of the last few years. "The market is saying, here's a new, sustainable price level that's 50 percent higher than the historical level," he said.
To Mr. Plank, low prices are not the only disincentive to investment in new drilling. Many producers, he said, continue to be scared off by wild price swings that can take the price of a thousand cubic feet of gas on a round trip from $2 to $10 and back to $2 all in the space of a few years. "With this price volatility," he said, "the industry just isn't able to attract sustained investment."

HEADLINE: Fed's Statement on Interest Rates 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates:
 The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points, to 2 1/2 percent. 
In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50-basis-point reduction in the discount rate, to 2 percent. 
 The terrorist attacks have significantly heightened uncertainty in an economy that was already weak. Business and household spending as a consequence are being further damped. Nonetheless, the long-term prospects for productivity growth and the economy remain favorable and should become evident once the unusual forces restraining demand abate. 
The committee continues to believe that against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, St. Louis, Kansas City and San Francisco.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Cheap Credit, Except for Those Who Need It Most

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve made it cheaper yesterday for some people and companies to borrow. But its efforts to stimulate the economy are being hampered by a plunge in consumer confidence and by financial markets that are hesitant to provide money to the companies that need it the most.
 "The Fed easing is not very effective at the moment, because there are powerful things working against the Fed," said Jan Hatzius, an economist at Goldman, Sachs. He pointed to a sharp drop in business investment and said it would probably continue. 
 The Fed's action cut the overnight rate on lending between banks, and was immediately followed by cuts in bank prime rates, which will in turn reduce the rates on some corporate and consumer loans, notably home equity lines of credit. That lowering of costs will save money that may be spent.
The cut was the second since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon three weeks ago, but since then the effective rates for companies with lower-quality credit, so-called junk-bond rates, have risen as investors have grown more worried about an economic slump and a possible increase in corporate bankruptcies. Borrowing is cheaper for companies with good credit but not for others.
Similarly, in the last week, share prices of high-quality companies have recovered a good part of the losses recorded in the week after trading resumed following the attacks. Lower-quality companies have recovered much less and face greater problems if they try to sell stock.
Broadly speaking, companies raise capital for two reasons, because they need the money to pay bills or because they want to make investments that appear attractive. Markets are not eager to provide cash to those who need it the most, and the volume of investment spending has fallen sharply from peak levels because some industries, notably telecommunications and technology, have excess production capacity. That glut is not likely to ease soon, and it is probable that investment spending will follow, not create, an economic recovery.
Still, Wall Street reacted positively to the Fed's cut, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 113.76 points. "As my grandmother would have said, it couldn't hurt," said Paul L. Kasriel, the chief economist of Northern Trust in Chicago. "It's very likely this will, with a lag, stimulate borrowing and spending in the economy."
The economy was probably in recession before the attack, which has shocked companies into making layoffs that many had delayed and seems to have paralyzed consumers, at least temporarily. Just how long those factors will continue is far from clear.
"Planning horizons of everyone we talk to seem pitifully shortened in a manner wholly out of character for such a dynamic economy," said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist with Salomon Smith Barney.
When the shock begins to ease, assuming that there are no new shocks, lower interest rates are likely to have a greater effect.
Many on Wall Street expect that the federal funds rate, the rate at which banks lend to one another and which the Fed can control, has farther to fall. It is 2.5 percent, having been cut from 6.5 percent in the Fed's round of nine cuts. At least one more Fed move, to 2.25 percent, is anticipated this year, and some think the rate will be cut to 2 percent. Fiscal stimulus, through additional government spending or tax cuts, is also considered likely and is deemed desirable by many economists.
For much of the 1990's, consumer optimism played a crucial role in helping the economy weather shocks like the Russian debt default in 1998. Industrial production has now fallen for 11 consecutive months, but surprisingly strong consumer spending kept the economy growing, albeit at a very slow rate, before the attack.
Surveys indicated that consumer confidence was fading even before the attacks. The guess now is how far confidence will fall before it starts to rise, and when that rise might begin. It is not something that anyone is forecasting with confidence.

HEADLINE: Results at News Corporation To Miss ItsFinancial Goals 

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL

 BODY:
Joining the parade of financial woes stemming from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the News Corporation of Australia said yesterday that it would badly miss its main financial goals for its fiscal year.
 Investors had largely expected such an announcement, and the company's American depository receipts rose 79 cents, to $25.68, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 With the announcement, four of the top five "pure play" media companies have indicated since the attacks that they would miss their financial goals. The attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon dashed hopes that the advertising market would rebound soon, prompting not only the News Corporation but also AOL Time Warner, Disney and Viacom to warn that their results would suffer. All four companies derive at least 23 percent of their revenue from United States advertising. 
Of the five top media stocks, only shares of Vivendi Universal of France closed higher yesterday than they did on Sept. 10. Not surprisingly, Vivendi generates a far smaller part of its revenue from United States advertising -- only about 0.75 percent -- than the other four companies do.
"The tragic and senseless events of Sept. 11 exacerbated an already weakening advertising environment, not only in the U.S., but in the U.K. and Australia as well," Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, said in a statement. "Our revised forecast assumes a continuing weak advertising environment for the rest of the calendar year balanced by stringent cost-cutting across all of our businesses and the addition of earnings from the newly acquired Chris-Craft stations."
The News Corporation acquired Chris-Craft Industries and its 10 local television stations in July for $4.4 billion.
In the fiscal year that ends next June, the News Corporation said it now expects to post operating income growth "in the high single-digit to low double-digit range." Previously, the company had predicted operating income growth of 15 percent to 25 percent. The company's Fox Entertainment Group subsidiary, which produces films and television programming, said that it expected growth of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, "in the low- to mid-teens." The previous forecast had been 31 percent to 37 percent growth.
Speaking at a Goldman, Sachs conference in Manhattan, Peter Chernin, the president of the News Corporation, said that almost all the shortfalls stemmed from the poor advertising climate. As television stations of all sorts went to all-news programming in the days after the attacks, they gave up at least $700 million in advertising, analysts said. Moreover, media companies with significant news operations are facing increased costs to cover the ensuing fight against terrorism.
With the collapse of the dot-com bubble and the general slowing of the economy, the advertising market was stagnant for most of the year even before the attacks. Though some experts had predicted that the advertising market would rebound in the late summer, some analysts say that did not happen.
If that is so, it appears that at least some of the big media companies would have missed their financial goals even if the attacks had not occurred. Indeed, the events of Sept. 11 are having significant direct financial effects on the media sector; Mel Karmazin, Viacom's president, said yesterday that his company would lose about $500 million in potential cash flow because of the attacks. Nonetheless, the attacks could shield companies that would have disappointed investors anyway.
"Yes, business was weak to begin with, though things were actually picking up before the Sept. 11 tragedy," said Jessica Reif Cohen, a media analyst at Merrill Lynch, who reduced her estimates for the News Corporation weeks ago. "Can some companies hide behind the Sept. 11 events? Certainly. But News Corp. and Fox are not one of those companies. One day the ad market will turn, and when it does, the companies that are the most leveraged will see the best growth."
But for now, it is not just the titans of the media world that are suffering. After the McGraw-Hill Companies warned on Monday that it would miss its financial goals, its shares dropped sharply yesterday, by $6.40, to $50.50, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Fed Cuts Interest Rates; Talks Intensify on Recovery
The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, to 2.5 percent, the lowest level in 39 years, continuing its effort to pump some vigor back into an economy that has probably lapsed into recession.
 With each day bringing additional evidence that the yearlong deterioration in the economy has intensified since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, the White House and Congress also stepped up their efforts to settle on an economic recovery plan. Page A1. 

Incomplete Trades Affecting Bonds
In the aftermath of the attacks, the Treasury market is still faced with billions of dollars of incomplete trades that traders now say are creating some distortions in the market. C10.

News Corp. to Miss Its Estimates
Joining the parade of financial woes stemming from the terrorist attacks, the News Corporation said that it would miss its main financial goals for its fiscal year. Investors had largely expected such an announcement, and the company's American depository receipts rose 79 cents, to $25.68. Another big media company, Viacom, said that it would lose about $500 million in potential cash flow because of the attacks. C7.

Auto Sales Fall Less Than Expected
Auto sales slumped last month but were better than analysts expected. Still, they think demand will plunge further, leading to more production cuts, plant closings and layoffs. C10.

F.T.C. Shifts Web Privacy Efforts
The Federal Trade Commission will abandon efforts for new laws to enhance online privacy and will concentrate on enforcing existing laws, people close to the matter said. C5.

Stocks Rise on Rate Cut by Fed
Stocks rose after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 113.76 points, or 1.3 percent, to 8,950.59. The Nasdaq composite index gained 11.87 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,492.33. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 12.78 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,051.33. C11.

Nortel to Cut Work Force by 20,000
Nortel Networks said that it was cutting 10,000 jobs and reducing its work force by 10,000 more jobs through the sale of businesses. C2.

Swissair Planes Stop Flying
Swissair stopped flying because it lacked cash to pay for jet fuel and landing fees and feared that its planes would be seized by creditors at foreign airports. A possible reprieve appeared when the Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse agreed to accelerate part of a restructuring plan. World Business, Section W.

How He Came to Love Stocks
Douglas M. Atkin, chief executive of the Instinet Group in New York, said when he was a junior in high school he became an assistant to a broker's assistant at a Merrill Lynch retail branch in Princeton, N.J., fetching coffee and answering phones. "From the moment I started that job, I fell in love with the stock market," he said. The Boss. C9.

F.A.A. to Let Private Craft Move
The Federal Aviation Administration announced plans to allow aircraft like business jets and helicopters to leave 204 airports, heliports and other sites where they have largely been grounded since Sept. 11. C10.

Welch Joins Leveraged Buyout Firm
John F. Welch Jr., the former chairman of General Electric, joined the leveraged buyout firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice. C15.

Airlines Step Up Promotions
As air travel slowly picks up again, the major airlines are promoting lower business-travel fares, tweaking advance-purchase and minimum-stay rules and devising new ways to sell tickets online and through direct e-mail promotions. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C10.

HEADLINE: The Battery Is Down, All Right; 
Once Happily Isolated, an Area Is Now Badly Crippled

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY

 BODY:
Living in Battery Park City today means having the National Guard's steely gaze upon you. It means not being able to have visitors drop in or have food or medications delivered without special permission. It means being cut off from the subway and having to walk two dozen blocks to Canal Street to hail a cab. 
 Living in Battery Park City means not being able to open your own front door without having your identity checked, sometimes as many as five or six times. It means living among trees still heavy with World Trade Center debris, a reminder of the tragedy, as if the smell of the smoldering site across West Street is not enough. 
 It also means hearing the deafening sounds of the recovery effort at close range, and needing to have your apartment "environmentally cleaned and assessed" before it is safe for living. 
"I moved back about a week ago, very optimistic, but it was so disturbing I just couldn't take it," said Craig Reider, a banker. "I made plans to put my wife and kids on a plane to California. The area is certainly not livable, even if it might be safe."
Battery Park City is facing the most extreme challenges of any residential area in the city since the Sept. 11 attack. The future of the 92-acre complex -- built, coincidentally, on a landfill of dirt excavated for the construction of the trade center -- had always seemed tethered to the towers, the neighborhood's major transportation connection to the rest of the city, and its cultural and commercial focal point. Never had that link been fully appreciated until it was severed.
Battery Park City, home to 9,000 residents, had never been known for an abundance of amenities. Now, what little there was is drastically diminished. One of the two large grocery stores, Gristede's, reopened Monday. There is no indication when the other, Sloan's, will be doing business again, it was so badly damaged.
These realities have left residents scurrying to SoHo and Chinatown for basic necessities. They are lonely and isolated in an area that, before the attacks, prized its seclusion. The proximity it enjoyed was to Lower Manhattan office space. Now many of those offices are gone.
Living in Battery Park City means not knowing when or if normalcy will ever return. Occupancy in some of the 20 residential buildings is as low as 31 percent.
"This is way more than an inconvenience, it's a major disaster," said Tom Goodkind, an accountant whose daughter Olivia, 5, broke down and began screaming when they returned to their neighborhood Sunday. The family left immediately.
"They say our apartments are a crime scene," Mr. Goodkind said. "Many people feel the area is a toxic dust bin, our issues are not being addressed and we don't know when or if our neighborhood will ever return."
The Environmental Protection Agency, which has set up at least 17 air monitoring stations in the neighborhood, has declared the air quality to be safe, but many residents remain wary.
Mr. Goodkind said he has slept in five places in the last seven nights with his wife and two little girls, who have been relocated to elementary schools outside of Battery Park City. The sheer expense of living without a home base is beginning to wear on the family, he said. "We are so out of pocket," said Mr. Goodkind, 47. "I can't say how many times I've dry-cleaned the same suit."
Residents were informed at a rancorous meeting Friday night that they would not be required to pay rent for the time spent evacuated from their apartments, and those evacuated from the most badly damaged buildings would get one month rent-free. The announcement drew a brief burst of applause. But will it entice many renters to stay?
"The biggest problem is that people saw some terrible things," said Donald Scherer, the president of the newly created Battery Park City Residents' Association. "It's a scary place and will be a scary place for a while."
At the meeting, many displaced residents screamed questions at representatives of the Battery Park City Authority, which leases land to developers, and at Jamie LeFrak of the LeFrak Corporation, a major landlord. They wanted to know about breaking leases.
"This is the biggest challenge our company has ever faced," Mr. LeFrak said.
He said the offer of a month's free rent was "to give people the opportunity to not have to make hasty decisions about their life and to give them a chance to come back without the stress and pressure of paying a rent bill."
As for breaking leases, he said, "We're handling it on a case by case basis."
Andrew V. Brisker, for one, wants to leave. A restaurant wine director who lives in Gateway Plaza, he said: "My apartment is completely trashed. That plus the mental trauma and having no place to find food, I have no desire to go back there. I can't live there. I just can't do it anymore."
To that end, he and other residents are organizing themselves and seeking legal advice. They plan soon to present their cases collectively to landlords and building managers.
Another Battery Park City resident, Karon Abe, has already found a new place to live on the Upper East Side, although it pained her to leave her favorite spot in the city.
"There are no services, no subways," said Ms. Abe, 32, a research scientist. "It's just depressing. People are really upset. Our building is open, but we chose not to go back." Ms. Abe's husband, Rhett Laurens, an investment adviser, called the area "logistically a nightmare."
It will take years for the No. 1 and 9 subway lines to be rebuilt, transit officials said. In the meantime, bus service is being expanded. On Monday, a bus shuttle service began running a loop around the northern part of Battery Park City.
"If they give us more streets to roll on we'll roll on them," said Al O'Leary, spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. "We are prepared once the N.Y.P.D., the F.B.I. and everybody else gives us the go-ahead."
When that will be is unclear.
Ms. Abe and Mr. Laurens could not wait indefinitely, they said, so they found a new home. Just last month, they had decided that there was no better place to begin their married life than Battery Park City. Their love for it was instant, Ms. Abe said, "a neighborhood with a personality so unexpected, it was almost like you weren't in New York."
Some of their neighbors, however, considered it the epitome of New York, with its sweeping view of the harbor and the Statue of Liberty, its closeness to the World Trade Center, its parks teeming with soccer players and sunbathers.
Diane Crupain's bedroom window framed the twin towers. "Battery Park City was our happy little haven, safe and landscaped," she said. "You could have the sunsets all to yourself on the water. We thought it was perfect."
That serenity has been shattered, at least for now.
"In the long term, it will come back," said Representative Jerrold Nadler, who represents the area in Congress. He said a task force of local elected officials had already put mobile health vans on the street, organized shuttles to grocery stores, and worked to deliver a consistent stream of information to residents.
Since its development in the late 1960's and 1970's, Battery Park City had become popular with young families, single men and women working in the financial district, and people who wanted to live in Lower Manhattan but feel as if they were somewhere else. Its modern residential buildings, copper-topped office towers and pristine riverfront parks made the area some of the most valuable real estate in the city. 
"I think it's a little early to be able to predict the long term beyond maybe a year, but I think the area will be back and stronger," said Timothy S. Carey, president and chief executive of the Battery Park City Authority.
Mr. Carey said he is speaking with all levels of government officials to make sure that Battery Park City has a large share of whatever economic stimulus package is planned for Lower Manhattan. 
Construction continues on the Ritz Carlton Hotel and residences, and will soon resume on two other sites: another tower, and a memorial to victims of the Irish potato famine, Mr. Carey said. 
Fast action is crucial, Mr. Scherer says. "The key is to give people information so they can plan for the future," he said. 
The residents' association's main complaint has been a lack of information from city officials about when buildings, roads and schools will reopen.
"If things are uncertain, people are going to leave," Mr. Scherer said. "If they leave, then the businesses close. If the businesses close, then more people will leave.
"It's a downward spiral," he said, "and that's how neighborhoods die."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FINANCIAL DISTRICT; 
Signs Differ For Future Of Business

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Sifting through the wreckage in Lower Manhattan for clues about the future, city officials, urban planners and real estate brokers are finding plenty of seemingly conflicting signs.
 Lehman Brothers, a major presence before the terrorist attack on the trade center, signed a lease last weekend for office space at 399 Park Avenue in Midtown and is sending hundreds of employees to new quarters in Jersey City. Although Lehman is also negotiating to take over a building downtown at 180 Water Street, many fear that the decisions by Lehman and other banks to sign long-term leases outside the neighborhood suggest a diminished financial presence in Lower Manhattan. 
 But last week, the New York Life Insurance Company provided a $68 million mortgage for a newly completed 27-story apartment house in Battery Park City, where workers and residents are still clearing away dust and debris from the trade center attack. Because the deal comes so soon after the attack, landlords regard it as a vote of confidence in Lower Manhattan. 
Both of these events provide a glimpse of Lower Manhattan's future, said Hugh O'Neil, president of Appleseed, an economic development consultant.
Investment banks and insurance companies have been migrating for decades to Midtown from the traditional financial district centered around Wall Street. And in recent years, Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber, Goldman Sachs, U.S. Trust, Cigna and others have moved some operations to the New Jersey waterfront as rents soared in Manhattan.
Those trends are bound to continue, Mr. O'Neil said, as displaced companies make decisions about where to situate employees
Mr. O'Neil, some landlords and many urban planners said that the city should continue to encourage the trend and do whatever it can to keep the financial services companies at least in Manhattan, if not downtown. Certainly the New York Stock Exchange, Nasdaq, the American Stock Exchange and the Depository Trust are staying put.
In the mid- to late-1990's, developers built about 7,000 apartments in old office buildings downtown and built hundreds of others at Battery Park City, and restaurants, museums and stores began to spring up. The Alliance for Downtown New York, the business improvement district for 14,000 companies in the area, promoted the ideas of a 24-hour community and tourism, even as it struggled successfully to keep the New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street.
Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance, emphasized the need to keep the financial core.
"In rebuilding Lower Manhattan it's important to provide the short-term financial incentives and space for financial companies to remain and grow so that the mutual dependence between business and residences can be maintained and strengthened," he said.
Frank J. Ollari, senior managing director of New York Life Investment Management, said he was confident in the future of residential development downtown.
"The building had been virtually fully leased before the attack," Mr. Ollari said. "We expect some of the tenants will not return, but others will take their place."
H. Henry Elghanyan of Rockrose said: "Some of those who moved to New Jersey are probably not going to come back. But there'll be others to replace them. New York is not going into a tailspin."
The Bank of New York has leased space at more than a dozen buildings in Midtown. Merrill Lynch, which had two buildings at the World Financial Center, has moved thousands of employees to Jersey City, Hopewell Junction and other places in New Jersey where the company had vacant space that it expected to rent to others. American Express, which was also at the World Financial Center, has leased office space in New Jersey and in Stamford, Conn.
After the attack, real estate executives estimated that 30 million square feet of downtown office space had been destroyed or seriously damaged. But it now appears that at least some of the damaged buildings will reopen sooner than expected. Brookfield Financial Properties is replacing 650 panes of glass in its tower at 1 Liberty Plaza and expects to be open in three weeks.
Richard Clark, president of Brookfield, hopes to have the tower at 1 World Financial Center ready in about seven weeks. There was no damage at 4 World Financial Center, which is leased by Merrill Lynch.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday: "We're making progress in getting some of those buildings open that are in the World Financial Center. Merrill Lynch, for example, now has a schedule date of being open by Oct. 22. The other buildings that are there will take longer, more in the 10, 12-week category."

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
An Injured City

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
Will the terror attack permanently damage New York's position as America's economic capital? No sentimentality, please, despite the mock headline in The Onion, "Rest of Country Temporarily Feels Deep Affection for New York." This is a real question and deserves a serious answer. 
 The reason it's a real question is that the economy of a city is different from that of the nation as a whole. Not only are America's resources -- above all the energy and skill of its work force -- almost entirely intact; they aren't going anywhere. We may go through a recession, during which some of those resources will temporarily be idled; but there is no question that the U.S. economy will eventually put its resources back to work. 
 But the resources of New York don't have to stay where they are. And it's conceivable that they won't.
 After all, America's pre-eminent city owes its position to historical accident. The natural advantages of New York -- its fine harbor, its location at the terminus of the only possible canal route to the Great Lakes -- were real enough during the city's rise. But those natural advantages have long since ceased to be important to the city's economy. What keeps New York a great city is circular causation; people and businesses locate there because of the opportunities created by the presence of other people and businesses.
 And because the city's economy is sustained by circular causation, a sufficiently large blow to that economy could in theory do permanent damage. If enough businesses and people leave, for whatever reason, the local economy could fall below critical mass and enter a downward spiral in which businesses leave because other businesses are leaving. 
The beneficiaries of such an exodus would probably not be other great cities; instead, businesses would move out into the endless sprawl. I was not the only person in suburban New Jersey who, somewhat to my shame, felt perfectly safe on Sept. 11: there are millions of people living and working nearby, but no obvious targets, because there's no there here.
 The question is, how large a blow would be needed to start such a spiral? How robust are cities, anyway?
 A researcher with vast power and few scruples could try to answer that question experimentally; he could destroy large sections of a city, then see if it recovered. (Maybe that's what Robert Moses was up to!) But in real life people wouldn't perform such an experiment -- or would they? 
Two economists at Columbia University, Donald Davis and David Weinstein, recently pointed out that America actually has tried that experiment -- on someone else's cities. Their paper, the product of many months of work, arrived with spooky timing. Titled "Bones, bombs, and break points: The geography of economic activity," it points out that the U.S. bombing campaign against Japan in the closing months of World War II constituted a sort of gruesome natural experiment testing the robustness of cities. 
 The important point for their analysis is not just that the bombing campaign was immensely destructive -- 56 square miles of Tokyo were entirely leveled, which as a proportion of the built-up area was only average for Japanese cities -- but that it was highly variable in its impact. Some cities escaped with only minor damage, while others were largely destroyed. The question they ask is whether the heavily damaged cities recovered to their prewar place in Japan's urban hierarchy, or whether they entered into a downward spiral.
 Their answer is slightly discouraging for economists who would like to verify theories about circular causation, but very encouraging for those who believe that New York's special, intense urbanism yields benefits to the nation that go beyond dollars and cents. Even in postwar Japan there were no downward spirals, and cities quickly returned to their original positions in the urban hierarchy. "Even large temporary shocks to urban areas," declare the authors, "have no long-run impact on city sizes." It seems cities are very robust indeed. 
 That doesn't mean that New York's future is assured -- while cities are very persistent, they do rise and fall over time. But if the Japanese parallel is at all relevant, the attack on New York, for all its horror, will have no effect worth mentioning on the city's long-run economic prospects.

HEADLINE: Liberties; 
All That Glistens

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The shiny red and silver Neiman Marcus Christmas catalog just arrived.
 It makes you a little sick and a little wistful. Even though it was printed only a month ago, it now seems as detached from the moment as cave drawings, a document of an extinct culture that reveled without apology in the trivial and gaudy, pushing luxury to absurd heights. 
 A simple hanger could not suffice when there was a $65 mink hanger "too beautiful to tuck away in a closet." 
A simple jean jacket could not suffice when there was a $2,785 jean jacket with rabbit collar and cuffs.
A simple baby carriage could not suffice when there was a $4,250 Burberry pram with matching $375 diaper bag. 
Simple black stockings could not suffice when there was a $500 pair with cultured fresh-water pearls hand-beaded on the lace border. (And when they run, do you salvage the pearls for an anklet?)
The only camouflage we were concerned with back then was designer camouflage cargo pants and lingerie, offering a frisson of danger to lives that were smugly unthreatened.
And there's Neiman's famous big-ticket fantasy item: your own $6.7 million Bell helicopter to fly you to black-tie parties. (Remember when flying wasn't terrifying?)
America has developed an aversion to consumer overindulgence at the very moment our leaders tell us the only way to prevail against the terrorists and prop up our economy is through consumer overindulgence.
Who could have predicted that the first war of the 21st century would be about stuff?
Past wars were fought to expand empires. But the new invaders want to explode our empire.
The puritanical Islamic warriors hate our stuff and think us decadent hedonist infidels who have lost our souls. "The Americans are fighting so they can live and enjoy the material things in this life," a Taliban spokesman said. "But we are fighting so we can die in the cause of Allah." 
As Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, once said: "Life can be led with just a few basics. The luxuries don't matter."
The terrorists don't want our stuff -- they lived among us and resisted being seduced by it. They don't want us to have our stuff. And they don't want our stuff to taint their holy lands; they want to banish our planes and equipment and MTV culture from the Persian Gulf.
America is still stunned that our sophisticated stuff could not protect us, that our trillion dollars' worth of weapons, radars and satellites all fell flat against a few brutes with box cutters. 
And now we are battling a bunch of atavistic ascetics who hate TV, music, movies, the Internet (except when they're planning atrocities), women and Jews, who live in caves in a country smaller than Texas with a gross domestic product smaller than Bill Gates's.
Up until the moment the twin towers fell, America was deep in a cocoon of self-gratification and self-improvement. We were on a giddy odyssey of self-actualization, epitomized by the headlines in Oprah's magazine: "Feel Good Naked: A fabulous 10-point plan, no diet required." 
Now we have to view our solipsism and wretched excess through the prism of the "epic wretchedness" of the Afghan people, as The Times's Barry Bearak called it. It's somewhat embarrassing that we didn't look outward sooner, that foreign wars got less TV air time than the war against wrinkles.
But our culture turns out to be about much more than its glittery surface, and that's been clear in all that's happened since Sept. 11: the exposure to the quiet lives of inspiration that so many victims led; the valor of rescue workers; the altruistic derring-do of the men who fought back on Flight 93; our concern about inflicting unnecessary suffering on innocent Afghans; the generosity and civic tolerance at the heart of our country's response to horrific loss.
With their oxymoronic holy war, Osama bin Laden and his murderous disciples meant to expose our moral vacuity. But they exposed only their own. 
They simply succeeded in illuminating -- not just to the rest of the world but to us -- how little all our baubles and all our booty have to do with who we really are.
The terrorists taught us this: We are more than the sum of our stuff.

HEADLINE: From Taiwan, a Fear of China Technology 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HSINCHU, Taiwan 

 BODY:
Morris Chang was born in China, but unlike some Chinese emigres, he feels little desire to return.
 "There's a big gap between what I'm used to and what China has become," Mr. Chang said in an interview at his company, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, which sits at the heart of a vast science park here, about 40 miles south of Taipei, the capital. 
 In addition to being a longtime China skeptic, Mr. Chang, 70, is arguably the most influential technology executive in Taiwan. He has often spoken of his belief that China, despite becoming a hotbed of computer manufacturing, was not ready to compete in the more advanced business of integrated circuits. 
So when he declared recently that the future of the world's chip industry lies not in Taiwan or the United States, but in China, political and business leaders sat up and took notice.
Mr. Chang's conversion was well timed. On Sept. 17, China cleared the last hurdle in its 15-year quest to enter the World Trade Organization or its predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The next day, Taiwan also received formal clearance to join the W.T.O., the club of trading nations. Experts say this will accelerate China's emergence as a technology power. It will also deepen the commercial ties between the mainland and Taiwan.
Mr. Chang's change of heart is the latest sign of how deeply China's economic rise is roiling its cousin across the Taiwan Strait. What started in the 1980's as a trickle of companies moving to the mainland has become a torrent as the initial wave of small-time garment and footwear makers eager to tap China's cheap labor spreads to Taiwan's biggest and most advanced companies.
For years Mr. Chang, the founder and chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor, was not impressed by all the talk of a new economic giant in the East. He says he believed -- based on a career at Texas Instruments, and 16 years in Taiwan helping to build its technology industry -- that China was not yet ready to succeed in silicon.
But that was before Shanghai became home to two chip ventures started by Taiwan entrepreneurs. One of those, Semiconductor Manufacturing International, is run by a former rival, Richard Chang, who sold his Taiwan operations to Taiwan Semiconductor last year. Richard Chang, who is not related to Morris, has since lured away 50 of Taiwan Semiconductor's engineers.
"I thought it would be very tough for these ventures to succeed," Morris Chang said between long pulls on his pipe. "But then our engineers started going over to them. That changed my thinking."
Now, Mr. Chang is rushing to establish a liaison office for Taiwan Semiconductor in Shanghai. He says his company, the world's largest contract manufacturer of chips, is likely to build plants on the mainland.
Even Taiwan's government, which has tried to stem the exodus with strict limits on the amount of money that local companies can invest in China, now recognizes that its commercial future is tied to China's.
"We see the need for Taiwanese firms to expand into China," said Tsai Ing-wen, the head of the government's Mainland Affairs Council. "A lot of people say Taiwan has to open up -- otherwise its economy will suffer. There is a need to establish momentum."
A few weeks ago, Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, accepted the recommendation of a government-business commission to scrap a $50 million limit on investments in China by Taiwan companies. The decision ends a policy known as "go slow, be patient," adopted by Mr. Chen's predecessor, Lee Teng-hui, who viewed the flow of capital to China as a threat to Taiwan's security.
In some ways, the lifting of investment curbs is just a recognition of reality. Hundreds of smaller companies circumvent the $50 million limit by registering their China ventures outside Taiwan, in havens like the Cayman Islands. Larger companies in strategic industries, which found it harder to skirt the rules, had put intense pressure on President Chen to do away with them.
Business leaders are also pressing him to lift a ban on direct trade and transportation links with China. The 50-year-old ban forces Taiwan companies with operations on the mainland to route supplies through Hong Kong, as well as employees making trips from Taipei to Shanghai.
"We just cannot wait any longer for direct airline routes to mainland China," said Daniel Wu, the president of EVA Airways.
Ms. Tsai, however, said establishing direct links was a thornier issue than lifting investment curbs because it raised questions of sovereignty. Beijing has demanded that Taipei recognize the existence of a single China before the two can negotiate. President Chen, whose party formally espouses an independent Taiwan, has refused to accept the "one China" principle.
How long Mr. Chen can hold out is a matter of debate. Taiwan is in an economic crisis, which began earlier this year with the collapse of technology industries in the United States and has worsened with the recent attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
In August, Taiwan's export orders plunged 16.7 percent as its main customers in the United States cut back sharply. Unemployment figures for August are expected to surpass 5 percent, and years of economic growth, even during the Asian crisis of 1997-98, have evolved into the likelihood of a recession.
Taiwan Semiconductor, which a year ago was lamenting its inability to meet the surging demand for chips, typifies the reversal of fortunes. Operations at its factories, which had been running overtime late in 2000, tumbled in the second quarter of this year to 44 percent of capacity.
Mr. Chang said his company's monthly sales hit bottom in May and June and predicted that they would rebound next year. But analysts said the terrorist attacks, and the prospect of military retaliation, make any revival in 2002 uncertain.
Indeed, the specter of protracted economic weakness in the United States will add to the pressure on Taiwan companies to move to China, where the labor pool is larger and cheaper.
"Taiwanese chip companies have to manufacture in China to be globally competitive," said Su Chi, a former head of the Mainland Affairs Council who advises the now opposition Nationalist Party.
Few countries have China's combination of low-cost and plentiful workers at many levels of expertise. Taiwan's universities produce 4,000 engineers a year; China turns out 145,000. A trained engineer in Shanghai costs one-third to one-quarter that of one in Taipei, according to Credit Lyonnais.
In the past, Mr. Chang said China was handicapped by a lack of infrastructure. He said that China -- even with its platoons of engineers -- lacked the companies that produce the raw materials for silicon wafers and the skilled labor to build and run advanced chip factories.
Now, Mr. Chang says, China can easily surmount these weaknesses. He noted that the Beijing authorities were dangling rich incentives, like cheap land and tax breaks, to lure semiconductor producers from Taiwan and elsewhere. Chip ventures also enjoy powerful political support.
The most talked-about foray from Taiwan into China, Grace Semiconductor Manufacturing, is a joint venture of Winston Wang, the son of a powerful Taiwan industrialist, and Jiang Mianheng, son of China's president, Jiang Zemin. The two are building a $1.63 billion wafer factory outside Shanghai.
Mr. Chang, who prizes his place atop the corporate pyramid, seems rattled by the prospect of being left behind. "Even if Taiwan companies did not go to China, even if no other foreign companies were interested," he said, "they could always do it themselves. You can pick up the low-end expertise pretty easily."
There are still a few brakes on China's chip industry. Restrictions on the exporting of advanced technology from the United States mean that the latest technology -- etching chips on 12-inch wafers -- cannot be done in mainland Chinese factories. 
But that leaves many simpler memory and logic chips that can be produced there. And analysts think that with China about to enter the World Trade Organization, the export controls will eventually disappear.
This will make the global chip industry, which has fallen into recession roughly every five years since 1970, even more cutthroat.
Since the early 1980's, when Japanese companies aggressively entered the market for memory chips, Mr. Chang said, these boom-and-bust cycles have been precipitated by new competitors, like companies from South Korea and Taiwan, building factories. 
As painful as the current recession is, Mr. Chang said he worried even more about the next one, when China's factories will be churning out chips.
"They will be enormously disruptive in about five years," he said. "I wish they would go away, but they're not going away."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SKIES; 
Debate on Air Security Fixes on Federal Role

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ and MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
The White House and both houses of Congress struggled today to agree on legislation that would tighten aviation security, as divisions remained over whether the federal government would run the whole security effort or just supervise it.
 The legislation under negotiation would upgrade equipment, install bulletproof cockpit doors and employ well-trained, well-paid airport security screeners. The Senate version would make the screeners federal employees. But the House version would not, and companies that now screen passengers are lobbying to keep the work in their hands. 
 The plan also calls for expanding the number of air marshals and gradually increasing their presence on flights.
Like the legislation, airline industry recommendations, made on Monday by an aviation task force appointed by the transportation secretary soon after the hijackings of Sept. 11, called for better cockpit doors. But they also raised new security questions, including whether the people who have been searching empty jetliners for weapons daily since Sept. 11 are qualified to do so.
The task force laid out some quick remedies, among them the use of passwords to get through the cockpit door. It suggested that in any attempted takeover of an aircraft, flight attendants be left on their own, with no help from the pilots. The flight attendants would, however, have access to "nonlethal" weapons. 
At every level, the shape of air security seemed to be in flux today, three weeks after the hijackings. Congressional Democrats have led the push for full federal assumption of the security job. House Republicans say federal employees should oversee the work but not do it. Other open questions are how much the security effort will cost and how much passengers will be charged to pay for it.
Though lawmakers remained divided, Congress was under pressure to reach a deal, and officials said the White House appeared to be moving toward those advocating a greater degree of federal involvement.
Senators Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said there was broad consensus in the Senate to nationalize security at all major airports, and argued that anything short of that would simply maintain the status quo. Mr. Hollings initially wanted to see security at all airports federalized but now says he is amenable to federalizing it only at the largest ones, a number somewhere between 140 and 200.
Smaller airports would have to comply with whatever stricter standards emerged from the new legislation but, with the help of federal financing, might be able to use local law enforcement agencies rather than federal workers to carry out the functions.
"The current situation is not acceptable," Mr. McCain said. "Let's see at least partial federalization."
But the executives of companies that now do the work came to Washington to argue that even if their past performance was poor, no one was ready to replace them. "We are going to be the trainers anyway," said Lior Zouker, president and chief executive of International Consultants on Targeted Security. "Let us train the right people." 
Along with competitors, Mr. Zouker asked that his company be hired by the federal government, not the airlines, and be brought up to higher standards of training and performance instead of being ordered by airlines to perform at minimal cost.
But advocates of federalization said making security a government function would also allow for a greater exchange of information among federal agencies, a benefit that they said could help identify and stop terrorists.
Like ideas for security on the ground, plans for security aloft were hardly settled. The panel of aviation experts that reported to the transportation secretary on Monday crossed into some areas that no one seems to have a conclusive judgment about, among them whether a crew trying to foil hijackers should intentionally depressurize the plane in flight or perhaps put it into a dive.
"While we do not openly recommend it," the panel's report said, "we acknowledge that aircraft defensive maneuvering and aggressive use of cabin pressure systems may be beneficial under certain extreme situations."
But it said that "any proposals must be validated for effectiveness and trainability before implementation."
The report also recommended barring passengers from "loitering" near the forward galley and lavatory, typically adjacent to the cockpit door, and leaving open the curtains that hang between cabins, so cabin crews can see what is going on in the whole plane. Flight attendants would also stop serving beverages before takeoff, so they could concentrate on boarding the passengers. 
Putting a video camera in the cabin would be a good idea to keep the pilots informed, the panel found, but finding a place in the cockpit for the monitoring screen would be a challenge.
The security legislation, meanwhile, is becoming entangled with other concerns. Setting up a possible battle with Republicans, the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said today that he wanted the bill to include a provision to help workers who have been laid off by the airlines and airplane manufacturers. The legislation would be aimed at those workers ineligible for unemployment or extended insurance coverage.
"It is our hope we can agree to that specific package," Mr. Daschle said.
The minority leader, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, said he would be willing to consider a narrowly tailored package.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE BUDGET; 
City's Budget Is Battered In the Aftermath of Attack

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
The attack on the World Trade Center has doubled the city's projected budget gap to roughly $4 billion, forcing the Giuliani administration to order all agencies to curtail spending.
 Some city and state officials are now calculating that just to clear the damage, they will ask the federal government for $40 billion or more, twice the amount already approved. In addition, they would also like federal help to stem losses in tax revenues caused by the attacks. 
 Many of the expenses related to the cleanup, like the overtime for firefighters and police officers and the removal of the wreckage, will likely be covered by the federal aid. But the concurrent sharp decline in revenue from thousands of fewer tourists and the loss of businesses in Lower Manhattan will cut deeply into the next mayor's budget, almost certainly leading to abandonment of many promises made along the campaign trail for things like housing and smaller class sizes. 
To the veterans of the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's and the severe cutbacks at the beginning of the last decade that led to dirtier streets, deteriorating schools and the exodus of many professionals to the suburbs, the economic forecast this time threatens to undercut much of the successes of the last several years. 
"We think this is going to be as bad as the early 1990's, if not worse," said Charles Brecher, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a civic research organization. "We were already saying that a new mayor would have big budget problems, but there are added problems now. Outside of the immediate losses, the mayor has to deal with restoring the psychological sense of security, which has implications for keeping business here. Housing plans will have to be rethought. I think everything will be on the table now." 
The gap for the 2003 fiscal year, which begins in July, was already expected to be between $2 billion and $2.5 billion because of a softening economy, bloating debt load and impending labor negotiations. Now that is likely to grow to $4 billion, analysts and city officials predicted. 
Estimates of the costs related to the disaster are staggering: $5 billion to remove the debris, $14 billion to rebuild the area, $3 billion for overtime for uniform workers and $1 billion to replace destroyed vehicles and equipment. Fire Department accident response vehicles, for instance, are $400,000 each.
How much money the city will get from the federal government remains unclear, but some expenses will be picked up by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
The city had already been promised part of $20 billion in new federal aid, but city officials have revised their estimated need to $40 billion, and the state's calculations are shifting even higher. New York City officials have already met twice with Bush administration aides to discuss the city's financial needs, and they are working now, along with the state, to come up with a detailed estimate of the costs. City and state officials plan to present their proposals to the New York Congressional delegation in the next several days, but both Democratic and Republican congressmen say they expect an uphill battle in trying to get billions more in aid. Congressional Republicans had already resisted approving the initial package of $20 billion.
"It is a steep cliff we're climbing; that's why it's going to be critical for there to be consensus among us New Yorkers," said Representative John Sweeney, an upstate Republican who is close to Gov. George E. Pataki and helps oversee appropriations. 
Senator Charles E. Schumer said that the New York delegation recognized how tough it would be, but added: "We will have opposition. But so far the support has been overwhelming. I hope and pray it stays that way."
As for the White House, Adam Barsky, the city's budget director, said the Bush administration had encouraged city officials to present economic development plans, which he said was a stark contrast to Gerald Ford's infamous response to the city's fiscal crisis in the 1970's. 
New York is likely to suffer the most long-lasting financial effects in areas like the falloff in tourism, depleted personal and corporate tax revenue and a possible downward spiral of real estate taxes. Mitigating factors, like the increase in construction and a successful bond issue, could staunch some losses.
But city and state officials are not taking any chances, and are already angling for ways to get the federal government to take the unusual step of reimbursing the city not just for expenses, but also for a loss of revenues. There is some precedent for Washington making up lost toll revenue after a state is hit by a natural disaster, but there is less precedent for reimbursements for corporate and personal tax losses. "FEMA's policy has been to not reimburse for those types of revenue losses," Mr. Brecher said. 
But the city plans to make the case that unlike a hurricane, the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center was really an attack on the country, and that therefore the federal government should take up more of the bill. "It is very important that there be a recognition that a significant cost of the attack will be a direct and indirect loss of revenues," Mr. Barsky said. "If the city is unable to get full reimbursement for all of its cost including those lost revenues, there will be difficult choices that have to be made."
The Giuliani administration had already asked agencies to come up with $500 million in reductions in anticipation of shortfalls from the state, and is pressing them for real proposals to make cuts, officials said. The administration is also examining programs that can be cut and other ways to trim costs, but doesn't plan to seek layoffs for now.
City officials and independent budget analysts concede that the future is uncertain. For instance, it is not yet clear whether hotel occupancy rates, which have fallen by 40 percent to 80 percent since the attack, will remain low, along with other aspects of the tourist industry. 
Some losses, like the roughly $1 million a day lost to meter revenues and parking tickets since the attack, will be limited in the normal course of things, once the city drops its car-pooling regulations and reinstates alternate-side-of-the-street parking. And the effect on the city's real estate tax base is entirely unpredictable. 
"The long term issues are clearly unresolved," said Colleen Woodell, managing director in the public finance department of Standard & Poor's.
The federal government has already set aside $20 billion for recovery efforts in New York City, northern Virginia and Pennsylvania. The first $10 billion will be distributed at the president's discretion among the three sites and the rest will be assigned by Congress later. And lawmakers are studying the appropriation bill carefully, trying to ascertain what expenses can be picked up with it.
But New York is already asking for another $20 billion that it insists is needed to cover losses. Among them are increased pay for the families of the dead, rebuilding the city's office of emergency management -- for $150 million -- and heavily increased security around the city. The city also may find itself with increased applications for financial help; 1,369 people applied for food stamps or emergency funds so far. 
Outside of the government aid and various funds set up by the city to assist victims' families, other factors may come into play. As insurance proceeds flow into the marketplace and construction begins, the boost to the city's economy may resemble what happens in cities that suffer natural disasters. The city issued a bond whose proceeds will be used to rebuild businesses downtown, and yesterday it received $2 billion in orders from institutional investors, on top of the $387 million sold Monday to individual investors, making it the biggest city bond sale ever, Mr. Giuliani said. 
The mayoral candidates have offered their own proposals for rebuilding the city's financial health. The Democrats, Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer, have talked about creating a panel of business leaders and others to come up with a detailed plan, and Mr. Ferrer said yesterday that he would immediately begin construction of lost office space and complete construction and rehabilitation of at least 10 million square feet of office space within two years. "The next administration will have to come up with a long-term plan to deal with this," said Jeffrey Sommer, acting executive director of the Financial Control Board.
