HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
WYNDHAM HOTEL CHAIN WI LL LAY OFF 1,600 EMPLOYEES

BYLINE:  Reuters

 BODY:
 The Wyndham International hotel chain said yesterday that it was laying off or furloughing 1,600 of its employees, or about 5 percent of its work force of about 28,000, because of an industrywide slowdown. 
Wyndham, an operator or owner of about 240 upscale hotels, said it hoped to bring some of those workers back on the payroll as demand increased. The company said 20 percent of its 27,000 employees who work at hotels were working reduced hours until occupancies rise. The company is delaying capital projects, but will finish work on the Wyndham Newark Airport property this year in New Jersey.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: France:Consumers Lose Confidence 

BYLINE:  By Kerry Shaw (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Consumer confidence in France fell in September to its lowest level since May 1998, the French statistics institute said. 
The index dropped to minus 15 in September from minus 10 in July, the last month it was published. The institute said that about 44 percent of the confidence survey was conducted before the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States. The report follows the institute's French business confidence index, which fell to its lowest point in five years last Thursday. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

HEADLINE: WINE TALK; 
The Hammer Comes Down On Wine On the Net

BYLINE:  By Frank J. Prial

DATELINE: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 2 

 BODY:
It was supposed to be the biggest wine auction in history.
 With almost a million bottles on the block, some of them prized rarities like 1921 Chateau d'Yquem and 1928 Chateau Lafite-Rothschild, it was to be a sale destined for the record books. 
 Held in a cavernous airplane hangar at the Napa Airport last Saturday and Sunday, the auction was expected to raise most of the $10.6 million owed by the defunct online wine retailer Wine.com. The wine, some 80,000 cases of it valued at $7.4 million, plus paraphernalia like glasses, decanters and storage racks valued at more than $2 million, were all that remained of Wine.com's assets.
But any hopes that the sale would pull in anything near the sums predicted were dashed when only about 300 people showed up on Saturday. Sunday's attendance was similar. "We had planned on about 6,000," said Roger Sanford, the chief marketing officer of Realm Connect, the parent company of AuctioNet, which conducted the sale. As the bidding wore down Sunday afternoon, Mr. Sanford acknowledged that the sale would bring in "only a fraction" of the $10 million that organizers had hoped for. 
A major part of the problem, of course, was timing: there was understandably little interest in investing in wine, or in flying to an auction, after the terrorist attacks three weeks ago. But the Wine.com liquidation was also dramatic evidence of how far interest in online wine has slipped. When even such a large array of bargains fails to attract many buyers, it's clear that, for the time being at least, the once-promising future of Internet wine sales is a thing of the past.
Wine.com was one of the largest online wine merchants. Much of its money was invested at a time when wine prices were at historically high levels. Wine.com was one of the few Internet services that kept large wine inventories, even while the economy was slowing and buyers were drifting away from online wine.
Restrictive government regulations also made business difficult. Wine.com wanted to ship to every state, and so it made expensive deals with distributors and retailers to accept and deliver the wine. Smaller online businesses, like eVineyard, are content to sell only where wine can be shipped across state lines. 
Anyone familiar with rare-wine auctions conducted by traditional auction houses would have been startled by the scene last weekend. Instead of dulcet-toned British auctioneers out of central casting, they would have heard Nuri Otus, the chief auctioneer, urging on his audience with, "C'mon, ladies and gentlemen, a buck a bottle, a buck a bottle."
Mr. Otus, the chief executive of Realm Connect, sounds, at full cry, just like the old Lucky Strike tobacco auctioneer on radio. He said that this was his first wine auction, but with occasional lapses, like making Haut-Brion "oat Brion," he quickly rose to the occasion, pushing old Lafite and Mouton with all the fervor of Christie's legendary wine auctioneer Michael Broadbent.
While pre-auction attention was focused on the rare wines on the block, most of the almost 3,000 lots were made up of large quantities of inexpensive wines, many from little-known producers. There were, for example, some 15,000 bottles of Beaujolais, 8,000 of St.-Veran, 8,000 of Anjou blanc and thousands of bottles of Austrian and Australian wines, most of them from unfamiliar wine makers and shippers.
Many wines sold for as little as 10 cents on the dollar. Most of these wines were purchased by dealers who were vague when asked what would be done with them. Before the auction, several wine-trade figures said they feared the wines would be dumped on the market at exceptionally low prices, undercutting conventional stocks. At the auction buyers predicted that that is exactly what would happen.
To prevent some of these wines from reaching the market at distress prices, a number of wine makers and distributors were allowed to buy back, before the auction and at wholesale prices, wines they had sold to Wine.com before the bankruptcy.
There were two groups of bidders: professionals interested in the large lots and collectors interested in the old bottles. As often happens at auctions, some overenthusiastic collectors paid more for wines than they would if they had bought them in retail shops. Several buyers paid $300 a bottle for the 1995 Chateau d'Yquem, while the retail price is about $195 in San Francisco.
Real bargains were few. A case of 1986 Chateau Cheval Blanc, valued at $4,500, sold for $3,000. A case of 1990 Chateau Margaux, valued at $6,900, sold for $5,500. Most of these wines were listed in the catalog with their ratings in Wine Spectator, a consumer magazine. The 1990 Margaux was rated 96 out of 100.
There were excellent lots of Spanish wines, from Priorato and the Ribera del Duero, but the audience show little interest. "Bodega?," said a man behind me. "Isn't a bodega a grocery store?"
Burgundies were among the best offerings. Producers included Roumier, Jayer-Gilles, Armand Rousseau and surprisingly large lots from Leroy and the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti. A case assortment of 1997's from the D.R.C. contained one bottle of Romanee-Conti, three of La Tache, two of Richebourg, two of Romanee-St.-Vivant, one Grands-Echezeaux and three Echezeaux; listed at $8,700, they sold for $2,800. 
Many wines, including several thousand bottles of New Zealand chardonnay and Blanquette de Limoux, a sparkling wine from France, were sold unlabled. Called "shiners," these are wines that are prepared for wine clubs or retailers who want private labels. Some of the Blanquette was labeled "Virtual Vineyards," an online predecessor of Wine.com.
Some lots were bizarre by traditional wine auction standards. A lot of 3,400 boxes of Italian pretzels, valued at $10,000, sold for $600. Green Italian olives, 1,452 containers of them valued at $6,400, sold for $750. "We tried the pretzels," Mr. Otus told the bidders, "and they were pretty good."
Thirty-three gift sets, composed of two bottles of wine, "minitoasts," Dijon mustard, salami, pickles, a soft-handle corkscrew, a knife, a cheese board, four tumblers and a "Delacroix wedding tray," valued at $1,800 for the lot, sold to an Internet bidder for $400.
Private bidders were limited to 20 cases to discourage resale. Total price included the winning bid, buyer's premium, taxes and shipping costs. All wine had to be shipped; since it was stored at another location, none could be taken away from the auction. Charges and shipping costs could add an estimated 25 percent to the initial price of the wine.
It was an anticlimactic ending to a tumultuous enterprise. In 1994, Peter Granoff, a wine enthusiast and restaurateur, along with partners, founded a company to sell wine on the Internet. They called it Virtual Vineyards. 
Five years later, Virtual Vineyards purchased Wine.com, a small online site with no appreciable retail business. "Frankly, we just wanted the name," Mr. Granoff said. Late in 2000, when enthusiasm for online wine and Internet sales in general began to wane, Wine.com merged with Wineshopper.com, a small competitor. "Our sales were 60 times greater than theirs," Mr. Granoff said. 
Between them, the two companies had run through some $200 million in financing from investors that included Amazon.com, The New York Times Company, GE Capital and Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers. The merger only briefly staved off the inevitable. In April, all that was left of Wine.com, its name and mailing list, were swallowed up by eVineyard, a former rival.
Wine.com may be out of the picture, but its name lives on. EVineyard sells wine online under the name Wine.com by eVineyard. EVineyard said it paid Sand Hill, a main investor, $10 million for Wine.com's name, goodwill and intangible assets but said it has no other interest in the defunct company. 
In fact, it once threatened to sue AuctioNet for using the Wine.com name in conjunction with the auction. EVineyard sells wine online in 23 states and Japan.
Is there a future for wine on the Internet? Mr. Granoff is convinced there is.
"With the contraction of wine distributors all over the country, it's almost impossible for small producers to bring their wines to market," he said. "For them, the Internet is the only way to go."
The most publicized sale at this auction was the 1921 Chateau d'Yquem, he said. "How was it sold? To an online bidder. Over the Internet."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
In an uneasy climate, the group approach is so popular, even rivals unite in campaigns.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
"UNITED we stand" can now be considered more than a patriotic exhortation. Increasingly, it is serving as a strategy for advertisers to attract the attention of consumers in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks.
 A growing number of television commercials, print advertisements, posters and other pitches are being presented under the sponsorship of trade groups, industry associations and umbrella organizations -- some longstanding, others ad hoc efforts formed after Sept. 11. 
 The trend toward cooperation is evident from Madison Avenue, where agencies are working with a former top executive of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide to produce campaigns under the aegis of the Advertising Council, to Wall Street, where 10 leading names in financial services joined forces for a newspaper ad declaring the country was "open for business," to Main Street, where airlines, insurance companies and tourist attractions are addressing customers together rather than separately.
One reason for the cooperative ads is that "pooling resources makes it seem like a bigger effort, like there's a lot of clout behind it," said Philip B. Dusenberry Jr., chairman for the North American operations of BBDO Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group. 
"And it's more cost effective," he added, "because it's easier and cheaper to run one ad than for each one to run its own ad." That is an important consideration because of the weakening economy, which had seemed to be slipping into a recession even before the wrenching disruptions caused by the attacks.
Another reason for these ads is "that by doing it all together, it takes you out of the realm of people questioning if you're taking advantage of the situation or their feelings," said Alicia Kriese, senior vice president and group account director at GSD&M in Austin, Tex. Her agency, also owned by Omnicom, helped produce the financial services ad at the request of a client, the Charles Schwab Corporation, which GSD&M shares with BBDO. Other sponsors of the ad included American Express, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley.
"Most days," Ms. Kriese said, "I want to kick butts" at sibling agencies like BBDO, "but we came together as an Omnicom family" for the ad.
"Reaching out to others is what this is about," she added. "What unites you is a lot stronger than what divides you, and a lot of times we forget that."
Among those preaching that in union there is strength are the American Insurance Association, which represents more than 370 property and casualty companies; the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, with more than 100 drug makers as members; the League of American Theaters and Producers, representing the Broadway community; the Travel Industry Association of America; and the Empire State Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which are spending $40 million on a coordinated "I <heart> New York" campaign to urge business and leisure travelers to return to the city; and the Advertising Council.
The council named Michael Sennott yesterday to oversee what Peggy Conlon, president and chief executive, described as "a high-level team to develop the communication strategy that will inform all the messages we're creating" for public service campaigns related to the attacks. Mr. Sennott, 59, is the former deputy chairman at Lowe Lintas and has just retired as senior partner and vice chairman at the Lowe Lintas parent, the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
"It doesn't mean individual agencies can't make their own contributions," Ms. Conlon said, "but the council is taking the same umbrella position, the leadership position, as we did 60 years ago," when the council was founded, as the War Advertising Council, after the attack on Pearl Harbor.
A coordinated approach can help "make sure we're more proactive, more strategic," she added, "that the campaigns work together, that we're able to measure their impact over time."
There can be pluses and minuses to uniting for ads, according to Simon Williams, chief executive at the Sterling Group, a corporate identity and brand consulting company in New York.
On one hand, "it shows an industry to be proactive and it gives a sense of caring," Mr. Williams said. "Individually, a company may feel isolated and not take out ads on its own."
On the other hand, he added, such ads "can seem like bland messages from inanimate objects, industry cartels, because I as a consumer have a relationship with a brand rather than an association."
Another fault Mr. Williams said he finds is that "the ads do look atrocious, like they were created by one of the finest agencies in Teaneck, N.J."
Needless to say, the organizations running the ads do not agree with that assessment.
"Our companies were also doing things separately, but we wanted to convey a sense from an emotional perspective that this was different for us," said Julie Rochman, senior vice president at the American Insurance Institute in Washington, who served as the copywriter for a plain, all-text newspaper ad signed by the organization's board, the chief executives of 18 property and casualty insurance companies from ACE to the Zurich Financial Services Group.
"We wanted to say that as much as it rocked us personally," she added, referring to the attack on the World Trade Center, "we are part of the recovery effort, that this is what we do."
Christopher Molineaux, vice president in Washington for the pharmaceutical association, known as Pharma, said: "We have not done this before. The decision was based on the enormous outpouring of support our companies engaged in, upwards of $82 million in cash and untold amounts of product. We wanted to express to all Americans, as well as our member companies, that the pharmaceutical industry is supportive of the nation and individual families when they suffer loss."
In some instances, unity is meant to pervade all aspects of the ads. For example, a line in the script for a TV spot for the "I <heart> New York" campaign, which read "Come see New York in its finest hour," was revised by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to read "Come see New York united in its finest hour." The mayor will appear in the commercial, scheduled to begin running next Wednesday, along with Gov. George E. Pataki.
"If different groups want to run their own messages about their own particular industries, that's fine," said Mike Rogers, president and executive creative director at the New York office of the Wolf Group, the agency for the development corporation, "but people look to 'I <heart> New York' to carry the ball."
"Not to be out there with anything would be noticeable," he added.
Perhaps the most notable example of the lion -- and "The Lion King" -- lying down with the lamb is the campaign from the theater league, which carries the theme "I <heart> New York Theater." It united the producers of 31 shows, who regularly compete against one another for ticket buyers; their press agents, who usually battle one another for column inches in newspapers; and two agencies that specialize in theatrical advertising, Serino Coyne and Spotco, regularly fierce rivals.
"I worked in advertising for 15 years, and you can work happily without ever working with your colleagues at other agencies," said Jed Bernstein, president of the theater league in New York. "You didn't need each other to get your business done."
"But on Broadway, the competitor today is the co-investor tomorrow," he added, "and the actor you lost the part to one month is on stage with you the next month."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Shares CloseUp After the Fed's Move to Reduce Rates

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by half a percentage point in an effort to revive a declining economy.
 Investors reacted cautiously after the Fed said that the terrorist attacks last month had significantly increased the uncertainties in an already weak economy. 
 "The market did not evidence a rip-roaring response to the ninth Fed interest rate cut this year," said Alan Ackerman, chief market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. 
"While the averages were up, there were many who believe that we need more evidence of an economic stimulus package and more liquidity to help both the economy and the market," he said.
The Dow Jones industrial average increased 113.76 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 8,950.59, after initially retreating when the Fed announced the rate cuts. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 11.87 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,492.33. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 12.78 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,051.33.
Shares of military contractors rallied yesterday as the prospect of American retaliation for the terrorist attacks seemed nearly certain. Alliant Techsystems rose $1.60, to $85, and Northrop Grumman gained $3.75, to $105.20. The CompuDyne Corporation climbed $2.95, to $17.75, while InVision Technologies gained 14 cents, to $9.84.
Boeing increased $1.85, to $34.25, after announcing yesterday that China would buy 30 of the company's 737 airliners, worth $1.6 billion. Lockheed Martin, Boeing's chief competitor, was up $1.39, to $45.
Airline stocks, especially regional companies, showed strength after several brokerage houses upgraded their ratings. Merrill Lynch upgraded Delta Air Lines, which gained $1.30, to $27.09; Alaska Air, which increased $1.36, to $21.16; and Atlantic Coast Airlines, which gained $2.33, to $15.94.
SkyWest Airlines rose $1.39, to $18.56, after it was added to the recommended list of Goldman Sachs.
Software stocks also showed strength. PeopleSoft increased $2.87, to $20.54; Siebel Systems gained $2.01, to $15.06; and Microsoft rose $1.26, to $53.05.
Earnings warnings continued, with McGraw-Hill tumbling $6.40, to $50.50, after it said it would miss its earnings forecast for the quarter and the year.
After the market closed, Nortel Networks said it would post a loss of $3.6 billion for the third quarter because of a decrease in sales. The company also said that it would cut at least 15,000 more jobs and that its chief executive, John Roth, would retire at the end of the month, six months ahead of schedule. Shares of Nortel fell 18 cents, to $5.29, in regular trading, and fell as low as $4.70 in after-hours trading.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve reduced its benchmark lending rate to the lowest level in four decades and suggested that more cuts may follow as growth slows in coming months.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 6/32, to 103 28/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.51 percent from 4.53 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 23/32, to 100 23/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.33 percent from 5.38 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Off in September, But Less Than Expected 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
United States auto sales slumped last month, but were better than analysts expected. 
 A drought in auto sales after the attacks has already led to additional belt-tightening for an industry that was trimming as the economy worsened. Now, analysts say demand will plunge more sharply, leading to more production cuts, plant closings and layoffs. 
 The Ford Motor Company said today that it would lose in excess of 10 cents a share in the third quarter, below most analysts' estimates. General Motors said it would cut fourth- quarter production by 30,000 to 50,000 vehicles, to just below 1.3 million. Morgan Stanley recently cut its 2002 earnings estimate for G.M. to $1.75 a share from $4. And the Chrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler, whose sales continue to decline sharply, said it would cut its October vehicle production by 26,000 vehicles and said it would intermittently idle five plants this month. 
Over all, the seasonally adjusted annual rate of auto sales in the United States fell to 15.8 million cars and light trucks in September, a 9 percent drop from the month last year, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, an automotive data service in Southfield, Mich. 
While overall sales fell, sales at General Motors, and to some extent Ford, actually held up surprisingly well in September. But analysts caution that new interest-free loan programs, started after the attacks, drove up demand. But they make it harder for Ford and G.M. to make money. 
Sales were better than expected for G.M. and Ford, said David Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities. "The big question," he added, "is how much of the sales at the end of the month were brought in by incentives?"
Lloyd Hansen, Ford's controller, appeared to agree on a conference call today. "Longer term, it's clear that we're going to have to de-escalate these levels," he said, referring to the current incentives. 
Coming into the month, the auto industry was expecting to have slower sales than last year's record pace. Sales had been slowing for a few months as the economic picture clouded. Then, sales plunged after the Sept. 11 attacks, which also led to parts shortages because of closings at the Mexican and Canadian borders and the halting of airport traffic. 
The Big Three were expected to fare worse than foreign automakers, but Ford, G.M. and Chrysler put aggressive additional incentive programs in place. They were partly motivated by talks with Bush administration officials, who urged them to do their best to keep selling cars and trucks instead of cutting production. 
The incentives seemed to be effective. In September, sales at G.M. fell 3 percent compared with September 2000. Sales at Ford fell 9.7 percent and sales at Chrysler fell 28 percent. By comparison, American sales at Toyota fell 4.2 percent, sales at BMW rose 4.4 percent and sales at Honda fell 3.8 percent compared with September 2000.
Chrysler continues to struggle more than G.M. and Ford as its staples suffer. Sales of the Jeep Grand Cherokee fell 39 percent as it lost ground to a torrent of new sport utility vehicles from foreign competitors and G.M. However, Chrysler's sales drop compared with September 2000 is somewhat distorted by the fact that last year the company was using heavy incentives to clear excess inventory. 
Ford was hurt by slowing sales at its Hertz unit, one of the largest rental car companies. Hertz and its competitors have all been hurt by greatly diminished air traffic, because much of their business is derived from cars rented at airports. 
"Their rentals have been off 30 to 35 percent through the second half of September as a result of lower air travel," said Mr. Hansen, Ford's controller. 
"It's been a major problem for the daily rental industry, and that's going to sharply reduce results for Hertz for the third quarter."
G.M. officials said during a conference call today that they would offset the costs of the company's new incentive package by cutting from some other marketing plans. The cost of the incentives should also be mitigated, somewhat, by falling interest rates, which make such offerings cheaper for automakers.
"It is not a budget-busting program," said Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director of global market and industry analysis. "We think it is a very targeted and a very timely and appropriate program given our leadership position in this industry." 
For many analysts, the true effects of Sept. 11, and of the overall economic downturn, will not be visible for a couple of months. But most expect sales to slow considerably next year, and profitability to fare even worse.
Ronald Tadross, an analyst at Bank of America, projects that G.M. could lose as much as $100 a vehicle next year. "Pricing is bad as it gets," he said. "Companies like G.M. are not making any money."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SCHOLARSHIPS; 
Endowments From bin Ladens Prove Awkward

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Months ago, Dale F. Eickelman, a professor at Dartmouth College, accepted a grant from a program at Oxford University to study the splintering religious and political leadership within the Islamic world, including the role of Osama bin Laden.
 But what distinguishes Dr. Eickelman from most scholars of Islam is that he is studying this fall under a fellowship endowed in memory of Mr. bin Laden's father, Muhammad, and financed by Mr. bin Laden's extended family, which has denounced the accused terrorist. This semester, Dr. Eickelman is, for better or worse, the bin Laden Visiting Fellow at the Oxford Center for Islamic Studies. 
 While Dr. Eickelman concedes that his title has taken on an unfortunate resonance in the days since Sept. 11, he said he has felt no pressure to return his $5,900 stipend.
"I've worked for 30 years in the Middle East," said Dr. Eickelman, who is on leave from a position at Dartmouth's anthropology department. "One is used to dealing with extended families, the different parts of which are not necessarily in close contact."
Still, these are awkward times for the students, professors and colleges that have been the beneficiaries of the bin Laden family's longtime largesse. The recipients of the family's philanthrophy are studying, or have studied, not only at Oxford but also at at least two American institutions: Harvard University, where the family has endowed fellowships valued at $2 million in the graduate schools of law and design, and Tufts University, which received $300,000 in the mid-1990's for lectures and language training at the Islamic studies program of its Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy.
Officials at Oxford, Harvard and Tufts said the family's estrangement from Osama bin Laden provided all the reassurance that they needed to spend the family's money. But a Harvard spokesman, Andy Tiedemann, said that if investigators ever linked the family's construction company, which made the donations, to the terrorist attacks, "then it would be a very different picture."
Still, the universities conceded that the Sept. 11 attacks had already necessitated adjustments. Harvard, for example, no longer lists the names of its bin Laden fellows on its Web site.
"It was done," said Joe Wrinn, another Harvard spokesman, "to prevent any kind of harassment and to allay any security concerns."
Frank Vogel, the director of the Islamic legal studies program at Harvard Law School, said he had met the bin Ladens in the mid-1990's through Osama bin Laden's half-brother Abdullah, one of at least 50 children in the family. Abdullah bin Laden received a master's degree from Harvard Law in 1993 and a doctorate last year.
Dr. Vogel said that he and the law school dean secured a $1 million donation from the family only after traveling to Saudi Arabia to meet with another of Osama bin Laden's siblings, Bakr Muhammad, who runs the family's construction company. (Though separated from the family and its company, Osama bin Laden, 44, is believed to have drawn much of his wealth from his family's fortune after his father died in 1968.)
Osama bin Laden's siblings "are known as very high-minded and high-principled donors," Dr. Vogel said, adding that "supporting needy students is always given high value in the Islamic moral system."
The law school used the donation to created two endowments. The investment income from one endowment has supported fellowships for professors and other researchers from overseas. The bin Laden fellows have used their time at Harvard -- as much as nine months -- to compare aspects of Western and Islamic law, more as students than teachers.
There are three bin Laden fellows at Harvard Law this year, but Dr. Vogel declined to identify them, saying they had been distracted and unsettled by the terrorist attacks.
The law school has also used income from a second endowment to finance annual scholarships for law students from predominantly Muslim countries. Their scholarships do not bear the bin Laden name.
Harvard's graduate school of design negotiated its own $1 million donation from the family. It has used the money to pay the research expenses of bin Laden fellows who are engaged in advanced research on issues of architecture and urban planning that "pertain specifically to Islamic environments," said Patricia Roberts, the associate dean for academic affairs.
As yet, no fellow has been named at the design school this year but in past years there have been as many as two, Dr. Roberts said.
The Oxford Center for Islamic Studies, a program associated with the university, was established in 1985 to bring together scholars of the Islamic and Western worlds. The center began its bin Laden fellowship program in the 1990's with a $150,000 donation from the family, said David Browning, the center's registrar.
Dr. Eickelman of Dartmouth is one of at least a half-dozen scholars who have held the fellowship. One fellow from Jordan studied Islamic art; another from Malaysia studied the economics of southeast Asia.
At Tufts, Andrew Hess, the director of the Asian and Islamic studies program at the Fletcher school, said he had met Abdullah bin Laden, the Harvard law graduate, at a conference in Boston and had negotiated the $300,000 donation with him. 
The money was given in installments from 1992 to 1994 and has been used up, Dr. Hess said. Despite the Sept. 11 attacks, he said he would gladly accept another donation.
"They gave the money with no strings attached, which is extraordinary," Dr. Hess said. "And they have made it clear that Osama bin Laden is not only unwelcome in their family but is engaged in destroying their business opportunities."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: STATE DEPARTMENT; 
Powell Says U.S. Had Signs, But Not Clear Ones, of a Plot

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ and DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the Bush administration had received a "lot of signs" that terrorists were planning attacks against the United States but extensive efforts by intelligence agencies failed to pick up enough information to stop the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. 
 Early this summer "there were a lot of signs that there was something going on," Secretary Powell said. "But we never got the fidelity and the information that we would have liked to, some warning of what did actually happen." 
 In looking back today in an interview in his State Department suite, Secretary Powell expressed frustration that, despite a summer of warnings of possible terrorist actions against American civilian and military sites around the world, the information was not sufficient to identify the specific targets that were struck last month. "The intelligence agencies were trying," he said. "We were watchful throughout all of our embassy systems." 
Mr. Powell praised George Tenet, the director of central intelligence, a holdover from the Clinton administration. The House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence is urging far-reaching changes in intelligence operations and an independent investigation into why the government did not foresee or prevent the Sept. 11 attacks. Page B2. 
While he was generally upbeat in his accounting of the progress so far in the global campaign against terror, he made it clear that the administration was still at the early stages of winning full cooperation from allied and other nations.
For example, despite pledges of cooperation, Saudi Arabia has not yet said publicly that the United States would be able to use air bases there for offensive operations against targets in Afghanistan.
Secretary Powell insisted that the administration is demonstrating to allies and moderate Arab governments that the case against Osama bin Laden and his network is convincing.
He asserted that "all paths" lead to Mr. bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network, although he cautioned not to see it in terms of a case "that's going to trial in a court."
Instead, administration officials have been briefing allies on what he called "pretty good information" establishing the link between the airplane hijackers and Mr. bin Laden. 
"It's a campaign in many parts and pieces all working to go after a common enemy," Secretary Powell said. "That enemy's name is terrorism. And in its most ambitious manifestation it goes by the name Al Qaeda and the head of that awful holding company is bin Laden and he is responsible for tragedy against humanity, crime against the American people, crime against the civilized world and he must be held accountable."
Secretary Powell described in general terms the cable that has been sent to American embassies around the world outlining the case against Mr. bin Laden. He said it describes the history of the terrorist network, and recites existing indictments filed against Mr. bin Laden for his alleged involvement in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa. It also describes evidence of Mr. bin Laden's responsibility "for past crimes against the U.S. and against civilization," presumably including the attack last year on the American destroyer Cole in Yemen.
While the administration has not made any documents public, as General Powell suggested that it might 10 days ago, he said today that "over time enough information would surface" to convince the American people. "The case will never be able to be described as circumstantial," he said. "It's not circumstantial now."
Secretary Powell also touched, gingerly, on the political future of Afghanistan. Despite a policy statement from the Bush administration last week stating that the Taliban does not represent the Afghan people, General Powell stopped well short of saying that the overthrow of the hard-line Islamic government is an explicit goal. 
"Our goal in the first instance as the president has laid out is to go after Al Qaeda and its leader bin Laden and its camps in Afghanistan," he said. "And the Taliban regime will pay a price."
Addressing the possibilty that the Taliban might not survive the coming confrontation, Secretary Powell said he hoped for the emergence of a new government that would be "representative" of the many ethnic groups that make up the Afghan people. 
"Hopefully, the Afghan people can find themselves under the leadership of a government that is representative of all the Afghan people and is a less repressive government than the kind that is there now." He held out the possibility of substantial economic assistance once the Taliban is out of the way. 
Already the Bush administration has made available $170 million in relief aid, and officials suggested this weekend that another $100 million would be on the way by the end of the year. Secretary Powell said that figure would rise, and the United States would try to bring "some level of stability in their society."
"We would see what we could do to put the country on a more secure footing," he said. "You're not doing your job if you are not thinking of future opportunities and possibilities."
Asked how he would define victory in the long campaign ahead, Secretary Powell gave a broad and ambitious definition -- one that centered more on how Americans felt than any specific military victory.
"I see the success of this campaign being measured in the restoration of a degree of security in society, where people are not as frightened as they are now," he said.
He added that another measure of success would come "when there is less terrorism, far less, preferably zero terrorism with a global reach of the world."
President Bush has often said many victories would arise from covert operations, never seen by the American people. But Secretary Powell said: "Even covert activities eventually produce visible results." 
Asked about his newly disclosed plans to declare that the administration supports the creation of a Palestinian state as part of a settlement in the Middle East, Secretary Powell said he had not decided when or where to outline his views.
After staying aloof from the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for most of the year, the administration was about to dive in when the Sept. 11 attacks occurred. Those attacks delayed the opening of the United Nations General Assembly in New York, where Mr. Bush had been planning to meet the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and Mr. Powell had been planning to deliver a speech outlining the administration's ideas for resolving the conflict. Today, Secretary Powell suggested that when that initiative resumed would depend on events in Afghanistan.
The intelligence warnings about terrorist attacks that Secretary Powell discussed today were received during the spring and summer, particularly before the Fourth of July and the summit meeting of industrialized nations in Genoa, Italy, that month.
Vice President Dick Cheney referred to those reports in an hour-long interview on "Meet the Press" on Sept. 16 when he said that the government had information that a "big operation" was planned. But, like Secretary Powell today, Mr. Cheney said there was "no specific threat involving really a domestic operation." 
Secretary Powell suggested that the State Department and the intelligence agencies had been on high alert against terrorism, and had been trying, though its embassies abroad, to hone in on Mr. bin Laden's plans. But twice he said that the American intelligence gathering effort never came up with enough "fidelity" -- a word that seemed to suggest that they either misunderstood the signals they were receiving, or simply did not have enough specific data.
"There were a number of reports that we were worried about but that never crystallized," he said. "There were a lot of signs that there was something going on -- nobody could ever get the fidelity in those reports."
In June and early July, United States intelligence officials warned that Mr. bin Laden and al Qaeda appeared to be planning terrorist attacks against American interests. Those warnings prompted public alerts by the administration of possible terrorist attacks timed for the Fourth of July holidays. 
When no attacks occurred around July 4, American intelligence officials began to assume that the immediate threat had passed. In retrospect, some American officials say that their focus on that holiday may have been a misreading of the information they had received. 
All through June and July, the State Department released reports warning that terrorist attacks were imminent in locations from the Mideast to East Asia. In July, for example, the department warned about possible attacks against installations in Japan and South Korea, as well as against American interests in the Arabian Peninsula.

HEADLINE: Florida's Secretary of State Seeks House Seat 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: SARASOTA, Fla., Oct. 2 

 BODY:
Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state who became a national figure during the presidential election last November, said today that she would run for Congress next year and that her role in the presidential contest would not be a major factor in her own race.
 Ms. Harris, a Republican, said she had moved on from the turmoil of the protracted presidential election and believed that most voters in the state had as well. 
 Now, she said, it is her own political future that is foremost in her mind. 
"I don't have any regrets," said Ms. Harris, who was harshly criticized by Democrats last November for decisions that were seen as helping George W. Bush. "I don't have any apologies or excuses. I think history will show that we followed the law exactly." 
She knows any Democratic challengers will probably want to remind voters about hanging chads and foggy definitions of voter intent. But, "I'm looking forward to the campaign," Ms. Harris emphatically declared.
She will run in the 13th District, a Republican stronghold around her hometown, Sarasota. The seat is held by Representative Dan Miller, a Republican who has said he will not seek another term.
Though political experts say Ms. Harris, 44, is almost certain to win the race in a district where Mr. Miller ran unchallenged in his last two elections, the new candidate said she is leaving nothing to chance.
"I'm not going to take anything for granted," Ms. Harris said in an interview here today. "I'm going to work door-to-door, I'm going to have town hall meetings, we're going to have issue groups, we're going to have senior groups that will focus on strengthening our national security."
Already, though, the Florida Democratic Party is seeking opponents to try to thwart Ms. Harris's hopes.
"She's been positioning herself to get in this race for a long time," said Bob Poe, chairman of the state Democratic Party. "We're glad she's doing it. She will excite Democrats more than anything we could do in that race.
"She will increase our turnout numbers substantially just by being in the race." 
Ms. Harris starts the race with several advantages. The 13th district votes solidly Republican, and for better or worse, she has national name recognition. She is also likely to have a fairly easy time with fund-raising, in part because, while her rulings during the recount on absentee ballots and late election returns were criticized as partisan by Democrats, they won her big points with the Republican Party.
Additionally, because of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, the Democrats may have trouble making an issue of her role in the presidential campaign, given the huge public support for President Bush.
"If the president's popularity is sustained, it will help her," said Lance de Haven-Smith, a political science professor at Florida State University. "Right now, the circumstances are as good as they could get for her."
The wealthy granddaughter of a Florida citrus baron, Ms. Harris represented Sarasota in the State Senate from 1994 until 1998, when she was elected secretary of state, making her the state's top election official.
As secretary of state, she has been an advocate for the arts and has worked to expand Florida's involvement in international commerce, though many Democratic legislators have criticized her for what they said was an unnecessarily lavish foreign travel budget. As a state senator, she headed the commerce and economic development committee.
Now, Ms. Harris said, she is hoping to expand upon her record of public service in Congress. "I get to come home and I'm really eager to do that, but I have a chance now to focus on federal issues." Although she had all but made up her mind to run well before the terrorist attacks on the United States last month, Ms. Harris said the assaults reinforced for her the need for all Americans to serve the country.
For most Americans, she said, "now more than ever we're just completely committed to making a difference. We can't all put on a uniform but this is a way I can fight for my country."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SAFETY AND LIBERTY; 
Plan to Expand U.S. Powers Alarming Some in Colorado

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
The people who live under the formidable jaw of Pikes Peak like their churches, houses and cars big, and their government small. They send a steady flow of Republicans east, and do not expect much to come west, unless it is tax cuts or farm subsidies.
 So to many it has come as a surprise, bordering on outrage, that a government thought to be safely controlled by like-minded conservatives is trying to expand the power and size of the federal policing authority, increase surveillance and wiretapping powers, even consider proposals for national identification cards. 
 "Here it comes -- our government trying to take away freedoms again in the name of a national emergency," said Ted Adamovich, a 53-year-old resident of Colorado Springs. "They can put a little more surveillance in airports, but beyond that -- no. Let them try to make me sign up for a national ID card. I dare them." 
Mr. Adamovich says he bleeds red, white and blue, and has been consistently loyal to one party. "I'm Republican, for now," he said. "But if they push this stuff, who knows where I'll end up."
His warning was echoed throughout the cradle of New West Republicanism, where it is almost as hard to find a liberal as it is a slice of street-side pizza. To hear some people talk, Janet Reno is still attorney general and Bill Clinton remains president.
"Some of this stuff they're proposing reminds me of a police state," said Bob Kosser, a member of the National Rifle Association, a Republican and an Air Force veteran who lives in this booming, conservative city along the Front Range.
"Cameras, wiretapping, e-mail surveillance," Mr. Kosser counted off, wearing a T-shirt featuring an embroidered American flag. "Are they going to be asking us to show our papers everywhere were go, like the Germans did?"
After the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995, Mr. Clinton proposed expanding the reach of government wiretaps and giving authorities power to trace gun powder from explosives. But a storm of opposition that blew in from the Rocky Mountain West and the South helped to kill the measures.
After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the Bush administration quickly put forward antiterrorism legislation to give the government more authority to seize people's assets, detain immigrants longer between court appearances, conduct broader wiretapping and other surveillance and to subpoena e-mail correspondence.
A national ID card was not part of the package the administration requested, but some members of Congress raised it as a possibility in the days the antiterrorist plan was being assembled.
Many leading Republicans, including Westerners like Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, favored the plan the administration introduced, and some called for even stricter measures. But Republican and Democratic negotiators in Congress have scaled back some of what the administration sought, deciding to make the wiretap provision temporary, for example. 
Still, the train of expanded government authority has run into the very people who helped to put many Republicans in power over the last decade -- strong gun supporters and former independents with a Western feistiness. They have been joined, for the moment, by allies from a distant and unlikely camp: liberals like Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, and the American Civil Liberties Union.
"My position, and the position of most pro-gun organizations, is that it is not a crime thing, it's a freedom issue," said Tony Fabian, president of the Colorado State Shooting Association, which is the state affiliate of the National Rifle Association.
"Any time the government is looking seriously at taking measures that roll back our freedoms as Americans -- whether it's guns, communications or transportation -- there needs to be very careful, cautious and measured evaluation," Mr. Fabian said.
The National Rifle Association, while expressing concerns that some provisions of the antiterrorist bill could be used by other administrations against gun owners, said it did not oppose the measure.
"As written, we don't see anything in the bill that goes to gun ownership," said Jim Baker, chief lobbyist for the N.R.A. "The way we read it, it's all tied into terrorist acts."
In interviews conducted randomly in Colorado, people seemed particularly concerned about the prospect of more surveillance. "I don't mind profiling as long as they don't do it on average people," said Kory Birge, a high school senior touring the Professional Rodeo Hall of Fame here. "But on the surveillance, I don't want it to get like London, where they have cameras everywhere."
Expanding the federal government's reach -- through the establishment of a new home defense agency, increased federal involvement in airport security and bailouts for faltering sectors of the economy -- has also struck a nerve among many Westerners. They said they thought the era of big government was over when Mr. Clinton declared it dead.
But the mood across the nation, according to several recent polls, shows that antigovernment sentiments have ebbed considerably. Not since 1966 has such a large majority -- more than 60 percent in several polls -- said that they trusted the government to do the right thing most of the time.
And here in Colorado, plenty of people say the government should take whatever security steps are needed to curb terrorism, even if it means a loss of civil liberties.
"I don't mind the stepped-up surveillance as long as they keep it in certain places, and don't try to come into the home with it," said Chuck Rice, 55, of Colorado Springs.
While most of the attention has focused on airport security, people here have started to voice concerns about the expanded federal authority.
"Just in the last few days, we've been hearing from a lot of people in the district who wonder what this bill means to them," said Sarah Shelden, a spokeswoman for Representative Joel Hefley, a Republican whose district includes Colorado Springs.
"Surveillance is a very big deal in our district," Ms. Shelden added. "People are concerned about Big Brother, that feeling that somebody might be watching them. It's just not the way they are used to living."

HEADLINE: The Dwindling Power of Rate Cuts 

 BODY:
Yesterday the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates for the ninth time this year. The federal funds rate, the key tool of monetary policy, is now 2.5 percent -- below the level of inflation. The Fed was hoping it would buoy investor and consumer confidence, and given the markets' current psychology, it probably had little choice. The stock market did respond well to the move. 
 Still, it is becoming clear that the nation's economic woes are not going to be fixed simply by continual rate-cutting. The attacks of Sept. 11 caught the Fed at just the wrong time. Under the leadership of Alan Greenspan, it had slashed rates by three and a half percentage points between January and August in an attempt to juice up a sagging economy. The effects of rate cuts take a while to kick in, and the nation should have been starting to feel their influence right now. But the terrorist attacks took a big, one-time bite out of the economy that lower lending rates cannot fully address. Quick but careful action from Congress and the Bush administration is going to have to do the rest. 
 Cuts in the short-term federal lending rate can help businesses offer consumers easier credit, but they cannot make businesses invest in growth when sales are down, or make consumers suddenly worried about their jobs and portfolios decide to go shopping. Only intelligently targeted government spending -- or, to a lesser extent, broad-based temporary tax cuts -- can stimulate purchasing.
Cutting the federal funds rate also cannot lower long-term interest rates if the markets have no confidence in the stability of the federal budget. Worries that the Bush tax cut would aggravate future deficits are one reason that long-term rates stayed stubbornly high for much of this year, although they have fallen since the terrorist attack pushed a recovery further into the future.
Markets have been looking to the Fed's announcements for soothing words of reassurance -- the perception, if not the reality, of a guaranteed safety net. Had the Fed not cut rates again, markets would have slumped and faith in the Fed's commitment to keep pumping up the economy would have dwindled. So the rate cut made some sense, but it will hardly be enough by itself.
Mr. Greenspan seems to believe that monetary policy changes may be sufficient to guarantee a recovery. Though he endorsed President Bush's irresponsible tax cuts earlier in the year, he has stopped short of recommending a fiscal stimulus now. Meanwhile, the Fed is running out of room. If it raises rates anytime soon, markets will react with fury. But there is a limit to how low short-term rates can go, and the Fed may want to save its remaining ability to maneuver for a time when cuts will have more impact. 
Mr. Greenspan might have saved the country from at least some of its current problems if he had not thrown his substantial influence behind the Bush tax-cut plan, which drastically reduced government revenues over the long run while providing little in the way of stimulus right now. Perhaps that is the reason he is counseling the government to go slowly on any economic stimulus package. But the nation's economic problems require more help than his own monetary tools can provide. It is time for Congress and the president to act, and for Mr. Greenspan to concentrate on his own brief.

HEADLINE: Treasury Market Is Faced With Incomplete Trades 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Even though many problems have been cleared up since the terrorist attacks, the Treasury market is still faced with billions of dollars of incomplete trades.
 Traders say one result is some short-term financial pain for big investors, an unwillingness to trade in part of the market and some difficulty for investors who want to offset some risk by hedging with Treasury securities. 
 Major dealers in the Treasury market, officials of the Bond Market Association and regulators from the Federal Reserve and the Securities and Exchange Commission have had regular conference calls to discuss the issue.
"There is something going on," said James R. Capra, president of Capra Asset Management in Rye, N.Y., and the head of an advisory committee to the United States Treasury. 
The incomplete trades are known as fails in the bond market. Fails average about $100 million a day, a tiny amount in a market where billions of dollars change hands quickly. Traders and officials agree that the affected volume is now in the billions of dollars.
Despite the name, a fail does not mean that one party to a trade has been unable to pay cash for securities bought or deliver securities sold, traders said. Both parties agree that a trade was made in most of the current cases, but they have simply been unable to complete it.
While these trades do not affect retail investors, they are causing at least temporary problems for large dealers and institutional investors, who expect eventually to complete the trades.
Immediately after the attacks, there were many settlement and clearing problems in the Treasury market, including some related to damage to a major clearing bank, Bank of New York. There were also billions of dollars of trades made on Sept. 10 and the morning of Sept. 11 that had to be settled even though telephone connections were disrupted and many of the participants were not in business or were operating at less then full capacity.
Three weeks later, many of those trades have not been settled, traders now say. As the volume picked up in the days after trading resumed on Sept. 13, more failures began popping up. "If fails do not clear up and I am doing new trades, it just adds to the problem," said a trader at a major firm who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
"I am seeing marginal increases in the fails numbers," he added. "It is not huge increases."
The effect is showing up in what is called the repo market, where Treasury securities are borrowed and lent. The repo market is crucial to the operation of the Treasury market because it provides the money the dealers need to pay for the securities they have bought and, therefore, helps keep trading running smoothly. The dealers use the securities they have bought as collateral for loans of cash and agree to repurchase the securities at a set date. Hence the bond market jargon, repo market.
The shortage of securities for use as collateral could be making it hard to conduct normal hedging against risk. When dealers buy corporate securities, especially a new issue, they often sell Treasury securities as a hedge against a decline in the price of the corporate securities. But they need to borrow Treasury securities to do this.
It appears that the main reason for the failure to complete trades is a shortage of some Treasury securities, including two-year, five-year and 10-year notes, traders and officials said. This means there are not enough securities to be delivered to complete trades.
This view is supported by the fact that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has been pumping billions of dollars of these securities into the market in the last few weeks. While the average amount of such lending by the Fed was less than $1.5 billion a day in the first and second quarters of this year, the daily average has exceeded $8.5 billion in the last seven days.
The reasons for the shortage, while difficult to pinpoint exactly, include a surge in demand for these notes as a safe investment, a reluctance by several foreign central banks to lend them recently and the end of the third quarter, which deterred investors from entering into such trades.
In addition, bond trading has picked up, and the Treasury market has tried to settle trades in one day rather then the temporary three-day and five-day settlement used right after the attacks.
The president of the Bond Market Association, Micah Green, said that clearance and settlement operations damaged in the terrorist attack were operating close to normal and were not a reason for the incomplete trades.
"While the system is still dealing with a diminishing backlog of unreconciled trades, the current phenomenon of fails in the repo market does not appear to be caused by operational glitches in the clearance and settlement process," he said.
Because of the rate of fails, said one trader who insisted on anonymity, dealers are reluctant to use their securities as collateral. They are worried that they might not have securities delivered to them from other trades they have made, he explained. Investors who have Treasury securities they could use as collateral for borrowing also appear reluctant, although the borrowing terms are very favorable.
The apparent unwillingness to lend securities in the repo market has driven the cost of short-term borrowing using Treasury securities as collateral to near zero. The rate for borrowing with Treasury securities as collateral until the middle of February is about 1 percent. Normally, the rate would be close to the federal funds rate, which is the overnight rate for loans between banks and the Federal Reserve's target interest rate. Yesterday, Fed policy makers cut that rate to 2.5 percent.

HEADLINE: The Next Moves in a Shadow War 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "From the Outside, Former Presidents Lend the Support of Insiders" (news article, Sept. 28):
 Before going to war, President Bush should send our former presidents individually on missions to Iraq, Iran, Syria and Libya or Sudan. 
 These missions should emphasize our determination to track down Osama bin Laden and to destroy his organization and other terrorist groups; ask for the countries' cooperation in the war on terrorism; offer economic cooperation if these countries join the war on terrorism; and make clear that the United States will regard any regime that aids or harbors terrorists to be an enemy and that we will wage war against that regime with all of our military might.

RICHARD VALERIANI
Sherman, Conn., Sept. 28, 2001

HEADLINE: Fed Cuts Its Benchmark Rate To 2.5%, Hitting 39-Year Low 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point today to the lowest level in 39 years, continuing its effort to pump some vigor back into an economy that shows all the signs of having lapsed into recession.
 With each day bringing additional evidence that the yearlong deterioration in the economy has intensified since the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the White House and Congress also stepped up their efforts to settle on an economic recovery plan. 
 President Bush said he and the leaders of the two parties in Congress had agreed in general terms on the need for a package of tax cuts and spending increases intended to put more money in the hands of consumers, encourage investment by businesses and provide additional aid to people who have lost jobs.
But Democrats and Republicans continued to express different views of how to achieve those goals, suggesting that it will take considerable negotiation to reach a deal and get a stimulus package through Congress.
Congress and the White House also came to a final agreement today on a $686 billion package of routine spending bills for the new fiscal year, $25 billion higher than Mr. Bush had proposed last spring. 
Citing the aftereffects of the terrorist attacks, the Fed cut its federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks to 2.5 percent from 3 percent, putting the rate at its lowest level since 1962. 
It was the second half-point rate cut by the Fed since Sept. 11 and the ninth time the Fed has cut rates this year. The reduction of four percentage points in the federal funds rate in nine months, from 6.5 percent at the beginning of the year, is the most aggressive cutting of official interest rates since 1985 and one of the most pronounced on record.
The Fed also cut its discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system to 2 percent from 2.5 percent.
"The terrorist attacks have significantly heightened uncertainty in an economy that was already weak," the Fed said in the statement announcing its decision. "Business and household spending as a consequence are being further damped."
The Fed said the economy's underlying strengths should become apparent again once the "unusual forces" set in motion by the attacks begin to recede. But the statement offered little in the way of immediate reassurance, and signaled that the Fed was likely to cut rates further in coming months.
Stock prices fell slightly after the Fed announced the rate cut around 2:15 this afternoon, then rose. The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 8,950.59, up 113.76 points for the day.
The Fed's action was intended to encourage economic activity by reducing borrowing costs. Banks immediately began cutting their prime lending rate from 6 percent to 5.5 percent, a step that will translate into lower rates on some home equity, automobile, credit card and small- business loans.
At the same time, though, rates paid on savings accounts have also fallen to their lowest levels in years, cutting into the returns earned by many retirees.
Longer-term rates, including fixed-rate mortgages and rates paid by corporations to borrow in the bond market, are determined more by investors' perceptions of the economic outlook and the federal government's borrowing needs than by the Fed. As a result, they have not fallen as much as short-term rates this year, and are not likely to change as much because of the Fed's action today.
The federal funds rate is now approaching, or by some measures passing, the point where it is lower than inflation, a threshold the Fed usually crosses only during recessions. The so-called core personal consumption deflator, the measure of inflation most often cited by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is running at a 1.6 percent annual rate, still lower than the federal funds rate. The better known core consumer price index is running at a 2.7 percent annual rate.
With rates already low and both businesses and consumers nervous about the outlook, analysts said the Fed's move would probably not lead to any immediate increase in spending and investment. But they said it would help ease the financial strain on households and corporate balance sheets as the economy goes through tough times.
Automakers, whose sales have taken a hit in recent weeks, are already offering buyers zero percentage rate financing on new cars. Companies are holding off on investment plans not because of the cost of borrowing money, but because they have more capacity than they can use.
"There are virtually no businesses or consumers who are not making investments or purchases now who will be induced to do so because interest rates are lowered from the already exceptionally low levels," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union Corporation. 
"What monetary policy can do," Mr. Orr said, "is cushion the downturn by reducing the interest cost of short-term floating rate debt, helping profit margins for companies and monthly payments for consumers."
The economy all but stalled during the spring. Economists said it almost certainly fell during the third quarter and would probably shrink again in the fourth quarter, which began on Monday. The most commonly used definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters in which economic output falls.
After meeting with the Congressional leadership at the White House this morning, Mr. Bush said that the stimulus package should not be so expensive that it clouds the long-term budget outlook. 
The prospect that the government might not be able to afford to carry out its plan to pay off much of the national debt could lead the bond market to keep long-term interest rates at higher levels, offsetting some or all of the benefits of a stimulus package.
"We've got to come together with a vision about how big the package ought to be to make sure we affect the economy in the short run in a positive way, but don't affect it in the long run in a negative way," Mr. Bush told reporters.
The House and Senate Budget Committees and the White House have sharply cut their projections of the federal budget surplus for the fiscal year that started on Monday to $52 billion, down from $176 billion a month ago. The new figure does not include the cost of any stimulus package beyond the $40 billion in emergency spending and the $15 billion airline bailout package passed last month. 
But there is no agreement yet whether to limit the size of any further stimulus package so that the government does not go into deficit spending this year. In addition to a stimulus package, Congress is likely to consider further spending increases for the military, increasing the chances that the entire surplus will be wiped out this year.
The agreement on the routine spending bills was completed after Mr. Bush agreed to send a letter to Congress stating that he supported that higher level of spending.
With pressure growing, the White House and the Congressional leadership were moving toward agreement on one component, extending unemployment benefits for laid-off workers for at least 13 weeks beyond the current 26-week limit. But they were sticking today to long-held ideological positions on other issues, especially on tax cuts.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: TOURISM; 
Travel Push Includes 10,000 Free Air Tickets

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented short-term plans yesterday to boost New York City's reeling tourism industry. The program includes a plane ticket giveaway to 10,000 out-of-towners.
 In the early afternoon, Governor Pataki and the president of the city's convention and visitors' bureau, NYC & Company, Cristyne L. Nicholas, announced a $40 million "I Love New York" advertising campaign encouraging travelers to visit the city in the wake of the attack. 
 A couple of hours later, Ms. Nicholas was by Mayor Giuliani's side to announce a Delta Airlines program to give 10,000 free tickets to New York to people outside the region.
Minutes afterward, Ms. Nicholas rushed off to an interview on CNN as part of the concerted effort to soften the economic blow delivered by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
Preliminary numbers underscore the concern: a conservative estimate puts the dollar figure on lost tourism in the first two weeks after the attacks at $163.7 million. Other figures signified some progress, however. Occupancy rates at some hotels were creeping back to around 45 percent, Broadway shows were about 70 percent full and restaurants seemed more crowded over the weekend. But tourism and finance officials said that it was not much of a bump, given that October is historically the busiest tourism month for the city.
"It's like triage," Ms. Nicholas said. "You've got to stop the bleeding and then focus on the long term."
To that end, the tourism bureau has set up a committee to come up with short-term strategies. As a part of the effort, Delta has become the official airline of NYC & Company. It will give away the 10,000 tickets through radio stations in 50 markets. The airline is also waiving redemption fees for those who use frequent-flier miles to fly into Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark Airports.
The committee has also coordinated the relocation of five major conventions that were planned for other cities: the American Society of Travel Agents, which was scheduled for Nov. 4 to Nov. 7 in Seville, Spain; the American Society of Association Executives, which was scheduled for Nov. 16 to Nov. 18 in Buenos Aires; the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees' women's conference, which was scheduled for Nov. 16 to Nov. 18 in Boston; the Magazine Publishers of America conference, which was scheduled for Oct. 21 to Oct. 24 in Phoenix; and Meeting Planners International, which was scheduled for Colorado on Oct. 27.
The conferences are expected to bring nearly 5,000 people to the city, tourism officials said.
In addition, the mayor of Portland, Ore., Vera Katz, a former New Yorker, is bringing several flights full of Oregonians to the city over the Columbus Day weekend. Mayor Giuliani said he was encouraged that tourists had "started to come back this weekend."
Ms. Nicholas stressed that there was serious concern that if tourism did not pull out of its tailspin, thousands more jobs would be lost. She said her office has estimated that there have been 6,000 layoffs, mainly of hotel workers, as a result of the tourism decline following the attack.
And she said that if job losses increased on Broadway and in high-end hotels, the trend would spread to neighborhood bodegas, pizzerias and shoeshine shops. "We need people to go to Broadway, and we are using Broadway as the tool to fill the restaurants and other businesses."
She added: "You do have to be respectful and understanding of people in mourning. We lost a lot of people we knew and loved ourselves. But there is a point where you have to focus on the things that keep things going."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PRESIDENT; 
Revised Travel Plans Reflect Goals of Administration Under War Clouds

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
In the old presidency, the one that ended shortly before 9 a.m. on Sept. 11, George W. Bush had plans to build up his image as a world leader with a 10-day trip this month to Beijing, Shanghai, Tokyo and Seoul. There were also early preparations for a trip to India after the first of the year. Closer to home, Mr. Bush had a mid-September weekend planned at his Texas ranch.
 But like many other Americans, the president's travel plans have changed, but more drastically so. The leader of a nation at war cannot clear brush and fish while an American armada assembles in the Persian Gulf and Arabian Sea. He cannot be gone from Washington for long periods, because of both pressing business here and security concerns, and he particularly cannot be tied up in the ceremonial rituals of extended trips overseas. 
 But neither can he stay put at the White House while urging Americans to take a deep breath and start flying again.
As a result, White House officials say they have been forced to recreate the whole notion and purpose of presidential travel. Before the suicide hijackings, most of Mr. Bush's domestic trips were designed to push his legislative agenda. Now administration officials say the goal is to keep a sense of momentum even as the White House delays military action, and to project the image of a leader eager to get out and console Americans while still working hard at home on the crisis at hand. 
"There are definitely different considerations from a month ago," said Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director. "Much of the travel is based on the war effort, and to bringing attention to issues related to that." 
The president's trips are now fewer and shorter, although with far more secrecy and security preparations. Including a visit to Manhattan on Wednesday, he will have traveled outside of Washington only three times since Sept. 11 -- twice to New York City and once to Chicago. Each trip was for eight hours or less, and each had a specific purpose. Officials said more short trips were planned, about one a week, for memorial services and meetings with families of the dead.
But as is now the White House practice, officials will provide no further details, citing security. Most trips are announced only 48 hours in advance. Today, the White House gave less than an hour's notice that Mr. Bush would make a trip to Ronald Reagan National Airport to announce that it would reopen on Thursday.
On Wednesday in New York, the goals are to reassure traumatized schoolchildren and show concern about the economy. Mr. Bush will meet with pupils at Public School 130 in Chinatown, which was temporarily closed after the destruction of the World Trade Center. He will also participate in what the White House described as a round-table discussion with business leaders about the nation's sputtering finances.
In Chicago on Sept. 27, the goal was to announce new airline security measures and to exhort nervous Americans to travel again. In a visit to the trade center site on Sept. 14, the goal was not only to thank rescue workers but also to show New Yorkers that a president who had never shown much love for the city in fact cared.
"The biggest tool any White House has in its communications tool kit is the president's schedule and its events," said Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist and former Bush campaign official. "All eyes are on Bush right now, and he drives message better and faster than anybody else."
For now, the president's foreign travel schedule has been heavily pruned. His 10-day trip to Asia has been cut back to Oct. 20 and 21 for the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Leaders Meeting in Shanghai. His trip to India, which was only in the planning stages, is now doubtful. But the president still has plans to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at Mr. Bush's Texas ranch in mid-November. 
"When you're at war, somebody has to be at home minding the store," said Stephen Hess, a scholar of the presidency at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "Part of the reason for the travel abroad was a reassurance that we had a president who knew something about the world. The world now knows him, and has taken the mettle of the man. Those trips no longer have the symbolic significance that they were designed to have."
Richard C. Holbrooke, the American delegate to the United Nations in the Clinton administration, agreed that for now overseas travel was far less important for Mr. Bush. "He doesn't need to make foreign trips," Mr. Holbrooke said. "He needs to make sure that his administration speaks with one voice. It's more important for him to be the leader of a united nation at home than it is to travel abroad for personal relations. These trips are very cumbersome, and the ratio of substance to ceremony is pretty unimpressive. Furthermore, most of the foreign leaders are going to come to Washington to see him."
