HEADLINE: Drug Giant To Introduce Discount Plan For the Elderly 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN and MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
GlaxoSmithKline, the second-largest drug maker, plans to announce today that it is creating a national discount program for low-income elderly people who lack prescription drug coverage, reducing the price of its drugs by 25 percent or more.
 Under the program, millions of elderly people would qualify to receive an orange-colored card that could be shown at most pharmacies to receive discounts on all the company's medicines sold outside hospitals, including Avandia for diabetes, Paxil for depression, and Flovent for asthma, executives said. 
 Jean-Pierre Garnier, GlaxoSmithKline's chief executive, said the company wanted to help elderly customers who cannot afford prescription drug coverage and who do not qualify for government programs like Medicaid. Many of the elderly begin to take the company's drugs for chronic illnesses like diabetes or heart disease, he said, but stop after a few months because they cannot afford them. 
"It is a shame some patients can't get the full benefits of our drugs for economic reasons," Mr. Garnier said. "We are trying to close the gap."
The discount program will also give GlaxoSmithKline, which is based in Britain, a marketing boost. For millions of patients, GlaxoSmithKline's drugs may now be cheaper than similar brand-name medicines sold by competitors like Pfizer, Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb.
"I do believe some companies will follow us," Mr. Garnier said.
The company is unveiling its new discount program at a time when drug costs have become a potent political issue for politicians in Washington and across the country. For several years, Congress and the White House, under Presidents Clinton and Bush, have been working on legislation to add drug benefits to Medicare, the federal health insurance program for people who are elderly or disabled. 
The drug companies, including GlaxoSmithKline, have been pushing for their own version of a drug benefit -- one run by private companies under the auspices of the government -- in part because it would help decrease criticism of drug prices by advocates for the elderly. 
For now, Congress has delayed debate on a prescription drug benefit while it works on legislation responding to the terrorist attacks. 
Mr. Garnier said that the discount program, which will be announced today in Washington, would help low- income elderly people until a Medicare drug benefit could be passed.
Several advocates for the elderly welcomed GlaxoSmithKline's price cuts, but said they might make little difference to most elderly people living on fixed incomes.
GlaxoSmithKline's medicines accounted for only about 6 percent of the prescriptions recommended by doctors last year to patients 65 or older, according to IMS Health. And even with the company's new discount, the drugs may still be out of reach for many of the uninsured. 
For example, a month's supply of Avandia, GlaxoSmithKline's diabetes drug, sells for $152 at a pharmacy in upstate New York, where drugstores have to contend with low-priced competition from Canada. With the discount, the drug would cost about $114. That is about 5 percent of the maximum monthly income a patient would be allowed to make and still qualify for GlaxoSmithKline's program. And many elderly patients need to take several drugs every day. 
"This is as much a public relations effort on the part of Glaxo as anything," said Ron Pollack, the executive director of Families USA, a non-profit organization that works toward affordable health care. "The numbers of people who will get relief is likely to be very small."
GlaxoSmithKline was one of the first big pharmaceutical companies to discount its AIDS drugs in Africa after advocates there criticized drug prices and governments contemplated making copycat versions of patented drugs. Most companies that make AIDS medicines quickly offered similar discounts.
But it is not clear whether other drug companies will follow GlaxoSmithKline's new program. 
Pfizer, the nation's largest drug company, said yesterday that it would watch what happened with GlaxoSmithKline. Bristol-Myers Squibb said it was considering adding new discount programs to some of the more limited plans it already offered, but said it could not give details. Merck & Company said it did not know enough about the GlaxoSmithKline program to comment.
To qualify for the program, which the company is calling the Orange Card, consumers must be 65 or over and have annual incomes at or below 300 percent of the federal poverty level, which is $26,000 for an individual or $35,000 for a couple. In addition, eligible people cannot have prescription drug coverage through a private insurance plan or qualify for a public plan like Medicaid. Disabled people of any age who are enrolled in the Medicare program will qualify if they meet the other requirements. The company said 11 million people could qualify.
GlaxoSmithKline said that it was guaranteeing that the elderly would get discounts equal to 25 percent of the price charged to wholesalers, which is known in the industry as the wholesale acquisition price. The company said it had asked pharmacies to provide an additional discount, but those negotiations are continuing.
The company said that it believed elderly people would ultimately get discounts of 30 percent or more off the prices they would have otherwise paid at the pharmacy.
Elderly people will begin getting discounts on Jan. 1, but they can sign up for the program now.
There are already a number of discount prescription drug cards available, but many of them require annual fees, and some studies have found that they do not generate significant savings for consumers. Many of the cards also require most of the discount to come out of pharmacies' pockets rather than from the drug manufacturers. 
In July, President Bush announced that the government would endorse cards issued by private companies to help Medicare beneficiaries pool their purchasing power and get discounts on prescription drugs. But the administration's plan has been temporarily blocked by a lawsuit filed by hundreds of pharmacies, which say it will hurt their businesses financially.
Barrett Toan, chairman and chief executive of Express Scripts, a drug plan manager that will administer the Orange Card program, said GlaxoSmithKline, and not pharmacies, would cover most of the cost of the new program. 
Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a managing director and a specialist in health care at the Carlyle Group, an investment firm, called GlaxoSmithKline's discount program "an innovative response to the political and economic environment." 
Mr. Abramowitz said that if the company "doubled the consumption of its products in return for a 25 percent discount, they would still be 50 percent ahead."
Ira S. Loss, a health care researcher at Washington Analysis, which does research for financial institutions, said GlaxoSmithKline's discount program was a small step toward helping people without insurance. "It's not half a loaf but a couple slices," he said.
"The real impact is a question mark," Mr. Loss said. "The target population for these drugs cannot pay for them at 100 percent or at 75 percent" of the retail price.

HEADLINE: Can New York Recover Without Giuliani? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Fred Siegel ("Making the Most of Giuliani," Op-Ed, Oct. 2) calls on New Yorkers to take advantage of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent celebrity in order to maximize the financial contributions to New York City's recovery. This is an excellent idea, but his suggestion that the mayor stay in office past his lawful term to ease this recovery is misguided. 
 Why should we assume that the new mayor will be incompetent to govern and unable to build an effective administration, even temporarily? 
 The subversion of the normal democratic process is always the wrong choice, no matter the circumstances of the moment, no matter how deep the crisis. Nothing is more important for the city and the country than the orderly and lawful transfer of authority. It is a prerequisite for our recovery, both spiritually and economically.

PAUL H. HEBNER
New York, Oct. 2, 2001

HEADLINE: Subdivided and Licensed, There's No Place Like Art 

BYLINE:  By JOHN LELAND 

DATELINE: VALLEJO, Calif. 

 BODY:
CALIFORNIA landscapes have long served as laboratories for social experiments, from the visionary to the flaky. On Sept. 8, several hundred people gathered on former ranchland 35 miles northeast of San Francisco to see the latest chapter, writ in cute cottages and mock-cobblestone driveways. The housing development, still under construction, is called the Village, a Thomas Kinkade Community. With narrow streets, stone pillars and picket fences, it evokes a nostalgic homeyness, imposed on Vallejo's bare, sunburned hills.
 But its ambitions are far from old-fashioned. The 101-home gated community is a licensed product, modeled on the paintings of a Northern California artist named Thomas Kinkade and marketed under his imprimatur. A new twist on sprawl, "The Village," as the developer calls it, is billed as the first community based on the work of a single artist. 
 In the kitchen of one of four model homes, Mr. Kinkade, 43, casually placed the village and his role into context. He wore black jeans, a plaid shirt and a goatee. "When Walt looked out over his citrus grove and envisioned Disneyland, it wasn't real to him yet," Mr. Kinkade said, inviting a comparison he would return to throughout the morning. "When he walked down Main Street it became real. So this is that moment for me." 
Mr. Kinkade is not a looming figure in the museums or art schools of America. His paintings, of pretty houses in pretty landscapes, sell mainly in mall galleries dedicated to his work, and have the burnished resonance of easy listening music. Yet in the last four years, his prints and ancillary products -- from greeting cards to decorative plates -- have generated more than $450 million in revenues for the Media Arts Group, the Morgan Hill, Calif., company he formed to market his work. The company says one in every 20 American homes has a Kinkade work displayed, at prices ranging from a few dollars to $10,000 for limited-edition canvas lithographs. 
On this Saturday, Bruce and Kathy Breitler joined the crowd touring a Tudor-style home that included a stone tollhouse. Some had come to the open house out of curiosity, some to shop or to hear Mr. Kinkade speak. The houses, built by Taylor Woodrow Homes, a London-based developer, start at $425,000.
Like many of Mr. Kinkade's collectors, the Breitlers are middle class and educated but had never acquired art before. "We bought 'Spring Gate' for $3,000, and now it's worth $15,000," said Mrs. Breitler, 49, a speech pathologist. (All of Mr. Kinkade's prints are available in different sizes and price ranges; in the most expensive editions, he adds highlights himself and includes a trace of his DNA in the signature.) Now the Breitlers seek out Kinkade galleries wherever they travel. 
They said they were drawn to Mr. Kinkade not just for his pictures but for the values they saw in them. "Religion is not that important to us," said Mr. Breitler, 59, a school superintendent. "But it's nice to see he comes from a religious perspective and talks about family." 
The outlines of Mr. Kinkade's faith and life are familiar to his audience from several autobiographies as well as from regular promotional appearances at his galleries.
The son of a single mother, Mr. Kinkade grew up in the Northern California town of Placerville, by his account poor and drawn to art. After short stints at the University of California at Berkeley and the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, he landed briefly in Hollywood, painting backgrounds for an animated film called "Fire and Ice," directed by Ralph Bakshi. 
In the 1980's he had two life-shaping experiences. The first was becoming a born-again Christian. The second involved his direction in the art world. Perturbed by what he saw as the elitism of modern art, which he eventually blamed for everything from "South Park" to gangsta rap, he decided to bypass the gallery system and go retail, publishing cheap prints of his work and, later, opening his own galleries.
Mr. Kinkade, a big man, speaks in big, polished paragraphs. His paintings, he said, while not overtly Christian are intended as ministry. "I view art as an inspirational tool," he said. "People who put my paintings on their walls are putting their values on their walls: faith, family, home, a simpler way of living, the beauty of nature, quiet, tranquillity, peace, joy, hope. They beckon you into this world that provides an alternative to your nightly news broadcast. It's compelling to people. People are reminded that it's not all ugliness in the world."
In the language of his company, Mr. Kinkade is more than a painter. He is an "art-based lifestyle brand," traded on the New York Stock Exchange. As his paintings caught on, spreading beyond Northern California, he expanded his business to 357 galleries and a factory where a staff of painters add highlights to his lesser editions. He does not sell his originals.
In the late 1990's, Mr. Kinkade began to accessorize his vision of the simple life. He licensed his name to Avon, La-Z-Boy, Kincaid Furniture, Imperial Wall Coverings and dozens of other companies to produce Thomas Kinkade lines of home furnishings. All that was left, finally, was to create a town to put the stuff in. "We finally got to the point where we had to build the homes now," said Eric Kuskey of Creative Brands Group, the company that licenses Mr. Kinkade's name. Mr. Kuskey gestured to Kinkade products filling the model homes, among them furniture and computer screen savers. Even the stuffed animals, glued down to prevent theft, belonged to Kinkade lines. Though the developer does not sell the furniture, the tollhouse by the entry gate will remain a gallery for the painter's prints and gifts. Mr. Kuskey predicted that half the home buyers would come from Media Arts Group's mailing lists. 
Along Summer Gate Avenue, as the open house crowds took long detours into the free-food tent, Keith McCoy strolled in the pleasant sunshine. Mr. McCoy, who helped plan and design the development, is not overly partial to Mr. Kinkade's paintings. "I'd go more Monet or classic," he said. "This was more of a branding thing." Yet he was not one to argue with success. He said that 1,000 people had expressed interest in the village before the paint had dried on the first house.
To design the community, Taylor Woodrow Homes hired William Hezmalhalch Architects of Irvine, Calif., and sent them several Kinkade paintings, for tone more than architectural specifics. Mr. Kinkade later had approval over the marketing materials but did not contribute to the designs. 
Mr. Kinkade likened the process to his other licensing deals. "It's taking the paintings as a starting point and then creating another world of the imagination," he said. "We've got a series of novels being written based on my paintings. That's kind of the tail wagging the dog: you start out with the cover of the book, then you write a story to go around it.
"This is in a way what happened. I wasn't commissioned to go out and create paintings that would become a village. But I was doing paintings that celebrate home and family."
In the 13 minutes he granted for an interview, Mr. Kinkade used the word "family" 17 times. 
There is a disconnect between Mr. Kinkade's talk of community values and the village: it is a gated subdivision on a commuter strip, without shops, schools, businesses or houses of worship -- the pillars of the village life he espouses. "The truth is, this isn't a fully developed, self-contained community," he conceded. "It's a bridge community. You would find your church and services in other communities."
The brand identity, and the values Mr. Kinkade attaches to it, also heighten the insularity and uniformity that can imbue a gated community. The residents will be linked not just by their position behind the gate but also by the Kinkade brand.
The village is not the first attempt to build a Thomas Kinkade community. A developer in Oakland Township, Mich., built a model home based on Kinkade paintings, only to find that her area was not interested, said a local real estate agent.
Before the Taylor Woodrow deal, US Home, a national developer, struck a licensing deal to build a community that would take advantage of Mr. Kinkade's marketing strength.
"We looked at the auto industry and saw they were doing editions with Eddie Bauer interiors," said Sherman Haggerty, a division president of US Home. But when his company conducted focus groups, he said, "what they said they really wanted they wouldn't pay for." After a year and a half, the companies ended their agreement. 
How the village will survive the sinking economy, especially around Silicon Valley, remains to be seen. Media Arts Group's sales fell 6 percent in the fiscal year that ended March 31. The company's stock price has dropped to around $2 a share from a 1998 high of $24.25. Earlier this year, Mr. Kinkade, who owns 37 percent of the company's stock, withdrew a bid to take over the rest because he could not get financing.
"We've been hit but not as much as the economy as a whole," said Tony Thomopoulous, the chairman and interim chief executive officer. 
The village has drawn more interest than any previous Taylor Woodrow property, said Fran Leach, the marketing director, though the first offering of 28 houses has not sold out. Ms. Leach said the tragedy of Sept. 11 had not dimmed interest but had left buyers nervous, slower to commit. 
The developer hopes Mr. Kinkade's name and built-in market will prove an insurance policy against such a turndown, said Cheryl O'Connor, vice president for sales and marketing. His royalty on each house, she said, came to less than she would pay a real estate agent. 
"It's a total marketing gimmick -- I don't want to say gimmick -- a total marketing plan," Ms. O'Connor said.
Mr. McCoy said other developers were watching closely, some skeptically, some with an eye to follow suit. If the village weathers the tough market, look for the hills to sprout other branded communities. "I think you'll see Martha Stewart communities," he said. "Why not?"

HEADLINE: Off Broadway Finds Ways To Keep Shows Open 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
On a good week, many of New York City's hundreds of Off Broadway theaters struggle to make the rent, pay salaries and entice customers to travel to often out-of-the-way venues with less than comfortable seats. 
 In bad times like these, many theaters have been hit hard by a loss of income and attendance, but the scrappy determination that allows them to plow on in normal circumstances has them vowing to weather the post-Sept. 11 period and survive. 
 In some cases, they are better positioned to press on than Broadway shows, several of which were forced to fold without a fight. 
"These theaters have certainly been through trouble before and will be through trouble again," said Virginia P. Louloudes, the executive director of Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York, a support organization for the city's nonprofit theaters. "These people will do whatever it takes to get the show on." 
Nevertheless, Ms. Louloudes added, there is deep concern that with the bear market, the damaged New York economy and the financial drain on charitable organizations with a host of new priorities, Off Broadway will be in dire financial straits. 
"At some point, you need money to pay the rent, you need to pay your actors, you need to clean the theater, you need to hire someone to take the tickets," she said. "And if you don't have those revenues, it's going to be much more difficult to go on." 
As for audiences, however, Ms. Louloudes and others say, they will keep coming, as they proved in the weeks after the World Trade Center attacks. Off Broadway audiences are mostly made up of New Yorkers -- not tourists whose visits to the city have dropped off precipitously -- and are typically stalwart and devoted theatergoers. And its theaters are smaller than those on Broadway, making them easier to fill. Several companies sell tickets on a subscription basis, giving them a steady audience base. And they do not have Broadway's sometimes daunting ticket prices or pay scales.
So while shows are closing on Broadway, those Off Broadway have so far tried to adjust rather than buckle. "Bat Boy" which announced that it would close, is now planning to come back on Oct. 18 on a reduced performing schedule of five shows a week, down from eight. The musical "Tick, Tick . . . Boom!" -- which is on Jane Street in Greenwich Village and had to miss three performances after the terrorist attacks -- has also gone to a five-show week. "Rather than shutting down, we chose to keep the momentum going," Roy Gabay, the general manager, said. 
Both shows were helped by concessions from theatrical unions. Actors' Equity Association, which represents stage actors, is temporarily allowing Off Broadway producers to lay off actors for up to nine straight weeks (up to and including Thanksgiving week). During that period, the producers can reduce performances to as few as five a week. Actors will be paid one-eighth of their weekly salary for each performance.
The theaters are also engaging in self-help. The League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, their umbrella organization, is offering a 50-percent discount through the end of the month on tickets to participating Off Broadway shows. To be eligible, theatergoers must present ticket stubs from other participating Off Broadway shows that they have attended.
Meanwhile, from Access Theater at Broadway and White Street, which has an annual budget of $100,000, to the Roundabout Theater Company on West 42nd Street, which has a budget of $30 million, New York's more than 400 nonprofit theaters are hunkering down for the long haul, hoping that their audiences pull them through. 
"These audiences are by nature an adventurous, committed and interested group," said Mark Rossier, the director of development and marketing at the Alliance of Resident Theaters. "So they're going to continue to go."
That said, nonprofit theaters still face an uphill climb, particularly those below 14th Street. Many of those that own their buildings, have lost crucial income from renting out space.
"All of our major rentals for the fall have pulled out," said Jacqueline Christy, the artistic director of Access Theater, who started her theater company 11 years ago in an old fabric warehouse. "The big problem right now is how to pay the rent and keep the lights on."
Daniel Aukin, artistic director of the Soho Repertory Theater on Walker Street, said his theater, which develops new plays, expects to lose about $25,000 from rental cancellations and $10,000 in ticket sales.
Some of Soho Rep's donors -- whose contributions make up about a quarter of the theater's $280,000 budget -- have said they now can't come through on their financial commitments. "A number of people who write larger checks are unable to, based on the hit their own businesses have taken," Mr. Aukin said. 
Theaters across the board are bracing themselves for this drop-off in funds. "We were heading into a slow economy to begin with," said Todd Haimes, artistic director of the Roundabout. "Now it's hard to believe there won't be a significant impact on contributions."
Although attendance has been rising since Sept. 11, some people are still in staying-home mode, so theaters say that filling seats remains a concern. 
This situation was particularly true for the theaters near ground zero immediately after the disaster. Soho Rep is in an area that was closed to pedestrians, and its phone line was down. The theater decided to proceed with the opening last week of a workshop production, "Signals of Distress," adapted from the novel by Jim Crace. To get the word out, the theater established a temporary box office phone number and publicized the production through e-mail, phone calls and signs posted in the neighborhood. Soho Rep prepared to escort audience members from the police barricade at Canal Street to the theater, but that proved unnecessary; the barricades were down by opening night, and the performance sold out.
Ms. Christy of Access Theater mailed ticket buyers written permission to pass through the police barricade to get to the theater at Broadway and White Street. The police, she said, honored the notes. 
Because it needed the money, the company canceled a planned workshop of one-act plays to allow its current rental -- a one-woman show called "After the Storm" -- to extend its run. Whether the theater will be able to proceed with its season's two main productions is in doubt.
The Flea Theater on White Street was closed for two weeks after the attacks and lost about $800 a day on rental income and canceled performances. Erik Sniedze, the associate producer, said the company was trying to raise money to pay last month's rent.
At nonprofit theaters uptown, the effects were also profound. The Signature Theater Company on West 42nd Street is raising money in the lobby for a "Sept. 11 Fund" put together by New York Community Trust and the United Way. Saks Fifth Avenue is matching the first $20,000 of the theater's $40,000 goal. 
Signature's artistic director, James Houghton, said he is trying to provide a sense of community for the theater's regulars.
"The immediate goal is to just bring people together, and the theater can do that," Mr. Houghton said.
Indeed, many theater professionals said that offering places where people can seek company, comfort or distraction was reason enough to continue.
In looking ahead, the theater impresarios said that even at a time that called for national unity, part of their recovery will come from remaining contentious and contrary. "Our mission is to produce work that is provocative or even subversive," said Douglas Aibel, artistic director of the Vineyard Theater on West 15th Street. "If we produce more comforting or crowd-pleasing work, we will be captive once again to these savages who did this to us."
George C. Wolfe, producer at the Joseph Papp Public Theater on Lafayette Street, said it was important for playwrights not to second guess what audiences can handle in the wake of the tragedy. "I'm really very cautious about getting into any process of censoring or surrendering ambition or edge," Mr. Wolfe said, "because I think it's what makes this city great."
No matter how difficult things become, the theaters' founders and operators said they were determined not to go under. "This theater is my baby," Ms. Christy of Access Theater said. "So I'm not going to let it die." Mr. Wolfe added, "Even in Shakespeare's biggest tragedies there is always a character who comes on stage and says, 'We must go forward.' "

HEADLINE: Securing the Lines Of a Wired Nation 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
IN the hours of torment and confusion after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, many people making phone calls to or from the affected cities encountered the grating "All circuits are busy" recording. E-mail messages, however, seemed to sail through the crisis to their destinations. The smooth traffic was hailed by many experts as testament to the underlying strength of the Internet. 
 But hold on just one nanosecond. Are we talking about the Internet, referred to by so many other experts as a famously vulnerable, fragile network that can be brought to its knees by college students in the Philippines or a teenager in Canada, with estimates of damage in the billions of dollars? 
 It is indeed the same Internet, ever a combination of flaky and robust. Fred Cohen, the computer security researcher who first applied the word "virus" to malicious software, said that the individual elements of the network were fragile but that the network over all was resilient. "It's easy to tear a piece of paper," he said. "Try tearing a phone book in half." Still, David J. Farber, a computer scientist and former chief technologist at the Federal Communications Commission, said that the Internet's success on Sept. 11 could largely be attributed to the fact that "nobody attacked it." 
Experts in the emerging field of cyberterrorism say that with such an inviting target, terrorists are bound to take up the hackers' wares. What will happen when an attacker with real resources and a deep desire to do harm grabs the keyboard?
It may not take long to find out, and the vulnerability may go far beyond Web sites or e-mail.
According to a report last week by the Institute for Security Technology Studies, founded last year at Dartmouth, "U.S. retaliatory strikes for the tragic Sept. 11 events may result in cyberattacks against the American electronic infrastructure." While such attacks may amount to no more than familiar nuisances -- like hackers' defacing Web pages or tying up sites by overwhelming them with traffic -- "the potential exists for much more devastating cyberattacks," the report said.
Those who watch trends in computer crime and terrorism say that the two are coming together with potentially catastrophic results. Richard A. Clarke, who will head cyberterrorism efforts for the Bush administration's Homeland Security Council, said in a speech last December that the government had to make cybersecurity a priority or face a "digital Pearl Harbor." 
In 1997, the President's Commission on Critical Infrastructure Protection noted that telephone networks and the Internet were increasingly the bonds of the world's economy, for everything from financial operations to the supply of water and power. 
Consequently, it said, "a computer can cause switches or valves to open and close, move funds from one account to another, or convey a military order almost as quickly over thousands of miles as it can from next door, and just as easily from a terrorist hideout as from an office cubicle or military command center." 
For Tom Marsh, who was the commission's chairman, the worst-case scenarios are nightmarish: a determined coalition of hackers, he said, could disrupt 911 service, air traffic control, the power-switching centers that move electricity around the country, rail networks and more. "It's a major undertaking," said Mr. Marsh, a retired Air Force general, "but it's not beyond the realm of possibility." The complexity of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, he said, showed that "even terrorist organizations can conduct very well-organized and sophisticated attacks." 
"We said in our report we didn't foresee an electronic Pearl Harbor, and I still don't," he said. "But I do believe that as cybercrime progresses, over time the terrorists are going to get more and more interested in it and see it as a very possible opportunity to cause major disruption."
Those who have worked in cyberintelligence say that the attention to the subject is timely. "Up until the 11th, people like me would talk in terms of the growing threat of transnational attack -- the prospect of new forms of terrorism -- and the basic reaction was, 'Yeah, yeah, yeah, but that's theoretical,' " said Jeffrey A. Hunker, dean of the Heinz School of Public Policy and Management at Carnegie Mellon University and formerly the senior director for protection of critical infrastructure at the National Security Council.
Since the attacks, he said, it has become clear that "there are clearly transnational organizations that are incredibly capable of executing sophisticated operations and are enormously creative and innovative." That, in turn, "makes much more real the possibility of new techniques or new types of terrorist attacks," including cyberterror, he said. "We're sitting on a cyber time bomb," he said.
Some experts have warned, for example, that systems accessible to the Internet like power grids could be brought down by a determined hacker, though as Mr. Farber put it, "it's a lot easier to throw a hand grenade down the highway south of San Jose and take out a major power station" than to do so by modem. And most would put cyberattacks in a different category from the weapons of mass destruction associated with visions of catastrophic terrorism; these are not nuclear arms, nerve gas or germs. Instead, many experts now call them weapons of mass disruption. 
"People aren't going to be killing us with computers," Mr. Hunker said, "but our life may be hell because of computer attacks."
The likeliest use of the technology, he said, would be to complicate matters further after a real-world attack, a tactic he describes with the military phrase "force multiplier." That could involve planting false information on the Web to create a panic or taking down crucial computers in the financial or communications sectors. 
The ripple effects of the World Trade Center attacks on everything from the travel industry to supply chains in manufacturing show the potential for havoc. "Besides the fact of the horrendous loss of life, it was really an attack on the critical infrastructures," said Mary J. Culnan, a professor of management and information technology at Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., and a member of the presidential commission that issued the 1997 report.
The Clinton administration started the first major national effort to upgrade computer security in government and business against cybercrime and terrorist attack. President Bill Clinton issued an order in May 1998 creating the National Infrastructure Protection Center, a collaborative effort of law enforcement, military and intelligence organizations to shore up defenses against computer crime. The center also developed an information-sharing network with major industrial sectors. 
Such activities will presumably be brought under the umbrella of the new Homeland Defense Council that President Bush has appointed Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania to run. Mr. Clarke will oversee cyberdefense initiatives for the council as head of its Office of Cyber Security.
Michael Vatis, the head of the Dartmouth cybersecurity group and a former head of the National Infrastructure Protection Center, said the stereotype of computer intruders as thrill-seeking teenage loners was misleading. Talented intruders who are motivated -- and perhaps banding together with criminal or ideological motives -- can go far, he said, citing little-publicized attacks on business and Pentagon computer networks by hackers who may be linked to organized crime in Russia. The attacks, beginning in 1998, are the focus of a federal investigation. "The type of access they were able to gain," he said, and "the amount of information and the types of information they were getting means they could do lots of stuff to those systems," both purloining data and disrupting operations.
Even more dangerous than outsiders, potentially, are insiders with specialized knowledge, according to the 1997 report of the President's Commission on Critical Infrastructure Protection. That report estimated that by this year 19 million people worldwide would have the skills to engage in malicious hacking and 1.3 million people would have advanced knowledge of the systems that control the nation's telecommunications infrastructure.
Whatever the nature of the attack, the tools are easy to acquire and the knowledge to use them even more so. A reasonably competent programmer who is willing to delve into the arcana of computer operating systems and networks can cobble together viruses or other destructive computer code from software posted online. Similarly, tools for examining computer systems for security holes and the programs that can be used to take advantage of them to gain unauthorized entry are also easy to find online, and computer vandals are happy to share their knowledge in Internet forums.
So what is to be done? Most of the measures that experts recommend, like keeping up with the latest antivirus software, using strong passwords to protect computers and networks and installing intrusion-detection software, are painfully obvious but still ignored by many businesses, government agencies and consumers. The Dartmouth report also recommends increasing protection at Web sites and keeping backups of their important data, with special attention to the potential for Web page defacement. 
That report also recommends vigilance, and appropriate software, to prevent or detect the surreptitious commandeering of computer systems for use in denial-of-service attacks. (A guide to the best security practices can be found at www.cert.org /security-improvement.)
Informal networks for intrusion detection are beginning to form among those who hope to find security in numbers. One such network, AirCert, has been developed by the CERT Coordination Center at Carnegie Mellon's Software Engineering Institute. The fledgling AirCert project places Internet-based security sensors on participating sites; those sensors automatically send data on intrusion attempts to a central CERT knowledge base that is able to analyze the information and share it quickly.
The idea has been suggested before. A network for intrusion detection in government computers, called Fidnet, was proposed late in the Clinton administration but never created because of assertions that the system might be used as a large-scale monitoring network for citizens' online communications. Government officials insist that was never the intention, but Mr. Vatis said that they did not make their case well.
Making that case may now be easier, but Professor Culnan, at Bentley College, said that mounting an effective deterrent to cyberterror was no small task. "It's a gigantic problem making this work," she said. "But at least we've started thinking about it."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
Australia Growing Up, But in a Warped Mirror

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Australia is our distant, down-the-rabbit-hole cousin, a nation that is vaguely the geographical size and shape of our own, where they speak the same language (more or less), worship the gods of capitalism and democracy, cope with racial inequities and economic disparity, generally have the freedom and wherewithal to laugh at themselves and hold to a pride at being a people that raised itself up by its own bootstraps.
 Still, for most of us it looms as a strange place, representing a skewed version of our culture, a younger America that has been nurtured by the atmosphere on the other side of the world. The warped-mirror quality is the most piquing element of "Cloudstreet," a theatrical epic being presented through Sunday at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. 
 The opening salvo of the academy's monthlong Next Wave Down Under festival, "Cloudstreet" is a mid-20th-century story of two very different families, the Pickleses and the Lambs, who out of desperation and serendipity end up sharing an enormous old house in Perth, on the west coast, which one character describes "as the most isolated country town in the world trying to be a city." 
And particularly in its first half, both the play (adapted by Nick Enright and Justin Monjo from a 1991 novel by Tim Winton) and the production (by Company B Belvoir from Sydney and Black Swan Theater from Perth, directed by Neil Armfield), achieve a rollicking momentum, hooking the audience with event-filled melodrama, well-defined if broad characters brought to life with idiosyncratic performances, and stagecraft that is both visually stirring and resourceful.
But at more than five hours long (including a dinner break and a second intermission), this production has more grandiose ambitions than merely entertaining the theatergoing tourist and doesn't come close to fulfilling them.
With the bravado of a national anthem, "Cloudstreet" spans more than two decades, from the 1940's through the 60's, a time when Australia emerged as a modern nation economically, began to develop a national identity and culture and became, two centuries after its colonization by Europeans, an inclusive democracy; its Aboriginal inhabitants were not able to vote until 1967.
Little of this is addressed directly in the play; rather, there is a dim awareness of changing times hovering around the two families -- the hard-working and nominally pious Lambs and the spirited, careless Pickleses -- who ostensibly represent two strains of the nascent Australian middle class.
The Lambs, Lester and Oriel, have four daughters and two sons; the Pickleses, Sam and Dolly, two sons and a daughter. (At the start, some are quite young; be prepared to see adult actors squealing like children and one wearing a towel as a diaper.) Not exactly enemies, the two families are mutually resentful and dismissive, and the play is at its best in its first-half scenes in which the characters are established and the inevitable merging of the two families is set subtly in motion.
Part of the script involves characters stepping forward and addressing the audience as if narrating their own thoughts. This device is melded swiftly and smoothly with straightforward dramatic scenes covering a Dickensian variety of events, from commonplace to outrageously coincidental, bland to portentous, dangerous and sexy to homey and aw-shucks. These give the play a distinct novelistic quality and the irresistible undulations of a book like, say Larry McMurtry's "Lonesome Dove."
This feeling is helped by fine characterizations, including John Gaden as the sweetly worrisome Lester Lamb, an accidental entrepreneur (he makes and sells ice cream; lucky audience members may get a sample); Gillian Jones as his severe, sorrowful wife, Oriel; Roy Billing, a stout and energetic actor in the Bob Hoskins mold, as the inveterate gambler and drinker, Sam Pickles, and Kris McQuade as Dolly, the slatternly, mean-witted wife Sam helplessly loves. In particular, Ms. McQuade, whose silk-and-gravel voice is as distinct as any I've ever heard on the stage, is riveting in a portrayal that can be as sexy as it is down and out, as funny as it is dastardly.
Indeed, it is in spite of the best efforts of this talented and well-rehearsed 15-member cast, whose memory work alone is awe-inspiring (in the course of 101 scenes, many are responsible for multiple roles that include stagehand), that the show slides precipitately in the second half into prosaic declaration, anthemic pomposity and pretentious metaphor.
Amid increasingly ponderous language that touts the unbreakable bonds of family and the creation of a unified Australian clan and flavors its patriotic soup with a carefully measured dollop of politically correct shame, the house at 1 Cloud Street emerges in the shape of Australia.
A Lamb son and a Rose daughter marry, move back home and become happily middle class; he becomes a policeman to participate in "the war against evil," as he puts it. An Aboriginal character known simply as Black Man becomes an increasing presence as a narrator -- the underlying guilt of white Australia -- which is as pandering as it is heavy-handed.
Emblematic of the play's overpresumption of its welcome is the character of Fish Lamb (Daniel Wyllie), to whom we are introduced in the opening sequence; in one of the show's most stirring scenes dramatically and visually, he is transformed from a fun-loving boy into a permanent 3-year-old when he nearly drowns in a boating accident, suffering brain damage.
The accident, in which Mr. Wyllie, suspended above the stage, thrashes about in a fishing net with his family shrieking below, first with laughter and then with terror, is gorgeous, chilling and simply conceived. And along with the illustrative music (both recorded and live, written by Iain Grandage and performed on piano and cello by Matthew Hoy) and the set -- a wooden plank floor on a stage-filling bed of sand, with a drawable curtain at the rear and most of the props stacked in view along the side -- it shows off the artful ingenuity of Mr. Armfield and his team of designers.
But then we have to live with Mr. Wyllie for several more hours; he's gained a telepathic gift along with his disability, and he communes with the ghosts in the house -- young indigenous women mistreated by the white mistress -- becoming the one character in the play with a conscious sense of historical injustice. But he can no longer communicate, get it?
Bellowing and whining, stumbling about with a Frankenstein-like gait, sometimes in soiled underpants, he is as persuasive a toddler as a 200-pound man can be. But he's not cute for long. Maybe they're more indulgent of their children down there, but in Brooklyn you wish the play would be more thoughtful and put him to bed.

CLOUDSTREET

Adaped by Nick Enright and Justin Monjo from the novel by Tim Winton; directed by Neil Armfield, set by Robert Cousins; costumes by Tess Schofield; lighting by Mark Howett; music composed by Iain Grandage; sound by Gavin Tempany; choreography by Kate Champion; assistant director, Anatoly Frusin. A production of Company B Belvoir from Sydney and the Black Swan Theater from Perth. Part of the Next Wave Down Under festival of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Bruce C. Ratner, chairman; Alan H. Fishman, chairman, campaign for BAM; Karen Brooks Hopkins, president; Joseph V. Mellilo, executive producer. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the Harvey Lichtenstein Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene.

WITH: Wayne Blair (Black Man), Roy Billing (Sam Pickles and Mr. Wentworth), John Gaden (Lester Lamb and Lawyer), Claire Jones (Rose Pickles), Gillian Jones (Oriel Lamb and Mrs. Tisborne), Kris McQuade (Dolly Pickles and Alma), Christopher Pitman (Quick Lamb) and Daniel Wyllie (Fish Lamb).

HEADLINE: Services Index Rises, but Trend Is Not YetClear 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
A survey of services activity that captured only some effects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks rose in September.
 The survey, by the National Association of Purchasing Management, showed yesterday that the transportation industries suffered. But survey officials maintained that business activity was virtually unchanged. 
 The association said the index snapped a two-month decline, rising to 50.2 in September from 45.5 in August. The results surpassed analysts' forecasts of 43.0.
But the association contended that the data "basically indicated no change in activity in September compared to August."
Ralph Kauffman, chairman of the survey committee, said in a teleconference that "chances are" that the index would have been higher had the attacks not occurred. "But the fact that it registered virtually no change from August," he asserted, "shows we didn't completely go off a cliff."
A bounce in export orders and imports led the rise in the overall index. A reading above 50 indicates expanding activity in services, which include a range of businesses like transportation, law and financial services.
The association's manufacturing index, published on Monday, has been mired below 50 for 14 months. The services, or nonmanufacturing, index has shown expansion for only two of the last six months.
Steven Wood, economist at FinancialOxygen, said: "With mounting job losses, eroding income gains and deteriorating consumer and business confidence, further contraction is likely in the months ahead. The economy was likely in recession before Sept. 11; if it was not, it is now."
Predictably, the report showed that business activity, new orders and employment all weakened in transportation industries as airlines grounded planes and canceled flights after the attacks.
The report noted that some members of the association expected a positive impact, particularly in armaments and some energy industries.
Ian Shepherdson of High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., expressed hesitation. "It may be that the full effects of Sept. 11 will appear over the coming months," Mr. Shepherdson said. But he called the survey, which many economists deem unreliable given its short four-year history, "helpful but far from conclusive."
The association's nonmanufacturing new orders index, seen as a leading indicator of future business activity, rose to 49.8 in September from 45.9 in August.

HEADLINE: OPEC Considers Reducing Oil Production 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Less than a week after deciding to maintain production levels despite sharply declining oil prices, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is considering a decrease in output by 500,000 barrels a day, said the group's secretary general, Ali Rodriguez Araque.
 OPEC members might opt for the reduction if the average of seven benchmark prices for crude oil remains below $22 a barrel for 10 consecutive days, a stretch that ends Friday. On Tuesday, that average hovered around $20.30. 
 "We are consulting with other ministers to make a decision" to reduce production quotas, Mr. Rodriguez told Bloomberg News yesterday "If there isn't cooperation, world economic growth is very, very low, and we can expect a collapse in prices." 
It remained far from clear why Mr. Rodriguez chose to reveal the deliberations or if the 10-member cartel would actually authorize a reduction in output, analysts said. Last week, when the group met at its headquarters in Vienna, OPEC left production at its current level of 23.2 million barrels a day, although prices had plummeted as the global economy drifted into recession and oil demand dwindled. 
At any other time, the cartel, which supplies about 40 percent of the world's oil, would have propped up prices by reducing oil supplies. But OPEC has worried about appearing greedy and insensitive at a time when the United States is coping with terrorist attacks and the global economy is reeling in their aftermath. While some analysts wondered whether Mr. Rodriguez's comments indicated a shift in OPEC's thinking spurred by a growing desperation, most said they thought the secretary general was trying to calm a skittish market. 
"Our sense is that they will try 'to talk the market up,' " said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "I would be surprised if they were so insensitive as to cut production now."
The cancellation of airline flights in the United States after the attacks and the drop in fuel demand as the economy stalled has bloated oil stocks and damped prices. Supplies of crude oil in the United States, at 307.7 million barrels, are 7 percent greater than a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute's weekly storage data. The news of greater supplies drove down prices of crude oil for November delivery by 3.1 percent, or 71 cents, to $22.08 a barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Oil prices have fallen 20 percent since Sept. 11.
The problem is, if OPEC promises to buoy prices and they remain low, the cartel might be pressed into decreasing official quotas, a move most analysts consider ill-advised, because of the fragility of the global economy. Instead, OPEC indicated at its meeting last week that it would tighten oil supplies by stanching the rampant overproduction within its ranks. 
Oil prices fell gradually this year before Sept. 11, but nearly all OPEC members pumped more than their official quotas to cash in on the then relatively high price of about $25 a barrel. A production cut of a million barrels a day, OPEC's third of the year, went into effect Sept. 1, and analysts said that if members could actually hold to it, oil supplies would shrink enough to bolster prices.
Although OPEC could reduce output by 500,000 barrels a day if prices dip below $22 a barrel, some analysts said OPEC might be able to tolerate $20 a barrel for some time, given the shakiness of the economy and the uncertainty over the United States response to the attacks. But even lower prices alarm the cartel, whose members rely almost exclusively on oil to finance their states. 
"OPEC is very worried," said Mehdi Varzi, senior energy consultant with the investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein. "They've been used to high prices for two years, and high prices are like a drug. They can't balance their budgets if prices fall below $20."

HEADLINE: Up the Creek in the Bronx; 
Fulton Fish Market Unhappy in Its New Home

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
The thing about fish is that it's got to be sold today. This is both a natural and an economic law. 
 This universal truth is being pleaded by fishmongers at the Fulton Fish Market, who, because of the World Trade Center attack, are no longer mongering fish from their open-air stalls in southern Manhattan, but rather from a desolate and filthy parking lot in the South Bronx. 
 The market, it seems, created traffic problems. So its relocation went into effect Sept. 15 on the order of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. 
"When the semis and forklifts are operating and fish is being sold outdoors, South Street is shut down," said Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation. "We need that street for the relief effort."
The move has brought impending bankruptcies, layoffs of workers, worries of a spoiled seafood supply and struggles for the neighborhood around the South Street Seaport, the merchants said.
The market is currently at 600 Food Center Drive in the Hunts Point Market site, the Bronx. It is sandwiched between the meat cooperative and the littered banks of the Bronx River. It leans like a shantytown against the old Hebrew National Foods warehouse. The names of the fish purveyors are spray-painted on the building. Just across an access road is a polluted brownfield and a dumping ground for batteries, house paints and other toxic materials.
"It's a horror story," said Joe Centrone, a cantankerous cigar-stained salesman for Arrow Seafood, who is known around the market as Joe Tuna. "We're getting slaughtered. None of the customers can find us up here, and even if they could, this ain't the nicest neighborhood in New York."
To make matters worse, the square footage of the temporary market is one-third the space of the Fulton Fish Market. The 1,200 forklifts, trucks and vans must jockey for available space among the narrow aisles and roads while avoiding the customers and workmen pushing handcarts. The merchandise is piled so haphazardly that the salesmen find it difficult to remember what fish they have in stock. 
The 59 wholesale operators find themselves working in the elements, without computers or cash registers, with nothing to shield them from the rain and wind. The sleet of December is on everyone's mind.
Since the move to the Bronx, merchants estimate that volume is down 40 to 50 percent. The market normally moves 100,000 boxes of produce a week, which translates into a $1 billion annual industry for New York City. But many say that business is now so poor that they don't think they can last another month in the current situation.
"It's a temporary home with no end in sight," said Vincent Tatick, president of the Joseph H. Carter Fish Company. "The city thinks they're helping us. But over all this location is killing us. If we can get back home, we want to get back home yesterday."
The wholesalers were scheduled to move to a new location in the Bronx in 2003, but construction on that project will not begin until later this fall, city officials said. For now, they will have to endure the parking lot.
"We've got no problem with the temporary move," said Tony Cirillo, president of Local 359 of the United Food and Commercial Workers, the union that represents the 400 journeymen and salesmen at the fish stalls. "We're Americans and we want to do our part. But enough is enough. The New York Stock Exchange is back open for business, for pete's sake. How about us?"
Because business is so bad, Mr. Cirillo said, 50 of his men have been laid off and more job losses are expected next week. 
"These are good jobs," he said. "This whole thing has a negative trickle-down on families and the city."
Some people at the market say Mayor Giuliani is using a national emergency to punish them for their long-running resistance to his authority. Mr. Giuliani effectively crushed the influence of organized crime at the Fulton Fish Market in the mid-1990's, requiring licensing and background checks on workers, which forced more than a dozen companies out of business.
City officials say the move is nothing more than an emergency measure to keep the fish market, the largest in the United States, solvent, and that every effort is being made to get the Fulton Fish Market back up and running. 
"There was no electricity or telephones and Lower Manhattan was immobilized," Ms. Patterson said. "At this point, South Street is an artery needed for the relief effort, and it's hard to say when we'll be able to move them back." 
The market operates like an open-air auction house, except there are no barkers and no tote boards to reflect supply and demand. Prices are set by the individual consignees and are determined by a strange combination of weather reports, fishermen's gossip and the prices at the neighboring stalls. 
The men still come to work at midnight, as they have for a century. Their language is rough and blasphemous. But many buyers, who come from as far away as South Jersey and northern Connecticut, are going to the Philadelphia and Boston markets rather than take their chances in the Bronx during the dark morning hours, the salesmen said. 
Judging by the sanitary conditions of the temporary fish house, one cannot blame them. The quarters are wretched. Rodent droppings line the walls. Exhaust fumes from the forklifts mingle with the fish. The floors are a slop of mud and oil.
The few toilets are filthy, and there are only a few hoses to wash down the entire 50,000 square feet of indoor cooler and storage space. The equipment at the temporary market includes 20 diesel trucks used for refrigeration, 15 portable spotlights and a handful of outhouses. One truck recently malfunctioned and $13,000 worth of seafood was lost overnight.
A city official who works with the market seemed content with the cleanliness of the Hunts Point location, saying the area is power-washed daily and the garbage is picked up. 
"Have you ever seen Fulton Market?" the official said. "It always looks filthy at the end of the selling day."
There is also the economic health of the old neighborhood to consider. Carmine's restaurant, at Front and Beekman Streets, and a favorite of market hands, has lost most of its food business, the owner reports.
Then there is Annie, a pillar of the Fulton Fish Market. She earns a meager living selling newspapers and socks and cigarettes. She has no pension. What happened to Annie, the men asked yesterday morning. 
Around 4 a.m., she arrived by car service. They were glad to see her until someone figured it out.
"Annie's here?" he said. "Oh, God. That means we're here to stay."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
For Polaroid, the bad news seems to be the only news.

BYLINE:  By Claudia H. Deutsch 

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT corporate America, the economic aftermath of Sept. 11 means hard times. For a company like the Polaroid Corporation, which was already well down the path to insolvency, it could mean the end of the road.
 The sluggish economy was already causing trouble for photography companies, long before terrorism reared its head. For example, the Eastman Kodak Company said last week that its third-quarter earnings would be much lower than the company had anticipated, because of low sales in August. Now Kodak, like many film companies, finds its bleak outlook even bleaker, as travel and revelry -- prime picture-taking opportunities -- are in a slump. 
 But Kodak, Fuji, Canon and most other photography players will probably revive when the economy does. Analysts are not as optimistic about Polaroid.
"Polaroid just does not generate enough cash to make it through until the economy recovers, and Sept. 11 made it even less likely that the company will ever be healthy," said Gibboney Huske, a Credit Suisse First Boston analyst who dropped coverage of Polaroid stock in July because she no longer saw equity value in it. 
The stock, which traded at $14.19 a year ago, closed yesterday at 49 cents a share, down 6 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. About 17 percent of those penny-stock shares are owned by employees. 
On Monday, the company, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., notified its employees that its pension fund had a $100 million shortfall, though Polaroid added that the fund's existing assets of more than $900 million would cover 90 percent of benefits.
Gary T. DiCamillo, Polaroid's chief executive since 1995, turned down requests for an interview, and no one at the company would speculate about its future.
Polaroid's problems have been a long time building. Financial missteps grew from maneuvers the company took in 1988 to duck a hostile takeover. And strategic blunders included a delayed reaction and a series of clumsy responses to the threat digital photography posed to Polaroid's chemical-and-paper instant pictures.
For years, though, the magnitude of those mistakes were not evident to the outside world. In February 1996 the company's management was promising Wall Street that by 2000 its annual sales would be more than $3.4 billion. In fact, last year's revenue was only $1.9 billion. The company began losing money in the third quarter of 2000, and the red ink keeps flowing.
Today, its credit and bond ratings are barely above junk grade. Polaroid has about $950 million in debt, more than half of it short term. Even though its banks have kept giving short-term waivers on principal repayments, the company's credit line will run out on Dec. 31. It has defaulted on several interest payments to bondholders and has $150 million in bonds that mature on Jan. 15. 
Polaroid says the negotiations with its bondholders are going well, but if they break down, they could force the company into bankruptcy. Some analysts have suggested that Polaroid pre-empt such a move by filing for voluntary bankruptcy, or reach a deal with bondholders that would let it trade much of its debt for equity. 
Other analysts expect either a financial investor or a camera company to buy Polaroid. Several point to Canon, which would welcome Polaroid's consumer distribution network, or to Olympus Optical, which already produces a hybrid digital and instant-film camera in partnership with Polaroid. Neither company would comment on the speculation.
"I expect by the time the year is out, the chairman will have resigned, Polaroid will have sold significant assets or the whole company, or bondholders will have clamped down," Ms. Huske said.
The real financial trouble dates to the hostile takeover attempted by Shamrock Holdings in 1988. Polaroid fought back by creating its employee stock plan, buying back shares and issuing preferred stock that was convertible to debt. Polaroid kept its independence, but by 1989 it was $600 million in debt -- $920 million, counting the preferred stock. It has rarely been debt-free since.
Analysts say Polaroid should have paid down the debt using some of the $925 million it received in 1991, when Kodak settled a patent violation suit. Instead, Polaroid tried to shore up its plunging stock by buying back shares, and to become more efficient by buying expensive resource planning software. Both moves pushed it further into a fiscal hole. 
Nor was digital photography a sudden new threat. "We'd known for 20 years that digital imaging was coming," said Carol Ulrich, a former president of commercial imaging who resigned in 1999 after 30 years with Polaroid. 
Ms. Ulrich had suggested a year earlier -- when Polaroid shares were selling at about $42 -- that the company sell itself. But Polaroid's board chose a different path: it would slash costs and sell real estate; farm out manufacturing and bring in marketing partners; milk older products for cash to finance newer ones. 
Polaroid's new instant cameras, like the JoyCam and the I-Zone, are selling well, but few analysts expect them to attain the popularity that instant cameras once had. "Polaroid mistakenly thought its new cameras were growth businesses, when in fact they have half the life and half the consumption of the older ones," said Robert L. Renck, who runs the brokerage firm R. L. Renck & Company. 
The company does have some promising new technologies -- notably, a couple of thermal printing processes that dispense with toners and inks. But these may be arriving too late. 
While many other companies are now pegging problems to the Sept. 11 attacks, Polaroid might have trouble making that case. Consumers rarely took Polaroid's bulky cameras on vacations, for example, so canceled trips would have less impact on it than, say, Kodak or Fuji. And government agencies and private companies, fearful of terrorism, might have clamored to utilize Polaroid's considerable expertise in making picture ID's. 
Mining that niche, though, has been more beneficial to a small company, Viisage Technology, which specializes in ID cards. Its shares soared from less than $2 on Sept. 10 to $9.80 last week before closing at $6.15 in Nasdaq trading yesterday -- even though Polaroid's $200 million annual ID business dwarfs Viisage's $26 million. 
"Even if the ID business takes off, it'll be too little too late," Ms. Huske said. 
Investors might not even notice an uptick, said Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Buckman, Buckman & Reid. He noted that Polaroid has been talking about selling the ID unit to raise cash.
"The market knows that Polaroid has valuable assets," Mr. Yannas said, "but it still thinks the company is kaput."

HEADLINE: New Rules on No-Fly Zones Are Hurting Smaller Airports 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: TETERBORO, N.J., Oct. 3 

 BODY:
The establishment of no-fly zones for private aircraft around major airports in the Washington and New York metropolitan areas after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks is costing smaller airports hundreds of thousands of dollars and threatening thousands of jobs, industry officials said today.
 In the New York region, the restriction on so-called general aviation flights within a 25-mile radius of Kennedy International Airport in Queens has grounded two-thirds of the flights here at Teterboro Airport in Bergen County, and at Republic Airport in Farmingdale on Long Island, airport officials say. Charter flights, which must file flight plans ahead of time and are easier to track, are permitted. 
 Westchester County Airport in White Plains, N.Y., is exempt from the 25-mile no-fly radius in order to allow some private flights in and out of the New York region, said William Shumann, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.
Federal officials are aware of the hardships, and are weighing national security concerns against granting relief by reducing the radius to 18 miles, which would allow flights at Teterboro, Mr. Shumann said. A special exemption has been requested for Republic Airport, which is 17.3 miles from Kennedy.
"Republic is losing $200,000 a day," said Representative Steve Israel, a Long Island congressman who has called on federal officials to tighten the radius and allow private flights at Republic and Teterboro. "If you're a terrorist and you charter a flight, you have no problem taking off. But if you're a businessman on Long Island, you're restricted."
Mr. Israel, who collected signatures from fellow members of the Long Island Congressional delegation on letters to the F.A.A., the Federal Department of Transportation and the National Security Council, said that a meeting was scheduled on Thursday between officials of Republic, which is owned by New York State, and the F.A.A. He said that airport officials would increase security if the restrictions were eased.
Mr. Shumann said it was up to the cabinet to ease the no-fly rules, after a recommendation from the F.A.A. A decision is expected next week.
In the meantime, officials say the grounded flights have affected businesses, including fuel dealers and flight schools.
At Teterboro, situated within 15 minutes of the George Washington Bridge and the Lincoln Tunnel, 1,250 airport jobs are at risk, with a potential impact 2,500 more jobs in support services, according to the New Jersey Aviation Association, a trade group lobbying federal officials on the airport's behalf. Around the airport, which is owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, hotel occupancy and catering are down 50 percent, and limousine companies have lost $100,000, the association said.
"Teterboro is operating at 25 percent of full capacity and it is having a devastating effect on the regional economy," Thomas D. Carver, president of the association, wrote in a letter to members of New Jersey's Congressional delegation. "Teterboro is arguably the most important business aviation airport in the country. It generates more than $469 million into the regional economy annually. Any shutdown has an immediate financial effect on major corporations as well as small businesses throughout the area."

HEADLINE: The War on Terror Finds Wary Support in France 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: THIERS, France, 

 BODY:
Alain Leforestier grew up in the Normandy region where the military cemeteries offer irrefutable evidence that American soldiers have laid down their lives when France was in need.
 He is quick to recall this. It is one reason, he says, why the French must now stand with the United States. No question about it. 
 But Mr. Leforestier -- a 44-year-old civil servant who helps run this small medieval village in the center of France where -- makes clear too that he is not wholly comfortable with this proposition. Exactly what America will do now and how it will do it are questions that gnaw at him. 
His trust does not go far. What he sees as the harshness of American society puzzles and worries him. He finds President Bush's dead-or-alive rhetoric "ridiculous" and "unpresidential." He would be far more at ease, he says, if the crisis were in the hands of someone like Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain.
"Mr. Bush scares me," Mr. Leforestier said. "He has such power and, on top of that, he has values that I don't hold, the death penalty, for instance. If it was Blair, at least, we would understand each other. We are Europeans and we have more values in common."
Even here, a four-hour drive from Paris, the terror attacks on New York and Washington have had enormous impact, constantly discussed and argued about. For many, the feeling of being safely tucked away in the countryside has been shattered. When Mr. Leforestier's wife, Pasquale, looks out of her kitchen window now at the river rushing below she sees the potential for biological and chemical attacks.
Like many in France, the Leforestiers see themselves on the same side as the Americans, yet they do not see themselves as being of one mind with Americans. 
France and America have long vied with one another to be seen as the true guardian of the free world. France's aspirations for its culture breed a resistance to American imports. In addition, a host of social and political issues have begun to come between the two countries, from America's support of capital punishment to a general sense that Americans are too concerned with money, unable to enjoy life or to reach out to those who have less than they do. Nowhere has resistance to what is portrayed as an American-led attempt to impose its culture and economic model on the world been stronger.
In the cobblestone streets here, as elsewhere in France, there is a huge fear about what the extremists who smashed airliners into crowded buildings might do next. But there is a parallel fear that the United States will act only in its own interests and that it could make things worse. 
"If Bush decides to drop a thousand bombs on Kabul, do we have to follow you?" asked Mr. Leforestier. "It is not O.K. to do whatever just because Bush wants to do it."
Polls show that the French overwhelmingly favor backing the United States militarily, if they should be called on to do so. One recent survey found 70 percent in favor of joining a military effort. But the country is nevertheless engaged in a far-reaching debate about whether America's behavior in recent years did not somehow encourage the attacks.
Marianne, a political weekly, ran a banner headline last week asking, "How far do we go in standing with America?" Another magazine divided its front page in half, putting pictures of the "guilty" -- such as Osama bin Laden -- at the top of the page and the "responsible" at the bottom. In the magazine's view, the responsible included Mr. Bush, for turning his back on negotiations in the Middle East. In passionate letters to newspapers, readers deplore what they see as America's narrow-minded desire for vengeance.
"Is it possible that some day the people of America will realize that the devastation, the suffering and the death they are now suffering is minuscule in proportion to what the U.S. has inflicted directly and indirectly on others," said one letter in Le Monde. "People are still dying as the result of American actions in Japan, Vietnam, Cambodia, Iraq and territories in the former Yugoslavia."
Some of Mr. Leforestier's co-workers agree that America deserved what it got for paying so little attention to the misery in the world. But Mr. Leforestier, who moved here as a teenager, and his wife , who was born here, find such arguments abhorrent. The Leforestiers, who have two teenage children, have never visited the United States. She likes to cook. He likes searching for and restoring old country furniture. They are slowly renovating their 17th-century house. 
Americans, they say, seem like people who rush around too much and care too much about money. But one of their best friends is a New York sculptor who designed a walkway along the river near their house.
"Sometimes America does not seem like a very appealing place, but then there is George and he is quite wonderful," said Mrs. Leforestier, referring to their friend. Even before the second World Trade Center tower was hit by the second plane on Sept. 11, Mrs. Leforestier was on the phone trying to make sure that he was all right. 
They are now glued to the television during every news broadcast. "No one can deserve such a thing," Mr. Leforestier said of the carnage he has seen. "War has many rules but this -- was just craziness."
Still, he says that once all that is said, it is time for America to examine its behavior.
America, he says, is expansionist. It is everywhere. It is the strongest. McDonald's are everywhere and the young people are going to American movies and people here feel this. Then there are foreign policy issues like what happened in Chile with the military coup in 1973. There are many others. Every French person, he says, has one or two in their head.
"Now if you look at Africa and some of the other underdeveloped places and think of how they see you, how can they not want to knock you cold?" he asked.
Mr. Leforestier does not see France as outside the sphere of blame. "We have the same politics, the same capitalist economy. And we are even the ones selling them arms. We must all examine ourselves."
For the moment, France and America seem to have come together over the tragedy. French politicians have repeatedly pledged solidarity, but have also made clear that they will not follow blindly. Disagreements over issues like the use of land mines and the need to preserve missile treaties, adhere to environmental pacts and set up an international court have not gone away. 
In many ways, France -- which endured a wave of terrorist bombings in the mid 1990's and has a growing Muslim population -- is far more aware of tension between the Western and Islamic world. Even in this town of about 10,000 people, there is a sizable Algerian and Moroccan population. Newspapers have made clear that, across the country, there is little sympathy for America among French Muslims. 
The Leforestiers are heartened that Mr. Bush seems to be taking his time before acting, and more heartened still by accounts that Americans are trying to read up on Islam, fanaticism and the Middle East.
"My hope is that it wakes up the conscience of the Americans," Mr. Leforestier said. "Ours too, of course. If what happens can make a new world order with progress then this is good. But did you really need this to happen first?"
