HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Videoconferencing may at last get the critical mass it needs.

BYLINE:  By Hal R. Varian; This column appears here every Thursday. Hal R. Varian is an economics professor and dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley. E-mail: hal@sims.berkeley.edu.

 BODY:
WILL the current reluctance to travel stimulate widespread use of videoconferencing? The stock market seems to think so. Shares of companies that specialize in videoconferencing have shot up 30 percent or more in the last two weeks.
 But people have been forecasting the takeoff of videoconferencing for decades. In the early 1970's AT&T offered Picturephone service in Chicago for $86.50 a month. Jeff Rohlfs, a Bell Labs economist who was involved with the project, describes the history of this technology in his new book, "Bandwagon Effects in High-Technology Industries" (MIT Press). 
 Based on his experience with the Picturephone introduction in the early 1970's, Mr. Rohlfs came up with a concept he called network externalities. According to Mr. Rohlfs's definition, a good or service exhibits network externalities when its value to a potential purchaser depends on how many other people have purchased it.
Fax machines and Picturephones are standard examples. The fax machine was a big success, while the Picturephone was a failure. Why the difference?
Mr. Rohlfs developed a model that showed that "network goods" would be successful only when they were able to achieve an initial critical mass of early users. If the initial number of purchasers exceeds this threshold, the market takes off. Otherwise, it falls back to failure.
The Picturephone had 200 users at its peak, apparently far less than critical mass, and the product was withdrawn from the market.
Nobody cares about a failed technology, and Mr. Rohlfs's work was rarely cited in the decade after its publication. Then in the 80's and 90's we saw fax machines, video players, the Internet, e-mail, and the Web, all of which exhibited strong network effects.
Other economists, like Michael Katz and Carl Shapiro, picked up on the idea and studied strategies that companies could follow to achieve critical mass. Bob Metcalfe, inventor of the ethernet, independently promoted a related concept now known as Metcalfe's Law: the value of a network grows as the square of the number of users.
Talk about network effects exploded in the late 1990's. It is one of those rare concepts that you could explain to budding chief executives in five minutes and they could pitch to venture capitalists for six months -- or until they got financing, whichever came first.
Videoconferencing never achieved critical mass because it has always been more attractive to hop on a plane. Real-time face-to-face meetings are costly, but that's the way business has been done for centuries, and it is hard to change ingrained patterns of behavior.
Those companies that have experimented with videoconferencing have had mixed success. Low-cost videoconferencing is flaky enough that you can't really count on its working, and the high-quality technology is still pretty expensive.
But the days of blithely hopping on planes are over, at least for a while, so many companies will experiment with the technology in the coming months. As more companies use it, the technology will improve and videoconferencing capability will become more widespread. Perhaps it will finally achieve the critical mass that has eluded it for so many decades.
Most large American companies have a good enough network infrastructure to experiment with videoconferencing. The situation is different for residential broadband, since only about 6 percent of American households have high-speed network connections. Silicon Valley would love to see residential broadband take off, since it hopes that would stimulate demand for PC's and related consumer electronics. This week there are two meetings in Washington devoted to this topic, part of a series of efforts by technology and telecommunications companies to change regulatory constraints that they say inhibit residential broadband deployment.
Two years ago, I worked as part of a team to estimate residential demand for broadband. We gave about 80 university faculty members, staff and students residential high-speed connections. Our setup allowed users to change their bandwidth instantaneously, and we could charge them based on their choices. We changed prices for bandwidth every week and observed how people responded.
Our findings were summarized in several reports, but they boiled down to the following. First, the average user isn't willing to pay much for bandwidth, at least given the applications available in 1998-99. Second, those willing to pay for bandwidth were primarily technical and administrative workers, who appeared to use it for telecommuting. Third, most people were willing to pay a significant premium for a flat monthly rate, rather than a rate that varied by use.
The General Accounting Office reported results of a survey run in late 2000 that indicated that about 50 percent of Internet users in this country reported that broadband was available to them, but only 12 percent actually signed up for it. This is consistent with our first finding: people like broadband, but they aren't willing to pay a big premium for it.
Dial-up Internet access is widely available for around $20 a month, while broadband costs about $50 or more a month. It just isn't worth it for many potential customers.
The people who really like broadband are technically oriented telecommuters. Uploading and downloading files is a lot faster, and broadband makes working at home a lot easier. This suggests that broadband providers might well consider offering service packages oriented to home workers.
Maybe videoconferencing will be part of the mix, if it becomes widely used in business.
Noncommercial use of high bandwidth is more problematic. Opinions are mixed about how much extra people are willing to pay for movies on demand, especially when there are so many movies available via cable and local video stores. There seems to be some sort of market for music, but worries about piracy are likely to slow the availability of music on the Internet.
Residential broadband will come, but it will be slow in arriving until compelling applications are available.

HEADLINE: White House Criticizes Republican Farm Bill 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
The Bush administration came out against the $171 billion House version of a farm bill today, saying it would give too much money to commodity subsidies and not enough to conservation efforts. The White House stance set up a battle within the Republican Party over who would determine farm policy for the next decade covered by the bill.
 Minutes after debate began in the House, the Office of Management and Budget released the administration statement, urging the House to rewrite the bill and make it "better for rural America, better for the environment and better for expanding markets." 
 The statement drew a bitter retort from Representative Larry Combest, a Texas Republican who is the chairman of the Agriculture Committee and the bill's chief sponsor.
"For you to come now at the last minute is an insult," Mr. Combest said, referring to the administration of his fellow Texan. "How could you dare do this to us?" 
Moderate Republicans led by Representative Sherwood Boehlert of New York said they were ecstatic with the new administration view, as it mirrors an amendment they are offering to shift $19 billion from crop subsidies to conservation projects.
Mr. Combest has promised to pull his bill if the House approves that amendment, which is also sponsored by Representative Ron Kind, Democrat of Wisconsin.
At the beginning of debate on the wide-ranging bill, which covers food stamps, rural development, conservation and crop subsidies, supporters said it amounted to an economic stimulus package. But as word spread through the chamber that the Republican administration had turned against their bill, speaker after speaker rose to denounce what they considered a cowardly betrayal.
"What this means is that Secretary Veneman needs a wake-up," said Representative Jim Nussle, the Iowa Republican who is the chairman of the Budget Committee, referring to Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman.
Mr. Nussle joined Mr. Combest in questioning why the administration's public opposition came so late. 
Ms. Veneman said she had presented her agriculture principles since taking office and hoped to work with Congress in writing legislation.
An open war had been building for several weeks and had included a preliminary round last Friday when Ms. Veneman told the Senate that there might not be enough money in the budget to pay for the House version. Nonetheless, lawmakers and advocates seemed surprised.
"I've been working on farm legislation since 1977, and I've never seen such a harsh assessment from the White House of any farm bill," said Ken Cook, president of the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit group supporting conservation programs.
In an effort to shore up support for the bill, the office of Representative Charles W. Stenholm, a Texas Democrat who is a co-sponsor of the House measure, sent an e-mail message to the offices of Democratic lawmakers warning that if they did not vote for the bill, their favorite programs, especially food stamps and nutrition programs, would be undercut.
Mr. Combest had anticipated several of the administration's objections in an amendment filed on Monday that would give the agriculture secretary authority to cut subsidies if they violated trade agreements.
And in a nod to growing support for international food aid since the attacks, Mr. Combest agreed to establish an international food program, named for former Senator George McGovern, now the ambassador for United Nations food programs, and Bob Dole, a former Senate majority leader.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: FEDERAL AID; 
Vastness of Request Is Greeted by Doubts

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON and RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
It is a breathtaking laundry list of need: $18 billion to clean up and rebuild Lower Manhattan, $12.5 billion in expected losses in state and city tax revenues, $3 billion in overtime and other staffing demands and $2 billion to replace fire trucks and other equipment.
 But even as the city and state continue to compute the damage caused by the Sept. 11 attack -- state officials said yesterday that it would total at least $50 billion -- skepticism is surfacing on Capitol Hill about whether Washington can fully meet New York's plea for help. 
 One aide to a Republican senator said yesterday that with a national recession seemingly taking hold, people from many states would soon form a line around the Capitol with "hat in their hand and tin cups looking for money." Another aide to a Republican House leader said that allocating much beyond the $20 billion already set aside for disaster relief for New York, Virginia and Pennsylvania was going to be extremely difficult. "We're already eating up the surplus, and the federal government has a war effort to pay for," he said. 
What has given some lawmakers in Washington greatest pause is New York's still evolving proposal to use billions in federal funds to help balance the state and city budgets over the coming 18 months. A spokesman for Dick Armey, the House majority leader, said any such plan would be met with intense scrutiny.
"That sounds like unprecedented, uncharted territory," said Greg Crist, Mr. Armey's spokesman. He said the House Republican leadership had not yet discussed the matter, or even seen a formal expanded aid request from New York.
No disaster in United States history has ever come close to the numbers already associated with the Sept. 11 attacks. The greatest amount of federal disaster relief paid out previously was the $7 billion allocated after the 1994 Northridge earthquake in California.
State officials and members of the New York Congressional delegation said they recognized the challenge they faced. Even as they argue that the damage in New York is the result of an act of war on the nation, they understand that the country is already beginning to focus on a potential recession's impact on the national economy.
"It's not going to be easy," said Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York. "There are other demands nationally."
Representative John E. Sweeney, an upstate Republican who is a close ally of Gov. George E. Pataki, said the city and state's enormous request for aid had not yet met with outright resistance, but New York officials were "getting signals that there's consternation out there."
And Representative Charles B. Rangel, a New York City Democrat, said even he was taken aback by the proposal for a federal grant of some kind to make up for lost state revenues.
"We just asked each other what the hell was that about," he said of the proposal, presented to a meeting of the New York delegation yesterday. "At first blush, that was very unusual."
To be sure, members of Congress from both parties say they remain ready to help clean up and rebuild New York, as President Bush has pledged. Dozens of United States senators and members of the House have toured ground zero in the last three weeks, expressing their sense of awe and anger at the scope of the destruction.
The open question is how far the federal government will go beyond covering basic cleanup and rebuilding costs. Reconstruction costs alone could be at least $30 billion, once debris removal, rebuilding, equipment replacement, overtime, utility damage, subway repairs and other costs directly related to the attack are totaled. That number could be reduced by some percentage because of insurance covering several damaged buildings in Lower Manhattan.
But city and state officials have added several unconventional categories to the damage assessment costs. The state has said that over the next 18 months, it expects to see tax revenues dip by by as much as $9 billion, with the city saying it expects to lose $3.5 billion in tax revenues. The losses are expected to come from businesses that have moved away, others that are no longer paying employees bonuses, and the severe decline in tourism and business travel to New York, among other factors.
"The New York City delegation, including the senators and congressmen, are going to have to spend a lot of time educating their colleagues," said Adam L. Barsky, New York City's budget director. "Keeping New York City and the state solvent and stable is important to the rest of the country. There is a question about their recognition of that."
But New York's requests will also be weighed against a similar though much smaller campaign by Virginia to compensate it for the economic impact of the extended closure of Reagan National Airport, which has since opened to limited flights.
"There is no doubt that there is a dramatic impact on the state of Virginia by enemy action," Gov. James S. Gilmore III said yesterday. "This is not a routine economic downturn."
Virginia has already submitted a revised estimate of the wide-ranging cost of the attack, in a letter sent last Friday to the administration's Office of Management and Budget. But the attempts by New York officials to agree on the actual size of their proposal and how best to add up real and future costs have created some tension among city and state officials.
The tension between New York State and city leaders flared up during a White House meeting last week, where representatives of the Giuliani administration threw out a figure that put the cost of the damage at roughly $40 billion. That surprised Pataki administration officials, who were also at the meeting, according to officials familiar with exchange. The state officials said the city's number was too low.
"The city and state aren't singing from the same page," one New York elected official said. "To make this work, all levels of government are going to have to work like a machine. If any one of them falls out of the picture, it will hurt New York."

HEADLINE: The Next Mayor's Job 

 BODY:
New York's next mayor faces one of the most daunting challenges in the city's history -- rebuilding after the World Trade Center attack last month. The two remaining Democratic candidates are now telling voters how they would tackle the job. It is important to listen. All campaign promises made before Sept. 11 that involve new spending have become virtually irrelevant. The most important question in this disrupted but crucial mayoral election is who has the skills, depth and fortitude to handle the rebuilding and the enormous budget gap that the attack helped create.
 Public Advocate Mark Green and Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer met in their first runoff debate last night, and responded to questions about how they would restore Lower Manhattan and balance the budget. Mr. Ferrer repeated what had originally seemed like an over-hasty promise to use the restoration process to decentralize the financial district's businesses throughout the city. Mr. Ferrer wants to build and rehabilitate office space in places like the Hub in the Bronx and Stapleton in Staten Island to accommodate back-office jobs. That idea might make those boroughs happy, but it seems unlikely to please businesses that located near Wall Street because they wanted the advantages of being at the center of the nation's financial markets, and presumably wanted their support staffs nearby. 
 Perhaps more important is the danger that Mr. Ferrer's plan would reduce the city's chances of getting needed federal aid. However much New York would benefit from spreading out development and jobs, Washington and the nation believe they are sending aid here to restore the area that was devastated by two hijacked planes. Any sign that the money might be spread throughout the city's political web would be counterproductive. 
At this point, Mr. Green's proposals provide a more reasonable focus on restoring the economic vibrancy of Lower Manhattan as a global financial center. He also puts a great deal of emphasis on getting more federal aid. His agenda should be given points for specificity. But Mr. Green also tends to use the idea of billions in additional federal aid to dodge questions about difficult budget choices. Both men have made a good beginning in working out a way to create a quasi-public corporation that would lead the rebuilding process.
While neither candidate has focused directly on how he would manage a newly devastated city budget, Mr. Ferrer has hewed more closely to his earlier agenda, saying as recently as Tuesday afternoon that "the towers of the World Trade Center have crumbled, but our priorities have not." His construction priorities include projects like the freight rail tunnel to New Jersey and new subway lines, which, while desirable, cannot be tackled until the existing infrastructure is restored.
An example of Mr. Ferrer's refusal to face reality was a moment in last night's debate when he insisted that as mayor he would increase the budget for parks. "Parks are an important part of the quality of living in our city," he said. No one would argue, but leading the public to believe that the parks budget may get bigger in the foreseeable future is borderline irresponsible. The next mayor will inherit a budget gap of at least $4 billion and probably much more. He will have to struggle to find money for police, firefighters and teachers. Although Mr. Green has been far from eager to deliver any specific bad news, he has been more forthright in saying that many of his old goals would have to be deferred.
The next mayor needs to hit the ground at a full stride on Jan. 1 with a ready-made staff of experts chosen for experience, not political connections. All the candidates need to give voters a better and more detailed idea of whom they will hire and how they will keep the city afloat while rebuilding after the attack. So far, the Democrats' clearest plans involve the role each envisions for Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. Mr. Green supports Mr. Giuliani's very bad idea to stay on three months beyond his scheduled departure time. Mr. Ferrer opposes that, but says he would name Mr. Giuliani as head of the Lower Manhattan redevelopment project -- a situation Mr. Green says would create, in effect, two mayors at the same time.
Democrats will decide between Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer in a runoff next Thursday. The winner will face the Republican nominee, Michael Bloomberg, in November. Mr. Bloomberg, a businessman, has so far focused more on a general touting of his own management skills than a specific agenda for rebuilding and balancing the budget. That must change once the runoff is over. At that point, Mayor Giuliani and his team should also be prepared to help out by briefing both nominees, bringing them up to speed in order to maintain continuity no matter who wins.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE NORTHERN BORDER; 
Vast U.S.-Canada Border Suddenly Poses a Problem to Patrol Agents

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SWEETGRASS, Mont., Oct. 3 

 BODY:
Raise the issue of illegal immigrants sneaking across the border, and images come to mind of people wading across the Rio Grande or hiking across a scorching desert.
 But for United States Border Patrol officials like Robert Finley, chief agent for a nearly 500-mile stretch of the United States-Canadian border here in the Great Plains, there are other situations to worry about now as he faces new mandates to secure the border against terrorists. 
 "There are all kinds of means to get across the prairie illegally," said Mr. Finley, whose district runs from the Continental Divide in Montana well into North Dakota. "People use bicycles here, they drive in on snowmobiles. They come over by horseback." 
Mr. Finley's concerns highlight the difficulties officials face as they race to tighten this country's 5,000-mile northern border. 
While Congress is set to triple the number of agents along the world's longest nonmilitarized boundary, those agents will have to accomplish very different missions in very different places. In the vast stretches of Rocky Mountain and Plains states, a more secure border would mean trying to close an open prairie. At the major urban crossings, it would mean stepping up security at the risk of creating the gargantuan backups that have occurred in the last three weeks. 
And while calls for a crackdown on the border here are understandable, they run counter to what had been the primary mission for customs, immigration and Border Patrol agents before the Sept. 11 attacks: to fulfill the promise of the North American Free Trade Agreement, to make the border as unobtrusive as possible and to build on the world's largest bilateral trade flow, now $420 billion a year. 
But that is no longer true, as Attorney General John Ashcroft and others vow to make border crossings more rigorous. While about 8,000 patrol agents are along the United States-Mexico border, just 300 are on the much longer Canadian front, which includes Alaska's boundary with western Canada.
"It'd be nice to be able to go 24/7 in some places," said Mr. Finley, noting that most of the 13 ports of entry in Montana were not staffed from 6 p.m. to 9 a.m. During those hours, some crossings are blocked with a locked gate; others have only an orange cone to show that they are officially "closed." Patrol chiefs like Mr. Finley consider themselves lucky to have one agent on duty for every 50 miles or more of boundary.
The call for a crackdown is posing equally vexing problems at the border's busiest crossings. 
Four such spots -- Blaine, Wash., near Vancouver; Port Huron, Mich.; Detroit; and Buffalo, N.Y. -- together account for nearly three-quarters of all crossings between the United States and Canada. Since Sept. 11, each has been the site of enormous delays, some stretching more than four hours, as customs and immigration agents have intensified searches. In Detroit, the busiest commercial entry point from Canada into the United States, the wait at the Ambassador Bridge into Windsor, Ontario, was about 45 minutes this afternoon.
These delays have disrupted daily routines, because many people near these crossings live in one country and commute to the other. But their greatest impact has been economic. Commercial truckers, whose vehicles require intensive searches, have been slowed considerably. Tourism has been hurt, too. At the giant Casino Windsor, which draws 80 percent of its clientele from the United States, business has plummeted since Sept. 11.
"We are now running about 55 percent of normal," said Jim Mundy, a spokesman for the casino, which has laid off 87 employees. Casino Windsor, just across the Detroit River, is Windsor's third-largest employer, behind Ford and Daimler-Chrysler and ahead of General Motors.
Meanwhile, in Niagara Falls, N.Y., several stores at the usually bustling Prime Outlets Mall, a popular destination for shoppers, say business has been down 50 percent or more in the last three weeks. 
Here in Sweetgrass and in nearby del Bonita, where small crossing outposts are dwarfed by prairie, long lines are not the problem. 
At del Bonita, an American visitor was subjected to a 20-minute search of his vehicle and luggage by a Canadian immigration inspector, as well as a computer check of his driver's license. The procedure caused a delay for exactly one car. 
The challenge here is the vast geography that needs to be covered. "There's going to be some cracks," Mr. Finley said. "Everybody knows that. We do the best we can with the manpower we have." Even a tripling of the forces, would still leave large areas unmonitored. 
Given that many more illegal immigrants try to come across the Mexican border, according to federal estimates, such disparities are understandable.
Still, the Canadian border is not unknown to terrorists. Participants in the World Trade Center bombing eight years ago appeared to have used Canadian immigration papers to gain access to the United States. Ahmed Ressam, who was arrested by United States customs officials in December 1999 with a carload of explosives, and convicted, had tried to enter Washington State by a ferry from Victoria, British Columbia.
In the nation's capital today, the chiefs of the Customs Service and the Immigration and Naturalization Service told a Senate subcommittee that they needed more agents and better technology to guard the border. But some experts are skeptical about how much of a difference additional agents would make.
"It will have a placebo effect more than anything else," said Demetrios Papademetriou, co-director of the Migration Policy Institute, a Washington nonprofit group that studies immigration and border issues. "It may make us feel a little better. There is no way you can truly secure that border."
One proposal, advanced by Paul Cellucci, the United States ambassador to Canada, would require the two countries to so enmesh their immigration laws and monitoring procedures that the border itself would be all but invisible. 
After Sept. 11, such concepts are even more firmly rooted in the realm of fantasy. Even the more realistic goal outlined in 1996 by Canada's then-minister of national revenue, David Anderson -- "a hassle-free border for honest travelers and businesses, and a brick wall for those who try to smuggle or break other laws at this border" -- seems far off. 
Congressional negotiators have agreed on the outlines of a plan for increasing border agents and providing the patrol, customs and immigration agencies with better technology. Some of the technology exists, such as remote-controlled video cameras, motion sensors and voice-recognition systems that could allow local residents to cross at all hours, even while detecting potential intruders. 
For now, though, the focus is on agents to police the border. "All the technology in the world doesn't do me any good," said Mr. Finley of the Border Patrol, "if I don't have an agent to respond to it."

HEADLINE: After Deaths, Bus Riders Wonder, 'Is Anything Safe?' 

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 3 

 BODY:
Here, in a bustling college town where Greyhound is often the next best thing to having your own set of wheels for getting home, news of the bus attack in Tennessee early this morning left students wondering, Is anything safe anymore?
 That question swirled this afternoon around the campus of the University of Illinois, where Bartholomew Sojka, 22, sat in the Student Union lobby. A Greyhound traveler who makes the 125-mile trip by bus from college to Chicago at least three times a year, Mr. Sojka said he would think twice about taking the bus again. 
 "It's like you feel like you can't be safe anymore anywhere," Mr. Sojka, a senior liberal arts major, said. "It's like you could either ride the bike, take your car or walk. And even walking is getting a little dangerous."
Mr. Sojka has his own car, a G20 Infiniti, on campus, but he takes Greyhound home because it is cheap ($32 a round trip), saves miles on his car and solves the parking problem in his North Side neighborhood. He plans to go home in early November, he said, but "I'm not taking Greyhound." 
While the authorities said the attack on the Greyhound driver was not related to international terrorism, it added another layer of worry for people already concerned about traveling by air. Others said they had not been deterred.
In Denver, at a downtown Greyhound terminal, Glenda Bell, a 42-year-old machine operator who is moving to St. Louis from Seattle, said, "I'm not really scared, but we just all need to be alert, watch the people around us."
In the South Station terminal in Boston this morning, Christian Ramirez, 20, a student at Emerson College, was waiting for a bus to Michigan. Mr. Ramirez said he shrugged it off when his mother called him this morning to tell him of the Tennessee incident.
"I say, 'Hey Mom, it's so crazy right now, but you can't stop your life,' " he said.
Others were more concerned. 
At the Denver bus station, An thonette Tarin, a 50-year-old day care worker from the Macy Indian Reservation in Nebraska, was on her way to San Bernardino, Calif., to visit her daughter and had chosen the bus over the plane out of fear.
"I had a dream about an eagle on my back that kept biting my finger," Ms. Tarin said, "and I took that as a sign not to fly, but maybe it meant this, that I should fly."
Loroy Adams, 20, a junior majoring in economics, said, "With the whole incident on Sept. 11 and then with this incident now, you never know what to expect. 
"Riding the bus, I will be like a little skeptical," Mr. Adams said. "I may try to find a ride home with friends in a car, try to carpool or something like that."
The American Bus Association, the industry's main trade group, said fears of traveling by bus were unwarranted. The bus industry carries about two million people a day, including those on package tours, charters and special school trips, Michele Janis, a spokeswoman for the association, said, and "motor coaches are the safest form of inter-city transportation, bar none."
Ms. Janis said that after the Sept. 11 attacks in New York and at the Pentagon, Greyhound ridership rose 50 percent in some markets, but that it had not translated to an overall increase in bus travel.
The attacks have "had a chilling effect on travel," she said. "People don't want to leave their homes."
Greyhound service around the country was halted throughout this morning after the incident in Tennessee, and many stranded passengers expressed frustration. 
Les L. Thomas, 46, of Tuskegee, Ala., was headed home from visiting a relative in Detroit, and got as far as Atlanta when bus service was halted.
"I guess we'll just sit here," Mr. Thomas said. "That's all I know to do till they get the bus running. It's too far to walk from here to Tuskegee."
In New York, Gary Coles, district manager for Greyhound's northeast corridor, said about 30 buses leaving the Port Authority terminal were affected by the shutdown, which began at 7:30 a.m.
The mood at the terminal was particularly somber because many people there are mourning the Port Authority Police officers missing after the attack on the World Trade Center. A sprawling memorial of flowers and flags, pictures and poems dominates the terminal's center hallway.
But even with news of the attack on the Greyhound driver, some people said they were determined to go about life as usual.
"I'm not at all thinking about canceling my trip," said Joe Arango, 44, a Bronx plumber who was scheduled to take a Greyhound to Manchester, N.H., for a job. "Mayor Giuliani wants the American people to use the rails and buses so I feel it's my obligation. It's my patriotic duty to do what I got to do."
But Mr. Arango's wife, Helen Smith-Arango, said: "I'd still rather a bus than a plane, but I'm not going anywhere for a long time. I'm just here to see him off. Then I'm going back home."
Here in Champaign, Mr. Sojka seemed just as concerned as Ms. Smith-Arango. 
"We've got to deal with it every day," he said, shaking his head. "In our classes, it's the topic. On the quad it's the topic, at home, with our friends. It's on the news.
"And every time something like this comes up, it's the topic to talk about."

HEADLINE: U.S. TAKES BIG ROLE IN AIRLINES' CRISIS 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Using power granted by emergency legislation, the federal government is taking on its biggest role in shaping the nation's airlines since the industry was deregulated a generation ago, government officials and airline executives say. 
 By determining which airlines will receive $10 billion in federal loan guarantees and on what terms, the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, established under the bailout legislation passed two weeks ago, will wield extraordinary power to determine which airlines survive the current crisis and in what financial condition. 
 "It's clear that the board will have a considerable amount of discretion," said David M. Walker, the comptroller general of the United States and a board member.
The actions of the board, which is led by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and includes the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, and the transportation secretary, Norman Y. Mineta, are already raising uncomfortable questions about the role of government in the marketplace. 
In the rush to sustain the industry, whose executives warned of imminent bankruptcies, the bailout legislation passed both the House and Senate by overwhelming margins and was endorsed by the Bush administration. Along with $10 billion in loan guarantees, the airlines were awarded $5 billion in cash to cover their immediate losses. 
"Once you start giving cash and loans to an industry, there is no end to the decisions that you have to make," said Robert B. Reich, the former secretary of labor who is now a professor of economics and social policy at Brandeis University. "The government becomes a kind of czar, or holding company, over the entire airline industry. It's the worst kind of industrial policy." 
Mr. Walker -- who has been through several airline bankruptcies during his years at the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation -- predicts that several carriers will be forced out of business, leaving survivors with a tighter grip on the country's biggest metropolitan airports. In recent years, the government has blocked major airline mergers but it has been reluctant to take significant action to promote competition at big airports. That may change.
"The question the government is going to have to address is should there be some reasonable limits on market shares at some hubs," he said. 
Congress was clear that it wanted the rescue package to make up the losses of healthy airlines that were thrown into crisis because of the attacks but not offer a new lease on life to carriers that were heading for failure on Sept. 10. Several airline executives said they agreed with that approach. But that places the board in the position of picking winners and losers, something all parties said they wanted to avoid. 
The country's airlines, which operate with high costs and thin profit margins, began to hemorrhage cash after the government grounded all flights for two days. Even after flights resumed, they have continued to lose tens of millions of dollars a day because of a sharp decline in passengers. 
The Bush administration opposed loan guarantees, but Congress rushed to add $10 billion in federally backed loans at the behest of the airlines. Unlike previous bailout legislation -- such as the aid package for the Chrysler Corporation in 1979 -- the law does not specify the terms of the loans. 
The Office of Management and Budget is now drawing up operating rules for the board and is supposed to issue them by Saturday. It has solicited opinions from airline executives, bankers and other experts. The intense jockeying among the airlines to influence the guidelines is an early indication of how difficult the new board's job will be.
Some carriers are pushing for tight restrictions on the loans and a short repayment period. "The loans are not intended to provide long-term underpinning for the industry," said Leo F. Mullin, the chairman of Delta Air Lines and a former banker. "They ought to be transitional, and they should be at a market rate, not a government rate."
But rival executives charge that relatively strong carriers like Delta and American Airlines are pushing for tighter restrictions on the loans in the hope that financially weaker airlines will be forced into bankruptcy. These executives have been pressing for fewer restrictions, giving the board flexibility to respond to what they say is a still developing crisis. 
"What is pretty unclear here and what is going to be the biggest challenge is that the magnitude of the problem has not been defined," said one airline executive who insisted on anonymity. 
On Tuesday, 13 senators wrote to Mitch E. Daniels, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, urging him to make the loans available to every airline. "Any attempt to make the program proscriptive and preclude certain airlines from its benefits would only put the government in the position of deciding which airlines are worthy of existing and which are not," they wrote. 
But that would end up supporting airlines that were doomed to fail before Sept. 11, critics say, something the senators said they opposed. 
It now appears that the board will be given broad discretion. But almost any action it takes, executives say, will color their decisions and distort market forces. For example, if the rules indicate that loans will not be extended to airlines who have filed for bankruptcy protection, carriers that might otherwise have filed for Chapter 11 may hold off in the hope that they can secure a loan. 
Despite deregulation, the airline industry has been heavily influenced by government intervention for years. In July, the Justice Department blocked the proposed $4.3 billion takeover of US Airways by United Airlines because it said that the deal would hurt consumers. 
The decision led Wall Street analysts and airline executives to conclude that industry consolidation, something many believe inevitable to insure the long-term financial health of the industry, would have to be put off for several years. 
"The best kind of industrial policy is one that acknowledges the role government has and focuses on the public interest but doesn't get into the details of individual companies," said Professor Reich, who has been a strong advocate of government intervention in the market in the past. "This is an industrial policy designed for shareholders of the winning companies."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CHARITY; 
Totaling Up the Damage, and Not Forgetting the Tips

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
After she graduated from Long Island University's C. W. Post campus with a B.A. in philosophy in May, Kristina Leath felt confident getting a nicer apartment. She had a job as a waitress at Windows on the World, and the money was good.
 Actually, the tips were good. Her pay from the restaurant itself was $3.57 an hour -- less than minimum wage. But with tips included, she earned about $40,000 a year, enough to pay her utility bills and the rent on her fourth-floor walk-up apartment in Long Island City, Queens. The rent alone is more than $1,000 a month. 
 Windows on the World, the upscale 24-hour restaurant at the top of the World Trade Center, used to be known as one of the premier places in the city to be a waiter or bartender -- the pay was lucrative, the schedule flexible and the workers like a family. It was enough to make Ms. Leath, 29, and her co-worker Franklin James, 23, both aspiring performers, put their careers on hold for a while and focus instead on enjoying their 20's in New York City.
Neither of them was working the morning of Sept. 11, and both said they felt lucky to be alive. (Windows on the World, which had 450 employees, lost all 73 who were working at the time of the attack, a spokesman said.)
But when their place of work was destroyed, their income vanished. "It's amazing how 25 minutes can change your life," said Mr. James, who like Ms. Leath served food at the Greatest Bar on Earth, on the 107th floor of the north tower.
After the towers were destroyed, the restaurant gave out paychecks -- $106 for Ms. Leath and $82 for Mr. James. Both of them applied for unemployment benefits and received $204 a month each.
The tips, of course, stopped coming. "Waiters have been really hurt by this," Mr. James said. "There's no way you can be compensated for tips."
The utility bills that came in during September were far more than Ms. Leath's income that month, and her savings were reduced to just a few hundred dollars. "Half my bills weren't paid, half my rent wasn't paid," Ms. Leath said. "I didn't even have an idea how I would look at the bills for October."
Her friend Mr. James, who also lives alone, in the Crotona Park neighborhood in the Bronx, faced similar circumstances. But after a co-worker told Ms. Leath about the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of the 10 local charities supported by The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund, the two were able to get the financial help they needed. 
The agency provided Ms. Leath with $986.37, which included the balance of her September rent, $620, and $100 for food. Mr. James received $873, including $483 for rent and $100 for food. The rest of the money they received went toward utilities.
Ms. Leath, a trained opera singer, has been hired to join a gospel group that is leaving on Oct. 28 for a tour of Europe. Mr. James has several job interviews scheduled and is optimistic that he will find a job before the end of the month.
Both are confident about the future, but not about the present. "When you're sitting here in an apartment with this size rent, and you're looking at a $200 unemployment and $100 Windows check," Ms. Leath said, "you're freaking out."
Maje Waldo, a social worker at the bureau, made the decision to help the two, but it was Mary Rick, an office manager who greeted all the people seeking help and cheerfully wrote out checks, who made the biggest impression on Mr. James and Ms. Leath. 
So much so that Mr. James is considering a career in social work, and has begun meeting with social service agencies. "I don't think she realized how much she changed my life," Mr. James said. "She must have the best feeling when she goes home at night, knowing that she helps so many people."

HEADLINE: San Antonio Journal; 
A Forum Recalls Unheeded Warnings

BYLINE:  By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
A certain I-told-you-so atmosphere wafts through the speeches and conversations of former intelligence officials, army special forces commanders and police chiefs attending a security industry convention here.
 "We've been talking for years about how terrorists would try to use weapons of mass destruction against American targets," Brig. Gen. Bob Disney, retired, of the New York Army Guard, said. But journalists and government leaders largely ignored past meetings of his group, he said. "Had the word gotten out, maybe we'd have been better prepared." 
 Henry A. Nocella, a former marine and security executive who was another organizer of the convention, said: "Nobody thought these things could happen in the U.S. America had a perception of its own invulnerability." 
"But Sept. 11 has changed that," Mr. Nocella said, joining the conversation minutes before a workshop today on global terrorism. "Now people sense our vulnerability." 
If past meetings of the American Society for Industrial Security, a private group based in Virginia, have gone largely unnoticed, this year has been different. The group's meeting has drawn thousands of participants and hundreds of journalists, scores more than usual, to San Antonio's convention center this week.
Some government officials who addressed the convention added their own regrets about warnings gone unheeded.
John Magaw, acting director of national preparedness at the Federal Emergency Management Agency, told an audience today that over the past dozen years, "two or three reports" were written urging the authorities to "prepare for an aircraft hitting one of our big buildings."
The reports, Mr. Magaw said, "kind of drew dust."
"The tragic events of Sept. 11 have reminded all Americans that we're not invulnerable to these kinds of attacks," he said. "It was the final big warning. But just like Pearl Harbor, there were lots of earlier warnings."
Warnings certainly dominated the agenda at this meeting. Government officials and private security industry executives, many of them retired intelligence, military and law enforcement officials, described many if not most features of the American landscape as vulnerable to terrorist attack. The country's water and food supplies, transportation and energy grids, industrial complexes, even libraries and community centers, could become targets, they said.
"Yes, there is the potential for chemical and biological attacks," President Bill Clinton's defense secretary, William S. Cohen, told an audience today.
American intelligence has documented efforts by Osama bin Laden to acquire the means to build biological and chemical weapons, Mr. Cohen said. Terrorists might try to cause a contagion of anthrax or smallpox, Mr. Cohen said.
The practice of vaccinating American citizens against the latter disease was ended in 1972, as the disease was practically eradicated worldwide, and today the government has only 6 to 12 million doses of the vaccine, he said.
"You'll see the government start increasing the doses on hand," Mr. Cohen predicted.
Even before the convention, questions of national security have been raised in San Antonio recently. In the days after the Sept. 11 attacks, the authorities in Fort Worth detained two men, headed for San Antonio, who were carrying box cutters and who investigators believe may have been preparing for a hijacking.
One of the most sobering expositions at this week's meeting came from Roger G. Breeze, an administrator at the Department of Agriculture. It would be relatively simple for someone with sinister intent to introduce foot-and-mouth disease, or other crippling livestock maladies prevalent on other continents that do not exist in North America, into herds of American livestock, he said. He knew of no specific terrorist threat, he said, and added that officials are prepared to control the disease whatever its origin.
To contain outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease in recent years, authorities in Britain and Taiwan have been forced to slaughter millions of infected animals. Effective preventive measures have kept the disease out of the United States since 1929.
But current agriculture practices, in which many American feedlots have 100,000 cattle or more, mean that applying the usual response to such diseases would be traumatic, Mr. Breeze said. Just to bury the cattle from one big feedlot would require a trench 10 feet deep, 10 feet wide and 25 miles long, he said.
Peter Probst, a retired Central Intelligence Agency official who is an author and consultant, and who delivered a talk today on the future of terrorism, agreed with Mr. Breeze's warnings to farmers.
"Agriculture is the soft underbelly of the American economy," Mr. Probst said. "It's an absolutely vital sector, but it's terribly difficult to protect."
As the experts outlined alarming possibilities, in a vast exhibition hall hundreds of companies were clamoring to market the new gadgetry they said could help protect the country: digital surveillance cameras, high-technology locks, fiber-optic fences, and laser-guided handguns.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A conference of security experts featured displays of items like a high resolution digital camera, which is able to record images in low light. (Mark Matson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Australia: Australia: Rates Lowered 

BYLINE:  By Becky Gaylord (NYT) 

 BODY:
 The Reserve Bank of Australia cut a crucial lending rate, the fifth time this year the central bank reduced interest rates. 
The overnight cash rate target now stands at 4.5 percent, down from 4.75 percent. Ian Macfarlane, the governor of the Reserve Bank, said global economic conditions had continued to soften in recent months. He added that the terrorist attacks in the United States would aggravate the downturn not only in Australia, but also internationally. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Syracuse: Indians Awarded $248 Million

BYLINE:  By Hope Reeves (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 A federal judge has raised the amount the state owes the Cayuga Indian Nation to nearly $248 million from $36.9 million, court documents show. 
The judge said Tuesday that the lower figure granted by a jury last year was inadequate interest on the value of more than 64,000 acres in Cayuga and Seneca Counties that were illegally seized more than 200 years ago. The tribe plans to use whatever money is awarded to buy back land there. The state plans to appeal the decision, saying the amount is too high. The tribe also plans to appeal, saying it is too low. An economist who testified for the tribe estimated lost interest at $1.7 billion. Hope Reeves (NYT)

HEADLINE: PERSONAL SHOPPER; 
For the Weary, Pillows to Fall Back On

BYLINE:  By Marianne Rohrlich 

 BODY:
 BUYING a bed pillow used to mean choosing a standard rectangle filled with down or the same size rectangle filled with synthetic fiber or foam rubber. One size, three fillings. Now, you can lose a night's sleep over the choices. There are pillows for backaches, neck aches and leg aches. Then there are the fills, from feathers, down and Dacron to space-age gels and foams that respond to body size, shape and temperature.

1. HEADLINE: Fidelity Investments Agrees To Help Rescue Colt Telecom 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct 3 

 BODY:
Fidelity Investments agreed today to bail out the Colt Telecom Group, a struggling British provider of voice and data services to companies, by helping it to raise roughly $:400 million ($590 million) of fresh equity.
 Fidelity, the giant American mutual fund company, holds a 47.7 percent stake in Colt through its venture capital arm. It has promised to buy new shares that will lift its stake to 54 percent, and has pledged to buy any remaining shares not sold to other investors. If it were to buy all 649 million shares on offer for 62 pence each, its stake would rise to 72.7 percent, the companies said. 
 The venture capital division, Fidelity Ventures, has bet big on nascent providers of telecommunications services and equipment, including ONI Systems of San Jose, Calif., a maker of fiber optic equipment, whose shares have fallen 86 percent this year.
"The business environment is brutal for all of those companies," said Scott Cooley, an analyst with Morningstar, the Chicago-based mutual fund tracking company. "There will probably be a few winners on the service side, and they will be the deep-pocketed companies."
Colt Telecom was founded in 1992 with an initial investment from Fidelity Ventures. It was one of several upstarts emboldened by the deregulation of European telecommunications markets and the accompanying high-technology boom to compete with former state monopolies like British Telecommunications. But with the economic downturn and the slowing of technology purchases, Colt's customers have delayed buying communications services.
In the last year, shares of Colt Telecom have lost 94 percent of their value. The stock rose 21 pence today, or 34 percent, to 83 pence.
Shares of other alternative carriers also gained on hopes that they, too, would get a financial bailout.
But analysts said this was unlikely, since most of Colt's competitors do not have a deep-pocketed shareholder willing to invest extra cash.
"Colt is a special situation," said Amanda Neff, an analyst with CIBC World Markets.
Atlantic Telecom, based in Scotland, is fast running out of cash; Ms. Neff estimates it has enough to last through the end of the year. But do not expect Marconi, one of its largest shareholders, with about 19 percent, to come to the rescue, she said.
Marconi, a telephone equipment maker, has been laying off workers in an effort to conserve capital as it faces a steep decline in demand for its own products. And the British utility company National Grid has said it intends to sell its 34.6 percent stake in the British Internet carrier Energis.
Colt said that British regulators had waived a requirement that Fidelity, a unit of the FMR Corporation, make an offer to all outstanding shareholders if its stake rises above 50 percent. It said the proceeds from the share sale would be used to complete its network and to provide additional services to its customers, which include the London Stock Exchange and Buckingham Palace.

HEADLINE: Sabena of Belgium Gets Loan and Asks For Court Protection 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
Sabena, Belgium's ailing airline, sought protection from creditors today, and the Belgian government provided a $115 million bridge loan for one month to try to salvage at least part of the airline.
 Sabena's decision to seek court protection followed Swissair's announcement on Tuesday that it would not pay its share of a $395 million rescue package it promised Sabena in July. 
 "This was the last straw," said Wilfried Remans, a spokesman for Sabena. The airline's pilots had been on strike for four days before the Swissair decision to back out of the rescue plan, costing Sabena $2.7 million a day. Other recent strike actions were discouraging travelers from making reservations on Sabena even before the attacks on Sept. 11, Mr. Remans said. 
Still, unlike Swissair, which owns 49.5 percent of the Belgian carrier, Sabena continues to fly. "We have seen at least 20 bookings on Sabena flights today," said Francine Decraen, a travel agent with Carlson Wagonlit in Brussels. But she added that some travelers were asking to travel on flights other than Sabena's.
And despite their partnership, Sabena is refusing to honor Swissair tickets for its flights. "Sabena is not helping Swissair in any way," said Monica Bielsa, a saleswoman for all airlines in the Qualiflyer group alliance, which includes Swissair and Sabena. 
The Belgian government's loan is intended to allow Sabena enough time to recreate itself, possibly as a European regional carrier, a move that could protect at least some of its 12,000 jobs.
Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt of Belgium said today that with more than 20 million annual passengers at the Brussels airport and with Brussels as the capital of the 15-nation European Union, "it should be possible to have a performing airline that specializes in Europe."
The Belgian government, which owns 50.5 percent of Sabena, said that it would take Swissair to court because it had not lived up to its commitments. Swissair bought into Sabena in 1995, promising to turn around the airline, which has turned in an annual profit only once since 1958. 
The Belgian government is also in talks with the transport and competition offices of the European Commission to secure approval of its financial assistance to Sabena. The commission, which has been critical of government support for airlines, has asked Belgium to submit its plans.
The commission is expected to decide next Wednesday whether to allow government support to airlines.
"We expect to adopt an E.U.-wide policy regarding national measures that can be justified by the exceptional circumstances created by the attacks on the United States," said the transportation commissioner, Loyola de Palacio.
Michael Tscherny, a commission spokesman for competition issues, said the commission "does not want to see general support for the airlines as there was in the past." He added that state aid should not be used to keep afloat companies whose problems do not stem just from the Sept. 11 attacks.
The latest rescue plan for Sabena called for cutting about 10 percent of the work force, dropping routes and reducing its fleet of 87 aircraft, most of which are leased.

HEADLINE: Governments Intervene to Prop Up AilingAirlines 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
Deeply embarrassed by the sudden grounding of Swissair on Tuesday, stranding thousands of passengers around the world, the Swiss government stepped in today with a bailout to get the airline flying again.
 The company said it would operate about half of its usual flights on Thursday, and would add more on Friday. 
 The government agreed to lend Swissair $280 million to pay back fuel bills, airport fees and other costs because the airline's banks did not want the airline to use their money to resume flying, officials said.
Airline officials, banks and government ministers exchanged acrimonious accusations of incompetence and profiteering, a highly unusual spectacle in a business culture usually characterized by clubby professionalism and decision by consensus. 
"It's the image of Switzerland that is at stake," said the finance minister, Kasper Villiger, explaining the government's decision at a news conference in Bern, the capital. Noting the country's pride in Swissair's longtime reputation for sterling service and reliability, Mr. Villiger said, "this crisis has caused huge damage." 
When trading resumed today in Swissair's stock after being suspended since Monday, it plummeted 84 percent, to 6.5 Swiss francs, or $4, a minuscule fraction of its value as recently as January, when it traded for $163. The plunge is a serious blow to many ordinary Swiss, because the stock is among the country's most widely held, both in individual portfolios and in pension funds.
Swissair's former prestige was small consolation to the thousands of passengers stranded in its hub in Zurich when service was halted on Tuesday. Many were taken in for the night by sympathetic Zurich residents, or taken by bus to the city's spare civil defense bunkers. Some airlines gave discounts on replacement tickets to Swissair ticket holders, but Swissair said it could not pay any refunds.
Damage from Swissair's near-collapse spread to Belgium, where Sabena, 49.5 percent owned by Swissair, filed for a type of bankruptcy protection today. Sabena's long-running financial troubles were made worse on Monday when Swissair reneged on a $123 million payment to Sabena that it promised last summer. But Sabena, which threatened to sue Swissair, said it would keep flying.
The two airlines are among the early victims of the steep decline in international air travel after the Sept. 11 terror attacks in the United States. Since then, the market value of European airlines has plunged 29 percent, according to Bloomberg News. Money-losing carriers in Australia and the United States have also shut down.
Swissair's finances, which analysts said were "better than a bank's" in the early 1990's, were badly drained in recent years by commitments to Sabena and half a dozen other European regional carriers. In an effort to build a pan-European alliance and customer base, Swissair had taken minority stakes in the carriers that obliged it to cover their losses without giving it operational control. Because Switzerland is outside the European Union, Swissair was restricted from taking full control of the carriers.
Swissair counted on its sound reputation to make the alliance a success, but it soon began to tarnish as punctuality suffered and several of the smaller carriers, especially Sabena, proved persistently weak. Three years ago, Swissair's image was badly jolted when a flight from New York to Geneva crashed after a fire, apparently in the cockpit.
Still, the airline's reputation for deluxe and solid service kept its planes 73 percent full through the first six months of this year, despite rising fuel prices and a souring world economy. 
But the progressive unraveling of the airline after 70 years as one of Switzerland's most respected symbols began to appear when it reported a $1.8 billion loss for 2000 and shook up its management. Debts kept mounting, and when cash flow dried up after Sept. 11, the company rapidly ran out of money for daily operations.
The Swiss government, which owned 3 percent of the Swissair Group, the corporate parent, was reluctant to bail it out. But ministers changed their minds after the turmoil that followed Monday's intervention by Switzerland's two biggest banks. 
Bern's action provides a bridge over the confusion that beset the deal Swissair announced on Monday with UBS and Credit Suisse, the country's two largest banks. The banks bought Swissair's 70 percent stake in its successful regional carrier, Crossair, and Swissair said it would transfer most of its flight operations to Crossair by Oct. 28 and put the rest of the company into bankruptcy protection. The banks were to provide new credit lines to both entities.
But charges soon flew that the banks were dragging their feet in transferring money to Swissair and that they had unduly restricted the uses to which it could be put. A UBS spokeswoman, Monika Dunant, said the money had been intended from the beginning for Swissair's catering, cargo handling and other business units, which are to be sold, and not for flight operations. Apparently, Swissair officials thought differently, and found themselves on Tuesday morning without the cash needed to operate.
Some 262 flights with 19,000 ticketed passengers were immediately canceled on Tuesday, and when no new cash could quickly be found, another 400 flights with 39,000 passengers set for today were scrubbed. 
Creditors moved to seize several Swissair aircraft on the ground, including two at Heathrow Airport near London, but they were later returned to Swissair.
UBS came in for bitter criticism in Swiss newspapers for treating Swissair too tight-fistedly. The big banks are viewed uneasily by many Swiss because of disclosures that they held onto Holocaust victims' accounts after World War II, and by what many see as the banks' abandonment of the domestic market in favor of becoming players in the global financial markets.
The conservative daily Neue Zuercher Zeitung said the banks "with their clumsy, if not stupid or infamous, behavior caused unbelievable damage to the trust in our economic system, and the reputation of Switzerland and the Swiss airline industry." A front-page editorial in Tages Anzeiger of Zurich wrote of UBS's chairman, Marcel Ospel, "Never in the history of this country has a democratically elected government been so humiliated by a bank manager."
The banks "snatched up the best part and left the rest behind," said Joerg Drittenbass of the Swiss airline workers' union, referring to the purchase of control of Crossair.
UBS, which has taken the lead role by putting up 51 percent of the money in the restructuring plan announced on Monday, said it had been unfairly singled out for blame in the Swissair debacle. The bank, confronted today with demonstrations by Swissair employees carrying "United Bandits of Switzerland" placards, said the rescue package, while "tough," was realistic and "unprecedented in size in Swiss history," and said Swissair had waited far too late before asking for help.
"Swissair faced up to restructuring only when it was out of cash. It was really a one-minute-to-midnight discussion," Ms. Dunant said. "We had warned Swissair that the situation was extremely grave," but Mario Corti, the chief executive, consistently took a more optimistic view.
A prominent financial commentator, Beat Kappeler of the Zurich weekly Weltwoche, said that situation would not shake the Swiss economy, despite the expected loss of thousands of Swissair jobs. Service by Crossair on former Swissair routes "will make the current shock effect disappear in time," he predicted.
But the precipitous fall of a proud symbol rankles all the same. "It hurts right now," said Philippe Mottaz of Swiss television, "We thought our business elite was brilliant, but it turns out they weren't, and it's hard to take."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
PRESIDENT URGING UP TO $75 BILLION TO REVIVE ECONOMY

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
President Bush urged Congress today to pass a package of tax cuts and additional spending worth up to $75 billion as part of the effort to shore up the faltering economy.
 "One person laid off is one person too many," Mr. Bush said. 
 As described by Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, the administration's proposal includes a mix of tax breaks for businesses, new money for state unemployment benefits and a quicker timetable for implementing the tax cuts approved earlier in the year. 
After Mr. O'Neill laid out the package in an appearance before the Senate Finance Committee, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, met with Congressional leaders behind closed doors and urged them to move ahead with a stimulus package, lawmakers said. Until today he had urged the White House and Congress to wait for a clear picture of the economic outlook in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
After the meeting, which also included former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, Republican and Democratic leaders said they would support an economic recovery plan of the scale suggested by Mr. Bush. But they said there was no agreement yet on the plan's components, and some Republicans expressed concerns about spending increases.
Speaking to reporters in New York after meeting a group of business executives, Mr. Bush said that "our government will do everything we can to get our economy growing, to make it as strong as possible."
In his appearance before the Finance Committee, Mr. O'Neill said the administration would like to help individuals by accelerating the timetable for enacting the income tax rate reductions contained in the tax bill passed earlier this year. 
He said the administration was open to the idea of complementing the rate reductions with a one-time payment to the more than 34 million low- and moderate-income households that did not qualify for rebate checks sent out over the summer.
For companies, Mr. O'Neill backed measures that would provide tax breaks for investing in new factories, computers and other equipment. And he said the administration would like to provide states with money they could use to help extend unemployment benefits and provide laid-off workers with help maintaining their health insurance coverage.
Mr. O'Neill signaled that the White House would be flexible in negotiating the details of the plan with Congress, where the Senate is controlled by Democrats and the House by Republicans. 
Democrats said they were happy in general with the White House's approach, though they differed with some specific proposals. 
In particular, Democrats said they would prefer that the individual income tax cuts go primarily or exclusively to low- and middle-income people. Under the across-the-board reduction in tax rates favored by the administration, the benefits would accrue mostly to upper-income people, who pay the most in income taxes.
But in a sign of the tricky task the administration faces in piecing together a plan that can win broad bipartisan support, the White House's approach came in for heavy criticism from Republicans on Capitol Hill, especially conservatives who object to increased government spending and tax cuts that would be limited to low-income people. They said that the White House was caving in to demands from Democrats too quickly and dissipating the economic impact of the stimulus plan in the process.
"I have a hard time seeing where the administration's coming from on this," said Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee.
At the Finance Committee hearing, Mr. O'Neill also got a taste of the pressure the administration faces from lawmakers and interest groups to use the recovery package to address a wide range of economic issues. Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, urged the administration to support construction of a natural gas pipeline from his state to Chicago.
Senator Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, suggested that the government should help the technology industry by increasing purchases of computer equipment for agencies like the Internal Revenue system. Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, proposed a tax credit for people who travel between now and the end of the year as a way of helping the beleaguered airline and hotel industries.
Mr. Bush said he had concluded that the economic plan should total $60 billion to $75 billion, a figure that would be on top of $40 billion in emergency spending and a $15 billion airline industry bailout package already signed into law following the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
In settling on that range, Mr. Bush threw his support behind a package at the bigger end of the range being considered in Congress, where both parties had been thinking of more like $50 billion. 
It was the first time Mr. Bush has put a figure on how big a stimulus package the administration would support, and it suggested that he was willing to push the government budget into deficit this year to deal with the economy and the costs of the campaign against terrorism. 
The surplus for the fiscal year that started on Monday is projected by the White House and Congress to be $52 billion before accounting for the cost of the stimulus plan and any additional spending for the military.
But Mr. Bush said he wanted to hold the cost of the package to within the range he suggested today, saying that letting its pricetag escalate would risk creating new economic problems by driving up long-term interest rates on borrowing like mortgages and corporate bonds. 
Economists say the prospect of lower federal budget surpluses in the coming decade -- and the virtual certainty of a deficit in the current fiscal year -- could push long-term interest rates higher.
The administration has already agreed with Congress on a $686 billion package of routine spending bills for the fiscal year that started on Monday, $25 billion more than the administration had proposed in its original budget last spring. Any stimulus package would be on top of those spending levels.
Speaking to reporters after meeting a group of business executives in New York, Mr. Bush said it was "important to be aggressive on the front end," by making sure the stimulus package was big enough to make a difference in an economy that produces $10 trillion of goods and services a year.
"But we're mindful of the effect on long-term rates, and we think that number is the right number," Mr. Bush said, referring to the $60 billion to $75 billion range.
Two of the main proposals initially put forward by Republicans in Congress for the stimulus package -- cutting the capital gains tax and reducing the corporate income tax rate -- now appear to have been dropped from consideration.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Stocks Rally on Tax Break Plan And Words From Cisco Chief

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday after President Bush proposed a hefty package of government spending and tax breaks to revive the national economy, which appears headed toward recession after the terrorist attacks.
 Technology stocks -- helped in large measure by heartening words from the top executive at Cisco Systems -- led the market, with the Nasdaq composite index gaining nearly 6 percent. It was the index's biggest gain in more than five months. Other broad market gauges retraced some of their sharp losses after the attacks in recent days, but the Nasdaq had been the laggard before closing some of that gap yesterday. 
 The rebound in the market and a few economic indicators offer a glimmer of hope that the extreme economic slowdown reported immediately after the attacks may have been overstated. For example, the auto industry reported on Tuesday that sales declined in September, but far less than had been expected. And the Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to cut interest rates, its ninth move this year, should ultimately help spur consumer spending.
But economists warned yesterday that a two-day rally in stocks and a few economic indicators do not tell a complete picture. The attacks, they said, would reverberate through the labor market, retail sales and consumer habits for months to come.
"The economy didn't completely implode after Sept. 11, which was what that auto sales number told us," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "Unfortunately, some of the biggest negatives are still to come."
But yesterday, investors cheered the president's economic stimulus proposal, and sent stocks upward in a broad rally.
The technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index jumped 88.48 points, or 5.9 percent, to 1,580.81. It was the biggest gain since April 18, when it rose 8.12 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 173.19 points, or 1.93 percent, to 9,123.78. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 20.95 points, or 1.99 percent, to 1,072.28.
Mr. Bush said that he would ask Congress to approve an economic stimulus plan of $60 billion to $75 billion for 2002, on top of the $40 billion in emergency spending and $15 billion in airline assistance already authorized. The plan would include investment tax credits, tax cuts for businesses and individuals, as well as additional spending.
"It's pointing to something that will probably lead people to believe that it's going to be helpful to corporate profits, which is a concern," said Steve Massocca, president and head of Trading Pacific Growth Equities. "People are looking to that and seeing a hopeful sign."
At the front of the pack, Cisco surged $2.47, or 21.5 percent, to $13.95, after John Chambers, the company's chief executive, said he was comfortable with analysts' estimates of the company's sales and earnings for the first quarter.
"That basically set the stage for the tech stocks to rally in a strong way," said Peter Cardillo, chief strategist and director of research at Westfalia Investments. "It's good news. Feeling comfortable with those analysts' estimates means that things are not getting worse but are perhaps beginning to stabilize." 
Software makers also posted significant gains. Microsoft rose $3.18, to $56.23; PeopleSoft jumped $3.14, to $23.68; Siebel Systems rose $2.55, $17.61; Veritas Software rose $3.59, to $23.49, and Check Point Software, which makes Internet security programs, gained $3.14, to $25.99.
Semiconductor stocks surged, with Linear Technology gaining $3.97, to $34.07; Xilinx rising $3.92, to $26.72, and Intel climbing $1.71, to $21.23. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor stock index rose 34.18 points, or 9.64 percent, to 388.81.
This is the week when many companies are disclosing whether they expect their financial results to meet Wall Street forecasts. A variety of companies from clothing retailers to hotel companies said today that they would come up short. 
Stocks first fell this morning after Nortel Networks and Eli Lilly said they would miss their previous financial targets. 
But Nortel was swept higher in the rally and ended up 25 cents, to $5.54. Late Tuesday, the company said it would trim its work force by 20,000 and post a third-quarter loss of $3.6 billion because of a decrease in sales.
Eli Lilly fell $3.62, to $79.25, after it warned yesterday that it would not meet Wall Street's expectations for the fourth quarter. The company pointed to a sharp decline in domestic sales of Prozac, an antidepressant, which has slipped as generic equivalents came to market. 
Investors were also encouraged by a report released yesterday that showed a bit more strength than expected outside the manufacturing sector. After falling for two consecutive months, the National Association of Purchasing Management's nonmanufacturing index rose to 50.2 in September from 45.5 in August. Economists had been expecting a decrease to 43. A number below 50 indicates contraction in the services sector, while a number above 50 denotes expansion.
Transportation suffered the biggest drop, according to the report. There was also weakness in insurance, retail, farming and construction. But there were gains in entertainment, health and energy. An increase in new export orders and imports was responsible for the rise in the overall index, but the data were basically unchanged from August. 
Still, some analysts questioned how much the report reflected events after Sept. 11.
 --------------------

Treasuries Increase
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices rose modestly yesterday, led by longer-dated securities, as a stock market rally late in the session caused some investors to switch from shorter maturities into 10-year notes and bonds.
But the prospect of future monetary easing from the Federal Reserve after the central bank delivered its ninth interest rate cut of the year on Tuesday kept a firm tone to the market despite the stock rally.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 10/32, to a price of 10 46/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.47 percent from 4.51 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32, to 101 2/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.30 percent from 5.33 percent on Tuesday.
