HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LEGISLATION; 
Gain for Trade Bill That Some See as Aid in Terrorism Fight

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
House lawmakers announced a compromise agreement today that would give President Bush the authority to negotiate trade accords with limited Congressional involvement, a tool the Bush administration says will help it recruit allies in the fight against terrorism.
 House Republicans said an agreement with several moderate Democrats allowed them to schedule a committee vote on expanded trade negotiating powers, known as trade promotion authority, on Friday, with a full House vote coming as soon as next week. 
 But its prospects remained uncertain. The bill includes language that supporters say breaks new ground on incorporating traditionally Democratic concerns about labor rights and the environment into trade agreements. But it still faces strong opposition from Democratic leaders in the House, including the minority leader, Representative Richard Gephardt, and it would also have to pass the Democratic-controlled Senate. 
The accord came on the same day the Senate overwhelming ratified a trade accord with Vietnam, sharply reducing steep tariffs and other barriers that have kept trade minimal since the United States and Vietnam re-established diplomatic relations in 1995. The agreement was reached by the Clinton administration last year.
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, has argued that after the terrorist attacks the administration needs expanded trade power to help build the alliance against terrorism. The United States needs to counter "threats to our security" by offering "economic hope" to poor nations, he said.
"America's trade leadership can build a coalition of countries that cherish liberty in all its aspects," Mr. Zoellick wrote in a recent op-ed column for The Washington Post.
The administration is seeking to start a worldwide round of trade negotiations at a summit meeting in Doha, Qatar, in November and has argued that new trade powers would give American negotiators leverage to cut a better deal. There are continuing efforts to extend the North American Free Trade Agreement across Latin America and bring Russia into the World Trade Organization, goals that administration officials say would be easier to achieve with the new authority.
The strategic arguments convinced at least some moderate Democrats that the time had come to give Mr. Bush the powers he sought.
"The real threat to our country are the millions of people who live in poverty and desperation around the world," said Representative James P. Moran, a Virginia Democrat who said he had joined the Republican-led coalition on trade. "The most potent weapon we have to fight that is free and open trade."
But the hard sell by Mr. Zoellick and Representative William M. Thomas, the Republican chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has angered some senior Democrats, who say an immediate vote by the full House on trade authority will shatter the bipartisan comity that has prevailed since the terrorist strikes.
Representative Charles Rangel of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, criticized Mr. Zoellick and some Republican lawmakers for seeking to use the terrorist attacks to promote a trade measure that would face heated opposition in normal times. 
"The flag is up and we are all supposed to salute," Mr. Rangel said. "But they are walking on very thin ice if they think that they can rush this through."
Most House Democrats have tended to oppose trade promotion authority, once known as fast track. They argue that it unduly restricts Congressional prerogatives to make sure that trade agreements do not undermine United States interests by impinging on its sovereign laws or subjecting American workers to unfair competition from abroad.
Enhanced trade powers were last approved by Congress in 1988, setting the stage for Nafta. President Bill Clinton's attempts to revive this authority failed repeatedly. Such trade authority usually extends for as long as seven years, or five years with a two-year renewal. 
The new compromise agreement contains language that supporters say would compel the president to address labor rights and the environment within the main text of any trade agreement, ensuring that nations do not degrade their own laws to gain a trade advantage.
But some Democrats, unions and environmental groups remain wary. They say the bill's language on labor and the environment remains too weak and that the bill does not grant Congress enough oversight.
"It's confusing to many people because it gives the appearance of making concessions on workers' rights and environmental protection when in fact it's totally inadequate," said Thea Lee, a senior official of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.. "There will be an all-out effort on our part to stop the bill."
The Vietnam trade agreement was far less contentious. The House approved the agreement last month, and the Senate, more pro-trade, added its endorsement with today's 88-to-12 vote. Mr. Bush is expected to sign the measure shortly.
Trade between the United States and Vietnam totaled only $1.2 billion last year, far smaller than United States trade with other Southeast Asian nations. Tariffs, a legacy of the war against Vietnam, remained high even after relations were normalized six years ago, and a lack of legal protections has discouraged some companies from investing there.
Some 250 American companies, including manufacturers who want to use Vietnam's relatively inexpensive but efficient labor force and some financial companies that want to sell their products in that market, pushed for approval of the measure.
Vietnam will gain freer access to the world's largest market for some exports, including shoes and farm products. But the agreement does not address market barriers to textiles and apparel, which are left for further talks.

HEADLINE: An Effective, Responsible Stimulus 

 BODY:
President Bush got more specific yesterday about what he wants to do to help the economy. During a trip to meet with business leaders in New York, Mr. Bush revealed he was aiming for $60 billion to $75 billion in tax cuts and new spending, over and above the $40 billion already pledged for recovery from the terrorist attacks. It was a promising start, and the administration should now start working with Congress to deliver a stimulus package as quickly as possible. 
 Under the president's plan, the total stimulus would amount to 1 percent of gross domestic product, enough to give the economy a good shot in the arm. But its effectiveness will depend on how the relief is delivered. Mr. Bush listed a range of options yesterday, some of which are much more likely to work than others. 
 To help businesses the president suggested a range of tax breaks, including temporary tax credits for new investment, accelerated write-offs for spending on buildings and equipment, and a cut in the corporate income tax. The first of these is the best, since it would directly encourage companies to start spending. Accelerated write-offs are less precisely targeted. They would cut the cost of existing assets as well as new ones, and companies' savings might or might not be used for growth. Of least use is a cut in the corporate income tax, which would have little if any effect on businesses' decisions on investment and employment.
To help consumers, the president suggested extending the duration of cash benefits and health coverage for the unemployed, more tax rebates and accelerating his existing 10-year package of tax cuts. Extending unemployment benefits is important, particularly for people who lost their jobs as a result of the terrorist attacks. Those workers probably were not searching for new jobs before Sept. 11, and they will have trouble finding new positions in hard-hit industries like tourism and transportation. Longer support will give them time to find better matches for their skills.
Tax rebates would certainly give consumers a boost, especially if the rebates went to lower-income Americans whose purchases are most constrained by their earnings. But accelerating the tax cuts the president has won from Congress makes less sense. Most of that relief would go to people who are already relatively wealthy, and whose spending decisions are less sensitive to an infusion of extra cash. The fact that so much of the Bush tax cuts kicks in somewhere in the future is one of the reasons they have not done more to help the economy. A more important explanation is that they were directed at the wrong people.
Rather than make them happen sooner, Congress should eliminate some of those tax cuts completely, to raise money for more effective stimuli and to reassure the markets that the nation is not plunging into a long series of serious budget deficits. 
Balancing tax cuts and spending today with higher revenues in the future will help to ensure stable long-term interest rates, and a quicker recovery for the economy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Nissan Workers Reject Union at Tennessee Plant
Employees at a Nissan factory in Smyrna, Tenn., voted by a ratio of more than 2 to 1 to reject the latest attempt by the United Automobile Workers to organize a plant operated by a foreign automaker.
 A victory was much needed for the U.A.W., whose membership has dwindled. But the results were no better than the effort to organize the same plant in 1989. Page C5. 

Bush Proposes Stimulus Package
President Bush urged Congress to pass a package of tax cuts and additional spending worth up to $75 billion. Republican and Democratic leaders said they would support an economic recovery plan of that scale, but they said they had not agreed on its components. A1.

Future Bleak for New York Economy
New York politicians, economists and business leaders are facing an economic outlook that ranges from awful to appalling. B1.

Janus Chairman to Sell 6.2% Stake
Thomas H. Bailey, the chairman of Janus Capital, the Denver mutual fund company, exercised an option in his contract to sell his 6.2 percent stake in Janus to the company's parent, Stilwell Financial, for $603 million, at least $360 million more than the market price for the shares. A spokeswoman said she expected Mr. Bailey to remain at Janus, where he supervises the company's investment policies. C2.

Agreement on Trade Authority
House lawmakers announced a compromise agreement that would give President Bush the authority to negotiate trade accords with limited Congressional interference. B1.

OPEC Considers Cutting Output
Less than a week after deciding to maintain production levels, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is considering a cut in output by 500,000 barrels a day. C6.

Bailout Reached for Swissair
The Swiss government stepped in with a bailout to get Swissair flying again. The company said it would operate about half of its usual flights today and would add more tomorrow. In Belgium, Sabena sought protection from creditors. World Business, Section W.

Polaroid's Survival in Question
Polaroid, which was already well down the path to insolvency before the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, finds its future even bleaker and its survival in question. Market Place. C7.

I.B.M. to Unveil Unix Computers
I.B.M. is expected to announce today a new line of Unix computers intended to challenge the market leader, Sun Microsystems. The move by I.B.M. comes a week after Sun introduced machines portrayed as an assault on the mainframe market, I.B.M.'s stronghold. Shares of I.B.M. rose $3.18, to $96.95, while Sun Microsystems rose 99 cents, to $9. C4.

File-Sharing Web Sites Are Sued
Having silenced Napster, the major record companies, joining forces with motion picture studios, filed a copyright-infringement lawsuit aimed at a new generation of music- and movie-sharing Internet sites. C4.

Fidelity to Aid Colt Telecom
Fidelity Investments agreed to bail out Colt Telecom, a British provider of voice and data services, by helping it to raise $590 million in equity. World Business, Section W.

The Outlook of Videoconferences
The reluctance by some people to travel may finally stimulate wider use of videoconferencing. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VISIT; 
Bush Tries to Reassure Children and Executives

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
President Bush sought to reassure schoolchildren and corporate executives yesterday on his second visit to New York since the World Trade Center attacks, then bought five pizzas for a lunch with firefighters and grieving relatives of the missing at Engine Company 55 in Chinatown.
 "He told me I had beautiful children and to hang in there," said Robin Freund, whose husband, Lt. Peter Freund, was lost in the collapse of the World Trade Center. "And whatever he could do to help me, let him know." 
 Mr. Bush told schoolchildren in Chinatown and executives on Wall Street something similar. At a private round-table talk with some 30 business leaders, the president announced that his administration would ask Congress to authorize an additional $60 billion to $75 billion to boost consumer confidence, enhance business investment and help displaced workers. Congress has already approved $40 billion in emergency spending for disaster relief and a $15 billion bailout for the airline industry.
"I think there's no question we all agree that the events of Sept. 11 shocked our economy, just like it shocked the conscience of our nation," Mr. Bush said after the round-table discussion at Federal Hall in Lower Manhattan, the site of George Washington's inauguration.
Mr. Bush said that he told the executives -- among them Kenneth Chenault of American Express, Sanford I. Weill of Citigroup and Betsy D. Holden of Kraft Foods -- that the federal government has a "strong, active" role to play in bolstering the economy.
Mr. Bush's five-hour visit to New York was intended to portray the president as comforter of the grieving and a steward of the nation's finances. Officials said it was important that Mr. Bush chose to make his announcement about a $75 billion stimulus package in New York City, the heartbeat of the nation's economy but a city that he has shown little love for in the past. 
That relationship has strikingly changed as the president has spent hours with the families of people killed in the trade center attacks, and has also provided billions of dollars in aid. Yesterday's visit coincided with statements by city and state leaders that they would ask the federal government for $40 billion more in assistance to cover the damage from the attacks on the twin towers -- twice the amount already approved.
Not surprisingly, Karl Rove, one of the president's top advisers, was seen at the corner of Broome and Mott Streets in Chinatown deep in conversation with Brad Race, the chief of staff to Gov. George E. Pataki, and Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. None of the three would say what New York was asking of Washington, but Mr. Rove offered this: "Did you ever see Carl Sagan, the astronomer, talking about the numbers of stars -- billions and billions and billions?" 
Afterward Mr. Race said that he and Mr. Gargano were asking for money to cover the cleanup in Lower Manhattan as well as for reconstruction at the trade center site. He would not put a dollar amount on the requests. "It's too much of a work in progress," he said.
Mr. Bush arrived in New York at Kennedy International Airport under heavy security. He took the presidential helicopter, Marine One, to the Downtown Manhattan Heliport, where he was met by Mr. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The president then traveled in an enormous motorcade -- 22 motorcycles and 37 cars -- to Federal Hall, which sits across Wall Street from the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Bush met privately with the business executives and listened to what he later described as a long list of their ideas for improving the economy. Among them, Mr. Bush said, were using some sort of tax cut to put money into the pockets of consumers, giving businesses tax breaks to invest in new equipment and helping unemployed workers. 
Among the executives at the horseshoe-shaped table were Douglas N. Daft, the chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company; Gerald M. Levin, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner Inc.; Maurice R. Greenberg, the chief executive of the American International Group, one of the largest commercial insurers in the world; and Dean O'Hare, the chief executive of the Chubb Corporation, another big insurer. Mr. O'Hare said there was "just a resounding commonality of view in the room by the C.E.O.'s that the administration was doing a great job and that we're going to win this war."
Standing on the sidelines was Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican nominee for mayor of New York City and the chief executive of the communications company that bears his name. Mr. Bush, in a not unexpected gesture to a Republican mayoral candidate, met privately with Mr. Bloomberg for 10 minutes before the discussion began. Bill Cunningham, Mr. Bloomberg's campaign strategist, said that Mr. Bloomberg told Mr. Bush that "he expects to be a full partner with the president in rebuilding New York."
Afterward, Mr. Bush went to Public School 130 in Chinatown, a school that was closed after the attacks and has since reopened. In Debra Nelson's first-grade class, the president told the students to appreciate their teachers. "You know why?" Mr. Bush said. "Because they love you. And if you've got any worries about what took place at the World Trade Center, they can help you."
From there Mr. Bush went to Engine Company 55. Along the way, a White House staff member used funds from the president's personal White House account to pay for pizzas, $11 each, at Sal's on Broome Street. Mr. Bush shared them with Engine Company 55, which still has five firefighters missing after the terrorist attacks.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE OUTLOOK; 
Only Certainty To Economists Is Dire Outlook

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
As President Bush met with corporate executives yesterday to discuss the national economy, New York politicians, economists and business leaders began to grapple with an economic outlook that ranges from awful to appalling.
 The number of jobs in the city has probably plunged by 28,000, and is likely to drop by at least 40,000 more this year -- maybe by 87,000 if the national economy stumbles into a severe recession. The unemployment rate, already edging up to 5 percent, could end the year as high as 6.7 percent, and might hit 8 percent by the end of next year. And the city's economy, which before the attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 appeared likely to grow slightly in the just-ended third quarter of the year, instead shrank sharply. 
 All of these statistics come from forecasts produced by Economy.com, which specializes in regional financial data. While many economists have been reluctant to assign such specific figures to the future, they tend to agree with the thrust of the analysis, which foresees a very hard end to 2001. 
"There's going to be a very painful contraction," said Rae D. Rosen, a senior economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Like many analysts, she predicts that things will improve early next year, but "a lot depends on how quickly people are in any position to rebuild."
Even if that rebuilding begins relatively soon, not everyone thinks the rebound will be sharp.
One is Stephen Kagann, the chief economist for Gov. George E. Pataki, who said yesterday that many areas that had experienced disasters like hurricanes and earthquakes had seen their economies bounce back quickly when federal aid and insurance money kicked in.
But in those places, he said, most of the damage occurred in residential areas, where homes could be repaired with relatively small sums of money. 
"When people's houses are wrecked or damaged, they can move very quickly -- I call it the Home Depot effect," Mr. Kagann said. Spending to rebuild Lower Manhattan's business district, he said, is likely to happen at a slower pace.
There are many imponderables that are making economists' crystal balls even cloudier than usual. One, of course, is the amount of federal aid and the speed at which it will arrive. So far, only $126 million in aid has trickled in to the city, according to the office of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.
While the federal government has released $5 billion of the promised $40 billion in special spending, half of that is going to the Department of Defense and to repair the Pentagon, the comptroller's office said. The Federal Emergency Management Agency is to receive $2 billion, but some of that money will go to Pennsylvania, where a hijacked plane crashed, and Virginia, for the Pentagon. President Bush, during his visit to the city yesterday, announced that he would seek $75 billion from Congress, but that would go toward stimulating the national economy. 
The Small Business Administration said yesterday that it had approved 117 loans worth a total of $11.9 million in the wake of the disaster. That is a tiny fraction of the 759 loan applications it has received, and an even smaller fraction of 7,881 applications that businesses have requested but have not sent back to the agency.
Looming even larger are questions about war and about terrorism "Will there be a more permanent impact, or will people just hole up in their homes, with their home theaters?" asked Robert Kurtter, a senior vice president at Moody's Investors Service, which analyzes the city's economy for investors. "I don't think any of us have built in an assumption of perpetual terror attacks or war, but it's clearly a risk." 
Another question for economists is what will happen to the national economy, which had been skidding into recession before Sept. 11. That prompted Mark M. Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, to develop three forecasts of the aftermath, which are progressively more negative depending on the national situation.
For example, his predictions for the city's unemployment rate at the end of 2002 range from 6.4 percent to 8 percent. If the twin towers had not collapsed, that rate would have probably been about 5.2 percent, he said. 
In New York City, a group of economists and consultants is racing to put together a detailed description of the state of the city's economy before the attack, the short-term effects and the long-term outlook. The effort is being organized by the New York City Partnership, a business group, because "after the loss of lives, the loss of livelihoods is the next most urgent issue to address," said Kathryn S. Wylde, the group's president. 
The city's economy, so strong for so long, had already begun slipping before the trade center disaster. 
But the collapse of the towers toppled three of the city's most important engines of economic growth: finance, tourism and entertainment, and retailing.
The loss of life has been, of course, the worst thing. Some small but important Wall Street firms like Keefe Bruyette and Cantor Fitzgerald were devastated in the attack.
Several very large firms, like Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers, had to move their operations to other parts of New York and to New Jersey. Others, like Goldman Sachs, were simply shut out of their offices for almost a week.
The Securities Industry Association, the trade group for financial firms, estimates that 45,000 employees of its members and their suppliers had to leave Lower Manhattan; about 25,000 of those found space elsewhere in the city. 
The good news is that the Federal Reserve's move to slash interest rates helped keep firms' losses relatively small, said Frank Fernandez, chief economist of the Securities Industry Association. The bad news is that those operating losses do not include the billions of dollars firms have spent and will spend to replace the property that was damaged and for relocation, he said.
Many of the 14,000 businesses in Lower Manhattan that were affected by the disaster were small shops selling jewelry or cigars or offering shoe repairs. Others were restaurants that cater to the Wall Street crowd. While business seems to be coming back near the tip of the island, many shops near the trade center remain closed, and the city's consumers are keeping their credit cards in their wallets.
Empty tables are easy to find at restaurants all over Manhattan, and probably half the hotel rooms in town are vacant, said John A. Fox, senior vice president of PKF Consulting. Typically, he said, occupancy rates would be as high as 95 percent in October, one of the busiest months in New York's hotel business. "This couldn't have happened at a worse time," he said.
On the other hand, there are some signs that tourism may be ticking up a bit. "You see on a daily basis that people are regaining confidence in airlines," said Arnon A. Mishkin, a partner at the Boston Consulting Group, one of the firms working on the New York City Partnership's economic study. 
The weekend after the trade center disaster, he bought tickets to the "Lion King" -- for that day's performance, he said, adding, "You can't do that any more."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CHINATOWN; 
Chinatown, Its Streets Empty, Quietly Begins to Take Action

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Though it was spared physically on Sept. 11, the Chinatown that President George W. Bush visited yesterday showed signs of trauma most everywhere, from jobless workers to streets with barricades to shops teetering on bankruptcy.
 Chinatown has been transformed into a near ghost town since the attacks on the World Trade Center. Most of the tourists are gone and many of the regular Asian shoppers from New Jersey, Brooklyn and elsewhere have taken their business to Flushing, Queens, where they can drive their cars more easily. 
 At times, it has been so hard for some trucks to get in and out of Chinatown that many of the 250 or so garment manufacturers there have cut production in half. People without photo ID's, including some street vendors, have been scared away or turned away at police checkpoints, leaving long stretches of the sidewalks bare. 
Telephone service remains so spotty that some pharmacies cannot fill prescriptions because of downed computer links, some shops cannot process credit card orders and some residents cannot call for help in emergencies.
In one case, Shiun Fuhai, 67, died of a heart attack in his apartment while his wife frantically searched for a pay phone, according to the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, which has been documenting some of the hardships.
"It's deceiving, because you still see people walking around, but these are local people and a lot of them are unemployed," said Don Lee, a businessman and community board member who was volunteering yesterday at the Chinese Community Center on Mott Street. "People want to think positive, but there is concern about whether we are going to make it."
Despite Chinatown's proximity to the World Trade Center -- about 12 blocks -- its business owners and residents have kept relatively quiet about their problems, moved instead by the consuming events farther to the south and roused by a newfound sense of patriotism and self-sacrifice.
A Cantonese radio station, WNSW 1430 AM, raised nearly $1.4 million in an on-air fund-raiser for the city's relief effort. The station's general manager, Tony Wong, said the company had also given away 200,000 paper American flags.
"In my 30 years in New York City, this is the first time people are united and working together," Mr. Wong said. "Chinese-Americans are feeling part of this society. You talk about assimilation; this is it."
With patronage off as much as 70 percent, some restaurant owners have turned to delivering hot meals to firefighters, construction crews and volunteers at the World Trade Center site.
"My waiters just stand around, stationary like burning candles," said Jijie Hong, who owns Shanghai Cuisine Restaurant at the corner of Mulberry and Bayard Streets. "There are no customers to serve." 
But in recent days, the atmosphere of stoicism has begun to give way to one dominated by practical concerns. More people are speaking up and looking to the authorities for help. 
As the city promotes Broadway shows in television advertisements and makes special efforts to encourage financial companies not to leave for New Jersey, there is a growing sense that Chinatown needs to be recognized as a casualty, too. In that regard, Mr. Bush's visit was seen as a welcome spotlight.
Mr. Lee said several days of pestering finally paid off on Tuesday when the authorities agreed to move some of the wooden barricades along Canal Street several blocks to the south. Even though pedestrians were able to pass, the barriers had created a psychological no-go zone for shoppers.
Now, some business owners have set their sights on getting rid of the highway signs from New Jersey to Long Island that advise motorists to avoid Lower Manhattan. 
"They are killing our business by stopping the traffic," said Eva Sam, the owner of Popular Jewelry on Canal Street.
Garment workers are also putting together a plan to encourage retailers to keep manufacturing work in Manhattan. Bruce S. Raynor, president of the Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees, said about 11,000 of the city's 60,000 garment workers were based in Chinatown. Almost all of them, he said, are now working part time.
"It seems as if the focus of many people has been on the financial industry and Wall Street," Mr. Raynor said. "Our workers have been just as adversely affected, if not more so, because they live closer to the line of survival."
At the community center on Mott Street, about 2,000 people from Chinatown and elsewhere in Lower Manhattan had taken advantage of a variety of services, including free legal advice, inexpensive cellular phones and small-business loans. But Mr. Lee said a survey of about 350 area businesses found that problems remained widespread. 
Among those seeking help yesterday were five drivers from Allen Car Service on Orchard Street. They were applying for loans to get through the month. They used to get customers from Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch, making as much as $300 a day. Now they are fortunate to take home $30, they said.
Some of the drivers have cut back on basics like food. One of them had just done his grocery shopping for the next few days: his plastic bag contained several loaves of bread and a can of tomato sauce. 
Another driver, Paul Ling, said he had cut out one meal a day so that he would have enough money to feed his daughter, who is 1. 
"I've eaten ramen noodles every day for a while now," he said. "It tastes terrible after a while, but you've got to eat. What can you do?"
Others in Chinatown said they were coping the best they could, confident that things would turn for the better.
The intricate Chinese paper cuttings of one artist, Bun Lau, were displayed on some scaffolding along the sidewalk on Mulberry Street. So were his hand-painted shirts with colorful scenes of lotus flowers and fish and dragons.
But yesterday, as President Bush visited an elementary school a few blocks away, Mr. Lau was putting his fine brushes to work on a design unlike the others. Spread out on a folding table was a T-shirt with an outline of the Lower Manhattan skyline. Featured prominently in the center were the twin towers of the World Trade Center.
"It'll be better tomorrow," Mr. Lau scrawled in both English and Chinese, lifting a verse from a popular Chinese song.

TIFFANY SAYS THIRD-QUARTER SALES WILL DECLINE

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Tiffany & Company's fiscal third-quarter sales will decline about 10 percent and profit will fall more than forecast as shoppers, worried about the slowing economy and shaken by the terrorist attacks, spend less on jewelry. 
Earnings in the quarter, which ends Oct. 31, will fall to 12 cents to 15 cents a share, from 24 cents a year earlier, Tiffany said. Tiffany, which is based in New York, had sales of $369.7 million a year earlier. Fourth-quarter profit will be 49 cents to 56 cents a share, compared with 56 cents the previous year, the company said.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
On 'West Wing,' a Twilight World Where Fact Meets Fiction

BYLINE:  By CARYN JAMES 

 BODY:
One minute we were in a fictional version of the White House, which the Secret Service had sealed off because of a security breach; seconds later the screen flashed information about how to contribute to the Twin Towers Fund, and then we were in the land of stylized commercials, lured by the neon-bright dazzle of Times Square to buy a car. That brief sequence on NBC near the start of "The West Wing" on Wednesday was more revealing than anything on the show itself, which Aaron Sorkin wrote as an oblique response to the terrorist attacks last month.
 Zooming from an invented crisis to a reminder of the real tragedy and on to familiar commercials, for a minute viewers were trapped in a twilight world between fact and fiction, panic and normality. Even the ads accidentally suggested the most unsettling questions of the day. (The words "You Want It" kept flashing on screen during the commercial, but who will be able to buy a new car if there's a recession?) 
 No one watches "The West Wing" for such inadvertent examples of how television is floundering to find the right tone, though. In itself, the show was preachy and self-important, everything we don't need drama to be. In advance, NBC played a Garbo game, hyping the show by being coyly secretive about the plot. The truth is there wasn't much of a story. And partly because the episode was produced so quickly, the characters mostly sit and talk.
In a clumsy dramatic device, high-school students are visiting the White House and have to stay there while the Secret Service investigates the security lapse. The White House staff drops by to chat, or rather lecture them. No one mentions the World Trade Center, but the characters allude to some recent crisis, and the image of scared adolescents adds another resonance of real life.
Yet the overall effect is to turn the television audience into captive students. Josh (Bradley Whitford) even offers a lesson based on the form of an SAT question. "Islamic extremists are to Islam as the Ku Klux Klan is to Christianity," he says. Occasionally the scene moves to an Arab-American who works at the White House, who is being harshly questioned because he is suspected of having links to terrorists. With ethnic tolerance one of the lessons the show hammers, it is obvious he will turn out to be innocent.
We want drama to touch our lives and illuminate what facts cannot. Instead, "The West Wing" spoon-fed us debates, as if its characters had wandered into "Hardball" or "Crossfire." C. J. (Allison Janney) says the United States needs more spies, and Toby (Richard Schiff) wonders what that might do to civil liberties. The president (Martin Sheen) tells the students, "Killing yourself and innocent people to make a point is sick, twisted, brutal . . . murder," as if he were a guest on "The O'Reilly Factor."
Viewers should get used to being in that twilight world where fact and fiction meet. John Wells, the producer of "The West Wing," has another show that plans to address the World Trade Center attack more specifically. This month "Third Watch," the NBC series about New York firefighters, police officers and paramedics, will do three weeks of related stories, one featuring real-life counterparts of the characters, another dealing with the effect of the attack on the fictional rescue workers. Drama is circling closer to the event, but that doesn't mean anyone really knows how to approach it.

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; 
A Hobby Offers Solace But Uncertainty, Too

BYLINE:  By KEITH MARTIN 

 BODY:
AS pastimes go, buying, restoring and driving old cars is a harmless -- though often expensive -- indulgence, far removed from the worlds of global politics and terrorist plots.
 Nonetheless, the destruction in New York and Washington has had a profound effect on collectors and the varied, far-flung businesses that support them. Some collectors are wondering when, and even whether, their avocation can get back to normal. For others, who have spent large sums to buy and restore cars, there is anxiety over market values. Prices plunged in the early 1990's, during the last recession. 
 More fundamentally, some people are wondering if it is even appropriate to indulge now in a flamboyant hobby that is, by its nature, intended to attract attention.
The attacks' most immediate effect on the hobby was the cancellation of a highly anticipated auction that was to have taken place at the Waldorf-Astoria on Sept. 26. Last year, RM Auctions, which presents the event, sold $6.5 million worth of vintage Ferraris, Aston Martins, Cobras and the like. The sale was expected to be even bigger this year, with cars including a 1937 Mercedes-Benz 540K Special Roadster once owned by Jack Warner, the movie mogul.
"Some of our customers were very disturbed that we canceled the auction," said David Gooding, chief executive of RM. "But others felt that raising their hand to buy a million-dollar car, just blocks from a place where thousands of people had so recently died, would just be wrong."
Mr. Gooding said it was his New York customers who most wanted the auction to go on. "But the people who lived outside of the city were really spooked about coming to Manhattan," he said.
There were, of course, logistical problems. It would have been difficult, if not impossible, to bring 50 expensive classic cars into Manhattan -- some by air, and others by truck -- under heightened security measures. And most of the bidders were coming from outside the New York area at a time when airline schedules were uncertain.
(Some of the featured cars from the Waldorf sale will be offered at RM's next auction, to be held in Phoenix on Jan. 18.)
Mr. Gooding said he had not yet seen indications that either the attacks or the weakening economy had significantly affected high-end collecting, though he has received calls from "bottom feeders" -- opportunists looking for bargains.
"But no owners have called saying they want to dump their collections," he said. "Rather, with paper securities in such a chaotic state, having your money parked in hard goods like vintage Ferraris suddenly seems like a pretty smart idea."
There are other signs that the collector market is holding steady, at least for now. McKeel Hagerty, president of Hagerty Insurance in Traverse City, Mich., a company that specializes in insuring collectible automobiles and boats, said that one previous indicator of major shifts in the market had been the number of cars added to, or removed from, the policies held by collectors.
"So far, we haven't seen any evidence that people are dumping their cars and canceling their policies," he said. "In fact, we've seen a slight uptick in new policies."
He predicted that there might be an increase in the value of American cars from the 1950's and 60's, as part of a wave of patriotism. That sentiment was echoed by David E. Davis, founder and editor emeritus of Automobile Magazine.
Mr. Davis recalled that in the 60's, soldiers in Vietnam "wanted their copies of car magazines, to think about the things they wanted to do when they got back home." He added: "Cars, especially collectible cars, have always been an important part of the way Americans enjoy and express themselves. This isn't going to change."
Donald Osborne, a vintage-car enthusiast in New York, offered a personal testament about the comfort that enthusiasts can find in their cars during troubling times. On Sept. 11, Mr. Osborne, sales director of Integrated Creative Experiences, a marketing and communications company, walked out of his office on Park Avenue South and saw the first tower collapse. He made his way home to Brooklyn Heights on foot, through the smoke and dust.
From his apartment, he watched the disaster unfold. "The 24-hour-a-day sirens, and the black smoke lit up at night by searchlights, were just overwhelming," he recalled. By the weekend, "I had to get away."
He drove to Connecticut, where he keeps his 1967 Lancia Fulvia Zagato. During a day behind the wheel, he reflected on the comfort of doing something familiar. "We have to find out what our new 'normal' lives will be," he said. "And the only way we can do that is by doing things we've always done, and seeing which ones still feel right."
He said he felt compelled to do things that reminded him that life would continue. "I just wanted to get back the parts of my life that I could get back. By driving my old car, I transported myself to a better, simpler, kinder place, if only for a few hours."
The biggest national gathering of collectors is the National Fall Meet of the eastern division of the Antique Automobile Club of America. It takes place next Wednesday through Saturday in Hershey, Pa. Of two auctions that had been scheduled to coincide with the Hershey event, one has been canceled; its presenter, Bonhams & Brooks, said that "holding a solely commercial event" would not be appropriate now.
The other auction will go on. "We have to continue, like the president says," said Rob Williams, general manager of the Blackhawk Collection, the organizer of that sale.
On the West Coast, the next measure of collectors' mood will come Oct. 27-28 in Santa Clara, Calif., at the eBay Motors Pacific Classic Collector Car Auction. It will be produced by Kruse International, an eBay subsidiary, and will be the first "land based" car sale by that Internet auction company.
"It's not a great time to be selling very expensive cars," said Timothy Sprague, chief executive of Kruse. "But we've lined up over 200 cars, most of them under $50,000 and many of them American muscle cars. We believe that's exactly what collectors will be looking for."
Even in September, some enthusiasts went ahead with scheduled events despite the strong emotions of the moment. In the resort community of Sun River, Ore., collectors held their annual car show and tour just a few days after the terrorist attacks.
"The World Trade Center was on everyone's mind," said John Draneas, the Portland lawyer who organized the event, describing the mood as subdued. "But we had the largest crowds ever, with many people waving American flags. We observed some formal moments of silence, but no speeches. It was as if everyone needed a break and wanted to think about something else."
Mr. Draneas said he was likely to buy more cars soon. "We've seen just how full of uncertainties life can be," he said. "I've put off buying some of the cars I've always wanted, but now I think it's time to buy them and enjoy them right now, not later."

GRAPHIC: Photos: David Gooding, chief executive of RM Auctions, in a '59 Cadillac convertible. (Marissa Roth for The New York Times); After days of watching tragic scenes in New York, Donald Osborne found comfort driving his '67 Lancia Fulvia in Connecticut. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF; 
Pay Cuts Shrink, Worry Remains

BYLINE:  By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:
The patient is alive. That was the consensus on Broadway this week as box-office figures continued to improve and several productions began to give back some of the wage concessions that unions approved after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
 That was good news for actors, stagehands and other off-stage staff. Alan Wasser, the general manager of "Les Miserables" and "Phantom of the Opera," said yesterday that the cast and crew of his shows would get back half the 25 percent wage cut they took beginning on Sept. 23. Producers were also giving back half at the Martin Beck Theater, home to "Kiss Me, Kate," where the cast and crew had been giving up 50 percent of their pay. And at "Chicago," the producers Fran and Barry Weissler told the company that they would probably get back the entire 25 percent if the show's box-office numbers continued to improve. 
 For all the good signs and good will, there were some serious concerns about what lay down the road for Broadway. Travel and tourism continue to suffer mightily -- why else would this week's story about 1,000 Oregonians coming to town be big news? -- a factor that some producers have already taken into account in their plans.
The problem is simple: while audiences have been buying same-day or same-week tickets, advance sales have been slow to bounce back. "It's very much a current-sale situation," Mr. Wasser said. "We're not really selling into the future, because a lot of the planes are coming in empty."
At "Les Miserables" and "Phantom," for example, about half the daily sales are usually for performances at least a week away. Lately that figure has dropped to as low as 20 percent, Mr. Wasser said.
In particular, many producers are deeply concerned about January through mid-March, when in a good year even the best shows suffer a bit as tourists stay home and people nearby avoid going out. This year, however, some fear the decline could be particularly harsh.
"You're in a place where a lot of shows are burning through their advance and not restocking the till," said one producer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If daily sales then dry up, as they always do in the winter, where's the money to keep you going to come from?" '
Indeed, while some long-running shows crept back into profitability this week, they did so only with union concessions, which expire in two weeks. And while industry executives give enormous credit to the mayor and other officials for encouraging people to come to New York and see a show, some producers wonder how long the love affair with New York will last.
"How are you going to extend the good will of New Yorkers and keep them coming to the shows until the spring?" asked one person in the industry.
Not everyone was pessimistic. Ronald Lee, president of Group Sales Box Office, a ticket service, said his business "ground to a halt" after the attacks, but winter sales were off less than 2 percent from last year.
Philip Smith, the president of the Shubert Organization, also tried to put a positive spin on the state of advance sales. "They're off, no question, but they're improving," he said.
But even Broadway's biggest boosters recognize the challenges ahead. "The next big decision comes after Christmas and New Year's," said Jed Bernstein, the president of the League of American Theaters and Producers. "After that comes the cold winter. We can only hope that the momentum will continue."

Delay for 'Vampires'
There is another Broadway postponement to report: "Dance of the Vampires," a musical based on the 1967 Roman Polanski film "The Fearless Vampire Killers," will not be seen this season.
Its producer, David Sonenberg, said yesterday that he had decided to push back the show's opening until next fall. The show, originally scheduled for late April, will instead open on Oct. 24 at the Minskoff Theater.
Mr. Sonenberg said most of the show's creative team, including John Caird, the co-director, was based in London, which caused myriad logistic delays. "We haven't been able to do anything productive since all this happened," he said. "We just realized there was no way to open before the Tony cutoff."
Another bloodsucking extravaganza may still be seen on Broadway. "Dracula, the Musical," which begins performances on Tuesday at La Jolla Playhouse in California, has booked the Broadway Theater. Expect it in late spring if the reviews are good.
Des McAnuff ("Big River") directs; Frank Wildhorn, an exponent of the pop-ghoul genre (see "Jekyll and Hyde"), is the composer.

Saved by a Carpenter
Joe Maher is a regular Joe. He has a house on Long Island, a beautiful wife and a good job as the house carpenter at the Martin Beck Theater.
Lately, however, he's got a new title: show saver.
It was just two weeks ago, after all, that Mr. Maher found out that his show, "Kiss Me, Kate," was to close after Broadway's theatrical unions decided to reject a proposed 50 percent pay cut for the musical's cast and crew. Barring those concessions, the production didn't seem to stand a chance.
Until Mr. Maher proposed a simple idea: instead of a full 50 percent cut, what if the cast and crew voluntarily gave 25 percent on top of the 25 percent already approved by the unions? Better yet, what if they used the money to buy tickets and donate them to rescue workers?
"I just felt it was a tragedy for this thing to close," Mr. Maher. "I mean, that's 100 people losing their jobs. And there ain't a lot of jobs out there right now."
The company unanimously approved the plan, and the closing notice was ripped up onstage by the show's producer, Roger Berlind. And on Sunday the cast presented Mr. Maher with a life-preserver signed by every member of the company and inscribed "Capt. Joe Maher, S.S. Kiss Me Kate." Mr. Maher, whose father, grandfather and great-grandfather all worked backstage on Broadway, said it wasn't that big a deal.
"I couldn't go on unemployment right now," he said, "I got to pay for my wife's new kitchen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joe Maher, house carpenter at the Martin Beck Theater, saved the show. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fed Cut Rates, Fearing Attacks' Economic Impact 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
The risk that terrorist attacks might weaken United States asset prices and the economy led Federal Reserve policy makers to lower their benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point on Sept. 17, according to minutes of a Fed conference released today.
 The reduction in interest rates, at that point the eighth in 2001, was made "against the backdrop of heightened concerns and uncertainty created by the recent terrorist attacks and their potentially adverse effects on asset prices and the performance of the economy," the Fed's minutes said. 
 All 10 members of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee voted for the rate cut, the third this year between scheduled meetings. 
At a regular meeting on Tuesday, the Fed moved again, lowering the federal funds rate a ninth time -- down a half-point more, to 2.5 percent, the lowest in almost 40 years.
After the attacks on Sept. 11, stock trading was halted for four days. An hour after the rate cut on Sept. 17, share prices plummeted in resumed trading and they continued falling for several days. 
The Fed rate-setting panel, at an earlier meeting on Aug. 21, had voted for a quarter-point reduction in the federal funds rate, the rate on overnight loans between banks, and it discussed the possibility of ending this year's series of rate cuts "relatively soon," the minutes showed.
The Fed by then had reduced the benchmark rate by three percentage points this year, to 3.5 percent. Policy makers said then that the cycle of rate cuts "probably would have to be terminated before available measures of economic activity provided clear evidence of a substantial strengthening trend" in the economy, the Aug. 21 minutes said. Still, "the strength and timing of the pickup remained uncertain and further weakness was a distinct threat in the near term," the Fed panel said.
And even while considering a change in the direction of interest rate policy, central bankers said "the economy continued to be weak -- indeed weaker than many had expected -- and data and anecdotal reports from around the country had yet to point to persuasive signs of a turnaround."
The Fed combined its Sept. 17 rate cut with a promise to supply "an atypically large volume of liquidity to the financial system." That, the minutes said, could lead the federal funds rate to fall below its target on occasion until "more normal conditions were restored in the functioning of the financial system."
Central bankers began to debate a further lowering of borrowing costs in a conference call two days after the attacks, the minutes showed. They held back because "financial markets were still too disrupted and the economic outlook too uncertain to provide an adequate basis for a policy move."

HEADLINE: Some Workers Are Finding It a Difficult Time to Strike 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
There is never a good time to go on strike, union leaders often say, but the walkout on Monday by nearly 28,000 Minnesota state employees seems to have come at an especially inopportune time.
 Gov. Jesse Ventura, business leaders, editorial writers and many other Minnesotans have condemned the strikers for walking out during a national crisis. When so many Americans are talking about the need for shared sacrifice and unity, it has suddenly become difficult, even risky, for unions to use their most potent weapon. 
 "This strike comes at a most unfortunate time," Mr. Ventura, an independent, said. "Our citizens are still hurting from the devastating attack on Sept. 11, we are coping with the possibility of a long and difficult war, and we are facing the prospect of an economy that is on the brink of recession."
For unions, public sympathy can be crucial in trying to outmuscle and outlast management in a strike. With the public showing less support for strikers after the attacks, labor experts say unions might become more reluctant to walk out.
In North Carolina, where state employees are threatening their first strike ever, many state officials say economic problems, made worse by the Sept. 11 attacks, make it harder for the state to meet the union's demands. When 200 teachers in Granite City, Ill., went on strike five days after the attacks, they were widely denounced as being selfish.
The local newspaper, The Belleville News-Democrat, wrote: "They lost credibility when they walked out days after the worst terrorist attacks in our nation's history. Beyond that, the attacks Sept. 11 weakened our nation's already shaky economy -- and made the union demands even more unreasonable."
Michael LeRoy, a professor of labor relations at the University of Illinois, predicted that there would be fewer strikes as a result of the new mood across the nation. Mr. LeRoy conducted a study on how various administrations, including those of Presidents Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower, sometimes accused unions of being unpatriotic when they went on strike during the Korean War and the cold war.
"A time of national emergency makes it more difficult for unions to engineer public support," Mr. LeRoy said. "And I wouldn't underestimate the importance of public sympathy in conducting a successful strike."
The shift in the collective bargaining terrain, coming when unemployment is soaring and corporate profits are falling, could weaken labor's hand at the bargaining table. But many union leaders assert that they should not shrink from striking.
"We sacrificed back in 1993, when we took a 0 percent raise," said Murray Cody, communications director of the Minnesota Association of Professional Employees, one of the two unions that went on strike on Monday. "We were told back then to sacrifice to help the state out, and they promised that when times got better, they'd take care of us. But they never came through on that."
Mr. Cody rejected some criticism that his union was being unpatriotic, noting that members had contributed more than $10,000 to the victims of the terrorist attack in New York. He said the union, whose contract expired in June, originally planned to strike on Sept. 17, but delayed the walkout for two weeks because of the Sept. 11 attacks.
Some union and business representatives forecast a decline in strikes because of the national mood. Patrick Cleary, senior vice president for human resources policy at the National Association of Manufacturers, said, "I believe that, barring some gargantuan problems, labor and management will find a way to make peace or defer battle."
New York City's teachers union, which has been without a contract for more than a year, has asked for a two-month delay in contentious hearings in its salary dispute. Leaders of that union say it is not an appropriate time to battle over wages. 
But Patrick Lynch, president of New York City's main police union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said the Sept. 11 attacks could strengthen the hand of uniformed unions, like police and firefighters, because the public had come to appreciate all the more the importance of those workers.
Some union strategists fear that managers of some companies and government bodies will seize on the national crisis to take advantage of their workers, knowing that it is a difficult time to strike. 
Ron Blackwell, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s director of corporate affairs, predicted that strikes would decrease, but that labor relations might remain tense, partly because executive pay has skyrocketed while rank-and-file wages languished. 
"Patriotism is a very important feeling in the country," Mr. Blackwell said. "But that doesn't change the relationship people have with their employers.
"No one is saying, 'Let's stop the American economy.' They're saying, 'Let's get some equity back in the employment relationship.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Striking Minnesota state employees, Liz Brown, left, and Marge Johnson, try to get motorists to honk their horns in support in St. Paul. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Some Rental Car Companies Lobby for U.S. to Back Loans 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
A coalition of rental car companies has begun lobbying Congress and the White House for a five-year, $1.5 billion package of loan guarantees, saying that they, like the nation's airlines, have been devastated by a plunge in business after the terrorist attacks, officials said yesterday.
 But the industry is divided, with rental giants Hertz and Avis Rent-A-Car Systems, along with Enterprise Rent-A-Car, opposed to any bailout of the industry. 
 The plan is being promoted by the ANC Rental Corporation, the parent of National and Alamo, and is supported by Budget Rent A Car and Dollar Rent A Car Systems, which includes Thrifty Car Rental.
"This is a vital industry, and it is in very serious need of help," said John Merrigan, with the Washington law firm of Verner, Liipfert, who is coordinating the effort. 
The chief executives of Hertz and Avis, however, sent a letter yesterday to Donald Evans, the commerce secretary, saying they did not support a relief plan. They urged the government instead to focus on efforts to restore the public's confidence in air travel.
"We believe that direct financial assistance of the car rental industry will inevitably take federal money away from domestic security programs, efforts to fight terrorism and initiatives aimed at strengthening the economy and the travel industry," said David Siegel, the chief executive of Avis, and Craig Koch, the head of Hertz.
Though Enterprise officials did not sign the letter, the company considers the proposal inappropriate, said Christy Conrad, an Enterprise spokeswoman. "It just wouldn't be right to ask for the money," she said. Officials at the companies would not say whether they would draw from the loan guarantees, if offered, however.
The $19.4 billion a year car rental industry was hurt by the terrorist attacks, which led to a nationwide freeze on air travel. Airport car rentals comprise up to 90 percent of transactions of the major companies, whose primary customers are business travelers. Business fell an estimated 50 percent during the days after the attacks, and 1.92 million vehicles were scattered across the country, as stranded air travelers rented cars to drive home.
Car rental traffic has improved the last three weeks, but executives at the companies say business remains down 25 percent to 35 percent. Officials estimate losses could be in the millions of dollars. To spur rentals, the companies are offering a series of discount deals.
Michael S. Egan, the chief executive at ANC Rental, said it could take years for the industry to recover from the impact of the attacks. In an interview, Mr. Egan said his company, which had faced financial difficulties before Sept. 11, might not survive without government help. On Monday, ANC Rental deferred a $70 million bridge loan payment for two months, and named new executives, including a new chief financial officer, who will direct a turnaround effort.
Before the attacks, "this company was a viable company," Mr. Egan said.
"We were doing things we felt would make us investable, salable or profitable for the future," he said. "We had every prospect of succeeding. On Sept. 11, the world changed." 
In their letter to Mr. Evans, the Hertz and Avis chiefs agreed that the industry had suffered financially. "Nevertheless, the long-term solution for our industry exists within the broader framework of efforts by Congress and the president to deal with this crisis, not in a car rental industry-specific rescue plan," the executives said.
Rudy Maxa, a travel consultant and commentator who is based in Washington, said the proposal might prove a tough sell. "They're not perceived to be as important as the airlines for the economy," he said. "Certainly business is down. But business is down a lot of places. Should they be asking Congress for a subsidy? I don't think so."
Industry experts suggested that the bid for federal assistance appears to be pitting financially disadvantaged companies against the industry's healthier players. 
Betsy Snyder, a director at Standard & Poors, the financial ratings agency, likened the debate to arguments that have broken out among airline companies in the days since Congress passed an emergency aid package. "It's a parallel situation," Ms. Snyder said.
Even before the attacks, Ms. Snyder said she was concerned about many of the rental car companies. "For the last year, business has been off, there has been pressure on pricing, and they had too many cars," she said.
Mr. Egan bristled at the notion that ailing rental car companies might be using the attacks as an opportunity to gain federal assistance that could help them assuage pre-existing financial problems.
"If anyone looks at us askance and says, 'Oh, you're just using this as an excuse,' that's like saying we're just using this incident to pursue people that we think are enemies of our country in the first place,' " Mr. Egan said. "It's crazy. What happened is unprecedented."

HEADLINE: Levy Tries to Calm Fears About Air Quality Near Ruins 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH and EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Trying to relieve parents' environmental concerns about schools near the World Trade Center, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he would move his office to one of the schools, Stuyvesant High School, when it reopened to students on Tuesday.
 Mr. Levy's gesture is largely symbolic; he plans to stay only four days and is taking only a secretary with him. He is responding to a growing outcry from parents at seven schools who are worried about air quality and the trucks carrying debris from the disaster site. 
 His effort apparently is not enough to allay fears of parents at at least one of the other shuttered schools, Public School 234, at the corner of Greenwich and Chambers Streets, one block east of Stuyvesant. That school was to reopen around Oct. 15, but so many parents raised objections regarding problems with air quality that the Board of Education decided yesterday to delay the return for at least another month.
Instead, the school's 675 students will move from one temporary space -- P.S. 41 on West 11th Street in Greenwich Village -- to another, St. Bernard School, on West 13th Street. 
The news of P.S. 234's latest plan infuriated many parents and teachers at P.S. 89, another school in Lower Manhattan that was closed after the attack on the World Trade Center. Those parents and teachers had also been hoping for the St. Bernard site, which was used as a Catholic elementary school until June.
"They don't understand how desperate we are," said Sharon Sprague, a P.S. 89 parent who was fighting tears after she heard the news. "They'd better come up with a good location for us fast or people are going to start giving up." 
The school has already been abandoned, at least temporarily, by more than 100 families who were left indefinitely homeless by the attack and have enrolled their children elsewhere, Ms. Sprague said. 
Catie Marshall, a spokeswoman for Mr. Levy, said yesterday that the board was scouting new locations for P.S. 89 and its sister school, Intermediate School 89. The students for those schools are now using severely crowded spaces at P.S. 3 on Hudson Street and I.S. 70 on West 17th Street. 
The permanent home for P.S. and I.S. 89 at Warren and West Streets, just three blocks from ground zero, will be used by the city's Office of Emergency Management for at least another month. Most of the roughly 700 students have not been able to move back into their homes in Battery Park City since the attack.
"The goal for both of these is to move them out to new locations next week," Ms. Marshall said. "We're looking for the locations now."
The students from P.S. 234 have been doubling and even tripling up in classrooms at P.S. 41, creating what Anna Switzer, the principal of P.S. 234, described as a chaotic environment. Under pressure from parents, the Board of Education promised to reopen P.S. 234 around Oct. 15.
But after learning this week that traces of asbestos had been detected in dust samples at nearby Stuyvesant High, many parents changed their minds. After several emotional meetings with parents and teachers this week, Ms. Switzer decided to delay the return. Instead, she said yesterday, the school would move into St. Bernard on Tuesday and stay there for at least a month. 
"We want to go back to our school more than anything," Ms. Switzer said. "But we can't go back until the adults have confidence that it's a completely safe move."
Stuyvesant High, which was used as a staging area for rescue and recovery workers until last week, is being tested for the presence of asbestos and other environmental hazards after an intense cleaning over the last several days.
Last month, before the cleaning, tests showed elevated levels of asbestos in dust on surfaces in the school. But air samples taken after the cleaning showed only traces of asbestos, well below the levels deemed dangerous by the federal Environmental Protection Agency. 
P.S. 150, a small elementary school on Greenwich Street, near Independence Plaza, was to reopen next week but will remain closed indefinitely because of a noisy construction project just outside the building, board officials said yesterday. Its students have been housed at P.S. 3 since the attack, but a spokeswoman for Mr. Levy said that they might be moved to a less crowded location.
The High School for Leadership and Public Service and the High School of Economics and Finance, which both sustained minor damage in the attack, could reopen in the next few weeks, board officials said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chancellor Harold O. Levy will temporarily move his office to a school near the trade center site to try to relieve worries about air quality. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fearing Unrest, China Presses Muslim Group 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
Abudu Pu'er, a young Uighur man from Xinjiang, the region in China's far west, didn't sleep much Sunday night. He wandered from gritty hostel to humble guest house looking for a bed, but was turned away at every door.
 "As soon as they see I am from Xinjiang, they tell me to go," he said Monday, standing with a handful of other weary Uighurs in the city's tiny Muslim neighborhood, which is itself slowly disappearing beneath churning construction sites. 
 Mr. Pu'er and his friends are members of a Muslim Turkic ethnic group with simmering resentment of Chinese rule who come to the city to trade raisins, melons and occasionally hashish. They now fear that Shanghai's police may round them up and send them to back to Xinjiang or to labor camps. 
A crackdown on Uighurs (pronounced WE-goors) in the city and elsewhere in the country is just one piece of a major effort to suppress potential unrest among the ethnic group, which poses the most credible threat of any group to China's internal cohesion.
If China were ever to break apart in the way that the Soviet Union did a decade ago, Xinjiang -- the region's name means New Territory, reflecting its integration into the Chinese empire in the 18th century -- could be the first to go.
China has joined Washington's developing alliance against Islamic terrorism in part because it is eager to win international support for its own campaign against Uighur separatists, who have long been viewed with sympathy in the West. The separatists claim that the Chinese government's economic and demographic policies are marginalizing the country's eight million Uighurs and will eventually lead to their cultural annihilation.
Since the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States, China has intensified the surveillance and control of Uighurs out of fears that its support for a war in Central Asia might ignite an uprising among the chronically restive population. Some Xinjiang Uighurs are known to have fought along the side of Afghanistan's Taliban rulersin preparation, they say, for fighting for their cause in China.
At least seven Uighurs were executed for "disrupting social order" and other vague crimes in the week leading up to the country's Oct. 1 holiday celebrating the Communist rise to power in 1949. Dozens of Uighurs have reportedly been detained.
"China is using the fight against terrorism as a cloak to round up Uighurs who they think may be dangerous," said Erkin Alptekin, the son of Isa Yusuf Alptekin, the late leader of the independent Eastern Turkestan Republic, which was established in Xinjiang in 1944.
Mr. Alptekin, speaking by telephone from Germany, fled with his family over the Karakoram Mountains to Indian Kashmir just before the Chinese Communists arrived in 1949. His brother, Arslan Alptekin, lost his toes to frostbite in the ordeal. A sister died.
He says the suppression of Uighurs is unwarranted because he and other prominent supporters of Uighur independence have never advocated violence, and militancy among the population is rare. Still, Mr. Alptekin said frustration among young Uighurs living under Chinese rule could be turned against the Chinese government if it backed a war in Afghanistan.
"We have been warning for years that Eastern Turkestan could blow up someday if it is surrounded by hot wars," said Mr. Alptekin, who is now general secretary of the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization, which promotes the interests of people not directly represented in the United Nations. "If that happens, other Central Asians might try to cross the border to help their ethnic brothers." Eastern Turkestan is the name many supporters of an independent state prefer for Xinjiang.
China argues that Uighur separatists are already getting that help. Wang Jianping, an associate fellow at the Institute of World Religions under the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in Beijing, says the separatists have in the past received moral support and arms from radical Islamic groups elsewhere in Central Asia and that some may have received training from the Taliban.
"There could be as few as 100, or as many as 500" who have received Taliban training, Mr. Wang said last week in a telephone interview. The anti-Taliban Northern Alliance has captured Uighurs fighting along with Taliban forces.
The immediate losers from the heightened tension are the majority of Uighurs in China who are increasingly unwelcome outside their home region, even as the ethnic Chinese presence in that region grows. Uighurs argue that the country's birth control policy ensures that their population growth cannot keep up with government-sponsored migration to Xinjiang by Han Chinese, China's dominant ethnic group, even though limits on the number of children they and other minorities can bear are less restrictive than for Hans. About 40 percent of Xinjiang's population is now Han Chinese compared with about 15 percent in 1949. Uighurs, once in the majority, have declined to about 47 percent of the population. Other ethnic groups include Kazakhs, Kyrgyz, Tajiks and Mongols. The population of the region's capital, Urumqi, is now 80 percent Han Chinese.
Shanghai, meanwhile, pared down its Uighur population after separatists in Xinjiang mounted a brief uprising and a subsequent string of bombings in several Chinese cities during the 1990's. Only a few dozen Uighur families have permanent household registrations in the city today and Uighurs say the city has stopped issuing temporary residency permits to members of the ethnic group.
The small hotel for Uighurs in the heart of the city's Muslim quarter on Zhejiang Road has been closed for more than a year. Chinese Muslims of other ethnic backgrounds pay $2.50 for a bed across the road at the Islamic Society's guest house in a crumbling former mosque built by Pakistanis before World War II, but Uighurs aren't allowed to stay there.
The intensified crackdown this month has further reduced their numbers and some Uighurs say they believe there are now fewer than 1,000 Uighurs in the city. Those picked up without temporary residency permits are put on a train back to Xinjiang, if they have the money to pay the fare. Otherwise, they are sent for a few months to a labor camp near Xuzhou, north of Shanghai, Uighurs here say.
China has also closed its narrow border with Afghanistan and moved troops to the border region, government officials say. The country has tightened controls at other crossings along its border with Pakistan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan.
Xinjiang Airlines has doubled to two the number of armed guards on flights between Xinjiang and Islamabad, Moscow and Central Asian countries, according to Reuters, and airport security around the country has been increased. .
While China has said it has not stopped issuing visas to vistors of any nationality, immigration controls have already been tightened. Shanghai's immigration officials are refusing to extend visas for some Middle Easterners and South Asians.
Security is particularly tight in Shanghai ahead of the visit later this month by President Bush, who will attend a summit with leaders of the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. His Shanghai visit, which has been extended to three days to incorporate meetings that had been scheduled to take place in Beijing, will be his first trip outside the United States since the Sept. 11 attacks. It will also be his first foreign trip since a summit meeting of the Group of Eight industrialized nations in Genoa, Italy in July, where, according to the Egyptian and Italian governments, Mr. Bush was the target of a threat by Islamic terrorists. 
Yang Guoqiang, head of the city's APEC Preparatory Office, said the Ministry of Public Security and Shanghai's Public Security Bureau had mapped out a comprehensive plan to create a "web around the earth and sky" that would ensure the safety of the summit's participants.

China, in lending its support to the global antiterrorism campaign, has intensified a crackdown on the Muslim Uighurs. HEADLINE: Claims for Unemployment Benefits Reach a Nine-Year High 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
The number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits soared last week to a nine-year high as economic damage spread from the terrorist attacks.
 Initial jobless claims rose by 71,000, to 528,000, in the week ended Saturday, the Labor Department said. The level of new claims is the most since the week ended July 25, 1992, during a companywide shutdown of plants by General Motors. 
 The rise comes after a gain of 64,000 the previous week and reflects job cuts at airlines and travel-related companies. The attacks disrupted business across the nation and probably pushed the economy into recession, analysts say.
"This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks," said Steven Wood, chief economist at FinancialOxygen Inc. "There's another wave behind it."
Announcements of job cuts rose to a record 248,332 in September, according to the outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. That was the most since 205,975 job cuts were announced in July and more than four times the number in September last year.
Increasing job cuts help explain why the unemployment rate probably rose to a four-year high of 5 percent in September, according to the median forecast in a separate Bloomberg News survey.
Employers are likely to have eliminated 100,000 jobs last month after a reduction of 113,000 in August, according to the survey. That would be the first time since March-April 1991, the end of the last recession, that payrolls were cut by 100,000 or more workers in consecutive months. The Labor Department is scheduled to release those statistics on Friday.
Because federal law requires companies under certain conditions to give workers 60 days' notice of mass dismissals, the latest surge in announced layoffs may not show up on the unemployment rolls for several more weeks.
The four-week moving average of claims, which smooths out volatility in the weekly numbers, rose last week to 453,500 -- the highest since December 1991 as unemployment continued to rise in the wake of the last recession -- from 424,000 the previous week.
"We are beginning to see secondary impact across the country" from the terrorist attacks, said Cynthia Ambler, a Labor Department spokeswoman. The department expects to have more detail next week when state reports are more complete, she said.
A separate government report showed new orders placed at manufacturers were little changed in August as inventories declined for the seventh consecutive month.
Factory orders were valued at $332.6 billion in August, after falling 0.1 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported. Orders excluding transportation equipment rose 0.2 percent in August after dropping 0.3 percent a month earlier.
Manufacturing has been in a 14-month slump through September, according to a report from the National Association of Purchasing Management that was released earlier this week.
Nonetheless, the group's measure of new orders showed that more manufacturers reported increasing orders in August and September than posted a decline.
