HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PENSION FUNDS; 
Leaders Say Union Funds Will Help Rebuild City

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall met yesterday with city and state union leaders who oversee a combined $280 billion in pension funds to develop a plan to help finance the rebuilding of office towers and transit systems destroyed by the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.
 The union leaders emphasized their desire to invest what could potentially be more than $1 billion in transportation projects and new commercial buildings in Lower Manhattan, alongside the federal government, which has promised $20 billion in aid to clean up the debris at the trade center and rehabilitate the area. 
 Also attending the meeting in Manhattan late yesterday afternoon were City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, who helps oversee five pension funds for municipal employees, and Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier who was at the heart of the city's recovery after the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and who has advocated investing pension funds in infrastructure projects nationally.
"We want to make it clear that we stand ready to provide some of the financial resources to move projects forward," said Mr. McCall, who serves as the sole trustee for the $112 billion of the state employees' common retirement fund. "We expect the federal, state and city governments, as well as the private sector, to do their part as well. We're willing to participate in the overall investment pool." 
The meeting yesterday reunited Mr. Rohatyn with the city's municipal union leaders in an echo of the 1970's, when New York City was teetering at the edge of bankruptcy. In 1975, Gov. Hugh L. Carey and the State Legislature appointed Mr. Rohatyn chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and a member of the Financial Control Board, which had been created to salvage the city's dire financial structure. The financier wielded considerable power through the assistance corporation and the control board, which had the power to reject city budgets, contracts and labor agreements.
The group that met yesterday did not make any specific commitments, and said that individual developments would have to be identified by state and city officials and private developers. But Mr. McCall said that the pension funds could purchase bonds issued by the state or the city and guaranteed by the federal government, could provide mortgage financing for office development or could invest directly in a project.
"Everybody's on board with the concept," said Alan Lubin, executive vice president of the New York State United Teachers, which represents about 460,000 members. "It's an important investment, given the crisis we're facing in the city and across the state. To me, the first need is for office space to try to keep the business and jobs in New York. I'm sure they're getting entreaties to go to Jersey."
Mr. Lubin and Mr. McCall, who were among the 30 people at the meeting in Manhattan yesterday, said that investments would be consistent with their fiduciary responsibility to get a good return. They said they hoped that the Federal government would agree to guarantee whatever bonds were issued.
Last month John Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said that the national unions in the association would make available $500 million in pension funds for economic development in the city.
Since the Sept. 11 attack, the city has endured a cascade of bad news, starting with the loss of more than 5,000 lives and continuing through the destruction of about 15 million square feet of office buildings.
Mr. Hevesi's office estimated yesterday that the disaster would cost New Yorkers as much as $105 billion over the next two years. So far only $126 million of a promised $20 billion in federal aid has seeped into the city. There is a great deal of confusion about whether the money can be used for new projects, tax breaks and to replace lost tax revenues.
In 1975, Mr. Rohatyn brought together union leaders and bankers under the banner of "shared sacrifice" in the effort to resurrect the city's fiscal affairs.
But the bankers closed the credit markets to New York City. So it was city employees who did much of the sacrificing. Mr. Rohatyn ultimately persuaded city labor leaders -- Victor Gotbaum, Barry Feinstein and Albert Shanker -- to accept a municipal wage freeze and layoffs and to use pension funds to buy more than $2 billion in municipal bonds.
Although the union leaders took an enormous risk, the bonds turned out to be a good investment, said Mike Wallace, a history professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
U.S. Acts On Shortage Of Treasuries

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The government, which normally announces the sale of Treasury securities well in advance, conducted an immediate auction for the first time yesterday in an effort to ease problems in the Treasury market.
 In the last two weeks, an unusually large amount of trades have not settled. If the problem persists, the big institutional dealers at the core of the market would not be able to function normally, which could lead to distortion of prices and an unwillingness to trade. 
 The United States Treasury market is crucial to the smooth operation of all financial markets, and worried investors flock to securities backed by the government in times of adversity. The recent terrorist attacks and military buildup have increased demand for these securities, even as market participants struggle to restore trading and settle transactions. 
But there were signs of some relief yesterday after the Treasury announced its snap sale at 11 a.m., and finished its auction of $6 billion in 10-year notes two hours later.
"We want to reduce the risk that these settlement problems turn into a much bigger problem for the Treasury market itself," said Peter R. Fisher, undersecretary of the Treasury for domestic finance. 
The large number of unsettled trades, which are called fails, stemmed from a shortage of the actively traded 2-year, 5-year and 10-year Treasury notes. There were simply not enough securities available to deliver to complete trades.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said that total fails, which may include double and triple counting of the same unsettled trade, reached $1.4 trillion in the week ended Sept. 19 and fell to just more than $800 billion the next week. The weekly average in the second quarter was $45 billion.
It was clear early this week that the threat of trades not being completed was creating a major distortion in what is called the repo market. By yesterday, the Treasury and major players in the bond market were worried that the distortions could spread.
"We have something that is self-compounding," Mr. Fisher said. "There is some point at which your fails pile up, and that is the point at which you damage the price-discovery process and the smooth operating of the Treasury market." He said that the Treasury would consider doing a similar sale of five-year notes if the shortage problem persisted there.
Eric Foster, the head of the government and federal agency securities division of the Bond Market Association, praised the Treasury move. "We need to have a marketplace where when a dealer says, 'I will deliver a security,' he will deliver the security," he said.
The repo market is where Treasury securities are borrowed and lent. It is crucial to the operation of the Treasury market because it provides the funds that dealers need to pay for the securities they have bought and, therefore, helps keep trading running smoothly. The dealers use the securities they have bought as collateral on loans and agree to repurchase the securities at a set date.
With the prospect that securities might not be returned, both dealers and large investors have become unwilling to lend them in the repo market.
This unwillingness drove the cost of short-term borrowing using Treasury securities as collateral to near zero earlier this week. Normally, the rate would be close to the 2.5 percent federal funds rate, which is the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, and the Federal Reserve's target interest rate.
Among the possible reasons for the shortage are an increasing demand for a safe investment, the reluctance of a number of foreign central banks to lend them recently and the unwillingness of some investors to enter into such trades at the end of the third quarter. Mr. Fisher said that there was no suggestion a large holder of Treasury notes was trying to manipulate or squeeze the market. 
In doing the sale, the Treasury issued $6 billion more of the same 10-year notes it sold in August. Those notes, which will mature on Aug. 15, 2011, are the ones in short supply now. The $6 billion in additional notes brings the total outstanding to $17 billion.
It will not be clear until the new notes are available today if the shortage is eased. But Paul Scheufele, head of United States repo trading at Credit Suisse First Boston, said, "The $6 billion in new notes should go a long way to help clear up the fails situation." He added that late yesterday there were signs that the problems in the repo market were easing.
In the Treasury market yesterday, the announcement of the sale sent prices of longer-term notes and bonds lower after they rallied on the report of a sharp increase in initial jobless claims. In late trading, the price of the 10-year note was down 10/32, to 103 28/32 while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, was up to 4.51 percent, from 4.47 percent Wednesday.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
City Says the Attack Could Cost $105 Billion

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi issued the first official estimate yesterday of how much the World Trade Center disaster will cost New Yorkers, and the number is a shocker: as much as $105 billion over the next two years.
 The estimate includes $34 billion in property damage and up to $60 billion in economic costs, including lost jobs and lost rents. 
 The encyclopedic study calculates everything from the cost of rebuilding the twin towers ($6.7 billion) to revenue lost because fewer traffic tickets will be issued ($82 million). 
While the comptroller's office is widely respected for its economic forecasts, it is clearly in the city's interest to make the total as big as possible so that officials can ask for increased federal aid. Mr. Hevesi urged them to do so, saying, "We took the hit for America." 
The report was issued as Gov. George E. Pataki's budget director estimated that the state would lose $1 billion to $3 billion in revenues in the fiscal year that ends in April, and $2 billion to $6 billion in the next fiscal year, as a result of the attack on the trade center. The budget director, Carole E. Stone, acknowledged that those were rough estimates based mostly on anecdotal information.
The governor has promised to balance this year's budget without resorting to layoffs or tax increases. Ms. Stone ordered state agencies in a letter yesterday to hold spending in their budgets for next year at this year's levels.
Almost 6,000 people who applied for unemployment benefits in the last week said it was because of the trade center disaster, bringing the total of disaster-related job losses so far to 16,747, according to the New York State Department of Labor.
The Hevesi report estimates that the city will lose 115,274 jobs in its current fiscal year, which ends June 30. The largest losses -- 28,717 -- will come in services, including at least 6,000 airline jobs. Sales, retail or wholesale, will also be hard hit, with job losses of more than 17,000.
But the biggest chunk of lost wages -- which will total almost $9.6 billion -- will come from a loss of Wall Street paychecks totaling $3.4 billion. 
One of the report's most controversial figures may be its estimate of the loss of "human capital," $11 billion. "It is impossible to put a real value on a human life and the pain of losing a loved one," Mr. Hevesi said.
But Mr. Hevesi noted that economists "ascribe value to human life" by calculating how much people might earn in their working years. Economists in his office assumed that about 5,600 people were killed in the disaster, that they had about 20 working years left apiece, and that their average income was $100,000.
The damage to the city's budget, while serious, is not as severe as the overall injury to the economy, Mr. Hevesi said. 
Tax collections are likely to drop by $738 million this fiscal year, the report said. The biggest decline will be in hotel and sales taxes, which are forecast to fall by $338 million.
Because the city has been running a small surplus, it will be able to take "manageable" steps to balance its budget, as required by law, Mr. Hevesi said. But the next fiscal year may be more of a problem. The comptroller's office had been predicting a deficit of at least $3.6 billion, and that will grow if tax collections fall by an estimated $567 million.
The report calculates that replacing the entire trade center complex and repairing damaged buildings nearby will cost $12 billion. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's losses in addition to the trade center (it owned the buildings and leased them to a private developer) are $2.4 billion.
Fixing the subways will cost about $3 billion, while repairing phone and electrical systems will cost $2 billion. Replacing what was lost in the trade center's stores adds another $2 billion to the tab. The report estimates the value of property in and around the towers, from cars in the garages to computers, was $12 billion.
There will be some money coming into the city that will help offset New Yorkers' losses, the report notes. Families of the victims are likely to receive about $4 billion from life insurance payments, while property insurance should contribute $17 billion. Other kinds of insurance, covering disabled workers and interrupted business, could pay as much as $18 billion, while workers' compensation would amount to about $3 billion.
Finally, there is federal and state aid. Congress has appropriated $20 billion for recovery, but the money must be shared with Pennsylvania and Washington, where hijacked planes also caused damage. "Clearly, given the costs," Mr. Hevesi said, "this will not be enough."

HEADLINE: Power Crisis Abates, but It Hounds Gov. Davis 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif., Oct. 4 

 BODY:
Gov. Gray Davis spoke animatedly with a cluster of national guardsmen today at a training compound here just south of Los Angeles, emphasizing his support for their critical mission: protecting airports. Although this was not the sort of appearance the governor used to make, it was the second this week in which he had placed himself in front of cameras with uniformed guardsmen. 
 In fact, it was just the sort of appearance governors across the country are making as they seek to identify themselves with the popular campaign for greater domestic security. But while many incumbents are enjoying a lift among the public, with voters expressing a desire for stability over change, Mr. Davis could turn out to be the exception, political experts say. 
 Mr. Davis, a centrist Democrat who took office with a landslide election victory three years ago, has seen his approval ratings slump for months, even as the state's energy crisis has abated. What appeared likely to be a runaway re-election race for which he has already raised more than $30 million now looks as if it could prove a tough battle. 
Polls taken in early September, before the terrorist attacks, showed Mr. Davis trailing former Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles, a potential Republican challenger in next year's race, by a couple of percentage points, even though Mr. Riordan has yet to formally announce and is not well known in many parts of the state. 
Mr. Davis took office at a time of vast prosperity and was fond of saying his three highest priorities were education, education and education. Now the state is facing a sharp decline in revenue and sliding into an economic downturn that some economists say could be deeper than that elsewhere in the country. 
The governor's biggest political problem, though, may be the lingering effects of the energy crisis, which started in the summer of last year.
Polls have consistently shown that while voters do not hold the governor responsible for the crisis itself, they are critical of his policies for resolving it. Those policies have included enormous state spending to provide adequate supplies of electricity and big rate increases that could last for years; rates of some customers are up 40 percent since last fall.
In addition, his plan for keeping Southern California Edison, the state's second-largest utility, out of bankruptcy has inflamed already angry consumer advocates, who say he is helping a campaign contributor at the expense of ratepayers. 
Even the fact that the state got through this summer without the power blackouts many had predicted has not helped the governor, in large part because of his approach to controlling the crisis. 
"Here we're in a situation where the market prices for electricity have dropped tenfold since the spring, and yet Davis's plan has locked in the rate increases for years," said Harvey Rosenfield, an official of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights. "Every time consumers get their bills, they are reminded why Davis has done a poor job." 
Shirley Bebitch Jeffe, a senior scholar at the University of Southern California, added, "I'm astonished that his polls keep getting worse, but it does show you how a pocketbook issue like this can stick." 
Garry South, a top adviser to the governor, noted that the latest poll reflecting trouble for him was taken before the terrorist attacks, and said private polls had shown growing support for his performance. 
But the energy issue has undoubtedly proved frustrating to Mr. Davis. Earlier this year, many political experts said that if he could just keep the lights on through the summer, his political fortunes would revive. 
The governor feverishly fashioned a virtual state takeover of the energy market at a cost of tens of billions of dollars, raised utility rates sharply and pushed conservation. By midsummer, the state actually found itself with a surplus of power and was forced to resell some at a loss, a sign that the worst was past. 
But surveys suggest that Californians saw such signs as evidence of questionable management. A poll by the nonpartisan Field Institute taken in early September, before the terrorist attacks, showed that more respondents disapproved of Mr. Davis's overall performance, 47 percent, than approved, 41 percent. Even after a series of blackouts last winter, the governor had a 60 percent approval rating in January. 
"Davis is seen as joined at the hip with the energy issue," said Mark DiCamillo, director of the Field Poll. "This is going to continue to be an albatross around his neck, because what people seem to be thinking about is the increase in rates. It's almost like a tax increase." 
Mr. South, the Davis adviser, said that "people don't know what the governor has done" to resolve the energy crisis. In any case, he said, Mr. Davis will ensure that the top campaign issue next year is not energy but instead Mr. Riordan, whom Mr. South described as "naive" and "a pathetic candidate." 
The governor himself said in an interview here today that he did not put much stock in polls but that he felt his response to the national crisis would ultimately help him politically. "I don't expect people to get up and applaud because the lights stayed on," he said. Then he added: "The bottom line is we're in extraordinary times, which require extraordinary leadership. I believe if I do my job well, everything else will take care of itself."

HEADLINE: House Rejects an Effort To Redirect Farm Policy 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
The House narrowly defeated an effort to shift billions of dollars to environmental programs today, derailing a measure endorsed by the Bush administration to redirect farm policy away from crop subsidies for big farmers in favor of trade and environmental measures.
 With the defeat of an amendment to shift the focus, the House was poised to approve a 10-year, $171 billion farm bill that would increase crop subsidies for grain and cotton farmers, as well as adding money for the food stamp program and several conservation programs. 
 By a vote of 226 to 200, the House rejected an amendment that would have given $19 billion to environmental programs rather than commodity programs for the largest farmers. 
The environmental measure was supported by a loose coalition that included lawmakers from Eastern and Western states that receive a relatively small share of the $20 billion in annual crop payments and representatives from urban areas who wanted more money for farmers to clean up water supplies and protect open spaces. 
"Even though we lost this vote, it sends a clear message that people want a policy that would benefit all farmers in all parts of the country and helps the environment," said Representative Ron Kind, the Wisconsin Democrat who co-sponsored the amendment.
The measure was defeated primarily by lawmakers from the traditional farm states. They considered the measure a threat to the current subsidy programs that largely reward only farmers of cotton, wheat, corn, rice and soybeans. The new House farm bill would not alter the present system, where 8 percent of American farmers receive nearly half of the federal subsidies.
"This amendment would devastate agriculture," said Representative Larry Combest, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee and sponsored the bill. "I didn't notice any people who farm are among the supporters of their amendment.
But in a sign of the growing strength of that environmental movement, defenders of the $171 billion House farm bill also argued that theirs was an environmentally friendly bill.
"This is the greenest farm bill that has ever passed Congress," said Representative Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, the ranking Democrat on the Agriculture Committee and co-sponsor of the House bill. 
In a largely Republican rivalry over the direction of American agriculture, the Bush administration officially objected to Mr. Combest's bill on Wednesday, saying it hurt foreign trade and gave too much money to big farmers and not enough to conservation programs. The administration also warned against locking in $171 billion for agriculture when the government was considering billions of dollars of programs to fight terrorism.
The Senate has yet to write its version of a farm bill to replace the current law, which expires in 2002. 
But the ranking senators on the Agriculture Committee have been vocal supporters of the administration's proposed overhaul of farm policy to reflect the explosive changes in agriculture. They have argued that the Depression-era subsidy programs have to be changed in favor of smaller farmers and the rural economy.
That sentiment was reflected in the debate on the House floor today.
"The future for farmers is about forging an alliance between urban and suburban areas and rural communities, to include the other half of America" said Representative George Miller, Democrat of California. 
Supporters of Mr. Combest's bill said the focus should stay on agriculture.
"This is a farm bill, not an environment bill," said Representative Gil Gutknecht, Republican of Minnesota.
The House also rejected an effort to debate whether to extend dairy compacts that set milk prices in the Northeast, Southeast and West. The pricing system for New England expired on Sunday.
The wide-ranging provisions of the farm bill also included increased financing for food stamp programs as well as school breakfast and lunch programs, the traditional trade-off for urban areas that are otherwise ignored in the measure.
In a vote of 239 to 177, the House defeated a bid to reduce the support rate for sugar by 3 cents a pound.
Animal rights advocates won passage of an amendment to ban interstate commerce in cockfighting roosters.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: PEACE ACTIVISTS; 
Groups Plan Vigils and Rallies to Urge Alternatives to War

BYLINE:  By GUSTAV NIEBUHR

 BODY:
Peace groups around the nation are preparing vigils and rallies on Sunday to demand legal and diplomatic alternatives to war.
 The American Friends Service Committee, Pax Christi USA, the War Resisters League and others have asked their members to participate in the local gatherings, including a march and rally in New York, beginning at Union Square. 
 "We're encouraging peace groups throughout the country to get together and formulate their own way to speak out and promote peace," said Janis Shields, spokeswoman for the American Friends, a Quaker organization.
The idea, Ms. Shields said, is "to call attention to the fact that not everyone is calling for war in these trying days." 
Leaders in the groups say there has been a growing grass-roots demand for public expressions of sentiment in favor of peace.
"It's really spontaneous," said the Rev. Chris Ney, national coordinator at the War Resisters League, a 78-year-old organization based in New York. "I wish I could say we're organizing it. We're just providing skills that we have."
Marches and vigils have been held in Washington, Philadelphia and western Massachusetts. Besides the New York rally, Sunday events are planned in Chicago, Philadelphia and Bangor, Me., and elsewhere.
Common themes include not just opposition to war, but also condemnation of the terrorist acts, a call to defend American civil liberties and a rejection of bias against Arabs, Muslims and immigrants.
The ideas are stated on the War Resisters League's Internet site, warresisters.org, which also calls for peace through "economic and social justice." That reflects a common view among peace groups that the United States must work to mitigate such problems as poverty in developing nations if it is to eliminate the threat of terrorism.
But the peace argument differs from another stand with a long history in Christian tradition, recently articulated by Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders, that there are instances in which war may be justly waged. 
In a recent interview, Richard D. Land, president of the Ethics and Public Policy Commission in the Southern Baptist Convention, said the central principle for allowing a nation to enter into war was "just cause." Mr. Land added, "War is only permissible to resist aggression and to defend those victimized by it."
In a letter laced with references to the theory of just war, the nation's Catholic bishops wrote to President Bush two weeks ago, saying military action must be considered as one option, along with diplomatic and legal means.
A further principle was enunciated by Cardinal Bernard Law, archbishop of Boston, in a recent column in his archdiocese's newspaper: "The grave obligation to protect innocent human life must govern our political and military decisions."
But leading opponents of war have argued that the terrorist attacks should not be regarded as an act of war, requiring a military response, but as an international crime, demanding legal pursuit, arrest and trial of the perpetrators, as well as diplomatic and financial penalties against the aggressors and their backers.
"We believe the perpetrators should be brought to justice, but under the rule of law," said Mary Ellen McNish, general secretary of the American Friends. "Not only the perpetrators, but those who supported them."
Similarly, Bishop Thomas Gumbleton, past president of Pax Christi, called the terrorist attacks a crime against humanity.
"So it ought to be dealt with by the whole community of nations," Bishop Gumbleton said. "This means you have to have an international tribunal where such crimes are brought into an international court."
Members of Pax Christi, the national Catholic peace movement, plan to participate in at least 13 antiwar events on Sunday, Dave Robinson, the group's national director, said. Among them will be a vigil at the Pennsylvania Capitol in Harrisburg, Mr. Robinson said.
Another will take place in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Palm Beach, Fla., where Pax Christi members plan to gather in a church to pray the rosary for peace, an act of special significance, given that Sunday is the Feast of the Holy Rosary.
Beth Cioffoletti, the chapter's coordinator, said that since the terrorist attacks, the Palm Beach Pax Christi group, with a "core group" of 25 active members, had drawn greater interest.
"At our last meeting, which was held the Friday after the World Trade Center calamity," Ms. Cioffoletti said, "we had three new people who walked in and said, 'I have to find people I can relate to.' It's unusual to have people walk in off the street."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 11, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about peace rallies misstated the name of a Southern Baptist Convention body headed by Richard D. Land, who said war was permissible only to resist aggression and defend those victimized by it. He is president of the Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission, not Ethics and Public Policy.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AN ASSESSMENT; 
In Germany, Terrorists Made Use of a Passion: An Open Democracy

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: BERLIN, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
While the terrorists who plotted and carried out the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States lived and worked in many European countries, including Britain and France, Germany appears to have been their haven of choice.
 There are many reasons, among them the fact that the terrorists could blend into a society with a large Muslim population and more foreigners than any other in Europe. It also seems that post-war Germany's hyper-consciousness about its totalitarian history -- both Nazism and East German Communism -- may have contributed to an openness and a laxity toward security threats that made it an almost ideal spot for "sleepers" to integrate and recruit others. 
 "Germans are so eager not to be Nazis that they can be lax about using the powers of the state," said Kai Hafez of the German Institute for Middle East Studies in Hamburg, where Mohamed Atta and at least four other suspects in the attacks lived. 
"From our own history, we've had to prove to the world that we're a democratic state," Mr. Hafez said -- careful about privacy and religious freedom, welcoming to asylum seekers, anti-war and anti-imperialist.
Catherine Kelleher, the director of the Aspen Institute Berlin, suggested that the very pride and protectiveness of Germans with respect to their post-war democratic gains made them reluctant to accept any infringement on personal freedom. Privacy and data-protection laws make it more difficult here than in America to check basic personal and financial histories, like credit-worthiness, salary levels or even addresses and telephone numbers.
In some ways, Ms. Kelleher and others said, the impact of the 1968 student revolutions was stronger in Germany than even in Paris. Here, the revolt against the staid post-war Adenauer government produced both pacifism and leftist terrorism, with the younger left -- now in power -- more committed to personal ideals and non-state goals than the traditional left.
From the 1960's onward, the influx of Turkish "guest workers" who toiled on behalf of the German economic miracle also brought large numbers of Muslims to Germany. Today, there are about three million Muslims here, some 2.5 million of them Turkish, Mr. Hafez said, and largely concentrated in big cities.
Berlin, for instance, is the third-largest Turkish city in the world, and there are districts of Hamburg and Berlin where a stroller sees far more head scarves than in New York or even London. 
Stronger anti-terrorism laws were put in place in the mid-1970's to give investigators and prosecutors more leeway against internal terrorists like the Red Army Faction. Yet it was not until 1998, for example, that the constitution was changed to allow wiretapping of private dwellings, which had been forbidden -- except under extraordinary circumstances -- under an article guaranteeing the inviolability of the home.
Until very recently, the government had also been hampered by traditional, post-Nazi restrictions on the exchange of information between domestic and foreign intelligence agencies, and between them and the local police, a senior German intelligence official said. All this is now being re-examined and adjusted, he said, along with some of the strict privacy protections on telephone and financial records.
The Bush administration is now proposing new legislation intended to make it difficult for terrorists to hide in the United States. Whether any such measures would have enabled authorities to detect the cell in Hamburg is not clear.
"In the last 10 years, we were too lax about the peace dividend," said Margarita Mathiopoulos, a defense and security analyst with the European Advisory Group. "The clue to these terrorists is that they behave normally and integrate into society. They managed well here, and I suspect they managed well in Paris and London."
Until now, if German security services learned something abroad, for instance, about support inside Germany for Basque or Mideast terrorists, they could not pass that information along to German prosecutors or internal intelligence agencies.
Terrorism itself was defined strictly as relating only to attacks on Germany. Much of German intelligence was devoted to that internal terrorism, to the cold war, and to the threat of neo-Nazis and other domestic extremists. The absence of major incidents attributed to German-based Muslim extremists -- a 1986 Berlin disco bombing that killed two American servicemen and one other person was attributed to agents from Libya -- also meant there was little history of Muslim extremism.
France, by contrast, with a population of five million Muslims, mostly from Francophone northern Africa, cracked down hard on terrorism in the mid-1990's following a series of lethal bombings. As a strong, centralized state, France had few legal impediments to such action.
Intelligence and legal officials from both France and Germany say that crackdown led the police to some extremists, while apparently dispersing others to Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany.
While Germany has profound policy and emotional ties to Israel, German officials say strong business and foreign policy ties to Iran, Iraq, Libya and other Muslim states created a historic disincentive among the intelligence services to make too many waves. "Sometimes the police here behave too much like the American Civil Liberties Union," one Western diplomat said. "And the secret services behave too much like the A.C.L.U. as well."
Mr. Hafez notes another connection. "Many Arabs feel close to Germany because of its history of partition, unification and external intervention, which they see as analogous to their own experiences," he said. 
Karsten Voigt, head of trans-Atlantic cooperation at the Foreign Ministry, points outs that Germany is a highly multiethnic country, where Muslims "can simply hide more easily than in New York." 
He also noted Germany's efforts, now being rapidly modified, to protect privacy and religious belief, even if religion is used to advocate hatred or raise money for terrorism. "The Turks tell us we are much too liberal," Mr. Voigt said. "The legal system protected you if you propagated hate crimes in the context of religion. Now that is changing."

HEADLINE: U.S. Agency Predicts Drop in Cost of Gasoline and Heating Fuel 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
The cost of gasoline, heating fuel and electricity are expected to be much lower this winter than last, the government said today.
 A report by the Energy Information Administration, the analysis arm of the Energy Department, said that prices had been declining and should continue to do so in the coming months. The reasons are adequate inventories and a declining demand for energy because of the poor economy, the agency said. 
 The most striking turnaround has been in the prices of natural gas, which heats more than 56 million homes.
A typical household using natural gas is expected to spend about a third less this winter for heating, a savings of about $320 over last winter, the agency said. 
Homeowners using heating oil and propane will most likely have their fuel costs drop 17 percent to 23 percent, a savings of at least $170.
Despite the lower energy prices, state officials and private groups helping the poor say that for low-income families, fuel costs could still bring tough times. Many of them have not recovered from the financial setbacks brought on by the high energy prices of last winter.
Industrial demand for natural gas fell by 18 percent over the first half of the year and is expected to continue falling because of the declining economy, the report said.
Gasoline prices, which normally decline in the winter, were projected to decline on a national average to below $1.35 a gallon by the end of the year. The price could be lower in some states with low fuel taxes.
The average price of regular gasoline nationwide was $1.41 a gallon this week, down about 11 cents a gallon from the same time a year ago, the Energy Information Administration said. That drop has occurred in the three weeks since the terrorist attacks, the administration's report said.
The lower energy prices across the board reflect largely the drop in crude oil prices combined with an expectation that the poor economy will lead to a further decline in demand this winter.
The spot price for light sweet crude on Thursday was $22.27 in New York with the price for delivery in December only 17 cents higher. Crude oil prices were $31 a barrel earlier this year.
With fuel prices dropping, the Bush administration gave a lukewarm reception to a suggestion by a Congressional panel that it pump more oil into the government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
With little debate and no opposition, a House subcommittee approved a resolution formally urging that the emergency stockpile be expanded to its full capacity of one billion barrels.
The reserve holds about 545 million barrels in salt caverns on the Gulf Coast along the Louisiana-Texas border. The United States uses about 19 million barrels of oil a day, about 10 million barrels of which are imported.
The resolution is expected to be taken up by the full House, possibly next week. 
The Energy Department had little to say about the proposal, releasing aone-sentence statement that said, "The secretary appreciates Congress' interests in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which is an integral part of our national energy security."
While not ruling out some modest increase in the reserve, administration officials are concerned any large purchase of oil could drive up prices even before the contracts go out. A jump in crude prices could quickly add to the economic downturn.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REAL ESTATE; 
Trade Center Leaseholder Pledges to Rebuild

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
The schedule for a Nov. 11 lecture at the Real Estate Institute of New York University called for its moderator, Larry A. Silverstein, to relive his triumph in acquiring a 99-year lease on the World Trade Center, a feat he accomplished in July. Last week, Mr. Silverstein, a real estate developer, decided not to cancel the lecture. Instead, he altered the pamphlet to read, "The World Trade Center: What Is to Come," and did not include a question mark.
 Less than a month after the famed twin towers fell to dust, Mr. Silverstein is making plans and hiring architects to rebuild the center. 
 "I am obligated by my lease to pay rent for 99 years, I am obligated to rebuild, and I have the money to rebuild," he explained, referring in an interview to his expectation that insurance companies would pay him more than enough money to build what he vowed would be "world class quality" office buildings. "It seems to me I am going to end up rebuilding; the only question is how best to accomplish that," he said. 
That sunny confidence, arching over the gulch of questions and concerns confronting survivors, financiers, lawyers, engineers and city, state and federal officials, works as a tonic for many who fear that the financial district may never recover. But Mr. Silverstein's pledge -- he said he wanted to erect an "appropriate" memorial to the 6,000 victims and resurrect ten million square feet of lost office space -- also serves as a way for him to stake his claim early in a shifting landscape of loss, economic uncertainty, competition and clashing political interests. 
Mary Ann Tighe, vice-chairwoman of the real estate brokerage firm Insignia/ESG Inc. and a longtime friend of Mr. Silverstein's, described him as an "extraordinary combination of optimism and total shrewdness." He was not among the leading candidates to acquire the trade center until very late, when Vornado, a larger firm that bid higher, pulled out, making room for Mr. Silverstein to achieve his "crowning glory" and win a niche in the chronicles of New York real estate. Its destruction made him a sad footnote in the nation's history. 
But at 70, Mr. Silverstein wants to play a leading role in the city's future. "I simply decided to dedicate the next five years of my life to this," he said. He added a cautionary message to local and national officials, many of whom have already hinted that the reconstruction effort needed in downtown Manhattan is far too vast and complex for any one developer: "Given good health and cooperation from the federal and city government, the governors of New Jersey, New York, the Port Authority, we're going to rebuild this thing." 
Observing him as he lays the groundwork for what he described as a patriotic mission is a little like staring at an Escher print; in one blink, his persona is suffused in optimism, in another, shrewdness dominates. Some in government, troubled by his haste, see mainly the latter. "It is still early to talk about this in terms of real estate," one city official said. "Larry needs to be careful not to slide from civic pride to crass personal interests." 
Mr. Silverstein has attended memorial services and fund-raisers, and he has also met with his lawyers, advisers and government officials. Last week, he hired the prominent architect David Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. New York officials went to Washington to meet with the New York congressional delegation to press for more federal aid. So did Mr. Silverstein, in meetings yesterday with Representative Charles B. Rangel and others. Mr. Silverstein sought federal guarantees for construction loans and protection from lawsuits brought by the victims or their families, according to a government aide who attended the meeting. 
Mr. Silverstein, who resembles a thin Arthur Godfrey, has a bouncy, avuncular manner in person that barely slows when he talks about the attack. He lost four employees and many friends and colleagues, and he steers the conversation away from death, lifting his arm at one point to ward off memories like bats. Instead, he focused on the few bright spots, speaking, for example, of watching rescuers go down into the tunnels below the twin towers and 7 World Trade Center, which he built and which was also destroyed. "They were taking one hell of a risk, if you'll excuse my language," he said. "It is so staggering to see how Americans will help each other in a time of crisis." 
The developer first heard about the news when his associate, Geoffrey P. Wharton, called him on his cellphone from the site, saying "something really bad is happening." Mr. Wharton had just reached the lobby from a breakfast meeting at Windows on the World when the plane hit the tower. Badly shaken, Mr. Wharton rode a squad car back to the company's headquarters on Fifth Avenue and 43rd Street, reaching it in time to watch on television alongside the proud new leaseholder as the two towers collapsed. 
"He was shocked, like everybody, but this was so personal, it just knocked the wind out of him," said Lisa Silverstein, the developer's daughter and a vice president in the company.
She said that he rallied quickly, but that something had changed. "This took a toll mentally and physically," she said. "He is still off-kilter. He usually bounces through the door like Tigger, then whoosh. And it was gone." 
Born in Washington Heights, Mr. Silverstein learned the real estate business working for his father Harry, a smalltime broker, while attending Brooklyn Law School at night. He started his own business in the 1950's, and rose to prominence and real wealth in the early 80's, buying a yacht, chairing the real estate board, and creating the real estate institute at N.Y.U.
In 1981, his optimism reached a peak: he began building 7 World Trade Center before signing up a single tenant. The much-celebrated agreement by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to rent space in the tower fell apart at the last minute when the Ivan Boesky scandal erupted. Mr. Silverstein eventually found another brokerage firm, Salomon Brothers, to lease the space, but lost profit when he had to refit the space to accommodate the new tenants. 
By 1998, he was buying major buildings again, and also preparing his move on the World Trade Center. He seems anxious to soothe the sensitivities of the Port Authority, which lost dozens of employees, including its executive director, Neil Levin. 
"In no way is this a unilateral act," he said, saying he would seek cooperation of all agencies and authorities involved. 
Mr. Silverstein said that he was entitled to $3.6 billion in insurance to cover the losses in each terrorist attack, and that since there were two, he was counting on $7.2 billion. He acknowledged that the insurance companies disagreed with his theory, but added, "they are showing every sign of acting like statesmen." 
P.J. Crowley, vice president of the Insurance Information Institute, an industry education group, said: "The issues are extraordinarily complex in this unprecedented event. This is a matter that will take months, if not years, to work through."
Mr. Silverstein prefers to cast the catastrophe as a low moment in a continuous cycle. "I've been through tough times in the 1960's, and in the 70's and the 1990's, and here we are in 2001," he said. "We can get through this too."

HEADLINE: Trade-Off by Environmentalists on Rebuilding; 
Looser Rules for Manhattan Are Backed to Avoid a Bigger Threat: Sprawl

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Corporate leaders and politicians who argue that New York City must rebuild Lower Manhattan as quickly as possible -- even if it means sidestepping or streamlining some environmental protection rules -- are getting support for their position from what might seem an unlikely quarter: environmentalists.
 Leaders at some major environmental groups in the region said that a rapid rebuilding in Manhattan had become a paramount objective for them partly out of concern for the city's long-term economic health and also because the alternative could have grim implications for the region: a wave of sprawled office development from New Jersey to Long Island as displaced corporations build permanent new space in the suburbs. 
 If that happened, the environmentalists said, the overall environment in the nation's most densely congested urban corridor could sharply deteriorate in the decades to come, with worsened air quality because of increased dependence on automobile travel, longer trips to work and a loss of open space.
"The No. 1 environmental concern is that the center holds -- all flows from that," said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a Manhattan-based conservation group. "If the question is spreading out or retaining a central core for the region, the environmental community can be expected to come down in favor of a strong central city." 
Already, three weeks after the attacks, dozens of displaced companies have made long-term plans to relocate outside Lower Manhattan -- especially to Midtown and New Jersey.
Mr. Goldstein and other environmental leaders say that while hardly anyone suggests giving up all environmental oversight on downtown development, the point seems almost universally shared that rebuilding the World Trade Center site will require finding a new balance between the old black-or-white advocacy for the environment and the broader needs of a city and region that has been thrown into deep stress by the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.
If there were no concerns about a sudden surge in suburban development, the environmentalists said, lawyers and community leaders would already be focusing on the plans for downtown, poring over the fine print about things like building heights and the resulting blockage of sunlight to nearby areas.
They would be urging studies on the air pollution impact of truck and vehicle traffic involved in the removal of debris and the construction of new offices. They would want input on the proposed mix of residential and commercial tenants in any new vision of downtown and on the question of open space and public access. Lawsuits, investigative exposes and public hearings -- the tools of the environmental trade -- would be at the ready or already deployed.
But the disaster at the World Trade Center created a new measure of environmental impact -- no longer confined to just one neighborhood or even one city. The wave of disruption and loss that rippled out when the towers fell -- thousands of lives lost and 15 million square feet of office space destroyed or made unusable -- affected families and businesses, as well as patterns of life, travel, work and play in the city and across the region.
So, too, environmentalists say, will the rebuilding -- and the missteps that could result from delay or errors in judgment -- affect the entire region. Looking at the fine print is no longer enough.
"Our greatest fear is that people will use this as an excuse to pave over more of the natural world," said Jeff Jones, the communications director for Environmental Advocates, an Albany-based conservation group. 
Mr. Jones said his organization and many other smaller ones it worked with would support a streamlined approvals process in Lower Manhattan to protect places like the Meadowlands in northern New Jersey from development. But he said that many groups would also likely seek assurances in return that plans for downtown would include elements of so-called green-building design, like energy-saving technologies and construction techniques.
How the new trade-offs in the region might work as the cleanup and rebuilding move forward is a question that is also being examined closely by urban planners and economists, some of whom have likened the New York metropolitan area to a giant puzzle that has been shaken apart and will now be put back together with new rules.
Sam Staley, director the urban futures program at Reason Public Policy Institute, a nonprofit market-oriented research group based in Los Angeles, said that decentralization out of Manhattan's financial district was a trend long before the terrorist attacks and that an intensification of that trajectory was inevitable now. He said it would be driven by reasons of economics and security.
Some experts like Mr. Goldstein say that troubles around the New York region in recent days -- nightmarish traffic congestion from heightened security measures and altered commuter flow as workers fight their way to temporary offices -- might be glimpses of the future if the wrong choices about rebuilding are made in the months to come.
How exactly the New York region's future will unfold, of course, is a great unknown, in part because no map exists for how to navigate it.
Should money be poured into mass transit improvements for getting people into New York City from the suburbs of Long Island and New Jersey on the assumption that more people will abandon their cars and take the train to avoid traffic nightmares and security checks?
Or would the money be better spent on the assumption that some degree of suburban development will take place? The money could then be concentrated on figuring out how to move people efficiently over what might be new emerging commuter routes.
Some environmental and transportation groups say that, as the city and region struggle through this crisis, some positive psychological hurdles could be cleared that might make for a cleaner city and surrounding areas.
For instance, Transportation Alternatives, a nonprofit group based in Manhattan that advocates environmentally friendly transportation like biking and mass transit, lauded Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's order last week restricting single-occupant cars from entering Manhattan at certain hours of the day.
The group also urged putting tolls on the bridges across the East River and raising the gasoline tax by 20 cents a gallon, with the money devoted to mass-transit improvements.
Other environmental leaders say what unfolds will depend in part on how much the public is included in the decision-making for the redevelopment. If the process feels open and inclusive, said Ned Sullivan, the executive director of Scenic Hudson, an environmental group based in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., the spirit could continue.
"But if they try to shut people out of the process, on the theory that we have to make this happen quickly," he said, "that will result in delays down the road."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
N.F.L. Made Wrong Move On Big Game

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON

 BODY:
A FRIEND from Connecticut called from the Upper East Side of Manhattan the other day. She and her husband were in need of a hotel room and did we know of a good one, not too pricey? Within minutes, my wife was online and locating one that rated four stars, five blocks from where our friends were calling, for $99 a night.
 I couldn't believe the rate and others available elsewhere, but it made sense, given the traumatized state of the New York economy. It also made me think: If we could find such a deal within five minutes, how well might the National Football League with a lead time of four months? 
 The New York hotel occupancy rate typically drops to about 55 to 60 percent in January and February from 85 percent in December, according to Cristyne L. Nicholas of NYC & Company, the city's tourism marketing organization. Under the current circumstances, Nicholas said, "We could have handled the Super Bowl pretty easily."
Nicholas, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's former press secretary, attended her first Super Bowl last winter in Tampa, Fla. "It opened my eyes to what this is," she said. "Two weeks of spending, investing in that city. I told my staff it would be wonderful if we could get this game."
She meant any year and especially this year, though just four days after the N.F.L. disclosed that New York was under consideration for a location switch, it announced Wednesday that the Super Bowl would remain in New Orleans, moved back a week to Feb. 3.
It was a wonderful proposal last week by Senator Charles E. Schumer, who said that a New York Super Bowl would be a "symbol of triumph over terrorism." If that sounded like one of my deadline cliches, so be it. Unlike the distant 2012 Olympics, the Super Bowl and all its consumer trimmings would have been a short-term boost to the economy, a way for the N.F.L. to demonstrate that charity can be much more than writing a check and that it does begin at home.
The league, after all, has its headquarters on Park Avenue, a cab ride from ground zero. Its employees were presumably like all other residents and commuters on Sept. 11, in dual states of shock and outrage over the permanent scarring of the New York City psyche and skyline. You can't convince me that the overwhelming majority of N.F.L. people would not have happily sacrificed a run to Bourbon Street for the privilege of bringing the game to Giants Stadium and its itinerant events into Midtown.
Just the other day, the city announced that Delta Airlines, in conjunction with several hotels, was offering bargain packages in an effort to jump-start local tourism. The American Society of Travel Agents switched its November convention from Seville, Spain, to New York. The Audio Engineering Society said it would bring as many as 20,000 members to the city Nov. 30 to Dec. 3 for a convention.
Nicholas said NYC & Company never heard from the N.F.L. By dropping New York into the Super Bowl mix on Sunday, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue was probably paying lip service in deference to Schumer or, much worse, using a disaster site as a bargaining chip in an effort to get New Orleans officials to help facilitate a deal. Coincidentally or not, the pieces soon fell into place, as the National Association of Automobile Dealers accepted a $7.5 million payoff from the N.F.L. to alter its own convention plans.
"Our fans and teams can look forward to a full complement of playoffs and to a great Super Bowl weekend in New Orleans," Tagliabue said. Normalcy was achieved and it would be, after a little arm-twisting and pocket-stuffing, Super Bowl business as usual. America's catered-to-the-wealthy, made-for-TV extravaganza was preserved. We may all look forward to the patriotic pageantry of a climate-controlled halftime show.
Giants Stadium is not weatherproof like the Superdome, one of the truly charmless American sports edifices, but football is generally played without the promise of temperate comfort and many of the sport's epic games have pitted man against the elements. With regard to annual Super Bowl locales, this argument is old and not winnable. Yet for this one occasion, it was worth making.
The game could have been made available to many of the suffering New York City firefighters and cops, who fill the bars and boost the ratings and fit Tagliabue's profile of "our fans" more than the majority of any Super Bowl crowd. Tagliabue said New York presented "security and logistical problems," and proceeded to place the game into the madness of Mardis Gras. He had an opportunity to do something bold and beautiful, and he blew it.

HEADLINE: Bank of England Makes Cut Of Quarter-Point in Key Rate 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
The Bank of England cut its benchmark lending rate by a quarter of a point today, to 4.5 percent, saying that it was worried that the terrorist attacks in the United States would send ripples through the British economy in the form of reduced spending and consumer confidence.
 With the reduction, the sixth this year, British interest rates are now at the lowest they have been since January 1964. The move comes a day after the United States Federal reserve trimmed interest rates by half a percentage point. The European Central Bank, which meets next Thursday, is also expected to reduce rates, economists said. 
 "It's all part of a concerted effort to pump liquidity into the financial system," after the Sept. 11 attacks, said David Donnelly, who runs Gordon House Asset Management, a hedge fund in London.
Investors welcomed the decision, which was expected. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares rose 2.75 percent to 5,016.20 -- its first close above 5,000 since Sept. 10.
Recently released economic data show the world economy was slumping even more than some economists and central bankers had thought, a wrinkle that entered into the monetary policy committee's decision to cut rates today.
"It now appears that, even before the terrorist attacks, the prospects for global activity were somewhat weaker than projected," the bank said in a statement. "The weaker world outlook and increased uncertainty have set back U.K. business and consumer confidence, and may, for a time, restrain business and household spending."
Economists say they expect Britain to fare better than the economies of the United States and the rest of Europe, pointing to recently revised data that show strong domestic demand. British consumers earned and saved more than economists originally predicted in the first half of the year; the unemployment rate continues to fall, and the housing market remains robust. Consumer confidence, while it has fallen from its highs of July, has dropped less sharply than the confidence of American consumers.
"The effects of the terrorist attacks so far seem to have been felt a little less strongly in the U.K. than in the U.S. or in Europe," said Robert Jukes, an economist with Credit Suisse First Boston.
In part, that is because Britain has coupled prompt interest rate reductions with increased tax cuts and public spending packages, providing a broad stimulus for domestic demand, said Michael Saunders, an economist with Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.
The manufacturing sector is technically in a recession, having contracted for two consecutive quarters, but it accounts for only a fifth of the gross domestic product. Services make up the balance and they have been growing, economists said.
But the British economy has also rising inflation. That could hinder further interest rate reductions, economists said.
"We are nearing the end of the rate cut cycle," Mr. Saunders said, although he held out the possibility of further reductions if the world economy continues to weaken.

HEADLINE: Bucking Government Bailouts 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
As governments across Europe rush to deliver emergency aid to an aviation industry on its knees, one airline's chief executive is shouting "Not so fast!" as loudly as he can.
 Michael O'Leary is every inch a maverick, sporting blue jeans and an open-neck designer shirt in his Dublin office and quaffing coffee from foam company-canteen cups during a recent interview that he peppered with earthy language. And in these days of economic retreat after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, he smells opportunity for his company, Ryanair, Europe's biggest low-cost, no-frills airline. 
 Like its model, Southwest Airlines of Texas, Ryanair has thrived by cutting both fares and operating costs to the bone. Beyond dispensing with free peanuts and giveaway magazines, Ryanair says it will not even absorb some airport charges for disabled people needing assistance to reach its planes, as other carriers usually do. 
That approach may not foster a warm and fuzzy public image, but it has done the airline's performance no harm. Ryanair posted sharply higher profits for the fiscal year ended in March. And as the economic slowdown became apparent over the summer and full-service competitors like British Airways began laying off workers, Ryanair and other discount carriers continued to report growth.
Ryanair's stock is counted among the hottest on the Dublin stock exchange, and its total market capitalization recently overtook that of British Airways.
The deep slump in passenger traffic after Sept. 11 turned the cracks in the market into yawning chasms that threatened to swallow up full-service "flag carriers" in many nations. Swissair and Sabena fell into different forms of bankruptcy protection this week, and the Swiss and Belgian governments bailed them out with emergency loans. Other carriers further from the brink got loan guarantees or help with insurance and security costs from governments.
All of which has Ryanair spitting mad. As Mr. O'Leary sees it, the full-fare carriers' troubles vindicate his business model. Breaking ranks with the rest of the airline industry, Ryanair has urged European Union officials repeatedly to block state subsidies to airlines, however financially troubled they may be. And today, Ryanair said it would challenge the Belgian government's aid to Sabena in court.
"We should complain, because I don't see why we should be forced to compete with someone who is getting subsidies," Mr. O'Leary said today at a news conference in Brussels.
The strains in airlines like British Airways and Swissair, which responded to slowing traffic by concentrating on premium-fare customers, were apparent before Sept. 11. "You are seeing people trading down from business class to economy and from full-service airlines to low-cost airlines," said Jonathan Wober, transportation analyst at Deutsche Bank in London. If the United States is any guide, analysts said, the bottom of the market, where Ryanair and EasyJet compete simply to pack planes at low cost, is where the growth is. 
Nowhere is the scramble for business more evident than on routes between Ireland and Scotland. When Go, a low-cost carrier that British Airways sold last June, announced plans for flights between Dublin, Ryanair's home base, and Scotland, Ryanair began a price war, and one-way tickets can now be had for as little as $14, including airport taxes.
"This is a skirmish on one of our 55 routes," Mr. O'Leary said dismissively. "Does it mean Go will pull out? No. But it'll mean they lose money every time they fly." Ryanair is counting on its greater financial reserves to help it outlast Go on the route.
Such battles break out because, as low-cost airlines look to what they all assume will be a growth market, "there's a bit of a race to gain critical mass," he said.
Mr. O'Leary, 41, has been running Ryanair for more than 10 years, casting himself as the iconoclastic underdog tilting at the stodgy formerly state-owned flag carriers. In some ways, history and technology are on his side.
The end of the cold war freed up former military bases for use by commercial carriers, like Frankfurt-Hahn in Germany, which is now used by Ryanair. The Internet offered low-cost airlines a cheap way to book passengers that bypasses travel agents and even call centers. Ryanair says it now takes 75 percent of its bookings on line; for Easyjet, the figure is 90 percent.
And, most of all, deregulation of European Union skies in 1997 opened up a virtually limitless prospect of flights, especially to provincial airports hungry for connections as prosperity spread to regional cities across Europe. Competing in the low-cost market with Ryanair, EasyJet and Go are two more carriers -- Buzz, a KLM Royal Dutch Airlines subsidiary, and the Brussels-based Virgin Express of Richard Branson-- but most analysts reckon the real fight is between the top two, Ryanair and Easyjet.
Ryanair has its own particularly defiant overlay, insisting on a pugnacious, underdog image even as it dominates the low-cost market. Its advertizing is so provocative that it has raised hackles. One ad depicting Pope John Paul II incensed some Catholics. An ad promoting new flights to an airport near Brussels used a famous Belgian statue of a small boy urinating to suggest that passengers might be fed up with Sabena's high fares; Sabena sued.
Because Ryanair flies to secondary airports to save costs, questions have been raised about how it advertises its destinations. Its flights to "Paris" land at Beauvais, 45 miles north of the French capital. Ryanair's "Brussels South" is Charleroi, 35 miles away. Frankfurt-Hahn is 50 miles from Frankfurt.
So what, Mr. O'Leary says. "It's not as if J.F.K. was in Central Park or Heathrow was in Pall Mall," he said. At the secondary airports, he added, lines are shorter, delays are much rarer and planes can be turned around faster -- so Ryanair can offer more frequent and convenient service as well as lower fares.
Choice of airports is one of the main differences between Ryanair and Easyjet, which flies into more expensive airports like Geneva and London Gatwick. And it is another example of Mr. O'Leary's penchant for casting aside industry wisdom. 
"I don't give a toss where people want to go," he said in the interview. "I'm in the business of creating a market for people to go where they never have heard of. What we do is stimulate huge demand, and then capture it."
At his Brussels news conference today, Mr. O'Leary said Ryanair was still on track to increase its net income by 26 percent this year, to $121 million, despite the fallout from the terror attacks of Sept. 11.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: AIRLINES (92%); AEROSPACE SECTOR PERFORMANCE (90%); BAILOUTS (90%); AVIATION SECTOR PERFORMANCE (90%); GOVERNMENT GRANTS & SUBSIDIES (78%); AIRPORTS (78%); TRANSPORTATION SECTOR PERFORMANCE (78%); BUSINESS FINANCIAL TROUBLE (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%); AIRLINES PASSENGER TRAFFIC (78%); SEPTEMBER 11 ATTACK (75%); ECONOMIC DECLINE (75%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (75%); EXECUTIVES (73%); EUROPEAN UNION (73%); INDUSTRY ANALYSTS (72%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (72%); COMPANY PROFITS (72%); STOCK EXCHANGES (70%); INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY (70%); TERRORISM (70%); AIRPORT OPERATION (69%); ECONOMIC NEWS (66%); MARKET CAPITALIZATION (65%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (55%) AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; FINANCES; PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES); COMPANY AND ORGANIZATION PROFILES

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
The Microsoft Conundrum

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly invoked both national purpose and practical reason last Friday as she ordered the two sides in the Microsoft antitrust case to return to the negotiating table one last time. The "recent tragic events," she said, lent an added urgency to resolving the issue, given its importance to the national economy. A settlement can surely be reached "if everybody is reasonable" and "acts in good faith," the judge declared.
 Those are fine sentiments, but the two sides still see the case so differently. Judge Kollar-Kotelly, of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, acknowledged that problem when she thanked Microsoft and the Justice Department, joined by 18 states, for cooperating to file a joint status report. "You didn't agree on a lot," she said, "but it was joint." 
 Negotiations started this week in Washington, under a deadline of Nov. 2. But the obstacles to a settlement loom large, and both sides have reasons to resist.
Although the Justice Department announced last month that it would no longer seek a breakup of Microsoft or pursue the claim that the company's bundling of its Internet browser with its Windows operating system was illegal, it is seeking restrictions that Microsoft has refused to accept in the past.
The Justice Department has said that it will pursue conduct restrictions based on the Federal District Court's order last year. Among other things, that decision ordered Microsoft to openly share technical information about Windows with other software companies; to offer personal computer makers the option of unbundled versions of Windows, without an Internet browser or other add-ons; and to sell Windows to all PC makers at the same price, though it could offer volume discounts.
The forced disclosure of technical information and the requirement for an unbundled version of Windows, with a slimmer price tag, are the two things Microsoft has most strenuously opposed. "That's where the action is here," said a former government official who was involved in the three previous rounds of settlement talks.
Microsoft is still resisting. In court last Friday, Dan Webb, a Microsoft trial lawyer, complained to Judge Kollar-Kotelly about the provision on sharing of information. That sanction, Mr. Webb said, would "require Microsoft to literally turn over its intellectual property" and would be "devastating to Microsoft."
The legal road map for remedies in the case -- through settlement or court hearings -- is the most recent ruling, the appeals court decision of June 28. But the two sides have very different interpretations of the implications of that ruling, which found that Microsoft was a monopolist that repeatedly violated antitrust laws.
The appeals court decision also scaled back parts of the District Court's legal findings against Microsoft and strongly suggested that the company should not be split in two, as the lower court had ordered.
Though dropping the effort to break up Microsoft, Charles A. James, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said he would still seek other remedies, modeled after the restrictions on the company's behavior included in the district court's order of June 2000 -- intended, at the time, as interim steps until a breakup was complete.
The Justice Department presented the move as a pragmatic response to the appeals court decision, a prudent tactical retreat. But by declaring that it would seek sanctions fashioned after the conduct remedies in the June 2000 order, the department seemed to signal that it still wanted to place some tough restrictions on Microsoft's corporate behavior.
Judge Kollar-Kotelly suggested that the government would have to determine what sanctions in the June 2000 judgment to pursue and "which portions are unsupported following the appellate court's narrowing of liability." 
The Microsoft camp reads the appeals court ruling fairly narrowly. George L. Priest, a Yale law professor and a consultant to Microsoft who is not involved in the settlement talks, said: "I don't think information disclosure should be on the table, and since the government has dropped the tying claim, what you have left is mostly getting rid of some of Microsoft's contract restrictions with PC manufacturers."
The federal government and the states read the appeals court ruling, and its implications, quite differently. The bundling, or tying, issue illustrates the point. In its ruling, the appeals court handled the subject delicately. The judiciary, it said, should generally not be meddling in product-design decisions, and it noted the often significant gains in efficiency and convenience from integrating products.
But in the monopoly maintenance section of its ruling, the appeals court found that two aspects of Microsoft integration of its browser into Windows did violate the law. At one point in the ruling, the court stated, "Obviously, we do not find that Microsoft's integration is welfare-enhancing or that it should be absolved of tying liability."
The court essentially said that adding features to a monopoly product, like Windows, was not illegal on its face. But the way it is done -- the intent of the bundling decision and its effect on competition -- can make it an antitrust problem. Microsoft did not get a free pass on tying from the court, and it is certain to be an issue in the settlement talks.
"Bundling is going to be the sticking point," said David Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "What's in and what's out. That's been the big issue going back to 1995."
With Windows XP, the new operating system that goes on sale later this month, Microsoft is aggressively pursuing its bundling strategy. The new system tightly integrates software for online shopping, playing music and video distributed over the Internet, personal identification and digital photography.
Microsoft has been investigated by the government for more than a decade. And it was sued in the landmark antitrust case. Yet its business practices, it seems, have changed little, if at all. Critics question whether the company has any incentive to settle now instead of letting further hearings and appeals run their course.
"Microsoft has lost the legal battles, but it is winning the war of attrition in the industry, stifling competition," said Ken Wasch, president of the Software and Information Industry, a trade group.
The incentives for the government to settle are not necessarily clear, either. Mr. James, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, inherited a suit that the previous administration had won. If he appears to give up too much in a settlement, he will be accused of caving in to Microsoft.
"The safe course for James is to just let the court figure out the remedy," said Stephen Houck, the former lead counsel for the state of New York in the case.
Another consideration in the settlement equation is how the political atmosphere might be changed as a result of the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. "I would think the heat is very much off James now," said Mr. Priest of the Yale law school. "Microsoft is no longer the hot issue it was. The Justice Department has more important things to deal with."
