HEADLINE: Big Loss at Nissan Seems to Undercut U.A.W. Objectives 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
The United Auto Workers thought that the Nissan workers in Smyrna, Tenn., would be the ones to finally unionize a foreign automaker's plant and provide a crucial first step in turning the U.A.W.'s fortunes around.
 Instead, the union was dealt a bitter defeat on Wednesday in a battle it had expected to win, or at least closely contest. The margin of defeat has surprised the auto industry and labor unions alike. Nissan employees rejected U.A.W. representation by a 2-to-1 vote, no better than in the union's failed attempt to organize the same plant in 1989. 
 "I thought it was going to be a lot closer," said Bob King, the U.A.W. vice president for organizing and the leader of the Smyrna campaign.
The defeat makes it less likely that the U.A.W. can resolve one of its greatest challenges before its president, Stephen P. Yokich, retires next year. Foreign automakers are the growth industry within the American automotive business, and without recruiting any of their workers, the U.A.W.'s rolls, concentrated at General Motors, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Group, are expected to continue to shrink. 
The union has never been able to organize a plant operated solely by a foreign automaker, though it has organized joint ventures. It was unsuccessful last year in an attempt to organize a Mercedes factory in Alabama, even though Mercedes and Chrysler are now both units of DaimlerChrysler of Germany.
While the presence of companies like Toyota and Honda has spread in the United States, the Big Three have cut jobs as business declined. As a result, U.A.W. membership fell to about 700,000 last year from a peak of 1.5 million some two decades ago. 
"It's a big defeat," said Sean P. McAlinden, director of the economics and business group at the Center for Automotive Research, an independent research firm in Ann Arbor, Mich. Mr. McAlinden consulted for the U.A.W. on the Smyrna vote. 
"It's bad for the union for two reasons," he said. "The only growth area in the auto industry in the United States in the next two to four years is the international sector. The second reason is that Nissan didn't make any significant economic promises to fend the union off, and the union still won." 
Part of the problem, Mr. King of the U.A.W. said, was that the union tried a new approach this time, after its failed vote more than a decade ago and attempts it abandoned in 1997 and 2000. Usually, the U.A.W. tries to recruit supportive workers on every work line and shift to campaign among fellow employees. This time, it used less inside support and relied more on phone banks, home visits and an Internet campaign. 
Mr. King said it was very difficult to compete when employers had a captive audience they can put pressure on at the workplace as well as obliquely threaten to move work overseas. But he said he would not repeat his new methods again. "It's my loss," Mr. King said. "I take responsibility for it."
Steve Babson, the labor program specialist at Wayne State University in Detroit, said a combination of factors was working against the U.A.W. in Smyrna. "It's a Southern environment with less of a union culture," he said. "It's a growing company that can promise opportunities for advancement. There's the carrot."
"The stick," he said, included "threats of disinvestments, threats articulated in one-on-one meetings and punitive disincentives for supporting the union."
But the U.A.W. also has lessons to learn, he said. "It appears the union presence inside the plant was not what you'd want to see."
The defeat means that Detroit's Big Three will remain at a competitive disadvantage because of the better benefits and more complicated workplace rules in place for the unionized work forces there. The U.A.W. lays out on its Web site the thousands of dollars in differences between the annual pension benefits its workers and Nissan workers stand to make.
An even bigger problem for the Big Three has been the greater number of retirees they support compared with the newer American units of foreign automakers. And there is still the Big Three's challenge of making cars that more Americans want to buy. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The U.A.W.'s vice president for organizing, Bob King, in Smyrna, Tenn., on Wednesday after the effort to represent Nissan workers failed. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Technology Shares Gain as the Broader Market Retreats

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY

 BODY:
Technology stocks rose for the third consecutive session yesterday after Dell Computer issued a reassuring earnings outlook, but they closed well off their highs.
 The broader market, meanwhile, retreated from its early gains and ended with some losses. 
 "It's the tug of war here between the market seemingly oversold on the short run and the cloudy outlook on the economic front," said John Forelli, senior vice president and portfolio manager at Independence Investment L.L.C. "Investors just have to be cautious. They're going to like companies reaffirming guidance in this environment, but at the same time they'll have to realize that there's still no earnings growth in the market." 
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained 16.50 points, or 1 percent, to 1,597.31. The Nasdaq surged nearly 6 percent on Wednesday.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 62.90 points, or 0.7 percent, to 9,060.88. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.65 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,069.63.
Dell rose $1.68, to $22.32, after it said it expected to meet its previously announced earnings and sales forecasts for the third quarter. Company officials said the company's financial and strategic position was "better than ever" despite the weak economic environment.
Dell's announcement was similar to one made by Cisco Systems on Wednesday, and it offered Wall Street a bit of hope for the economy, which has deteriorated since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.
"It's hard to envision a situation where PC demand is weak and Dell does well," said David G. Dietze, president and chief investment officer at Point View Financial Services. "Investors are going to bet that if this is the largest PC maker by market share, that probably says something about the health of the sector. There's a whole other series of companies that are probably going to experience good results."
Other computer makers drew strength from Dell. Compaq Computer was up 20 cents, to $8.85, and Gateway rose 15 cents, to $4.85. After the market closed, Gateway said that it would post a wider-than-anticipated third-quarter loss but that it expected to return to profitability in the fourth quarter.
Software makers moved higher as well. PeopleSoft rose $1.47, to $25.15; Veritas climbed $1.12, to $24.61; and Siebel Systems advanced $1.20, to $18.81.
Semiconductor stocks also posted gains. Intel rose 32 cents, to $21.55; Linear Technology increased $2.76, to $36.83; and Advanced Micro Devices rose 54 cents, to $9. 
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor stock index rose 16.73 points, or 4.3 percent, to 405.54.
Shares of network equipment makers continued to rise one day after Cisco Systems said it was comfortable with analysts' estimates for its earnings and sales. Cisco rose 47 cents, to $14.42, while Tellabs rose 91 cents, to $11.42. 
Juniper Networks jumped $1.27, to $13.27, after analysts from Merrill Lynch upgraded the company to "outperform" from "neutral."
Despite the gains in technology stocks, analysts warned investors not to expect an extended rally. Even upbeat reports from bellwethers like Dell and Cisco should be viewed in context, they said.
"It doesn't necessarily mean that the industry is out of the woods," said Howard H. Mackey III, executive vice president and head of the trading desk at M. R. Beal & Company. "And it doesn't really show that Dell or the rest of the industry is really poised to do well over the next several quarters. I think that's why you didn't see follow-though on the part of major institutions today."
Companies continued to pepper the stock market with disappointing earnings warnings as the pre-announcement season continued in full swing.
Among retailers, Stride Rite said it would not meet analysts' estimates for sales for the coming quarter, and the company, a shoemaker, expects to report of loss of 6 to 8 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Shares of Stride Rite fell 28 cents, to $6.70, even though the company reported earnings that met lowered expectations for the third quarter.
Marriott International lost $1.40, to $32.10, after the hotel chain reported an 8 percent decrease in third-quarter earnings and warned that a further decline in its business in the wake of the terrorist attacks could depress its financial results for the fourth quarter and next year.

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on
Page 12.

Now Playing

* "APOCALYPSE NOW REDUX," starring Martin Sheen, Marlon Brando, Robert Duvall, Dennis Hopper and Laurence Fishburne. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola (R, 196 minutes). Nearly an hour has been added to Mr. Coppola's 1979 Vietnam epic, making the movie richer, stranger and more coherent. It has been rereleased in a stunning new print that showcases Vittorio Storaro's lustrous cinematography and Walter Murch's swirling, precise sound design, as well as Mr. Coppola's grand and sometimes murky vision. The movie's essential seriousness, its brave ambition and the dedication of its cast (now expanded to include Colleen Camp as a Playboy centerfold and Aurore Clement as a French widow) have grown more impressive with time. The current vogue for digitally enhanced computer-generated special effects in live-action movies, for jumpy, gestural editing and for glib pseudo-irony has lulled us into a pixilated, hyperactive slumber. With its grandeur and its horrific, exhilarating magic realism, "Apocalypse Now Redux" jolts us awake (A. O. Scott).

* "THE CLOSET," starring Daniel Auteuil and Gerard Depardieu. Directed by Francis Veber (R, 86 minutes; in French with English subtitles). A classic French farce with a contemporary twist, this very funny comedy spoofs political correctness, homophobia and corporate hypocrisy in its story of a mousy divorced accountant (Mr. Auteuil) who pretends to be gay to save his job in a condom factory. He can't be fired, he reasons correctly, because of corporate fear of a lawsuit for discrimination. Mr. Depardieu is hilariously galumphing as an obsequious homophobe who goes to such ludicrous extremes to demonstrate his tolerance that he drives himself crazy (Stephen Holden).

* "THE DEEP END," starring Tilda Swinton, Goran Visnjic, Jonathan Tucker and Josh Lucas. Written and directed by Scott McGehee and David Siegel (R, 99 minutes). In this tidy and sophisticated film noir, Mr. Lucas plays Darby, who is brazen, magnetic and ruthless and comes to an early end. A woman named Margaret (Ms. Swinton) becomes enmeshed in a murder involving Darby and his latest target: Margaret's 17-year-old son, Beau (Mr. Tucker). Margaret has to handle things on her own, because her husband, a naval officer, is away. She does whatever it takes to keep her boy safe from the clutches of the law and the thugs who were part of Darby's circle. "The Deep End" is fastidious and smart, and Ms. Swinton's fixated intensity isn't ever remote; we're always aware of how deeply she's feeling. Her work is magnificent, an actress burrowing inside herself to play a woman doing the most horrible thing in the world to restore order to her life (Elvis Mitchell).

"DON'T SAY A WORD," starring Michael Douglas, Sean Bean, Brittany Murphy and Jennifer Esposito (R, 110 minutes). In this exhausting, incoherent thriller, Mr. Douglas plays Nathan Conrad, a Manhattan psychiatrist whose young daughter is kidnapped by a sadistic band of jewel thieves. The ransom they demand is the intensive treatment of a mentally ill young woman who has a piece of information they need to recover a ruby they stole 10 years earlier, which the young woman's father, one of their accomplices, snatched away from them. Adding to the confusion is a tough, sexy homicide detective (Ms. Esposito) whose investigation of a series of murders leads her to Dr. Conrad. The movie is as over-elaborate as the criminals' scheme, and similarly doomed, from the outset, to fail (Scott).

"GLITTER," starring Mariah Carey. Directed by Vondie Curtis Hall (PG-13, 145 minutes). This film wants to be a heart-tugging tale of a rags-to-pop-royalty climb made poignant by love and loss. But "Glitter," with Ms. Carey as a talented performer who goes from backup singer to troubled star, is mostly dross, an unintentionally hilarious compendium of time-tested cinematic cliches that illustrate the chasm between hopeful imitation and successful duplication (Lawrence Van Gelder).

"THE GLASS HOUSE," starring Leelee Sobieski, Diane Lane, Stellan Skarsgard, Trevor Morgan and Bruce Dern. Directed by Daniel Sackheim (PG-13, 101 minutes). After their parents are killed in a car accident, Ruby Baker (Ms. Sobieski) and her brother are sent to live with the Glasses, a pair of dysfunctional creeps who also turn out, to no one's surprise but the children's, to be diabolical criminals. The movie might have succeeded as a minor entry in the thriller subgenre that includes "Single White Female" and "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle," but it takes more than a spooky score and horror-movie editing tricks to generate suspense. Mr. Skarsgard, who plays Terry Glass, is so cold and repellent from the start that it's impossible to imagine that anyone would trust him with a pet goldfish, let alone two innocent (and, of course, once it comes to outwitting him, absurdly resourceful) children (Scott).

"HARDBALL," starring Keanu Reeves, Diane Lane and John Hawkes. Directed by Brian Robbins (PG-13, 110 minutes). Daniel Coyle's nonfiction book about a children's baseball team from Chicago has been adapted into a mawkish, cutesy tearjerker. Mr. Reeves, as self-conscious as ever, is its reluctant coach, a down-and-out gambler who redeems himself (and pays off his debts) by leading these latter-day Bad News Bears to victory. The star is forced to deliver inspirational sound bites like the movie's meaningless tag line, "The most important thing in life is showing up" (Holden).

"HEARTS IN ATLANTIS," starring Anthony Hopkins, Anton Yelchin and Hope Davis. Directed by Scott Hicks (PG-13, 101 minutes). One of Stephen King's sappier novels has been pummeled into mush by Mr. Hicks's shallow magazine-glossy depiction of late-1950's America. He is aided by William Goldman's screenplay, which fills the mouth of its persecuted hero with kitschy inanities. That hero, a mysterious Christlike mind-reader who becomes a young boy's surrogate dad, is played by the painfully miscast Mr. Hopkins. Compared to this bunk, even the movie of Mr. King's "Green Mile" seems austere (Holden).

"LIAM," starring Ian Hart, Claire Hackett, Anne Reid and Anthony Borrows. Directed by Stephen Frears (R, 90 minutes). Like many other movies that revisit the turmoil and deprivation of the past century from the perspective of a child, Mr. Frears's new film, about a young boy in 1930's Liverpool, England, walks the delicate boundary between politically inflected realism and costumed sentimentality. At its best, "Liam" explores the effects of unemployment and poverty on Liam's working-class Catholic family with an impressionistic, detached lyricism that captures a boy's puzzlement and curiosity without being too cute about it. But the anecdotal treatment of the family's life gradually and inexorably turns melodramatic, and the violent conclusion seems not to grow out of the lives of the characters, but to be clumsily imposed on them (Scott).

"THE MUSKETEER," starring Catherine Deneuve, Mena Suvari, Stephen Rea, Tim Roth and Justin Chambers. Directed by Peter Hyams (PG-13, 106 minutes). This hopelessly confused and poorly written adaptation of "The Three Musketeers" tries to blend traditional costume adventure with MTV-ready attitude and Hong Kong-style duels. The nervous jump-cut editing chops the action sequences into visual coleslaw, and Mr. Chambers's lead character, D'Artagnan, mumbles like a dazed lobotomy patient. Ms. Deneuve and Mr. Rea, in small roles, pretend they're in another, more coherent movie, but it doesn't help (Holden).

"THE OTHERS," starring Nicole Kidman, Alakina Mann and James Bentley. Written and directed by Alejandro Amenabar (PG-13, 104 minutes). At 29, Mr. Amenabar, a Spanish filmmaker directing his first English-language movie, shows an impressive mastery of the ghost-story form. He sends his camera down shadowy corridors and into cavernous rooms to create a mood of elegant dread. Though a bit too long and too cluttered in the middle, "The Others" is persuasively spooky and even manages to be poignant, thanks to a fierce performance by Ms. Kidman. She plays a woman living with her two children and three peculiar servants in a fog-shrouded house on the island of Jersey in the English Channel (Scott).

* "OUR LADY OF THE ASSASSINS," starring German Jaramillo, Anderson Ballesteros and Juan David Restropo. Directed by Barbet Schroeder (R, 100 minutes; in Spanish, with English subtitles). One description for the ambience of this devastating portrait (filmed in high-definition video) of the corrupt Colombian city of Medellin might be documentary hallucination. With a screenplay adapted by Fernando Vallejo from his novel "La Virgen de los Sicarios," the film gazes into the soul of a burned-out homosexual writer who returns to Medellin (his hometown) after 30 years and finds it transformed into a circle of hell plagued by rampant, casual slaughter. He falls successively in love with two nihilistic street boys, both killers (Holden).

"RAT RACE," starring John Cleese, Whoopi Goldberg, Cuba Gooding Jr., Seth Green and Vince Vieluf. Directed by Jerry Zucker (PG-13, 112 minutes). A wealthy, thrill-addicted casino owner (Mr. Cleese) contrives a race from Nevada to New Mexico with a $2 million prize. The hand-picked, scrambling contestants include a pair of inept, scuffling brothers (Mr. Green and Mr. Vieluf) and a humiliated N.F.L. referee (Mr. Gooding). "Rat Race" crams much antic activity into its meager story line, much of it lifted from other movies. The script is unashamed about stooping into any sewer for laughs. The premise of the contest produces so much anxiety that Mr. Zucker's Zen-like direction can't help making you feel uneasy (Mitchell).

"ROCK STAR," starring Mark Wahlberg, Jennifer Aniston and Jason Flemyng. Directed by Stephen Herek (R, 142 minutes). Based on the true story of a heavy-metal fan who replaced the lead singer in the band he worshiped, this sloppy, charming melange of "This Is Spinal Tap" and "Almost Famous" looks back nostalgically at the big-haired, leather-and-spandex pop metal of the mid-1980's. Mr. Wahlberg, playing a Pittsburgh head banger who unexpectedly lives out his fantasy of sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll, captures both the naivete and the passion of obsessive fandom. Though the story of his transformation from regular guy to metal god and back again is predictable and unconvincing, the movie is full of well-observed details and authentically awful music. It both celebrates and, with gentle knowingness, ridicules the noisy, raucous world of big arena shows, endless touring and androgynous machismo that was 80's metal (Scott).

"TWO CAN PLAY THAT GAME," starring Vivica A. Fox, Morris Chestnut and Anthony Anderson (R, 90 minutes). Written and directed by Mark Brown. In this formulaic, featherweight romantic comedy, Ms. Fox, playing Shante, a young, supersuccessful advertising executive, dispenses tough-minded, good-humored advice on how to keep a man in line. Her resourcefulness is tested when her own man, a lawyer named Keith (Mr. Chestnut), threatens to stray. The two principals are appealing enough, but what little comic spark the film has comes from Mr. Anderson as a colleague of Keith's who becomes his counselor in love and war (Scott).

* "VA SAVOIR," starring Jeanne Balibar, Sergio Castellitto, Marianne Basler, Jacques Bonnaffe and Helene De Fougerolles. Directed by Jacques Rivette (PG-13, 150 minutes; in French, with English subtitles). Mr. Rivette's gracious -- and graceful -- character comedy is droll and lovable, a piece that has earned all of the wrinkles on its brow and around its mouth. What's surprising is that on close examination those crinkles turn out to be smile lines. "Savoir" is a luminous, humid roundelay, as three men and three women tumble in and out of one another's minds, hearts and arms. Everyone is looking for something other than what he or she has. That lusty self-interest is the motor of all great farces. The film's title has been translated as "Who Knows?," and it is a wistful, rueful shrug: an unforgettable gesture as sexy and controlled as Tony Bennett chugging his way through "I Wish I Were in Love Again" (Mitchell).

* "ZOOLANDER," starring Ben Stiller, Owen Wilson and Will Ferrell. Directed by Mr. Stiller (PG-13, 89 minutes). An evil band of international fashion designers want to end the tenure of a new prime minister of Malaysia, who plans to stop the exploitation of child labor. They force their subaltern Mugatu (Mr. Ferrell) to find a supermodel pawn to assassinate the beloved ruler. There's only one blunt instrument suited to this job: the dumb and monumentally earnest Derek Zoolander (Mr. Stiller), the star and unfortunate potential hero of this often unspeakably funny new comedy. "Zoolander" is a gleaming fashion-world tour. It makes sense that the film would have the stylish, high-resolution glaze of a fashion shoot. Mr. Stiller has also crammed the movie with energy; it seems still to be bouncing on the screen long after it has run its 89-minute course (Mitchell).

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Dell Says It Will Meet Its Forecasts In 3rd Quarter

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

 BODY:
The Dell Computer Corporation, offering investors some cheer in a bleak industry, said yesterday that it remained on track to meet sales and profit forecasts for its fiscal third quarter, as demand for its computers returned more quickly than expected after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
 The achievement, hailed by analysts as an affirmation of Dell's build-to-order business model, was highlighted by a warning later in the day from Gateway, the fourth-largest PC vendor. Using early results from its just-ended third quarter, Gateway said it lost more money than expected and would take a charge of as much as $130 million, largely because both PC demand and the value of its investments declined after the attacks. 
 With four weeks left in its quarter, which ends Nov. 2, Dell became the second high-tech bellwether in two days to surprise Wall Street with an announcement that it expects to meet estimates, joining Cisco Systems, the networking company that issued its forecast Wednesday. 
"We still are very hopeful for the quarter and think the business model is humming along better -- operationally and financially -- than it ever has," said Kevin B. Rollins, president and chief operating officer of Dell, the world's largest PC maker.
Dell's announcement, made before the markets opened, lifted its shares by more than 8 percent. Dell stock finished the day $1.64 higher, at $22.32.
"It just shows you that the market has been so beat up that even neutral statements are being received very well," said Kevin A. McCarthy, an analyst who covers Dell for Credit Suisse First Boston.
Dell executives cautioned that the volatile economic and political environment had made all forecasts unusually difficult. They said they would not predict fourth-quarter results until Nov. 15, when they plan to report this quarter's earnings.
The company, based in Austin, Tex., said it stood by its earlier forecast of 15 to 16 cents of profit a share and revenue of $7.2 billion to $7.6 billion.
Dell is one of few vendors still making money on selling PC's. Like its competitors, it has had to reset its expectations as the once-booming PC market is poised to shrink this year for the first time. During the comparable period last year, Dell earned 25 cents a share on revenues of $8.3 billion.
Earlier this week, Moody's Investor Service lowered Dell's rating outlook to stable, from positive, indicating that Moody's does not expect the credit rating to change during the next year. Richard J. Lane, a senior vice president at Moody's, said yesterday that Dell's business model set it apart from its competitors, but that its exposure to a slumping business prompted the downgrade.
James M. Schneider, the chief financial officer at Dell, said business had exceeded his expectations during the first five weeks of the quarter, slowed to a virtual halt in the two days after the terrorist attacks, then quickly began to pick up again.
"We actually were a little surprised at how fast things rebounded," Mr. Schneider said.
Government agencies, relief agencies and corporations in the World Trade Center and damaged buildings nearby bought computers immediately after the attacks, helping to offset a sudden drop in general consumer and corporate demand, the company said.
Michael S. Dell, the chairman and chief executive, said his company won customers from the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Compaq Computer Corporation, which on Sept. 3 announced plans to merge. Mr. Dell called the merger a "profound opportunity" for his business.
After a conference call with Dell executives, analysts expressed surprise at the company's vague optimism going into the fourth quarter and next year. The threat of a recession has caused corporations to delay spending on many large information technology projects, and PC upgrades are often the first to go.
In a report last week, Merrill Lynch widened its projections for the PC industry's decline this year, to 6 percent from 5 percent, and tempered its optimism for 2002.
Engaged in a corporate restructuring and retreat from the European market, Gateway said it expected to report a loss of 14 to 17 cents a share, compared with its previous predictions of a "slight loss," excluding special charges. Gateway, which will report in more detail on Oct. 18, also said it would take a charge of $100 million to $130 million to write down investments, in addition to a $475 million restructuring charge announced in August. 
Theodore W. Waitt, Gateway's chairman and chief executive, said sales only recently returned to the levels they had reached before the terrorist attacks. He added that he was "cautiously optimistic" of a return to profitability in the fourth quarter. 
Earlier this week, Compaq said it expected to report a loss for its just-ended quarter. The terrorist attacks left both Compaq and Gateway with only two anxiety-ridden weeks to complete their sales before the quarter ended, while Dell had six weeks. 
"I think it's a difference of execution," said Kimberly Alexy, an analyst with Prudential Securities. "Dell is winning hands down." 
In regular trading, Gateway shares gained 15 cents, to $4.85. Compaq gained 20 cents, to $8.85.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael S. Dell, Dell Computer's chairman and chief, says his company has been winning customers from Hewlett-Packard and Compaq. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIRLINES; 
Lobbying Down to the Wire As Industry and Politicians Battle Over Aid to Carriers

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
New rules expected to be released by the Bush administration today will give a four-member panel headed by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, broad powers to dole out $10 billion in federally backed loans to the airline industry. 
 Airline executives, lawmakers and others lobbied fiercely yesterday to influence the final rules governing the loan-guarantee program, which was passed by Congress two weeks ago. 
 An early draft of the rules was distributed on Tuesday to members of the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which also includes the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill; the transportation secretary, Norman Y. Mineta; and the comptroller general, David M. Walker. The draft suggested that just 80 percent to 95 percent of each loan be given the guarantees from the government and that the loans be paid back in three to seven years. 
But some airline executives were pressing yesterday for the loans to be fully guaranteed and to stretch for as long as 10 years. 
Executives at the financially weaker carriers have argued that they will not be eligible for the program if the loans are not made available on more generous terms. They have charged that the larger, more financially healthy carriers are using the current crisis to try to reduce competition. 
"There are some people out there who may be trying to use this to impact their competitors," said Ed Faberman, executive director of the Air Carrier Association of America, a group that represents five small airlines. 
Congress gave the airlines $5 billion in cash and the $10 billion in loan guarantees to make up the losses caused by the government's decision to ground all airplanes after the terrorist attacks. The Office of Management and Budget was asked to draft guidelines for the board, which will decide which carriers are to receive the loans. 
The budget office is concerned that if the loans are given too liberally, the program will end up becoming costly to taxpayers. But given that it had only two weeks to write rules and was under heavy pressure from the industry, the budget office appears to have left many hard decisions up to the board. 
That pleased several of the airlines. "We want the maximum flexibility, and we will take our chances in front of the board," one airline lobbyist said yesterday.
The draft rules give the board broad discretion to decide who will receive the loans and what the terms will be. Carriers are required to document that their losses were caused by the events of Sept. 11 and they must provide a large amount of financial detail. No carrier in bankruptcy is eligible for a loan. 
The board is also free to decide how much money an airline can receive and what constitutes a reasonable interest rate. Preference is to be given to guaranteeing loans that include significant collateral, have shorter repayment periods and give the government preference in the event of a bankruptcy. 
The board is also supposed to favor applications that offer the government the opportunity to participate in the airline's future success in the form of stock. That requirement was written into the legislation by Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, a Republican of Illinois, and Senator Jon S. Corzine, a Democrat from New Jersey. 
Both senators sent a letter yesterday to the members of the board urging them to demand an equity stake from any airline that receives a loan. "Hardworking U.S. taxpayers should not be asked to bail out the airline industry with absolutely no strings attached," they wrote. 
Other lawmakers urged Mitch E. Daniels, the director of the budget office, to make sure that the loans were made available to small airlines, that airlines did not cut service to small cities and that they treated their laid-off workers fairly. 
Some industries with an indirect interest in the loans also weighed in. The Boeing Company urged the government to act quickly to help the airlines, which are its customers. Credit card companies wanted the loans to be contingent on a pledge from each airline to honor tickets issued by any other airline that filed for bankruptcy. Otherwise, the credit card companies would have to pay refunds. 
Travelocity and Expedia, two online travel agencies, wanted to preclude any of the loan money from being invested in Orbitz, a rival owned by five major airlines. 
Some airline executives were urging that people with more direct experience in the industry play a larger role in the deliberations.
"If you have never dealt with the airline industry and all of a sudden you have two weeks to set up a $10 billion loan program," Mr. Faberman said, "you may not have an awful lot of opportunity to learn a lot about that industry."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: REAGAN NATIONAL AIRPORT; 
Shuttles From New York to Washington Return to Sky

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 4 

 BODY:
As dawn broke this morning and planes lifted off from Ronald Reagan National Airport just outside Washington for the first time since Sept. 11, Captain Neal O'Brien's voice came over the intercom of the Delta shuttle to La Guardia.
 He thanked his 22 passengers scattered among the plane's 156 seats and added this, "On a personal note, I would ask that you assist our flight attendants and support them, as you see the need arise, in the cabin." 
 Most of his passengers seemed to know exactly what he meant as the resumption of airline shuttle service between New York and Washington re-established a vital economic link between the two cities, which share an important psychic link as common targets in the terrorist attacks.
"It was a very well-crafted way to put it," said Rob Bartenstein, 32, an investment banker from Virginia on his first trip back to New York since terrorists killed many of his colleagues in the World Trade Center. 
"It wasn't, 'Help the flight attendant if someone tries to commandeer the airplane,' " Mr. Bartenstein said. "It was just a general plea to be heads up, be aware and participate."
Mr. Bartenstein was among the first passengers to take to the skies today from Reagan National in its first day of operation since it was shuttered as a security precaution immediately after a plane hijacked from Dulles International Airport slammed into the Pentagon. The airport reopened on a limited basis, with just 102 flights, compared with the average of 450 before the attacks. Crews on the ground applauded when planes took off, and passengers applauded when they landed.
Given National's proximity to the White House, the Capitol and the Pentagon, the government has imposed especially tight restrictions on passengers here as a prototype for the nation. Camouflaged members of the Virginia National Guard, packing pistol belts, patrolled the security checkpoints this morning. 
Passengers were not allowed to move from their seats for at least 30 minutes after takeoff and passengers flying into National were not allowed to move 30 minutes before landing. Armed, undercover sky marshals accompanied all flights.
Linda Downs, head of education programs at the National Gallery of Art, arrived at National at 5 a.m. for the first shuttle, leaving at 7, and found the airport deserted. "I was expecting it to be crowded," Ms. Downs said. "It was a little eerie."
Business travelers on the shuttle, one of civilian aviation's legendary passenger routes, were important emissaries in the Washington-New York power corridor and in the national economy, which President Bush has said he hopes the reopening of the airport can help revive.
"The shuttle links the political capital in Washington and the financial capital in New York and the intellectual-high-tech center of Boston," said Rick Weintraub, a spokesman for US Airways, which runs a competing shuttle between the three cities. "Therefore it has an import that goes far beyond simply serving those communities."
The Delta shuttle accounts for about 2.5 percent of that airline's business, but both airlines paid keen attention to their passenger loads today. US Airways' first three shuttles from National to La Guardia carried 79 passengers, then 26, then 45. Delta's carried 22, 13 and 21.
US Airways and Delta are in competition not only with each other but with Amtrak, which has picked up much of the business travel in the last three weeks. Amtrak has added trains in the Northeast corridor and has seen demand rise by thousands of passengers each day. The Acela, which runs between New York and Washington in less than three hours, is often sold out. Today, the Acela that left Washington at 7 a.m. had 215 passengers and had reached its capacity of 304 by the time in reached Wilmington, Del., on its way to New York. The airlines are offering discounts and mileage advantages to try to win these travelers back.
The renewed availability of flying as an option between Washington and New York drew passengers today for two overriding reasons -- patriotism and convenience.
"We actually scheduled our business appointments up here for today so we could take the shuttle," said David Armstrong, 34, Mr. Bartenstein's colleague, noting that the losses in the financial community from the attacks had put their business on hold for the last three weeks. Added his friend, "It was the first thing we felt like we were able to do, apart from give money or give blood, and actually stick our thumb in the eye of the people who did all this in the first place."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gate agents for US Airways received instructions yesterday as Reagan National Airport reopened. (Photographs by Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
Bush Proposes Extending Aid To the Jobless

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
With new data showing unemployment rising sharply, President Bush proposed measures today to help people who lost jobs in the wake of the terrorist attacks, and the administration began negotiating in earnest with Congress on broader efforts to revive the flagging economy.
 Mr. Bush proposed extending unemployment insurance for workers in states hardest hit by the economic effects of the attacks and making $3 billion available to states to help them provide additional aid for people who have been laid off. He said he would also encourage states to draw on unspent federal money already allocated to job and welfare programs. 
 "We hear the cries of those who have been laid off," Mr. Bush said. 
He spoke after the Labor Department announced that new claims for state unemployment insurance last week were 528,000, up 71,000 from the previous week, putting them at the highest level in more than nine years. The government is scheduled to release the unemployment rate for September on Friday.
On Capitol Hill, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill met with the senior Republicans and Democrats on the tax-writing committees in the House and the Senate. People who were briefed on the meeting said Mr. O'Neill indicated that the White House would be flexible in coming to terms on a package of tax cuts to stimulate the economy.
In particular, they said, Mr. O'Neill left open the possibility that the administration would compromise on its proposal to accelerate the income tax rate reductions included in the tax bill Mr. Bush signed into law in June. Under that bill, tax rates came down slightly this year and are scheduled to fall again in 2004 and 2006. The administration has been pushing for making at least part of the planned reductions effective immediately. 
They said Mr. O'Neill discussed the possibility of only speeding up the planned reduction for those in the 28 percent income tax rate, which is paid by about 45 percent of taxpayers, rather than also accelerating the planned reductions for those paying the top rates. Under the tax bill passed this year, the 28 percent rate would eventually fall to 25 percent.
Democrats objected to accelerating the reductions for those in the top income tax rates, which currently extend up to 38.6 percent, saying any tax cuts should be concentrated on low- and middle-income people.
Democrats said Mr. Bush's proposals to help the unemployed were a good first step. But they called for a more aggressive effort to help the unemployed than Mr. Bush proposed. And members of both parties said it was clear that their pledges of bipartisanship would be tested by a continued ideological divide in Congress over how best to pull the nation out of what now appears to be a recession.
A senior official at the Treasury Department, speaking on the condition that he not be identified, said all or most of the $60 billion to $75 billion that Mr. Bush has said should be allocated to steps to stimulate the economy should go to tax cuts. His statement, in a briefing for reporters, seemed intended to quell criticism from conservative Republicans that White House officials were giving in too easily to Democrats as they negotiate the details of the economic recovery plan. 
Democrats said they would still push for a substantial part of the money to go to new spending programs. Democrats in the House drew up a nationwide wish list that included $4 billion for repairs and improved security at federal buildings, $1.5 billion to upgrade mass transit systems and $1.2 billion for school construction and renovation. Those types of programs, Democrats said, would create jobs and encourage people to spend more money.
"You could fashion a good balance that includes both tax cuts and spending," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, "and that's what we ought to be about." 
The top Democrats and Republicans on the House and Senate budget committees said Congress and the administration had to keep in mind that the stimulus package would push the government into deficit this year for the first time since 1997. They said the government should plan to return as quickly as possible to its plan to pay off most of the $3.3 trillion national debt within a decade.
At the same time, interest groups stepped up their efforts to get a piece of the stimulus plan, with groups like textile makers, insurers and small-business owners making a case for why they need help.
Members of both parties suggested that they are likely to include in the economic recovery plan a proposal to give a one-time tax rebate of $300 per person, or $600 per couple, to the more than 30 million working people who did not earn enough money last year to qualify for the rebates sent out this summer as the first installment of this year's tax cut.
The senior Treasury official said the proposal would probably provide an additional payment to people whose income was high enough to receive a portion of this summer's rebate, but not the entire amount. 
The rebate plan would cost about $16 billion to $20 billion, the official said.
Democrats pressed for the business tax cuts to be temporary while Republicans said they should be permanent. But members of both parties said they agreed in general on the need to allow companies to more rapidly write off their investments in new factories and equipment to stimulate new investment.
Mindful of both the economic and political costs of a rise in joblessness, Mr. Bush made helping the unemployed the focus of his public statements on the economy today.
At an appearance at the Labor Department, the president said his plan would extend unemployment insurance payments for an additional 13 weeks beyond the standard 26 weeks in states where the unemployment rate increases by at least 30 percent after Sept. 11. 
It is too early to know how many states will meet the requirement, but New York and Virginia, where the attacks took place, are the most likely candidates. The program would be available for 18 months, and would be paid for entirely by the federal government. The cost would depend on the extent of the rise in unemployment.
Mr. Bush also proposed making $3 billion in emergency grants available to all states to help workers who lose their jobs because of the economic effects of the attacks. 
The money could go to help people maintain their health insurance and receive job training, and could also be used by states to make cash payments to unemployed workers.

HEADLINE: Spending Is the Hard Part 

 BODY:
After a week of jousting, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and New York State's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, have agreed to share responsibility for coordinating the distribution of nearly $700 million in private charity raised since the World Trade Center disaster on Sept. 11. It is not clear how this will play out in practice, but an inappropriate turf war seems to have been avoided.
 As Mr. Spitzer noted when he volunteered his services last week, spending all this money equitably and efficiently will not be easy. It will be even harder if the people who should be providing guidance cannot get along. There is also no room for petty discord when the universe of direct and indirect victims continues to grow and when each day seems to bring some new challenge to the task of matching resources to needs in an intelligent way. 
 It is becoming increasingly clear that the thorniest problem -- at least as difficult as coordinating the private charities -- involves the relationship between private philanthropy and the big sums of money promised by the federal government. In addition to New York's share of the $20 billion pledged by President Bush -- which will inevitably be swallowed up by the physical costs associated with cleanup and reconstruction -- Congress created an open-ended compensation fund for victims' families. Approved as part of the airline bailout package, the fund would compensate for economic loss, pain and suffering and thus spare the airlines endless lawsuits. The aggregate cost of the program could be an added $15 billion, and the individual awards could range above $1 million for direct victims of the attack -- the nearly 5,400 killed or missing as well as those who were seriously injured. 
This raises an unexpected question for private philanthropy. Given the prospect of large federal settlements for direct victims, should the charities begin thinking about distributing a greater share of their aid to the "indirect" victims -- the people who survived the collapse of the towers but lost their homes, jobs or small businesses, suffered mental trauma or found their lives disrupted in other ways?
The answer is almost surely yes. One of the unfolding truths of the recovery process is that the universe of victims is a great deal larger and more complicated than originally thought. To take one example, there are an estimated 1,500 small retailers below Chambers Street in Lower Manhattan who are now out of business or in serious trouble. They need and deserve assistance. To take a less visible example, the disaster shut down a shelter for battered women. Those women still need a place to go. 
This ever-expanding circle of suffering merely reinforces the need for coordination among the many sources of help. As it happens, private agencies like United Way and big foundations like Carnegie are beginning to talk to one another on a regular basis, but even they agree that some sort of overall guidance would be a good idea. A week ago Mr. Spitzer, whose office oversees private charities, volunteered to serve as a clearinghouse for information among the 140 or so organizations involved in the relief effort and to provide regular briefings on which needs were being met and which were being left unattended. On Monday Mr. Giuliani insisted that he wanted to be coordinator in chief because his agencies had already developed a day-to-day relationship with the victims' families.
At least for now, the two have agreed to work together and play to each other's strengths. That is welcome news. As this tragedy reverberates in unpredictable ways, the task of sorting out who needs help and who can best provide it is going to get harder rather than easier.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Yes, But What?

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Judging from the foreign press, the most popular world reaction to the terrorist attacks on America has not been outright condemnation, but rather: "Yes, but . . ." Yes, this was terrible, but somehow America deserved it or is responsible for the anger behind it.
 One can only be amazed at the ease with which some people abroad and at campus teach-ins now tell us what motivated the terrorists. Guess what? The terrorists didn't leave an explanatory note. Because their deed was their note: We want to destroy America, starting with its military and financial centers. Which part of that sentence don't people understand? 
 Have you ever seen Osama bin Laden say "I just want to see a smaller Israel in its pre-1967 borders," or "I have no problem with America, it just needs to have a lower cultural and military profile in the Muslim world"? These terrorists aren't out for a new kind of coexistence with us. They are out for our non-existence. 
None of this seems to have seeped into the "Yes, but . . ." crowd, whose most prominent "Yes, but" states: This terrorist act would never have happened if America hadn't been so supportive of Israel. 
My response is, "Yes, but . . . but . . ."
Yes, there is no question, America's support of Israel -- even when Israel builds greedy, provocative settlements in the heart of the Gaza Strip -- has produced understandable Muslim anger. But the argument doesn't end there. America has also taken the lead role in trying to reverse this situation. We know the Sept. 11 attack was being planned a year ago -- exactly when President Clinton was proposing to Yasir Arafat a Palestinian state on roughly 95 percent of the West Bank and East Jerusalem -- with the Israeli settlers uprooted from all but 5 percent. In other words, this terrorism was being planned because America was trying to build Israeli-Palestinian coexistence, not because it wasn't.
Ah, say the "Yes, but" folks, but Arab public opinion has been inflamed by the Arab TV images of Israel suppressing the Palestinian uprising. Yes, at times Israel has used excessive force, and one can understand how that looks to Arab eyes, but Israel has also been responding to Palestinian suicide attacks on Israeli pizza parlors and discos -- which isn't highlighted on Arab TV. 
Moreover, this uprising by the Palestinians was not their only recourse. There was an active U.S.-sponsored diplomatic track, with a deal on the table, which may not have been fully acceptable to Palestinians but was certainly worth building upon and hardly justified suicide-bombing Israeli civilians. The Arab media and leaders now talk as though the Clinton proposal for a Palestinian state never happened. But it did. 
The second "Yes, but" is that the terrorists reflect a protest over Muslim poverty. Yes, poverty can breed desperate people. However, most of the hijackers were middle-class Saudis or Egyptians.
Is it America's fault that the richest ruling family in the world, the Saudis, have citizens who are poor and frustrated? Is it America's fault that Korea had the same per capita income in the 1950's as many Arab states, but Korea has managed its development so much better since that it now dwarfs all Arab economies? Afghanistan is run by a medieval Taliban theocracy that bans women from working or going to school. How could such a place not be poor? And who was the biggest protector of that backward Taliban society? Osama bin Laden and his men.
There is something wrong with Saudi Arabia citing U.S. support for Israel as the root cause for this Islamist terror -- when many Saudi men were among the hijackers, when the Saudi regime has tolerated the harsh Islamist movements that provided ideological guidance for these young men, when Saudi Arabia was the biggest funder of the Taliban, when the Saudi ruling family has alienated some of its most devout subjects to a degree that produced Islamist militancy, and when the Saudi regime -- as The Economist just noted, in an article titled "Saudi Arabia: The Double-Act Wears Thin" -- winked at indirect fund-raising for Mr. bin Laden in the Kingdom as a way of currying favor with its hard-line Islamist critics. 
I don't want to see the Saudi regime destabilized. I'm sure it wants to be part of the solution now. But how about a little candor? YES, America should look deeper into its policies and actions -- BUT, BUT, BUT we're not the only ones who need to look in the mirror.

HEADLINE: Sailing Into a Sea of Troubles; 
No Grace Period for New Chief of American Express

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Everything is so topsy-turvy at the American Express Company these days that some midlevel managers have spacious offices with soothing water views but Kenneth I. Chenault does not.
 Mr. Chenault, the first-year chairman and chief executive of American Express, has been operating from a spare interior office in Jersey City for the last three weeks as he tries to hold together a company that was already plagued by serious financial problems even before Sept. 11. 
 The attack on the World Trade Center left 11 American Express employees dead or missing. It drove Mr. Chenault and 4,000 employees out of the company's headquarters in the World Financial Center, across the street from the destroyed towers, and scattered the company's staff over the suburbs for at least the next few months. It immediately darkened the outlook for a company whose fortunes are inextricably linked to corporate spending on travel and entertainment. 
Few companies have more riding on President Bush's proposal to stimulate the economy with another $75 billion in government spending and tax cuts than American Express. That is why Mr. Chenault was sitting shoulder to shoulder with the president on Wednesday at a gathering of business leaders in lower Manhattan and was chosen to deliver the group's supportive response to the president's plan.
Mr. Chenault praised Mr. Bush's show of leadership since the attack and said, "We will not succumb to this evil."
If any corporate chief had reason to wave a white flag, it might be Mr. Chenault. In his first six months as chairman, he twice had to tell investors that mounting losses in the company's portfolio of junk bonds were chewing up its operating profits. He announced two rounds of layoffs that will eliminate almost 7,000 jobs, or 7 percent of the work force.
Now, this.
On Sept. 17, American Express issued its third earnings warning of the year. The company said it had been on track to meet investors' expectations before the attack, but it could not forecast afterward how far short it would fall.
Its stock fell $9.40, or almost 27 percent, in the first week of trading after the attacks, cutting about $12 billion from the company's market value. In the middle of that decline, Standard & Poor's lowered its outlook on the company's debt rating to negative from stable.
"He's had nothing but trouble since the day he stepped into the job," said Richard Fuld, chairman and chief executive of Lehman Brothers Holdings, an investment bank that was a neighbor of American Express in the World Financial Center and is now a neighbor in Jersey City, across the Hudson River.
But by all accounts, Mr. Chenault has remained rock steady, dealing with the personal losses, refusing to complain about the deteriorating situation of American Express, taking time to listen to employees' commuting nightmares and even doing favors for other companies.
"It's certainly been a challenging year," Mr. Chenault said, leaning on a small table in his temporary office after a grand tour of the not-so-grand quarters American Express's where top executives have retreated. "But I don't feel that I've been put upon."
John O. Utendahl, chairman of Utendahl Capital Partners, said he had detected little change in Mr. Chenault's calm demeanor through all the adversity.
"I saw the same intensity I see all the time," said Mr. Utendahl, who has known Mr. Chenault for 20 years. "There was no break in his voice, no sweat on his brow."
Mr. Chenault, he said, knows that everyone from the lowest-ranking employee to the company's biggest shareholder and its board is monitoring his every move. "They're looking at his eyes, his hands -- whether they shake, whether his knees are weak," Mr. Utendahl said.
Judging by Mr. Chenault's performance as he made the rounds this week of the company's newly leased offices in Parsippany and Short Hills, N.J., those looking for the slightest flinch will have a hard time detecting it. As Mr. Chenault wandered through mazes of freshly scrubbed cubicles and newly painted corridors, he exchanged hugs and handshakes with everybody he encountered. Most greeted him with a casual "Hi, Ken."
It was moving-in day at both buildings, and workers gathered in groups, sharing war stories about their new commutes and getting stress-relieving massages from tables set up in hallways. Mr. Chenault listened patiently in an elevator as one woman described the trip of two and a half hours she had made from her home on Long Island.
Not everyone was complaining. Edward P. Gilligan, who runs the company's corporate services division, said he had driven to Parsippany from his home in Summit in 20 minutes -- counting a stop at Starbucks.
Mr. Gilligan said he was telling employees to expect to be working from the suburban offices for as long as a year but that he would try to arrange for many of them to work from home or occasionally from the office closest to home.
The dislocation of American Express might have been reduced had Mr. Chenault not been so magnanimous. In the scramble for office space before the smoke cleared in the financial district, Mr. Fuld discovered that American Express was trying to sublease the same three floors of a new building on the waterfront in Jersey City that Lehman Brothers wanted. On Sept. 13, Mr. Fuld called Mr. Chenault, who had been grounded in Salt Lake City all week, and pleaded his case.
The space, with floors raised to accommodate lots of wiring, was ideal for Lehman's trading operations, Mr. Fuld was explaining when Mr. Chenault cut him off.
"He said, 'Dick, go no further. I'll stand down,' " recounted Mr. Fuld, whose company was once owned by American Express. "I have always liked Ken, and this just reinforced that feeling. I like the way he has handled a tough situation."
Mr. Chenault was visiting one of his company's offices in Salt Lake City when the attacks occurred. Grounded there for the next two days, he managed the company by hourly conference call.
At first, a few of his lieutenants, including Alfred F. Kelly Jr., who runs the company's charge card business, joined in from the kitchen table in a young employee's apartment in Greenwich Village. Her home was chosen because her husband works for the company and had three phone lines working during the widespread service disruptions.
The calls brimmed with nervous energy but Mr. Chenault, who had set up a command center in Salt Lake City, cut through it by asking a series of direct questions that dealt first with people, an executive who participated in the calls said.
One of his first orders was to have operators at the company's call center in Greensboro, N.C., locate all of the New York employees. Eventually they tracked down everybody except 11 employees who had been working in a client's offices on the 94th floor of 1 World Trade Center.
During an interview in a sedan ferrying him between office buildings, the only time Mr. Chenault averted his gaze and looked out the window was when he was asked about those victims. He blinked twice and said that the company would hold a memorial service for them after their families had received more information.
Despite the dislocation, he said, the company's "business continuation" plans had worked without a hitch. 
"The way I judge a plan is, 'Do you need top management intervention for the plan to go forward?' " he said. Clearly, he was pleased that American Express had not.
Several days later, the operators in Greensboro were assigned to contact all the New York employees again and invite them to an afternoon pep rally at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 20. Mr. Chenault said there were some doubts about whether people were ready to reassemble in Manhattan, but about 4,000 showed up to hear Sheryl Crow sing "God Bless America" and watch Tiger Woods, another American Express endorser, deliver a televised message of support.
"The employees needed to hear from me about how I felt about them and the state of the company," Mr. Chenault said. "It was a way to begin the healing process."
While the company heals, Mr. Chenault must determine how it will cope with its financial distress. He has spent much of his time studying how American Express responded a decade ago when the Persian Gulf war slammed the brakes on air travel, consumer spending -- and the company's charge card billings.
That conflict ended quickly but the company's business did not recover for about a year, said Mr. Chenault, who was running the card business then. Mr. Chenault and his former boss, Harvey Golub, responded by broadening the company's offering to include revolving credit cards to reduce its vulnerability to a crisis in the travel business. Nonetheless, about half of the company's charge card revenue still comes from travel-related services, Michael Hughes, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said.
"A quick end to the current crisis would make American Express a very attractive stock," he said. "A prolonged battle would not."
Mr. Chenault knows that war plans are beyond his control. So he said he would focus on guiding American Express through another rough period.
"If you're the leader, you've got to feel you're the person where the decisions rest," he said. "This is no time for excuses."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CONSERVATIVES; 
Some in G.O.P. Balk at Growing Federal Role

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL and RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
Little more than three weeks after the terrorist attacks, some conservative Republicans are pointedly challenging the Bush administration on the scope of the stated campaign against terrorism and its new receptiveness to an expanded federal government.
 The dissension was initially muted as the president moved the nation onto a wartime footing after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But in recent days it has started to break out into the open on Capitol Hill. 
 And while most lawmakers had thought the mood of bipartisanship was too good to last, they had expected relations to fray between Republicans and Democrats. Instead, many say, the tensions are most acute right now within the Republican Party. Mr. Bush is facing challenges from the very conservatives who were once his base. 
At one Senate hearing on Wednesday Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, hotly condemned the administration's approach to economic stimulus, arguing that the White House was sanctioning big spending and giving up too easily on conservative tax-cutting priorities.
"It looks to me as if we're moving toward a package which I'm not going to vote for," Mr. Gramm told Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill.
In an interview today, the senator said, "The whole idea of even trying to balance the budget or controlling spending seems to have been thrown out the window. I can't turn that quickly. I've got whiplash."
At a recent closed-door briefing for House members on the military buildup, Representative Dana Rohrabacher, Republican of California, accused Secretary of State Colin L. Powell of leaving the job undone at the end of the Persian Gulf war, which Mr. Bush's father halted with the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein still in power. Mr. Powell was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff during the war.
"I confronted him directly on the floor in front of everybody," Mr. Rohrabacher said today. "I didn't say you were the one who stopped us from getting Saddam Hussein. I did draw the analogy that we had not finished the job in Iraq." 
Like Mr. Rohrabacher, many conservatives and neo-conservatives, including some Democrats, argue that Mr. Bush cannot limit a war on terrorism to Osama bin Laden. In a letter to the president circulated by William Kristol, who was chief of staff to Vice President Dan Quayle, several signers, including Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former United Nations delegate, wrote that killing Mr. bin Laden could not be the only goal of the struggle and endorsed a "determined effort" to oust Mr. Hussein.
Republican officials are careful not to criticize Mr. Bush personally or to question his conduct in responding to the terror attacks. Mr. Gramm blamed the Democrats for pushing new spending programs. And Mr. Rohrabacher said he had faith in Mr. Bush, describing him as "more like Ronald Reagan than his father."
Internal Republican struggles began almost as soon as Mr. Bush promised New York's senators in the week of the attack that an extra $20 billion would be dedicated largely to New York. Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the second-ranking Senate Republican, and Mr. Gramm raised questions that kept negotiations going well into the night.
Now some Republicans, who thought Mr. Bush's election heralded a golden era for conservatives, say they are shocked at how quickly the antigovernment sentiment of the 1990's has shifted. For them it seems like an eon ago that candidate George W. Bush lampooned Al Gore, saying that Mr. Gore trusts the government while he trusts people.
Senator George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, cited concerns in the party over the shape of the economic recovery package and the efforts to give the government responsibility for airline security.
"Some of the things being recommended are New Deal, Great Society-type things that are going to cost an enormous amount of money," Mr. Voinovich said.
Moreover, Congressional Republicans themselves are not seeing eye to eye.
Senator John McCain of Arizona, the ranking Republican on the Commerce Committee, has become a strong proponent of putting the government in charge of airline security. But Representative Bob Barr, Republican of Georgia, has gone from fighting to tone down some of the surveillance proposals in the administration's antiterrorism package to fighting against the idea of federalizing airline security.
"To me as a conservative, I look at a problem and ask, Is this a federal function?" Mr. Barr said. "Faced with the crisis we make the illogical jump that the government is the only one that can do it."
When Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta told Republican leaders at a meeting today that the White House would have to put the government in charge of airline security to win over Democrats, Representatives Dick Armey and Tom DeLay, the second- and third-ranking House leaders, rebelled, Republican aides said.
The White House today made efforts to tamp down the Republican discontent, bringing an array of party leaders to the White House.
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, noted in his daily briefing that the president had said "it's important that people in Congress don't start inventing or designing new systems, newfangled notions."
"He also thinks it would be a mistake if people tried to engage in a whole series of new government programs," Mr. Fleischer said.
Representative Thomas M. Davis III of Virginia, the chairman of the House Republicans' re-election efforts, said he was aware of some of his colleagues' grousing. But Mr. Davis said it was misplaced, adding, "It's not a time to get hard-core partisan."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: EVIDENCE; 
British Detail bin Laden's Link to U.S. Attacks

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 

 BODY:
In the days before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, Osama bin Laden indicated that he was "about to launch a major attack on America," according to a British government document released today.
 Prime Minister Tony Blair said the evidence detailed in the document left "absolutely no doubt that bin Laden and his network are responsible" for the attacks on New York and the Pentagon. 
 The document says that known associates of Mr. bin Laden named "the date for action as on or around 11 September." Others were warned to return to Afghanistan before their plot unfolded, the document says.
It asserts that one of Mr. bin Laden's most senior associates, who is not named, was the man "responsible for the detailed planning of the attacks," and that at least three hijackers "have already been positively identified as associates of Al Qaeda," Mr. bin Laden's organization. Text, Page B4. 
Some statements were winnowed from intercepted telephone conversations and others surfaced in interrogation sessions in Europe in the frantic days since Sept. 11, intelligence officials said today. Together, they form the keystone of a 16-page document, released on the Internet by the British government and accusing Mr. bin Laden and Al Qaeda of "responsibility for the terrorist atrocities in the United States."
Mr. Blair read some of the bill of evidence to the British Parliament before the whole document was posted. As America's closest ally, he thus relieved the Bush administration of bearing the sole burden for making the case against the Saudi-born Islamic extremist and his group.
Today, Pakistan became the first significant Muslim ally to declare that it accepted America's case that Mr. bin Laden was to blame for the Sept. 11 attacks. Page B5. 
According to American officials, the Central Intelligence Agency reviewed the evidence outlined in the document, which was the product of American and foreign intelligence-gathering operations. While the document released by the British government includes new bits of evidence, it does not disclose the most highly classified information. Mr. Blair told Parliament that was because people and technical sources would be jeopardized if revealed.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell 12 days ago promised a public accounting of the evidence against Mr. bin Laden. But ever since, objections by the intelligence community over the potential disclosure of sensitive sources prevented any detailed public release of information. 
Earlier this week, Mr. Powell sent cables to United States embassies so that foreign leaders and allied governments could be briefed, but the American public has been waiting for the case against Mr. bin Laden.
An American intelligence official said some of the most sensitive conversations intercepted and pieced together show convincingly that Mr. bin Laden's top lieutenants in Al Qaeda were directly involved. 
"There are indications of clear prior knowledge," the official said. "People in the operation knew details both before and shortly after" the attacks that "couldn't have been known unless you had been involved in the planning of the attack."
In London, a spokesman for Mr. Blair said of contacts with the United States, "We have been in close contact throughout and in advance of publication." He asserted that it was "a U.K. government document that has been put together here."
Mr. Blair, like Mr. Bush, is under pressure from European and Middle Eastern allies to present a persuasive public case of Mr. bin Laden's guilt before launching any military operations against Afghanistan. The British apparently had less trouble skirting classification concerns than their cousins in American intelligence.
The document asserts that "several of the perpetrators" of the bomb attack on the destroyer Cole in Yemen were trained at Mr. bin Laden's camps, and that two commanders of the Cole bombing were also involved in the August 1998 bombings of two American embassies in East Africa.
Mr. bin Laden has been indicted in the United States for the embassy bombings and is suspected of masterminding the attack on the Cole.
One of the three hijackers identified as being associates of Al Qaeda also "has been identified as playing key roles in both the East African embassy attacks and the U.S.S. Cole attack," the document says.
It has been previously reported that one suspected hijacker, Khalid Almihdhar, had met with suspected associates of Mr. bin Laden in Malaysia last year. The C.I.A. later determined that some people at the meeting may have been involved in the Cole attack. 
The document provides a great deal of detail about Mr. bin Laden's connection to a half dozen terrorist attacks on American citizens or armed forces. It asserts that Al Qaeda and Mr. bin Laden "have a close and mutually dependent alliance" with Afghanistan's ruling Taliban regime, and its leader Mullah Muhammad Omar.
"They jointly exploit the drugs trade," the document says, and Mr. bin Laden provides financing and fighters for the Taliban militia, which in turn protects his terrorist training camps and the drugs stockpiles that help finance both, it says.
Though it offers no details, the document also asserts that Mr. bin Laden and Al Qaeda "have sought to acquire nuclear and chemical materials for use as terrorist weapons."
Speaking in Parliament, Mr. Blair said, "Our findings have been shared and coordinated with those of our allies, and are clear" on Mr. bin Laden's responsibility.
Laying a basis for possible military action, the document states that ever since Mr. bin Laden returned to Afghanistan in 1996 to ally himself with the Taliban, "the United States government had made it clear to the Taliban regime that Al Qaeda had murdered U.S. citizens, and planned to murder more." 
Mr. Blair said, "Military plans are robust," and identified the enemy as Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda. "We will act because, for the protection of our people and our way of life, including confidence in our economy, we need to eliminate the threat bin Laden and his terrorism represent," he said.
Attorney General John Ashcroft and others have urged Americans to be vigilant and said they cannot rule out another terrorist attack, particularly if the military action is taken in response to the Sept. 11 assaults.
The language of Mr. bin Laden's incitement to murder and hatred of the United States is knitted throughout the document. 
"The killing of Americans and their civilian and military allies is a religious duty for each and every Muslim to be carried out in whichever country they are found," his February 1998 fatwa, or religious edict, states. 
The British document says that Washington can rely on evidence from earlier terrorist attacks attributed to Mr. bin Laden in preparing a military response. 
In October 1993, for instance, the document states that "operatives of Al Qaeda participated in the attack on U.S. military personnel serving in Somalia" that killed 18 Americans. 
By the end of 1993, Al Qaeda operatives were scouting out the United States embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, for the truck bomb attack executed in 1998 that killed 213 people. A Saudi member of the bombing team, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-Owali, survived the explosion and fled. 
"After a few days, he called a telephone number in Yemen to have money transferred to him," the document says. "The number he rang in Yemen was contacted by Osama bin Laden's phone on the same day as al-Owali was arranging to get the money." 
After he was arrested, Mr. al-Owali admitted that he was a member of Al Qaeda and had asked Mr. bin Laden for another "mission" after fighting in the Afghan civil war. Mr. bin Laden sent him to East Africa as the embassy attacks were being planned.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Oil Experts See Little Chance Of Cut in Russian Production

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 3 

 BODY:
Russia, the world's second-largest oil exporter, is unlikely to reduce output or even slow its growth, despite pressure from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to fall in line with its attempts to shore up prices by restricting supply, analysts say.
 Russia made a small gesture in OPEC's direction this week when it agreed to bring together representatives of its biggest oil companies for talks on working with the cartel to prop up prices. But few in the industry see any prospect of concrete moves to rein in exports. 
 "They've talked the talk, but have little intention of actually following through," said Gary Ross, chief executive of the PIRA Energy Group, an energy consultancy based in New York. "It's just not in their interests. It's better to be a freeloader and let it be OPEC's problem." 
Russia has exported 9 percent more oil so far this year than it did in the corresponding period in 2000, according to the Energy Ministry. Its shipments are growing faster than any other country outside OPEC, and they undermine OPEC's efforts to keep prices high, a struggle that has become more difficult since the terror attacks on Sept. 11.
With a global economic slowdown apparently at hand, OPEC is considering trying to reduce its members' total output by 500,000 barrels a day -- exactly the amount by which Russia has increased production this year.
Unlike rivals in the Middle East, Africa and Asia, Russia has an oil industry made up of many competing private producers and traders, not a state-controlled monolith. Moscow would have a difficult time allocating and enforcing production cuts on such a fractious -- but influential -- industry.
"It's unclear politically and logistically whether they would actually manage it," said Al Breach, an economist for Goldman Sachs in Moscow. "It requires a degree of discipline which I'm not sure that decentralized Russia has."
The oil companies say it would be problematic to slow production in Russia, where most wells are old and small, pumping an average of just 100 barrels a day each. They also feel pressure to wring returns from the billions of dollars they have invested repairing old wells and upgrading fields over the last two years, ever since high world oil prices and a currency devaluation caused profits to soar.
"We're enjoying new technology that allows us to increase production," said Simon Kukes, chief executive of the Tyumen Oil Company. Slowing production, Mr. Kukes said, "is expensive -- it changes the economics for us." He said Tyumen would consider it only if the benchmark price fell below $15 a barrel.
Oil and gas are central to Russia's economy, supplying half its export earnings and one-third of the federal budget. A sharp drop in prices would puncture the budget, delicately balanced on an assumption that oil will fetch $18 a barrel, and could thereby erode President Vladimir V. Putin's popularity, which has been steady so far. 
"There's no question that a lower oil price really hurts them," Mr. Breach said. "The lower you go in the teens, the tighter the fiscal situation becomes."
The government could decide to intervene by limiting exports instead of production. The main export pipeline is run by a state-owned company, Transneft, and the Energy Ministry already sets quotas, generally allowing each producer to export about one-third of its output.
"If the government really wants to limit exports, it will," said Dmitri Savelyev, a member of Parliament who once headed Transneft.
But choking off exports without slowing production would flood oil onto Russia's domestic market, where demand is already weak and where crude sells for about two-thirds of the world price.
"It's a puny market," said Mikhail Perfilov, an editor in Moscow for Petroleum Argus, a trade publisher. "For now, the wider the pipe, the more companies are going to export."
