HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
New Software Patent Law For Europe Looking Limited

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 5 

 BODY:
The European Union appears to be moving toward unified regulations for software patents that would be less encompassing than regulations in the United States and Japan.
 Competition officials at the European Commission, the executive arm of the 15-nation union, met Wednesday with their colleagues in charge of drafting a new law for the union, to press their case for limiting its scope. Their concern is that overly protective patent regulation could hinder competition by helping large software manufacturers maintain their dominant positions. 
 A person involved in the discussions said the concerns of the competition officials had been met. "We haven't agreed on a final position, but I don't anticipate any further difficulties in getting the draft directive approved within the commission," he said.
The approach being adopted by the commission would allow patents only for software of a technical nature, and it would not permit patents on business methods. The United States and Japan allow patents on a much wider range of software applications, and they both permit patents for business methods.
Software of a technical nature would include, for example, applications that increase the processing speed of a personal computer. Business methods include innovations like one-click purchasing, for which the online retailer Amazon received a patent in the United States in 1999. Amazon used the patent to get an injunction against use of a similar purchasing feature by a rival, Barnesandnoble.com, but that injunction was lifted by an appeals court this year pending a trial.
"The United States has swung far too far toward granting patent protection," said Thomas Vinje, a lawyer in the Brussels office of Morrison & Foerster, which represents several information technology companies. He said the appeals decision in the Barnesandnoble case was a swing back to the more sensible approach being adopted in Europe.
"The commission appears to be taking a wise approach to the software patent law," he said. "They will have come under considerable pressure to come up with something more in line with the United States and Japan. But I am glad they appear to have resisted."
Those favoring greater scope for patent protection argue that Europe's failure to adopt more protective regulations has harmed software innovation in Europe by denying the protection innovators need to get financial support for their ideas.
The European Union committee of the American Chamber of Commerce in Belgium has urged the commission at least to permit business methods to be patented.
"Some would argue that in Europe, where there is a narrower view of what can be patented, economic opportunity from software invention is limited," said Thaddeus Burns, a lawyer with the Brussels office of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld. Europe's approach to patent law, he said, has encouraged some software engineers to seek better returns from their work elsewhere.
The software patent law for all of Europe about to be introduced by the commission follows a yearlong consultation process with the software industry and the open source software community, which develops nonproprietary computer code. The proposed directive appears to be following the less restrictive approach of the existing individual laws in place in the 15 countries of the European Union, the person involved with the discussions said.
The European Patent Office can register patents for every country in the European Union. But the system is expensive because applicants have to pay each country's national patent office to exercise their protection in that country, Mr. Burns said.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Rises at a 1.7% Rate 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 

 BODY:
Consumer credit rose by a seasonally adjusted $2.3 billion in August, or a 1.7 percent annual rate, the Federal Reserve reported today.
 Americans used credit cards more freely in August than in the previous month and took out more loans to finance big-ticket items like new cars and vacations. 
 Before the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, consumers -- whose spending accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity -- were the main force keeping the economy out of recession.
Economists were hopeful that tax rebate checks of up to $300 for individuals and $600 for couples would encourage consumers to keep spending. Most of the checks were mailed out in August and September.
But analysts now fear that consumers will cut spending, making the economy even weaker. In fact, given the economic fallout from the attacks, most economists say a recession this year is unavoidable.
The economists said they believed that consumers, faced with growing layoffs, would be reluctant to take on extra debt. 
In July, consumer borrowing fell $576.6 million, or at a rate of 0.4 percent, the second straight month of a decline in credit use.
But in August, consumers borrowed more freely. Revolving credit, like that used for credit cards, rose $1.2 billion, or at an annual rate of 2.1 percent, compared with $1.1 billion and a 1.9 percent rate in July.

HEADLINE: Cayun Journal; 
Persistence Reclaims Indians' Ceremonial Grounds

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: CAYUN, Argentina Oct. 4 

 BODY:
At 83, Filomena Cayun is missing several front teeth and needs the help of a long stick to hike the wooded Andean trails of Lanin National Park. But her memory is acute and the memories of the Mapuche Indians are full of struggle and pain.
 "My grandparents had everything, all the potatoes, goats, horses and cows they needed," she recalled. "Then the park guards came. They wouldn't let us work, and all the young people left our lands." 
 She lived in the 250-square-mile park before rangers began limiting Indian ranching and agricultural rights in the late 1940's, and now in her twilight years she is part of a resurgence of the Mapuche here.
As the rangers saw it, they were protecting the magnificent Patagonian oak and beech forests from deforestation and erosion. But by impinging on Indian land rights and burning down the huts of four Mapuche families responsible for caring for a remote holy Indian ceremonial site, the rangers stoked a lasting antagonism.
Just three years ago, 30 Mapuches stormed and occupied the central Lanin park office in nearby San Martin de los Andes. That action, along with a series of new laws and the changing attitudes of the government of President Fernando de la Rua, have spurred a new relationship between the Mapuches and the people whom the Indians still derisively call the "huincas," or palefaces.
It has taken two years of negotiations, but now government officials and Mapuche leaders meet regularly in an effort called "co-management." The growing cooperation has reversed many past policies and given the 1,500 Mapuches who live in the park new self-governing responsibilities and an array of nascent forestry, tourism, education and housing projects that emphasize self-help and jobs.
A loose confederation of hunters and fishermen, the Mapuches were fierce fighters who first resisted the Inca empire and then the Spanish on their traditional lands in Chile. Most Mapuches still live in Chile, and their contentious land battles continue there to this day. 
But tens of thousands of others were pushed into Argentina in the 18th and 19th centuries; most were massacred by the Argentine Army in the 1870's and 80's. The military campaign, known as the "Conquest of the Desert," is still commemorated on the Argentine 100 peso note.
Some 40,000 Mapuches live in Argentina today, their culture mostly broken. 
Here in Cayun, a sprawling agricultural community where many of the 20 families go by the surname Cayun, people still cling to the myth that a nearby pointed-rock formation is an enchanted volcano that has the power to discharge thunderclaps before storms arrive. Few Mapuches speak their ancient dialect, and traditional Mapuche dress has mostly been discarded.
But there is something of a cultural renaissance unfolding.
The Mapuche dialect is being taught in the local school again. Newborns are being given Mapuche names like Ayelen ("Flower") or Nahuel ("Tiger") for the first time in years. The Mapuches give much of the credit for the revival to their new relationship with the government and the National Park Service.
Thirteen houses have been constructed that combine traditional Indian materials like round volcanic rocks and the types of lumber that Mapuches here favor, but with modern insulation and bathrooms.
Ms. Cayun, who recently retired as the village leader, said she was delighted with her new house, but added: 
" We need tools to work the land and we need pavement on the roads. We need some help, but we want to do it for ourselves." 
Her house is a mix of the new and the old, with an old cast-iron stove that sits atop a modern tile floor and emits pungent wood smoke.
One house serves as a community hall, and another as a school, where a Mapuche teacher is instructing youngsters in the dialect of their ancestors. 
Esteban Manqui, 30, who works on a new government sponsored forestry project, said he derives particular satisfaction from hearing his eldest daughter speak to him in the Mapuche dialect. "I can't understand what she is saying," he said. "So I have to go to her notebook with her, and she teaches me new words." 
A community reduced to 50 people just four years ago has grown to 100. The rebirth of this village has been duplicated in others, increasing the Mapuche population in the park by 30 percent. That growth has spurred some concerns in San Martin de los Andes that conservation may be losing priority to the economic needs of the Mapuches.
Financing for the new projects is scarce, and not all the programs have gone smoothly. 
An effort in one village to replace herds of goats with llamas, which are less voracious grazers and cause less erosion, was abandoned when dogs owned by the Mapuches attacked the llamas. Since the Mapuches depend on their dogs for rabbit hunting and guarding their sheep from puma attacks, the llamas are gone. Goats are back.
More successful programs have brought Mapuche villages across the park drinking water, electricity and fencing to control animals. Several communities are being taught how to be guides for tourists who visit to fish trout or hunt wild boar.
Descendants of the four families who lost their houses in the northern reaches of the park are being allowed to return to care for the old ceremonial grounds, where a religious totem is carved in an old cypress stem. The sole condition of their return is that they do not ranch so the forests can grow undisturbed.

HEADLINE: Official Says Turkey Is Advancing in Drive for I.M.F. Financing 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 

 BODY:
Turkey's economy minister said today that he had gained support in his effort to work out a deal with the International Monetary Fund by the end of October to bridge a financing gap projected for 2002.
 The minister, Kemal Dervis, confirmed that in a series of meetings this week with the I.M.F., the World Bank and the United States Treasury, he had requested additional financing for next year to help Turkey deal with the economic fallout from the attacks on the United States. 
 The minister said there was "definite support" for helping Turkey bridge its financing gap and that he was "confident" negotiations would be successful.
"I don't have an exact timetable, but I believe the next few days are going to be very important on all sides," Mr. Dervis said at a news briefing. 
"I hope we can have the review, perhaps not in the middle, but before the end of October," he said, referring to a review of Turkey's $15.7 billion I.M.F. loan program.
Mr. Dervis said he hoped that review would include bridging the financing gap for next year with either multilateral aid or some other form of support.
Turkey had been expected to complete the next review by the middle of October, but the nation's economy has suffered in recent weeks as a result of the attacks, which have shaken confidence in emerging markets around the world.
On Monday, Mr. Dervis said the impact of the attacks would wipe as much as one percentage point off economic output next year after a contraction of about 8 percent this year -- an outlook that is forcing renegotiation of I.M.F. goals for 2002.
Turkey needs foreign help to manage a huge domestic debt load and extricate its economy from its worst recession since 1945. The debt load and contraction are legacies of financial crises in November of last year and February of this year.
"We have explained through official channels the need for financing that matches the targets of our program; they will definitely support us," Mr. Dervis said. "The need for some official financing that was not originally foreseen in the 2002 numbers is accepted on all sides."
Mr. Dervis said that he had general agreement that international uncertainty following the attacks on the United States meant that Turkey, a crucial NATO ally, needed additional financing in 2002.
"Everyone accepts that because of the latest events there is a higher financing need," he told reporters. "We have to decide on the amount and shape of these in the coming days."
Mr. Dervis declined to specify how large the financing gap would be or how it would be bridged, saying only that all alternatives were under discussion.
A global downturn has shelved plans by Turkey to export its way out of trouble, and upheaval in the Middle East has hurt its ability to borrow on international markets.
Turkey has an economic recovery plan backed by $15.7 billion in I.M.F. and World Bank lending for this year. Markets in Istanbul are very keen to see details of aid for 2002, which some analysts say will have to be $10 billion to $15 billion.
Mr. Dervis said he would update Washington on the economic situation and reiterate Turkey's support for fighting against terrorism.
He also emphasized that Turkey would have to take action at home in order to secure a deal with the I.M.F or other lenders.
"Like other countries, we have to show additional efforts," he said. "Particularly on the budget and related issues, we must be fast and determined. We are working on cutting state spending as quickly as possible."

HEADLINE: Correspondent; 
The 40-Year War

BYLINE:  By BILL KELLER 

 BODY:
A dozen years ago in Termez, a dusty Uzbekistan border town that may again become a dateline, I watched the Russian Army begin its retreat from Afghanistan. As paratroopers crossed a railroad bridge into the waiting arms of parents and girlfriends, an all-girl, all-drum band from a local school tapped out a cheerless homecoming rhythm. When I asked the soldiers what they had accomplished down there, expecting at least a rehearsed sample of national pride, they would stare blankly. "We survived," one weary private shrugged. The war that had sent home 15,000 zinc coffins had also killed off a lot of illusions.
 No, this is not another warning about the perils of Afghanistan. The American officials I've talked to understand the frustrations of playing hide-and-seek in a mountain labyrinth. They appreciate the lethal instability of that country's tribal politics. The risks they take will be as calculated as they are justified. 
 What those paratroopers in Termez had lost in Afghanistan, and what our commandos are undertaking there now, is one skirmish in a bigger struggle between rival ways of seeing the world. Whether the declared war against terror will amount to a new cold war I'm not sure. The war against Communism had a definable end, where ending terrorism is a goal without a goal line. And I wonder if we have the patience for another 40-year war. Still, President Kennedy's "long twilight struggle," a bit of inaugural poetry that has been getting a lot of replay in the past few weeks, is an instructive analogy for a war that you don't so much fight as live. Certainly the new cause is giving sudden focus not only to our novice commander in chief but to anyone who has felt a little disoriented in the disorderly decade since our favorite enemy died.
There is, of course, no Soviet Union of terrorism, but as John Lewis Gaddis, the dean of cold-war historians, has been telling his classes at Yale since Sept. 11, there are striking parallels. Communism in the 1950's, Professor Gaddis points out, was seen not as a rival state but as a fearsome, state-sponsored, international conspiracy, one that threatened us from within as well as externally. The American response was called "containment," a kind of global gopher hunt aimed at countering Communist influence wherever it surfaced, using diplomacy and economic power and armed proxies more often than American military might. Rather than a wholesale frontal assault on Communism, which might have caused it to adhere, we tried to divide the Communist world -- supporting Tito in Yugoslavia, for example, and later trying to tease China apart from Russia. The grand idea of containment was that ultimately the societies stewing under Communism would reject it -- much as we now hope the host countries of the Terror International will turn against that pathology. Interviews with refugees who tell of Taliban panic and defections suggest that something of the kind may already be happening in Afghanistan.
If we are serious about this, it is one of those conflicts that can realign the world. Like the cold war, this one, while it lasts, will assert a gravitational pull on everything. It will determine who our friends are, revise our priorities and test the elasticity of our ideals. It will influence which departments are suddenly overenrolled in our colleges and who the bad guys are in our movies. It is siphoning our charity from a hundred important but suddenly less topical causes, and turning grade-school fire drills into the modern equivalent of my childhood duck-and-cover exercises. It will provide -- already is providing -- a new, opportunistic national-interest spin for lobbyists peddling everything from corporate tax cuts to medical research to farm subsidies. It may, belatedly, reshape our lumbering military and our neglected intelligence services. In the cold war, we trained soldiers to fight on great battlefields and spies to pass for diplomats. Now, if we're smart, we'll be buying agility and shrewdness and daring. We'll be featuring Islamic Americans in our Army enlistment ads and maybe recruiting some of those bright Saudi college kids from the prolific bin Laden family.
The new cold war will determine which foreign leaders and which issues occupy the president's attention. Adios, amigo, Vicente Fox and your campaign for more porous borders! Welcome, soul-brother Putin! The original cold war taught us a good deal about the value of allies. It gave birth to the Marshall Plan and NATO and those comforting arms-control treaties that, at least until recently, the new administration belittled as constraints on our freedom. Now the common fear of terrorism is beginning to drive us together, much as the fear of nuclear annihilation did. The new cold war has finally got us to pay our United Nations dues.
One price of coalition politics is unsavory bedfellows. Most Americans are more pragmatic about that than op-ed page moralists. Consort with nasty regimes if you figure it's worth it, but keep rechecking your arithmetic. We need the Russians now, as we needed Stalin once, and if that means our president pulls a punch on the subject of the indiscriminate civil carnage in Chechnya, I can live with that; the punch had no muscle behind it anyway. If there is even a remote chance that we can make Syria and Iran and Pakistan a little less hospitable for terrorists through the instrument of craven diplomacy, let's talk to them for a while, as long as talking does not become an end in itself. (I'd draw the line at selling the Iranians weapons and diverting the profits for covert wars somewhere else. That would be really stupid.) President Bush's increasingly disenchanted right-wing chorus will say we are forfeiting the moral high ground. But they managed to swallow their qualms when we were cozying up to killers in Latin America and Africa during the first cold war, and I don't recall that Jonas Savimbi was much help in the triumph of democracy.
In such a war, collateral damage means more than the civilians who perish in the path of your air strikes. It means how much you sully yourself by empowering ugly regimes in the name of common struggle, how much you compromise your freedom in the name of security, how much you undermine public trust through lies and patriotic-sounding cant. The chronicle of friendly fire upon our own people and principles in the first cold war began with the Red Scare and continued through Vietnam to the Iran-contra scandal and the eccentric politics of our Cuba policy.
This is going to be a trying time for those who promote human rights, and for those who advocate humanitarian intervention. That decent 1990's impulse to do good in Bosnia and Kosovo, even at the price of alienating Russia and China, was already, before Sept. 11, giving way to a foreign policy based on an unsentimental notion of our national interest. Now the calculations will be even colder.
On the home front, the first cold war gave us J. Edgar Hoover and Joseph McCarthy. This time, the dangers of constricting our civil liberties and forsaking our privacy are real -- ask any American Muslim or Sikh -- but they are tempered considerably by a heartland suspicion of excess government that should be deep in the fiber of this administration. As for the temptation to demonize, our tolerance has been stretched but not broken. The Wall Street Journal's editorials have been questioning the patriotism of any professor who suggests we try to understand the motives of the attackers. Some of the more hawkish demagogy aimed at Colin Powell recalls Senator McCarthy's slurs on the patriotism of the last four-star secretary of state, George C. Marshall. So far, though, it seems to me we are mostly within the bounds of robust debate.
It always bears remembering that we won the cold war less because of what we did than because of what we are. We won it because the Soviet Union had nothing to offer the least bit as enticing as what its people saw and envied in us. (The earthbound Communists could not even offer Al Qaeda's illusion of a happy next life.)
Fifty years ago, in the first flush of Red panic, George Kennan, the author of the containment policy and one of the shrewdest students of the cold war, wrote a letter warning that the fear of Communism could turn us "intolerant, secretive, suspicious, cruel, and terrified of internal dissension because we have lost our own belief in ourselves and in the power of our ideals."
"The worst thing that our Communists could do to us," he went on, "and the thing we have most to fear from their activities, is that we should become like them."
Copies of his letter should be inserted in the orientation package for employees of the new Homeland Security Council.

HEADLINE: Meeting Lean Times, Salesman Casts Net Wider and Deeper 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: ELKHART, Ind., Oct. 5 

 BODY:
Rolling down County Road 38 in his dark green Plymouth Neon with an American flag taped to the antenna, Tom Giorgio looks out at the suburban landscape and talks about how much better the economy was not just before Sept. 11, but a year or two ago.
 "This was just a boomtown. Everything was chugging along," said Mr. Giorgio, a salesman here for W. W. Grainger Inc., which sells tools, maintenance supplies, light fixtures and other industrial supplies. "Now, we're in a recession, definitely in a recession. You can see it everywhere." 
 Mr. Giorgio, 44, sees it on his first sales call this morning, a 9 a.m. meeting in nearby Goshen at Benteler Automotive, which stamps metal parts for the auto industry. He does not get past the receptionist before hearing about how hard times have become. 
"Hello," he says. "Here to see Donna." They chitchat. "How are things going here?" Mr. Giorgio asks.
"The recession hasn't hit yet, but they're expecting it," the receptionist says. "They did halt all air travel, because they want to cut down on expenses. We sometimes fly to Tennessee when we could drive. So it's coming."
Donna Scheffers, a purchasing manager, paints a similarly stark picture after ushering Mr. Giorgio into a conference room. He pulls out his cost reports; she pulls out a pack of Doral cigarettes and says that Benteler has turned "cautious" on spending. People in the tool room, she says, have already accepted rolling two-week layoffs. 
There is no sale to be made today at Benteler. And that has often been the case for Mr. Giorgio since early last year, when the area around Elkhart, 15 miles east of South Bend and just south of the Michigan border, began feeling the first effects of an economic slowdown. On Sept. 11, the slowdown became an abrupt halt. Now, people are ready to see Mr. Giorgio again, but they are reluctant to buy. Projects are being put off; budgets are tight. And Mr. Giorgio sees the little recessionary indicators each day as he travels to his business calls.
"One sign that we're in tough times is that people have toys for sale," he says, driving through Goshen. "That was a canoe for sale back there. People are selling snowmobiles, boats and fancy R.V.'s, all their expensive toys."
The slump, Mr. Giorgio explains, has forced him to alter his sales practices. He used to spend 80 percent of his time with 20 percent of his customers -- the big purchasers like Supreme Industries, which builds trolley cars and airport buses, and Coachmen Industries, one of the recreational vehicle manufacturers which has headquarters here, earning Elkhart the nickname R.V. Capital of the World. 
Now, he is broadening his reach. "I'm out looking for new customers -- people unaffected, like school systems, food companies," he says.
So leaving Benteler, he runs over to Fairfield High School in Goshen, where he spends half an hour trying to solve a lighting problem in the gymnasium.
The head maintenance man is not too sure that Mr. Giorgio's lighting solution is going to work, but he notices that the salesman is working a little harder these days, searching catalogs and running cost estimates.
"Are you guys going to start stopping in every week now?" he asks. 
"Every other week," Mr. Giorgio replies.
"Wow. We've never had that before," the custodian says.
Back behind the wheel, heading to a 10 a.m. appointment at Supreme Industries, Mr. Giorgio points through the car windows to manufacturing plants where the workweek has shrunk to four days, in hopes of avoiding layoffs.
"This is middle America," he says, a place where subdivisions nestle against Amish farms and the local Wal-Mart has a hitching post. "But this is middle America in a downturn."
At Supreme, Mr. Giorgio makes small talk with Orv Kropf, a purchasing manager, about Notre Dame football, the 450 layoffs at Utilimaster, a local truck builder, the attacks on the World Trade Center and the prospect of war. Then the conversation turns to the 24 light fixtures that Mr. Kropf wants to order.
"Things are bad right now," Mr. Kropf says. "We need a better price. We need you to come down some." 
Mr. Giorgio, accustomed now to such talk, promised to do the best he could. Married, with two children, he is facing his own financial slowdown. He squirreled away some of his earnings from 1999, when he made the President's Club at Grainger as one of the company's top salesmen. That year, Grainger sent him and his wife, Shelley, to Cancun. This year, the family vacationed at Yellowstone National Park, a trip that he says was extremely frugal.
But like many sales people, Mr. Giorgio, who grew up in Munster, Ind., and has a degree in marketing distribution from Vincennes University, has trained himself to remain optimistic. He likes to talk about not giving up, about thinking of his sales task like a perpetual motion machine: you don't want to move a semi-truck from a dead stop.
That is why on most days he starts making calls at 6:30 a.m., planting the seeds of new sales at dawn. He knows all of his good customers well, their likes, dislikes, hobbies and recent projects. ("Hey Donna, how's your husband doing with the cars?") ("Hey Larry, how's that clamp working out?") ("Hi, Orv. How's your son's house coming along?")
At the Elkhart County archives, Randy Yohn, the county clerk, greets Mr. Giorgio with conversation about Nascar racing. Then reality sets in. "Anyway, we've been out of money," Mr. Yohn says abruptly. "That means we'll have to wait on some things. We have to wait for the next appropriation."
The county has leased a storage facility for its records, and Grainger is supplying the shelving and a few odds and ends. Mr. Giorgio generally deals in bigger items, but these days he does not mind writing up even the small sale that Mr. Yohn eventually agrees to -- for a push broom and a 55-gallon garbage container. 
He trots out to the car to get a Grainger catalog -- roughly the size of the Yellow Pages -- to look up the item numbers.
"When everyone started pulling back their purse strings, I started selling deeper in the catalog," Mr. Giorgio explains a little later. "I started saying, 'Why aren't you buying your janitorial supplies from me?' "
The recreational vehicle business, whose growth in the 1990's fueled Elkhart's boom, has led the local economy down. High interest rates and fuel prices, and a falling stock market that kept retirees from buying recreational vehicles, crushed sales at Coachmen and Jayco Inc., both industry leaders.
"A lot of economists use Elkhart as a barometer, because the R.V. industry is usually the first to go down in a recession, and the first to come back," Mr. Giorgio says. "I don't know why, but that's what they say."
After lunch, he declares, "I need to see Liz," and he steers the car toward Jayco's headquarters in Middlebury. ("It's really Mayberry," Mr. Giorgio jokes. "It's a great town.")
Elizabeth Jackson is the company's purchasing manager, and Mr. Giorgio hovers outside her office until she gets off the phone. They review some billing questions, and he asks her about the privately held company's business.
"It's not too bad, but it's nothing compared to last year," she says, and she seems less than optimistic about the prospects for a quick turnaround. She orders some janitorial equipment and ladders.
"Anything else I can help you with, Liz?" Mr. Giorgio asks. "Any projects?"
No, she says. "Everything is on hold now. They're watching things closely."
Mr. Giorgio smiles as he leaves. Not a bad day at all, he says, considering the economy. Average. 
Or maybe a little better. Supreme faxed to his office a request for a price on nine tons of rock salt. It had not been clear earlier in the day if Orv Kropf needed salt. Apparently he does.
"This is a good thing," Mr. Giorgio says, pulling into the office driveway. "I think things are going to get better."

HEADLINE: Green Assails Ferrer's Call For Decentralizing Business 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mark Green charged yesterday that Fernando Ferrer was not prepared to rebuild the city's economy in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center, saying his plans did "not measure up to the crisis" and warning that his call to decentralize office space could break up the financial district.
 "Anybody who understands how integral financial services is to New York, anyone who understands the way markets operate, should know that you don't break up Wall Street," said Mr. Green, the public advocate and a Democratic candidate for mayor. "You don't break up Broadway, Detroit doesn't break up the auto industry, and New York doesn't break up downtown Manhattan and financial services." 
 His remarks were the latest in a series aimed at raising doubts in the minds of voters about whether his opponent for the Democratic mayoral nomination, Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, was prepared to guide the city through the current crisis.
Mr. Green has taken to speaking of his "citywide experience" a lot in recent days. On Thursday he said that Mr. Ferrer had not "risen to the emergency when it comes to safety and security." 
A spokesman for Mr. Ferrer, John Del Cecato, said, "When your political opponent attacks the details of your plan, you know you've struck a nerve."
At the heart of the debate is Mr. Ferrer's call for decentralizing office space. Mr. Ferrer released a proposal on Tuesday which said that "while Lower Manhattan must be rebuilt to have a critical mass of finance and related industries, this is an opportunity to pursue much needed development opportunities in the city outside Lower Manhattan, including the other four boroughs."
Mr. Green called a news conference yesterday with two supporters from the field of municipal finance -- the current and previous city comptrollers, Alan G. Hevesi, and Elizabeth Holtzman. They all warned that any plan that would disperse businesses from downtown would be dangerous. "A plan that calls for decentralization is not a plan for the future of New York City," Ms. Holtzman said.
Mr. Del Cecato said that Mr. Green and his supporters were misreading Mr. Ferrer's proposal. He said decentralization was a short-term solution.
"The mayor's office suggested that it will take a least a year just to clear the site," he said. "If we don't provide at least 10 million square feet of office space elsewhere, those businesses will leave, and we can't afford to have businesses flee New York City."
But in a statement that accompanied the release of the plan, Mr. Ferrer also described the need to decentralize office space as "a longer-term objective." In a debate between the two candidates on Tuesday, Mr. Ferrer said that the shape of Lower Manhattan would have to be decided in the future.
Mr. Green's salvos on the economy were representative of the more sharply confrontational tone his campaign has taken as the race heads into the final days before the Oct. 11 runoff.
Ever since Mr. Ferrer finished first in the Sept. 25 primary, and won several important endorsements -- including one from former Mayor Edward I. Koch and, yesterday, another from the United Federation of Teachers -- Mr. Green has shown a new willingness to openly criticize him.
This week Mr. Green accused Mr. Ferrer of running a "polarizing campaign" because of his theme of running for "the other New York."
He has said that the Rev. Al Sharpton, who is supporting Mr. Ferrer, was wrong to diminish Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's response to the recent terrorist attacks by saying that even Bozo could have brought the city together. And Mr. Green has repeatedly questioned Mr. Ferrer's plans to rebuild the city and provide security.
As Mr. Ferrer received the endorsement of the teachers union, he said: "There should be no negative campaigning here. I won't engage in it. I won't respond to it."
Mr. Green still has a big financial advantage over Mr. Ferrer. Papers filed yesterday with the Campaign Finance Board indicated that Mr. Green had more than four times as much money on hand as Mr. Ferrer does, but that Mr. Ferrer has been raising more than he has in recent weeks.
From Sept. 18 to Oct. 1., Mr. Green raised $87,435 and spent $1,397,617, according to the filings. His campaign said that its balance at the end of the period was $3.8 million. During the same period Mr. Ferrer raised $134,011 and spent $878,159, his campaign reported. They said that the campaign's balance at the end of the period was $892,609.
When Mayor Giuliani was asked about the new tone of the race, he said: "If each of them would stop accusing each other of being divisive, then nobody would. . ." Then he stopped in midsentence. "If I say anything about the Democratic primary, they'll say I'm interfering in the Democratic primary," he said. "That's either a sin or a crime." He was not so circumspect earlier, when he made a series of daily attacks on one of the candidates, Mr. Hevesi, which many Democrats believe were critically damaging.
Mr. Green was endorsed yesterday by the unions representing New York City police captains and lieutenants and the Uniformed Fire Officers Association. Capt. John Driscoll, the president of the Captains Endowment Association, painted Mr. Green as a consistent police critic back in August, after endorsing endorsing Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker.
But yesterday he praised Mr. Green as someone who would stay "vigilant on crime."

HEADLINE: Group of 7 Set to Explore Ways to Recharge World Economy 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said he and his counterparts from the world's leading industrial nations would explore fresh ways of stimulating their economies when they gathered here this weekend. But European and Japanese leaders played down expectations that wealthy countries would act in concert to address the worsening global slump.
 Mr. O'Neill said the Group of 7 finance ministers also plan to step up their coordinated crackdown on the finances of terrorists by making sure all allied countries have laws in place that would make it harder for terrorists to use the international financial system. 
 The United States and its peers were suffering a synchronized slump even before Sept. 11. They have now entered a period of severe weakness, with both the United States and Japan likely to experience recessions this year and Europe growing at a negligible rate.
American officials have urged their Japanese and European counterparts for years to overhaul their economies and reduce the cost of money so they can grow as rapidly as the United States. The idea that Europe and Japan need to fuel their economies has become even more pressing now, with the United States unable to serve as a locomotive as it did through much of the 1990's.
Though Mr. O'Neill did not provide details of what he hopes to achieve at this weekend's meeting, he sounded optimistic that a renewed spirit of unity after the terrorist strikes might prompt the other industrial nations to become more aggressive in stimulating their economies.
"Things that up to now seemed not possible are all of a sudden not only possible, but quick action is possible with lots of countries," he said.
For Europe, the main topic will be increasing fiscal spending to counter the downturn without breaching the rules set when the region's common currency, the euro, was created. Under the Stability and Growth Pact, countries risk fines if their deficits exceed 3 percent of gross domestic product. But they have the leeway to suspend that requirement in a crisis, and American officials are clearly hoping that Europe will agree to put the rule in abeyance.
Japan, which has already cut interest rates to zero and spent its way into huge deficits to try to ignite its economy, is under pressure to tackle its banking woes. Some American officials would like to see Japan print more money to counter deflation.
The United States has taken steps to counter its own economic problems. The Federal Reserve has lowered the benchmark interest rate by a full percentage point, to 2.5 percent, since the attacks. The Bush administration and Congress are working on spending and tax cuts of $100 billion or more.
It is unclear, though, whether the Group of 7 can muster a consensus for forceful action. Though Gordon Brown, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, said his country would support doing "whatever we have to do" to revive growth, his German counterpart damped expectations.
"A concerted economic stimulus package is out of the question," Hans Eichel, the German finance minister, said in Berlin before departing for Washington. "The attacks affected the U.S. in a different way to the rest of the world. Therefore, such a package is not relevant to Europe."
Japanese officials also signaled that they are not eager to take decisive new steps. "If there is a shift in the international economic situation, then we may have to consider" fresh measures, Finance Minister Masajuro Shiokawa said. "But we can't decide what to do so soon."

HEADLINE: I.N.S. Urges Immigrants to Report the Missing 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
The chief of the nation's immigration agency yesterday urged immigrants who are in the country illegally to report friends and family missing in the trade center attack and to seek disaster relief without fear of retribution.
 The comments of the immigration commissioner, James W. Ziglar, came after widespread reports that illegal immigrants were reluctant to file missing-persons reports and seek disaster relief for fear that they would be discovered and deported by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Their fears are compounded by a 1996 law that requires states to report, four times a year, information about people who are in the country illegally. 
 But Mr. Ziglar, speaking to reporters at a Roman Catholic church in Midtown after a rare meeting with immigrants' advocates called at his behest, insisted that his agency was not interested in knowing which victims of the terrorist attacks were here illegally. 
"We would not use that information against them," Mr. Ziglar said. "Frankly, we don't want that information."
A spokesman for the I.N.S. in Washington added later that the reporting requirement for states was not enforced and most states did not adhere to the letter of the law.
Mr. Ziglar, appointed by President Bush in July, is in a delicate political position in the wake of the terrorist attacks. With the heightened anxiety about foreigners, the nation's immigration policy has come under intense scrutiny. Members of Congress have called for measures like a moratorium on issuing student visas, and the Bush administration has sought to expand its authority to detain immigrants who are not yet United States citizens.
In measured tones yesterday, Mr. Ziglar cautioned that "people of ill will" should not use the terrorist attack to foment anti-immigrant sentiment. "What happened on Sept. 11 is not about immigrants; it's about evil," he said.
Nevertheless, he said, changes are likely to ensue, including a greater vigilance on tracking foreign students and those who overstay their tourist or temporary work visas. Negotiations over a program that would give legal status to the nation's eight million illegal immigrants has been suspended.
"I don't personally see some sort of harsh anti-immigrant policy coming out of this," he said. "I will weigh in on behalf of balance and good faith and compassion."
The number of illegal immigrants who were among the dead, missing and injured in the World Trade Center attack is impossible to know. According to State Department estimates, the citizens of 79 countries are among the missing.
There has been vast confusion and fear in immigrant communities about seeking relief. Families of those who are missing or injured are entitled to compensation from the State Crime Victims Board. Those who are unemployed as a result of the attacks, while ineligible for federally financed unemployment insurance, can apply for aid from private charities, like the Red Cross and United Way's Sept. 11 Fund.
Still, some immigrants who are here illegally have had great difficulty proving where they worked and how much they earned. They were paid off the books, so they have no pay stubs to offer. Some say they have had great difficulty obtaining a letter from their employers. Others have gone to agencies to apply for relief only to leave when asked for a Social Security number. For some disaster aid, they are not required to furnish a Social Security number.
Yesterday, the advocates who met with the commissioner said they hoped that his message was heard by workers at the relief centers.
Margie McHugh, director of the New York Immigration Coalition, an advocacy group, added that while she was reassured by the commissioner's comments, she still had concerns about how information about the immigration status of those applying for aid would be maintained and used. Until recently, a city law prohibited city workers from sharing such information with immigration authorities. But that law was superseded by the 1996 federal welfare statutes.
"There will be extensive records kept of people who access these programs," Ms. McHugh said. "In our view, it's essential that those records do not contain information about an individual's immigration status."

HEADLINE: Backing Ferrer, Union Focuses On Teacher Pay 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
As the union representing New York City teachers formally endorsed Fernando Ferrer for mayor, its leader sought to portray him yesterday as the candidate who would rebuild Lower Manhattan and make New Yorkers feel safe without abandoning the goal of making teachers' salaries competitive with those in the suburbs.
 Randi Weingarten, the union president, harked back to the fiscal crisis of the early 1970's and warned that the impending recession must not have the same devastating impact on the school system. 
 "Freddy understands that you cannot rebuild New York unless you ensure that our schools work for all our children," Ms. Weingarten said in a news conference at the Manhattan headquarters of the union, the United Federation of Teachers. 
But it remains unclear whether the union's 100,000 members who live in New York City will follow Ms. Weingarten's lead and vote for Mr. Ferrer in the runoff on Thursday. After the union endorsed Alan G. Hevesi for the Democratic primary, only 20 percent of teachers voted for Mr. Hevesi, compared with 29 percent for Mr. Ferrer and 32 percent for Mark Green, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls.
In an interview after the news conference, Ms. Weingarten suggested that many of her members did not vote for Mr. Hevesi because the union stopped promoting his candidacy after Sept. 11, the day of the World Trade Center attack. "The members want signals," she said, "and once we didn't give them a signal, in school after school, they voted for whomever they wished to vote for."
One longtime union delegate said yesterday that since this week's meeting for the endorsement vote was scheduled at the last minute, the delegates who ended up attending -- only about 500 out of 2,800 -- were those closest to the union leadership and most likely to support the candidate Ms. Weingarten favored. Many teachers had hoped the union would remain neutral in the runoff, the delegate said.
Ms. Weingarten said she had seriously considered remaining neutral until after the two Democratic candidates addressed the delegates and Mr. Ferrer was received fervently. "I think it's very fair to say that Freddy Ferrer earned the endorsement of the delegates," she said.
Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, repeated some of his remarks to the teachers at yesterday's news conference, saying that school reform would remain a top priority. "The minute we abandon our school system, the minute we sacrifice the things we say we believe in, then we've lost a long-term fight for New York," he said.
Yet even as Mr. Ferrer reiterated his goal to invest heavily in schools, both he and Ms. Weingarten acknowledged that his cornerstone proposal, raising teachers' salaries by 30 percent at the cost of at least $1 billion a year, would not be achieved anytime soon.
Ms. Weingarten even suggested that Mr. Ferrer's 30 percent figure, which he has discussed repeatedly and insistently since January, had been more a symbol than a concrete goal. She said that she had chastised Mr. Ferrer for proposing such a specific salary increase when he first did so in January, but that Mr. Ferrer had assured her that he was only trying to make a point.
"What he said to me initially, privately, was, 'What I was doing was making sure people knew how important it was, and if I didn't put a number out there that was very big, people wouldn't understand how important it was,' " she said.
Ms. Weingarten said that both Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Green, his opponent in the Democratic runoff, had assured the union's delegate assembly on Thursday that they would not abandon their major education proposals. But Mr. Green, the city's public advocate, failed to persuade the delegates in attendance that he had "walked in their shoes," Ms. Weingarten said. For example, she said, Mr. Green emphasized his plan to reduce class sizes in kindergarten through third grade, which would not affect the tens of thousands of members who teach older children.
Ms. Weingarten said that many teachers were also reluctant to endorse Mr. Green because he had agreed to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to remain in office for three more months. The union loathes Mr. Giuliani because he has harshly criticized teachers throughout his tenure and has refused to meet their demands for a raise of at least 20 percent. Unlike Mr. Green, Mr. Ferrer refused to support the mayor's request.
Besides sharply raising the starting teacher's salary of $31,910, Mr. Ferrer has promised to keep all the city's 200 middle schools open until 6 p.m. on weekdays and create weekend programs for middle-school students. To cover the estimated $100 million annual cost, Mr. Ferrer would reinstate part of the surcharge of the personal income tax.
Mr. Ferrer's spokesman, John Del Cecato, said yesterday that Mr. Ferrer was still "completely committed" to raising taxes to finance his after-school proposal. But he said that Mr. Ferrer would be more insistent that the state meet a court order to sharply increase aid to New York City schools. Gov. George E. Pataki has appealed the court decision, which would increase state education aid by at least $1 billion.
Mr. Green had long rankled the teachers' union by putting the reduction of class sizes at the top of his education agenda, a strategy that the union saw as a distraction from the goal of steep raises for teachers. While his spokesman said yesterday that Mr. Green still embraced both goals, he made clear that smaller classes remained the top priority.
"Along with rebuilding the city, reducing class size remains for him a No. 1 priority," the spokesman, Joe DePlasco, said. Asked about increasing teachers' salaries, Mr. DePlasco said that Mr. Green was still committed to doing so, but that the police also needed a raise.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SEMICONDUCTOR MAKER PAYS DOWN AND EXTENDS ITS DEBT

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Agere Systems Inc., a maker of semiconductors and optical components, said it had paid back $1 billion of the $2.5 billion of debt it took on when it was spun off by the telecommunications equipment maker Lucent Technologies Inc. in March. 
Agere also said its bank lenders had extended the maturity date of its remaining $1.5 billion credit facility to Sept. 30, 2002, from Feb. 21, 2002. The banks modified other parts of the facility as well, the company said. The company, based in Allentown, Pa., said the lower debt and amended credit facility would give it room as it struggles with the economic slowdown.

HEADLINE: Counterpoint to Unity: Dissent 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The novelist Alice Walker argued that the best way to punish Osama bin Laden for the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 would be not to strike militarily: "The only punishment that works is love." Noam Chomsky, the perennial dissenter from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, argued that American actions around the world had caused more death and destruction than took place in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania. Chalmers Johnson, a political science professor, in an article in The Los Angeles Times, wrote that a military "overreaction" by the United States would turn the country into a "rogue state" that would be subject to more terrorist attacks.
 As Americans waited for the Bush administration to act against Mr. bin Laden and the Taliban in Afghanistan, a few voices of opposition could be heard, even as peace demonstrations took place in Washington and on many university campuses. Intellectuals, in other words, were doing what they always do, and what a free society usually expects them to: trying to anchor opinion in knowledge, giving priority to reason at a time when many others may be overcome with emotion, and pricking the consciences of their fellow citizens. 
 As always, too, sober, refined and thoughtful statements were mixed with a degree of what some critics of the dissenters were treating as the higher silliness. And so, not surprisingly, some of the dissenting statements produced angry or sarcastic rejoinders. 
The liberal New Republic, for example, put what it called an "Idiocy Watch" on its Web site (www.thenewrepublic.com) and invited readers to submit examples of silly things being said in the wake of the attack. And the conservative Weekly Standard last week gave what it called its first Susan Sontag Certificate, as its "way of recognizing inanity by intellectuals and artists in the wake of terrorist attacks." 
The magazine's jokey awards were a measure of the attention that Ms. Sontag, the essayist and critic, attracted with a short article she wrote in the New Yorker the week after the attacks. In it Ms. Sontag said the attacks were aimed not at American freedom but rather at "the world's self-proclaimed superpower, undertaken as a consequence of specific American alliances and actions." If anyone was a coward, she said, it was not the suicidal hijackers but those -- presumably American -- pilots who bomb from the air, safe from harm themselves.
On the left, where most of the dissent derives, essentially two arguments have been made against the early pronouncements and programs of the Bush administration. One is that military action would only increase the cycle of violence while failing to cure the root cause of terrorism, which the writer Barbara Ehrenreich called "the vast global inequalities in which terrorism is ultimately rooted." 
Mr. Johnson, a professor emeritus at the University of California at San Diego, agreed that those responsible should be brought to justice and that it would be appropriate to declare war on any state that harbored the terrorists or helped them. But he warned that an American overreaction -- namely a war against "the hopeless and impoverished people of Afghanistan" -- would produce "a further cycle of terrorist attacks, American casualties and escalation."
On the right side of the spectrum, the opposite point of view -- that the military response must be overwhelming -- prevails, and since the Bush administration has promised to get Mr. bin Laden dead or alive, there has been less dissent from official policy despite a few comments like that of the writer Mark Helprin that the attacks were a consequence of American "appeasement." 
The other common critique offered by the left is a more general one, that American policies and actions around the world caused the anti-American fury that erupted on Sept. 11. 
The idea that the United States is widely hated because of its policies -- rather than because of its freedom -- is a common theme. Stanley Hauerwas, a professor of theological ethics at Duke University and an avowed pacifist, argued that the United States should arrest those responsible instead of killing them. 
"The events of Sept. 11 have brought home to America that war is about dying," he wrote in The Chronicle of Higher Education. "I'm not quite sure how that will be received. I suspect it will produce a more repressive politics than we already experience. Americans have no sense of how it is that we can be this hated. It never occurs to them that our country's actions have terrible results for other people around the world, and that they blame us."
Paul Kennedy, the Yale University professor best known for his book warning against American imperial overreach, provoked a stir when he asked students to imagine how they would feel if the United States were small and the world dominated by a unified Arab-Muslim state. "In those conditions, would not many Americans grow to loathe that colossus?" he asked. "I think so."
This prompted a rejoinder from Donald Kagan, a Yale classics professor and a conservative in foreign affairs, who said that Mr. Kennedy's comments were a "classic case of blaming the victim." 
Other commentators have reacted more strongly to such expressions of dissent. Andrew Sullivan wrote on www.andrewsullivan.com, his Web site: "The middle part of the country -- the great red zone that voted for Bush -- is clearly ready for war. The decadent left in its enclaves on the coasts is not dead -- and may well mount what amounts to a fifth column." 
In addition to these sharply polemical exchanges, some thoughtful scholars have established a kind of middle position, one in which they blame the terrorists for terrorism but caution against a response that would erode democratic values or commitment to laws. Richard Falk, the political science professor from Princeton, known as a leftist critic of American foreign policy, argued like other dissenters that the deeper cause of terrorism was "the mass of humanity" that "finds itself under the heels of U.S. economic, military, cultural and diplomatic power." 
Still, he labeled the attacks "massive crimes against humanity" and said that those responsible should be punished to the full extent of the law. "Any use of force," he argued, "should be consistent with international law and with the 'just war' tradition governing the use of force -- that is, it should discriminate between military and civilian targets, be proportionate to the challenge and be necessary to achieve a military objective, avoiding superfluous suffering." 
Mr. Falk is a familiar figure from the years of the anti-Vietnam War movement of a quarter century ago, and so are some of the other figures on the left who have spoken out. Howard Zinn, the Boston University history professor wrote, "We need to think about the resentment all over the world felt by people who have been the victims of American military action -- in Vietnam, in Latin America, in Iraq." 
Another figure from the antiwar movement is Mr. Chomsky, who has never stopped criticizing American foreign policy as the major cause of hardship and harm in the world. He has long since stopped getting much notice among mainstream journals of opinion in the United States, but he retains an avid following among the numerous small leftist groups with magazines and Web sites and among the foes of so-called globalization. 
"The terrorist attacks were major atrocities," Mr. Chomsky wrote, "but in scale they may not reach the level of many others, for example, Clinton's bombing of the Sudan with no credible pretext, destroying half its pharmaceutical supplies and killing unknown numbers of people." His reference was to the 1998 missile attack against a factory that was believed by American intelligence to be a cover for a chemical weapons plant.
Statements like these have generated responses both from the more moderate left and from conservatives, like the editors of The Weekly Standard, who declared that Mr. Chomsky "fell off the cliff into goofiness more than 30 years ago and hasn't made any effort to climb back." 
His most visible critic from the left was the writer Christopher Hitchens, whose columns over the years in The Nation have not generally shown him to be an uncritical admirer of the American role in the world. Mr. Hitchens, beginning several public exchanges with Mr. Chomsky published in The Nation, excoriated what he called "the liberal-left tendency to 'rationalize' the aggression of Sept. 11," which, he added, was "a plan, deliberated for months, to inflict maximum horror upon the innocent." 
To conservative commentators, remarks like those of Ms. Sontag, Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Chomsky smacked of an old leftist impulse to find the primary fault with the United States and to assume that its enemies were reacting naturally and understandably to the American abuse of power around the world. The specific measures, for example, that Mr. Johnson recommended were these: 
"We must recognize that the terrorism of Sept. 11 was not directed against America but against American foreign policy. We should listen to the grievances of the Islamic peoples, stop propping up repressive regimes in the area, protect Israel's security but denounce its apartheid practices in Palestinian areas and reform our 'globalization' policies so that they no longer mean that the rich are getting richer and the poor poorer." 
One difference between dissent during the Vietnam War era and now, however is that nobody feels any sympathy for the forces decreed by the American government to be the country's enemies. The arguments are not that Mr. bin Laden's organization, or the Taliban, are progressive or revolutionary forces, but that war fever, as some critics have characterized the American response so far, will only lead to no good. 
But has war fever really taken over? As the week ended, there was no full-scale invasion or massive bombing of Afghanistan; the White House has been talking of a carefully calibrated response. It seemed as though the recommendations of some supposed critics of American policy were indistinguishable from the actual policies being carried out. The Bush administration's announcement that it would send $320 million in food and medicine to Afghanistan, for example, seemed consistent with the belief of Katha Pollitt, a columnist for The Nation, that the United States should take the money it would spend on bombs "to help the wretched Afghan people and support those among them who favor democracy." 
In this sense, some of the dissent seemed more to anticipate events rather than react to them. It will be up to thinkers and commentators in the weeks ahead to see if the worries they have expressed were real.

HEADLINE: Job Cuts Increased Even Before Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
In the weeks before Sept. 11, the American economy lost more jobs than in any similar period in the last decade, the government reported yesterday, making clear that the country was sliding into recession even before the terrorist attacks.
 The layoffs extended far beyond the manufacturing sector that had earlier suffered the brunt of the slowdown and into the usually stable service sector that makes up most of the economy. Supermarkets, restaurants, clothing stores, movie theaters and temporary-help agencies all cut thousands of jobs in late August and early September. 
 "We were headed into a recession already on Sept. 10," said John P. Lipsky, the chief economist at J. P. Morgan Chase & Company. 
The Labor Department, which conducted its monthly jobs survey shortly after the attacks, considered anybody who worked at all during the week beginning Monday, Sept. 10, to be employed in September. Even so, the economy lost 199,000 jobs from the month before, the agency reported, the most since February 1991, when the United States was last in a recession. 
With airlines, other travel-related businesses and a variety of companies in different industries having already made or announced large layoffs in the last three weeks, economists said the unemployment numbers were likely to become significantly worse in the government's next report, which will be released early in November.
In September, the unemployment rate held steady at 4.9 percent, but economists said that disguised the labor market's weakness. Since January, the survey of households, which produces the unemployment rate, has offered a more pessimistic picture of the work force than a more comprehensive survey of businesses. Yesterday's report brings the two sets of statistics more closely in line with each other.
The decline in payrolls was twice as large as most analysts had expected, and stocks fell after the report's release. They recovered in the afternoon, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 9,119.77, up 58.89 points, or 0.65 percent.
The jobs data underscored the difficulty of the task facing policy makers who are trying to revive the economy through a combination of interest rate reductions, tax cuts and government spending. Even before the Sept. 11 attacks shocked many Americans into reducing spending, if only temporarily, consumer confidence was falling sharply. That heightened concerns among analysts that the strongest part of the economy over the last year -- personal spending -- was on the verge of weakening further. 
"The consumer had hung in there and hung in there, shrugging off a lot of adversity, like the decline in the stock market," said Stephen Slifer, an economist at Lehman Brothers. But in the few weeks before Sept. 11, he added, the consumer "was suddenly worried about his job, and that's a horse of a different color." 
The overall earnings of American workers also appear to have begun shrinking, as companies reduced the total number of hours worked last month more quickly than they increased wages. For much of this year, increases in wages were at a healthy pace, as a labor market that remained tight by historical standards prodded most companies into continuing to raise the pay of their employees.
In September, average hourly earnings rose 0.2 percent, to $14.44, while an index that tracks the hours worked by a large number of employees fell 0.3 percent, its fourth consecutive decline. The terrorist attacks may well have affected or partly distorted the data on hours worked, economists said.
Still, Mr. Lipsky of J. P. Morgan said, many consumers now have much stronger reasons to spend less money than they had been during the summer: the smaller paychecks they are receiving and the newfound uncertainty they have about the country's future.
President Bush, speaking yesterday in the Rose Garden, said nearly all of the stimulus package now being debated in Washington should consist of tax cuts, giving people more money to spend. Democrats in Congress want more of the money to go toward payments to unemployed workers and toward new spending programs the Democrats say will create jobs.
Over all, the American economy employed 132.2 million workers in September, down from a high of 132.7 million in March. The Labor Department revised its August numbers, saying that the economy had shed 84,000 jobs, not the 113,000 that the department originally reported. 
Still, said Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, "These are two months of sickening declines in a row."
"It says we were in even worse shape than we had thought," added Mr. Roach, long one of Wall Street's most pessimistic economists.
Manufacturing has been hit the hardest, suffering primarily from steep cuts in corporate spending on new buildings, equipment and technology. Factory employment fell in September for the 14th consecutive month and has declined by 1.1 million jobs, or 6 percent, since July 2000.
In the weeks before Sept. 11, the malaise spread to the giant service sector, which accounts for more than 80 percent of jobs. Last month, services lost 102,000 jobs, the first reduction this year and also the largest drop -- other than a one-time aberration related to the employment of census workers -- since February 1991.
One of the few bright spots was health care. Hospitals, doctors' offices and other health care companies added 29,000 jobs, bringing their total to 10.4 million. Employment at hotels also rose slightly, in a clear sign of the report's pre-Sept. 11 time frame.
The report also confirmed that the downturn was now affecting less-educated, lower-paid workers more than it was earlier this year. 
After staying largely unchanged for most of the year, the unemployment rate for people without a high school diploma has risen to 7.8 percent, from 6.6 percent, since July. The jobless rate for college graduates rose from 1.6 percent to 2.2 percent between December and June but has only edged up to 2.4 percent since then.
The government considers only those who are jobless and actively looking for work to be unemployed.
In the weeks since the attacks the number of people filing for unemployment benefits has surged, to 528,000 from 431,000, its highest level in more than nine years. That suggests that the October unemployment rate will easily surpass 5 percent, economists said, putting it above that mark for the first time since early 1997.

HEADLINE: SHELF LIFE; 
Pleasure Domes Built of Giggles and Moonlight

BYLINE:  By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
 Once upon a time a great pleasure palace was built on the edge of the sea. Streets curled past onion domes and minarets; statues moved as if they were alive; great elephants shed their lumbering bulk as they plunged down enormous slides. At night the edges of the cupolas and balustrades were draped with what was said to have been "a huge mantle of light," a luminous -- almost lunar -- demonstration of magical powers. 
 Such was Luna Park built in Coney Island, Brooklyn, in 1903 by an entrepreneur and visionary, Fred Thompson. So remarkable was this first theme park that before long imitations sprang up throughout the United States. By 1915 there were Luna Parks in Berlin, Buenos Aires, Rome and Melbourne. Thompson dreamed of creating one along the Seine, giving Paris what he called its "first taste of American outdoor amusements," something that had to wait for the building of Euro Disney. 
But Luna Park was gone a few decades later, and Thompson's other grand project, the $3.5 million Hippodrome Theater on Sixth Avenue and 43rd Street in Manhattan, was demolished in 1939. By the end of his career as producer, architect, designer and entertainer, Thompson was bankrupt and broken, a pathetic dreamer of grandiose extravaganzas. It was as if he had taken a long ride downward on the giant electric teeter-totter he had invented. 
Now though, Woody Register, a professor of American Studies at Sewanee, the University of the South, has restored weighty significance to Thompson's flighty achievements. Mr. Register, adding to the growing academic literature about consumerism and culture, shows that Thompson represented a historic shift in American life. And despite some repetitions and exaggerations, Mr. Register's tale is vivid and compelling.
During the 19th century, Mr. Register argues, leisure was seen as an indulgence; industrial capitalism demanded renunciation of distracting pleasures. But Thompson created an "ethos of fun" that has extended into the present day. Thompson called Luna Park "the Biggest Playground on Earth"; Mr. Register says it "challenged the moral economy of the 19th century." 
It seems that this was precisely what Thompson intended. In 1901, for example, The Pan-American International Exhibition in Buffalo was meant as a solemn celebration of the values of "civilized progress" and was designed by the same architect who built the New York Public Library. But attendance was dismal until Thompson was brought in, declaring that "an exposition is not, nor should it be, a serious thing."
The public thrilled to novelties like human cannonballs, a marriage ceremony that took place in a sky-borne balloon, and 800 dancers on an open stage. He created "A Trip to the Moon," an early version of a Disney-type ride; the passengers' airplane rocked and tilted as scenery moved by, until the plane finally landed on a moon populated by midgets. 
"The trouble with this present age," Thompson said, "is too much work and too little play." He scorned architecture with "straight lines," which were, he said, "as hard and serious as baccalaureate sermons." And he celebrated, as Mr. Register argues, the Peter Pan view that we can all remain children. "We're all just tots grown," Thompson once wrote. "We're playing games and the toys may be the theater, the mart of trade, the stock ticker, the factory or the laboratory, but they're toys just the same."
It is no accident, Mr. Register argues, that it was around this time the toy industry began to grow, with purchases tripling between 1913 and 1919. So prevalent had stuffed animals become that some worried over their effects on the maternal instinct. Dolls were becoming so realistic, one woman was mistakenly accused of murder after she discarded two. 
This is remarkable stuff. Thompson's celebration of pleasure and play also anticipated in many ways some of the arguments about high and low culture still being made. But there are other themes touched upon by Mr. Register, primarily involving gender roles, that are less convincing. In addition many aspects of Thompson's enterprises were neither as pioneering nor as uniquely American as Mr. Register suggests. In European courts similarly extravagant displays and amusements were regular offerings. Thompson's efforts were so notable because for the first time these fantasies were offered to a working middle class.
But Mr. Register is right that something profound takes place in the midst of these forms of play. Play reflects the world, offering forms of escape and promises of mastery. 
In contemporary Disney parks -- the most obvious heirs to Thompson's vision -- every visitor passes through an idealized premodern village that is deliberately scaled down; perspectives are altered to create a sense of intimacy. The rides do just the opposite; they attempt to dwarf the merely human in regions whose very names suggest the untamed or unknown, like Frontierland or Tomorrowland. In these rides, in the midst of an unpredictable rush of sensation, everything seems out of control. But the rider survives and is eventually returned to that comfortable, miniaturized town, with its promises of control and order. We can always come home.
There is comfort in Disney, and a certain amount of confidence. Thompson's vision, however, was more distracting but perhaps less reassuring. 
In one of his theatrical productions at the Hippodrome, "A Yankee Circus on Mars," for example, a barker onstage offers the pleasures of paradise to a town of prospective customers. But he is interrupted by disgruntled workers who want to strike for unpaid wages; even the sheriff arrives to auction the bankrupt circus's property. At that moment a spaceship arrives, bringing the entire company to Mars for a command performance. Hundreds of elaborately costumed Martians dance about, elephants are driven onstage wearing goggles, and the Yankee circus performs to great acclaim. We can always flee home. 
Each fantasy offers pleasures, but Thompson's escape from disorder and unrest offers less enduring comfort. Maybe that's why his fantasies faltered on the eve of World War I and why similar fantasies of escape and distraction may also change in the next few years.

THE KID OF CONEY ISLAND
Fred Thompson and the Rise of American Amusements
By Woody Register
Illustrated. Oxford University Press. 400 pages. $30.

HEADLINE: A Flawed Stimulus Plan 

 BODY:
Responding to the demands of Republicans in Congress, President Bush has laid out a stimulus package that relies in large part on ineffective, irresponsible and regressive tax cuts. He gave short shrift to Democratic demands that the stimulus contain government spending designed to boost the economy as well.
 For the first time, the president asked for permanent abolition of the corporate alternative minimum tax, which forces companies that can mask their profits with lots of deductions to pay at least some taxes. There is no reason these businesses should be helped more than companies that are actually losing money. The latter pay no taxes and would not be helped at all. It is also far from clear that any change in corporate income tax rates would actually stimulate the economy. Most important, there is absolutely no reason to use permanent tax changes to battle a temporary economic slowdown. 
 Mr. Bush also repeated his request for acceleration of the huge package of income tax reductions he won from Congress earlier this year. Yet these cuts overwhelmingly favor high-income Americans, who feel the pain of a recession least and whose spending is least influenced by tax cuts. On the positive side, the president did recommend that low- to moderate-income people receive some relief as well, presumably through the payroll tax. A team of top Wall Street economists speaking at the Council on Foreign Relations yesterday morning cited that policy as the most effective way to stimulate the economy.
The spending portion of the president's package -- some $60 billion in all -- does not seem adequate to stimulate the economy quickly. Most of the $45 billion already allocated for recovery, counterterrorist efforts and the airline bailout, including $11 billion for a defense appropriation that was originally requested by the White House last summer, will not take effect until next year. Much of the remaining $15 billion would be used to extend cash assistance and health coverage for workers left unemployed by the terrorist attacks. These benefits will give people extra time to find better jobs, but most of the money will not begin to help the economy directly until March 2002, when current benefits run out. To boost the economy, spending must have a more immediate impact.
So far, the president has said next to nothing about how he would pay for the stimulus. This omission is particularly irresponsible given his fondness for permanent tax cuts that would hurt the government's finances for years to come. Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate and House Budget Committees agree that a stimulus should be temporary and should not push up long-term interest rates.
Congress should reject permanent tax cuts out of hand, and consider rolling back -- not speeding up -- the regressive parts of the president's 10-year tax plan. Even a truly temporary stimulus should not be allowed to saddle the nation with tens of billions in future debts.
